HEADLINE: Canada's Beleaguered Currency

 BODY:
The British pound is on the up and up. On Friday, it rose to $1.7330, its highest level against the dollar since March of 1989. The jump came after the release of trade figures that were slightly better than expected and another statement of commitment to high interest rates from John Major, the Chancellor of the Exchecquer. With London apparently finally committed to join the European Monetary System soon, the rally should continue. In Canada, concern over the constitutional crisis weakened the Canadian dollar so much that the Bank of Canada and the Bank of England intervened to support the bleaguered currency. After the Government said it might get an extension of the June 23 deadline for a constitutional accord, the Canadian dollar rebounded a little.

HEADLINE: Shared Space;
Germany Again Forces a Redefining of Europe

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FIFTY years ago this summer, Germany had traumatized Europe for the second time in this tragic century: Austria had been annexed; Poland, France, Holland, Norway and Belgium had been defeated, Czechoslovakia and Denmark were occupied, and British troops had been driven into the sea from Dunkirk. The Battle of Britain in the skies over London lay ahead, as did the subsequent decision to turn instead on the Soviet Union. In the 12 short years of the Thousand-year Reich, Hitler, Himmler, Goebbels and Goering destroyed their country's good name and nearly destroyed the European civilization that had been marked indelibly by Germans like Bach, Beethoven, Goethe, Kant and Leibniz.
Yet, even in those dark hours, Germany's actions shaped the new Europe that rose out of the ashes of World War II. The consequences of German aggression and German barbarity divided the country and the continent for four decades; the United States was forced to define itself as a European power and the Soviet Union, with half of Europe in its clutches, got the opportunity to define itself as a superpower.
Today, West Germany is a democracy, not a dictatorship. It is also a loyal and respected partner of the NATO alliance and of the European Community whose commitment will not be in question after the 16 million East Germans and their new democracy become part of the Federal Republic, perhaps as early as the end of this year. 
In the West, two German generations have grown up in a free, open society with a remarkable economic stability never known in the brief few years of the Weimar Republic.
Even so, the idea of German unification causes anxiety among its neighbors, even for people who did not live through the war.
The reason, perhaps, is that for most Europeans, ''Germany'' has been a point of reference that has shaped their own idea of who they are today. And suddenly, the Germany they have known for 40 years will become, tomorrow, something very different. What, then, are its neighbors to make of themselves?
The whole European Community was built around a central lesson from the war: There would be no lasting peace or prosperity in Europe unless Germans had a stake in both. But even more than most of them realize, the other European states have defined themselves in the modern era by their relationship to Germany. When they worry about unification, they are worried about themselves.
 
The French View
Charles de Gaulle, for example, created a whole new modern idea of ''eternal France'' out of the resistance to German occupation that he almost single-handedly willed into existence with a speech broadcast from London 50 years ago last week. France, viewed as the pre-eminent military power of prewar Europe, had been deeply demoralized by its unexpected sudden defeat in 1940. Even 25 years ago, when the General was President and his Fifth Republic still in its infancy, French illustrated magazines were full of articles about the 25th anniversary of the German conquest.
Today, 20 years after de Gaulle's death, they are full of celebrations of him and the redemption he symbolizes, and President Francois Mitterrand finds it politically wise to be seen as close to Chancellor Helmut Kohl as de Gaulle was to Konrad Adenauer.
Perhaps no other country has defined itself by its relation to the Germans in recent times so much as the Soviet Union. Until Mikhail S. Gorbachev, every Soviet ruler since Stalin explained not only its fixation on military strength but also its political repression and economic backwardness by reference to the Great Patriotic War, as the struggle against the Nazis is usually called in Russian. Even Mr. Gorbachev recently asked Americans to understand that he could not simply accede to German unity without taking account of the sufferings of the 27 million Soviet citizens who died during the war, and of the feelings of their survivors, children and grandchildren.
But both the Soviet attitude toward Germans and the German attitude toward Russians have always been far more complex than the Nazi and Stalinist stereotypes allowed. Life is full of examples like the West German businessman living in Moscow in the late 1970's who had returned to the Soviet Union out of nostalgia, having been held as a prisoner of war in Siberia until the early 1950's.
When Russians over 40 speak any foreign language at all, it is most often German, picked up during the war or learned at school, and when they talk about Western consumer goods it is German quality and style they admire. For years the Germans, East and West, have been the Soviets' biggest trading partners.
But self-doubt and anxiety about the economic future are nowhere more acute today than in the Soviet Union, and this is one reason it agonizes about German unification even more than its former Eastern European satellites do. Another may be the realization that after unification, Germans will be the most likely advocates and agents of Western economic help for Soviet efforts to rebuild their defunct centrally planned economy.
This would suit both of them, the Soviet Union with its inferiority complex, and Germany with its impossible yearning to be loved as well as respected. It would also assuage the German sense of guilt, which is far stronger in relation to the Soviet Union and, because of the unique barbarity of the Holocaust, to Israel than it is to France, Britain, or the United States.
Some Germans also feel guilt toward Poland, where Willy Brandt, as West Germany's Chancellor in 1970, fell to his knees at the monument to the victims of the Warsaw ghetto uprising. Despite that symbolic gesture, German-Polish relations are deeply troubled today; the trouble is mainly over the definition of what Poland is.
Germany, which nearly destroyed Poland half a century ago, had to cede large areas of territory in order for Poland to be re-created, and last week finally gave up any claim to redraw the existing border by adopting a joint resolution of the East and West German parliaments.
But economists, politicians and diplomats in Poland acknowledge that whatever they do for themselves and whatever assistance they can get from the United States, their path to economic recovery will have to run through Germany. The Czechoslovak authorities under President Vaclav Havel have recognized this even more explicitly.
It is not only the countries that suffered under German occupation that have changed their ideas of themselves. Dunkirk and the Battle of Britain left their mark on British psychology about ''Europe,'' which many of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's admirers and detractors alike view the way she does, with profound ambivalence.
At the European Community summit meeting in Dublin this week, she can be expected to repel what the British see as attempts by bureaucrats in Brussels to limit the hard-won sovereignty of the British Parliament, saved -along with the country itself - by Churchill when he repelled the Nazis. Last Monday, she admitted that the prospect of a united Germany in a tightly integrated European community did cause her to feel ''a little bit of apprehension'' as well - apprehension about Britain in that kind of Europe, in which a united Germany, with 78 million people and a $1.3 trillion economy, would be by far the most powerful member.
Germans like Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who was 15 years old when the war ended, have defined themselves as Europeans and democrats for so many years that they have trouble understanding why their neighbors and the world can never absolve them for what their fathers' generation did. Unification could make Germans more self-assertive and impatient with the burden of guilt, or it could make them more self-confident and tolerant; nobody knows, so everybody worries.
 
Shifting Views
''Often people think two different things about Germany at the same time,'' said Francois Heisbourg, a former French diplomat who is now director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. ''Depending on what time of day it is and what mood you're in, you find yourself more or less worried. But I've never been terribly concerned about it. If there's any place that's not nationalistic these days, it's West Germany.''
Most people in Germany's smaller neighbors would agree, despite their jitters over occasional surges of right-wing German political feeling over the years. In the cobblestone squares of Brussels, people admit to anxiety, mostly about terms of trade. Lysiane D'Haeyere, director of a small publishing house, said: ''We feel a bit crushed. So much wealth, so much power. At first, we were all very happy for them. Now, we'll see.''
In the Czechoslovak spa town of Karlovy Vary, known to Germans as Karlsbad, Jiri Kovarik, the 47-year-old Mayor, said he thought the main threat from Germany after the currency unification that takes place next weekend would be too many East German tourists, newly armed with D-marks, laying waste to the shelves of local stores, and perhaps too many West German businesses buying up Czechoslovak hotels and enterprises as well.
There is another explanation for the ambivalence that many people in the neighboring states feel about unification, and that is the complicity of their own countries during the Nazi occupation. ''The resistance during the war was blown up afterwards to heroic proportions,'' said Hugo Claus, a Belgian Flemish novelist who came of age during the occupation. ''A lot of the Flemish people had seen the French as oppressors, and welcomed the Germans. After the war we discovered that everybody had been Belgian patriots.''
The lesson Europeans draw at the end of all this painful self-discovery could well be a new self-confidence, with which they can reassure themselves about German unification and succeed in making a united Germany as good a neighbor as West Germany has been all these years. Many of them already realize that the Germans might never have had their cataclysmic national nervous breakdown half a century ago if their neighbors had only had the foresight to treat them as wisely in 1919 as they did after it was all over in 1945.

HEADLINE: The World;
Can Central America Win a War on Poverty?

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON

DATELINE: GUATEMALA

 BODY:
THE futility of efforts to attack the basic causes of Central America's endemic poverty preoccupied President Vinicio Cerezo one day three years ago as he sat in a hotel room with friends. Some topics, he complained, were so explosive they could not even be mentioned. Asked for an example, he paused. Then he replied, ''agrarian reform.'' In that instant, the chandelier fell from the ceiling with a crash.
That anecdote was told last week by a friend of the Guatemalan President to illustrate the roadblocks that confront the latest effort to end the poverty that has brought Central America a decade of civil war. 
The initiative, announced at the end of a three-day meeting of the area's five Presidents, is the most ambitious regional economic program since the birth of the Central American Common Market 30 years ago.
The strategy of the five Presidents - Mr. Cerezo, Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, Rafael Callejas of Honduras, Rafael Calderon Jr. of Costa Rica and Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua - is to integrate their foundering economies and coordinate all aspects of development, from agriculture to tariffs, environmental protection to debt management. The leaders agreed to work together to revitalize their common market, renegotiate debt, set common tariffs and rebuild dilapidated infrastructures.
The plan got an immediate boost from the United States. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with the Presidents in Antigua, a small city 30 miles west of the capital, and proposed an American-led effort to marshal international aid to the area, which is in its worst economic crisis in a century. ''This region has a historic opportunity today to realize three goals: democracy, disarmament and development,'' Mr. Baker said.
But neither plan even mentioned many underlying reasons for the poverty that ensnares millions of Central Americans. The initiatives will do little or nothing to break the economic grip of a small group of families. Neither do they contemplate reallocating land or improving the social safety net. They differ fundamentally from programs advocated by the guerrillas and left-of-center political parties. These see the root of conflict as a pervasive social imbalance that condemns millions to poverty. Peace, these groups say, depends on redividing the pie.
By contrast, the underlying assumption of the five conservative Presidents - indeed, the gamble implicit in their plan - is that they can buy social peace simply by increasing national wealth. The leaders hope to create social contentment merely by expanding their econonomies through increased entrepeneur-based development. This latest version of the rising-tide theory of development was perhaps best summarized by a saying used to introduce their final declaration. Taken from the Popol Yuh, the sacred book of the Maya-Quiche Indians of Guatemala, it said: ''That everyone rises up, that everybody be told, that no one group, nor groups among us, will be left behind.''
In the eyes of the five Presidents, the initiatives from Central America and the United States combined to mark a regional watershed. After a decade of ideological strife that has claimed an estimated 130,000 lives, they said this was the moment in which the region and its superpower ally finally turned their attention from the need to settle conflicts to the need to build prosperity. In this recognition of the role of economics, the five conservative leaders took a belated step toward acknowledging that the roots of Central America's crisis are social as much as political and that poverty, not militant leftism, is the greatest threat to stability.
 
Echoes of Failure
But while widely welcomed, the two plans had a familiar and hollow ring to many students of history. Almost 30 years ago, a newly inaugurated John F. Kennedy announced the Alliance for Progress - a 10-year, $100 billion program intended to forestall revolution through evolution. And in a comprehensive policy report on El Salvador, the so-called Kissinger Commission in 1984 proposed new economic aid. It recognized the social roots of the Salvadoran conflict and suggested a crash economic and ''human development'' program. Both plans quickly were undermined by the precedence given to fighting leftist revolution.
While the region's economies have expanded and been modernized to some degree in the years since 1961, neither the Alliance for Progress nor the Kissinger plan achieved a single one of its ambitious social goals. Today, the vast majority of the region's 30 million residents have living conditions and wage levels as bad as - often worse than -those at the beginning of the 1980's. In Managua, families build homes from discarded milk cartons. In San Salvador, long-time residents of the main dump complain of so much competition that they can no longer scavenge enough to feed their families.
Despite $3 billion in American aid over the last decade, Salvadoran wealth is as tightly concentrated as ever. While the rich spend $10 for a box of imported Raisin Bran, many poor families now call beans, a traditional staple, ''rich people's food.'' Government statistics show that the poorest 20 percent earned less than 4 percent of the country's income in 1985, the last year for which figures are available, while the richest 20 percent earned almost 55 percent. The gap is slightly larger than what existed in 1970.
Three decades of development efforts have done little but help feudal oligarchies seize the tools of industrialization. Meanwhile, murderous conflict, tight credit and soaring populations forced the offspring of peasant families to flock to cities in search of elusive factory or service jobs. Guatemala and San Salvador are estimated to have almost doubled in size to about 2 million residents.
 
Power to the Military
Simultaneously, the region has suffered the most rapid military buildup in its history. The Salvadoran, Nicaraguan, Honduran and Guatemalan forces more than doubled in size between 1981 and 1986. More than ever, the armed forces in all four countries are shadow governments with de facto veto power over civilians' decisions. ''He's only the President,'' a Honduran colonel recently said in rejecting a request from President Callejas to allow a visitor to enter the country. And opposition from the Sandinista Army forced President Chamorro to sharply curtail her efforts to cut the size of the armed forces.
Despite recent emphasis on conducting open and fair elections, civilians remain presidents largely in name. While they influence the agenda for debate, they remain powerless to confront entrenched interests, most often on the right. Although all five regional leaders have recognized that disarmament is a key to development, they didn't dare to discuss the issue. It was, they said, too explosive. Other volatile topics like population control and land redistribution were not even mentioned in the final communique.
So it remains difficult to see how the two initiatives will redress the region's imbalances and create a new consumer class, which economists like to point to as the root of social peace. ''There's no sense of retribution,'' a development expert said in reviewing the successes and failures at the summit. ''They're not righting historical wrongs, but they are trying to correct the fatal flaws.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1146 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
For Japanese Art Collectors, Acquisition Begins at Home

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
IF high-rolling Japanese buyers are snapping up paintings by big-name Western artists - Van Gogh, Renoir and Lichtenstein -who's buying Japanese art?
The very same Japanese, along with a slowly increasing number of buyers from Western countries.
The booming Japanese economy and the dollar's slide relative to the yen have helped spur acquisitions by Japanese of Japanese art. Western collectors are beginning to sense that this art - growing scarcer and rising in price - is still a bargain in the overheated international art market. 
Among the factors driving the Japanese art purchases is a new blossoming of museums all over Japan, some set up by wealthy corporations and others by local governments.
''Traditionally, Japanese art has been undervalued and controlled by Japanese dealers,'' said Leighton Longhi, a major dealer in pre-l9th-century Japanese art who is based in New York. ''But prices have gone up tremendously in the past two years.''
The Japanese attraction for Western culture has made Western-style Japanese painters like Foujita, Kuniyoshi and Umehara very popular in Japan. But there is also a great interest in contemporary artists who follow traditional Japanese modes - Sugiyama, Hirayama and Kayama.
Last month, a painting by Tsuguji Foujita, an early 20th-century artist who worked in Paris and whose work blends Oriental and European styles, sold for $6 million at Christie's in New York, to a Japanese buyer. In April, a painting by Ryuzaburo Umehara, also an early 20th-century painter, was auctioned by Sotheby's in Tokyo to a Japanese dealer for more than $2 million.
The Japanese have long collected their own art such as ceremonial swords, lacquers and ceramics associated with the tea ceremony, a complex cultural ritual. But prices for this art have also risen. To the intense surprise of the Japanese art trade, at a Christie's auction last March in London, two pairs of ornate, 17th-century Japanese flower screens - estimated to bring between $300,000 and $600,000 apiece - were sold for more than $1 million each, to Japanese buyers outbidding Westerners.
''A few years ago, the dollar dropped in value, so Japanese collectors started paying what to us are very high prices for Western paintings,'' Mr. Longhi said. ''Then contemporary dealers in Japan said if Japanese pay that for Western art, we can start boosting our prices in the area of Foujita, Kuniyoshi and so forth. The price increases rolled over into classic Japanese art.''
According to Mr. Longhi, two types of new buyers have entered the market. ''Private people with new money in Japan,'' he said, ''and then people of wealth in the Western world who are starting to look at Japanese and Chinese art and see how undervalued it has been.''
Even so, he said, the number of Americans and Europeans who buy Japanese art remains small. In this country, aside from museums, only a few collectors buy top-flight Japanese art regularly, among them Mary Griggs Burke of New York, John Powers of Carbondale, Colo., and Joe D. Price of Bartlesville, Okla. Mr. Price's donation of money and the promise of his collection are the basis for a pavilion of Japanese art that opened two years ago at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
 
Largely Hidden Art Transactions
''Japanese art is a much more intimate trip than European,'' said Klaus Naumann, a German-born dealer in Japanese art who lives in Tokyo. ''To collect it, you need some understanding of Japanese customs. Besides, good traditional Japanese art is very hard to come by. It's in the hands of the wealthy, not found in secondhand stores.''
Transactions between dealers and clients in Japan are largely hidden, because of the luxury tax imposed on owners of art. ''Therefore, you don't hear about the real splashy prices that are paid for some things there,'' said Eric Zetterquist, a dealer based in New York. But he, like Mr. Longhi, suggested that Japanese art ''is still one of the best bargains in the art world, especially when you consider that until very recently, the works of some of the most important contributors to Japanese art were priced at under $1 million.''
Kazuko Shiomi, the president and chief executive officer of Sotheby's Japan, explained that so little art was available because Japanese families keep artwork bequeathed to them over generations. ''In Japanese interior decoration, only one or two pieces are put out at a time, and changed according to the seasons, visiting guests and so forth,'' Ms. Shiomi said.
The scarcity also reflects the interest of Japanese corporations. ''They buy just as many Japanese as Western paintings, except the market is quite local, so you don't hear about it internationally,'' Ms. Shiomi said.
Japan is also experiencing something of a museum boom. Older corporations have established generously endowed private museums, among them Idemitsu, Suntory and Bridgestone, as have an increasing number of newer businesses.
The success of the Japanese economy has also spawned a large number of museums set up by local government units. These so-called ''prefecture museums'' have been collecting both Japanese and Western art.
''Every prefecture now has its own huge, empty museum, and they're trying to fill it,'' said Barbara B. Ford, assistant curator of Asian art at the Metropolitan Museum, who specializes in Japanese art.
Joan Mirviss, a New York-based dealer in 18th-, 19th- and early 20th-century woodblock prints, paintings, screens and contemporary ceramics, says there are now more American customers for Japanese prints and paintings. ''In terms of subject matter, they are more broadminded than the Japanese,'' Ms. Mirviss said. ''They'll buy figurative prints and those depicting the Kabuki theater, which are not popular in Japan. Also things from the Meiji period in the late 19th century, and even 20th-century prints.''
Although Americans had been buying woodblock prints, also known as ukiyo-e, since the 1860's, she said, Japanese interest didn't become evident until the mid-1970's. ''As the Japanese became more affluent, more dealers arose in Japan, and they began coming to the West to repatriate the prints from auction houses and dealers,'' Ms. Mirviss said.
Prices of ukiyo-e prints are very low compared with Western art, ''but in the last three years they have escalated terrifically,'' Ms. Mirviss said. In 1985, an average work by Hokusai, one of the most famous woodblock artists, she pointed out, ''might have sold for from $4,000 to $6,000. Now, the same impression would sell for maybe $30,000. And it's solely due to Japanese demand.''
Most Western buyers, according to Mr. Longhi, are too late to form comprehensive collections of Japanese and Chinese art. ''But,'' he said, ''there will be more of them buying things of real esthetic value, rather than third-rate Impressionist paintings.''

CORRECTION-DATE: July 1, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the market for Japanese art misstated which branch of an auction house sold two pairs of 17th-century flower screens for $1 million each. It was Christies in New York.

HEADLINE: Deregulation Is Nothing but a License to Steal

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your two-part editorial in praise of deregulation (June 10-11) misses the point: the public needs protection from monopolistic industries.
Deregulation's downward pressure on wages, which you call ''loss of wage premiums,'' has resulted in a lower-paid work force running our transportation system. 
Why credit deregulation of the phone company for new communication devices? Who can say that they might not have been developed sooner and at lower cost to the consumer under regulation? And what about the expense and inconvenience for businesses and consumers who must use several competing classified directories, instead of one?
Some have made (and lost) billions buying and selling previously regulated corporations, exposing investors to huge losses on ''junk'' bonds. The half-trillion-dollar ripoff of the deregulated savings and loan system (which will cost each taxpayer thousands in the next decades) makes the Teapot Dome scandal look like a tea party.
Antitrust legislation and regulation of monopolistic industries were legitimate responses to the 19th-century robber barons. Now that these safeguards are being dismantled, how will the public be protected? Is the return of laissez-faire policies anything more than granting certain interests a license to steal?
 
JOHN GLASEL
President, Associated Musicians
of Greater New York, Local 802
American Federation of Musicians
 New York, June 13, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Deregulation Is Nothing but a License to Steal;
Only Consumers Lose

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Deregulation has worked,'' you say (editorial, June 11), but the funny thing is, consumers haven't heard about it. Take the airlines, telephone and cable industries.
In the airline industry, business travelers who don't want to stay over a weekend pay dearly for the right to be with their families. An over-the-weekend promotional fare on Eastern Airlines from New York City to Savannah, Ga., can be as low as $198, but zooms to $644 for those who want to be home by Friday. In regulatory days, customers paid a standard price lower than top fares today. Savannah is lucky; it still has major carrier service. Many cities now make do with commuter service at steep tariffs. 
While telephone deregulation has lowered long-distance rates, the cost of local service, the bulk of residential bills, has risen nearly 45 percent in the last five years. Some of the new communications companies - which often sell their services to hospitals, schools and hotels (captive audiences) - charge up to $1 for a local call and equally exorbitant rates for long distance.
Cable television deregulation has also meant higher prices for consumers. Communities used to negotiate set fees with cable companies. Now, the companies are unrestricted. Basic service in Manhattan with Paragon was $13.95 in 1987. Now, it is $16.95, an increase of 21.5 percent. A survey recently conducted by New York City showed heavy subscriber unhappiness with service in Manhattan, and the city is holding up franchise renewal. Nationally, rates have increased 43 percent since deregulation, 10 percent in 1989 alone, twice the rate of inflation.
Regulation protects the public when there are no alternatives. Until a true variety of consumer choices exists, deregulation will line the pockets of the few at the expense of the many.
 
ANDREW BLAU
 New York, June 15, 1990
 
The writer edits Telecommunications Consumer Coalition Newsletter.

HEADLINE: High-Tech Monarch for National Insect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Choosing a National Bug,'' Nicholas Wade's Editorial Notebook (June 1), which pits socialistic against self-interested insects as candidates for a national bug, seems a curious critique of the American propensity to measure value in narrowly defined economic advantage.
One might argue that the honeybee, rather than socialist, is the ideal capitalist because it has sense enough to bank immense natural resources in its hive. However, Mr. Wade correctly rejects the honeybee as our national insect because it will soon be a very serious threat to children through interbreeding with the killer bee.
But demeaning the monarch butterfly as a frivolous creature caring only for today obscures its valid candidacy. The monarch, a truly American insect (not a bug), has the most fantastic navigation system and migration behavior of any animal on earth. Each fall the fresh monarchs born in the Northern United States search their genetic memory, pull up their computer program, and fly inerrantly for 2,000 miles to a winter sanctuary high in the Mexican mountains.
Then, these same individuals, protected by their chemical defenses, survive the winter and fly 1,000 miles back into the United States to establish a new spring generation. Just as the cold war has ended because of the intelligent wielding of information and defenses, so the monarch has survived for tens of thousands of years by employing its biological information and chemical defense systems.
What better symbol of American recognition of biological values beyond the crass could there be than by designating the marvelous monarch butterfly as our national insect?
 
LINCOLN P. BROWER
Professor of Zoology
University of Florida
 Gainesville, Fla., June 11, 1990

HEADLINE: The Civil Rights Act: White Men's Hope

BYLINE: By Julian Bond; Julian Bond, former Georgia State Senator, will be a visiting professor this fall at the University of Virginia.

DATELINE: Washington

 BODY:
President Bush and Congress have overlooked an important reason why they should immediately enact the Civil Rights Act of 1990: to help white men overcome their feelings of inferiority.
Let me explain. Many whites and some blacks now argue that preferential racial treatment creates deep- seated feelings of deficiency and mediocrity in its beneficiaries. They warn that race-conscious practices, in hiring or education, cast suspicion on the competence of those given an advantage. 
But if that is so, we need the new Civil Rights Act more than ever, to overcome the sense of inferiority that has afflicted American white men for years.
Think of it. For decades, white men have known they've received favored, front-of-the-line positions in jobs, education and the benefits of a race- conscious society.
Without having to compete with minorities or women, any white man, no matter what his qualifications, had a head start. All he needed was membership in the favored race and sex.
The knowledge that maids, porters, garbage collectors, unemployed teenagers and cotton pickers were suspicious of their credentials took a heavy psychic toll on white American males. Some even chose to remain unemployed rather than take a job or a place in a prestigious university solely because of their race.
''How would you feel,'' one said, ''if everyone knew you had your job just because you were white?''
Social scientists say white male inferiority complexes began to diminish with the passage of early civil rights laws in the 1960's, and when blacks and women began to enter the work force in larger numbers.
But even relaxing the discrimination - which had reserved jobs as diverse as Supreme Court Justice, professional baseball manager, big city mayor, U.S. Naval officer, professional quarterback, talk show host, serial killer and newspaper columnist and publisher for white men exclusively - did little to ease the cruel intimations of mediocrity that ran rampant among white males.
These feelings of inadequacy began to return during the Reagan years. Some white men adopted a victim complex, blaming the Federal Government and the courts for mistreating them. Last year's Supreme Court decisions were the final straw.
The Court made it harder for minorities to sue against white privilege and harder for women to litigate employment rules that discriminated against them. It guaranteed a return to favored status for white males.
''It's all I can take,'' a white investment banker said. ''I'm sure my gardener was laughing at me as I drove into town this morning. Then the waiter at the club had a funny smirk on his face. I've had it, I tell you!'' the anguished Anglo-Saxon mourned.
If President Bush has any compassion, he will move swiftly to remove the awful stigma of race.
These victims have suffered long enough. Free white men!

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: The Region;
As Floria Changes Politics, His Foes Are Overwhelmed And His Allies Are Nervous

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
RELENTLESSLY over the last five months, Jim Florio, who took over the governorship of New Jersey on Jan. 16, has overwhelmed his enemies and unnerved his allies with a series of initatives that, as of last December, most politicians said a governor should not, would not or could not get done.
Mr. Florio asked the Legislature for a ban on assault weapons, an overhaul of the automobile insurance system, huge increases in income and sales taxes, stiffer penalties for polluters, and a new way to finance public schools that will pump billions into poor and middle-class school districts and hand the wealthy the tab. By the end of last week he had won them all.
On Thursday morning, when exhausted Democrats in the State Assembly gave Mr. Florio his final victory in the school financing plan, Florio aides bragged that they had changed more public policy in New Jersey in five months than other governors had in the previous decade. 
But the central question for New Jersey Democrats now is whether the man they have decided to follow, a high school dropout from Camden, is an emerging national figure blazing a path for a timid national Democratic Party, or a quirky ideologue leading his troops to political disaster.
''Florio now has a chance to become a significant player in the national Democratic Party,'' said Richard W. Roper of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University. ''If his policies succeed, other Democratic leaders will have no choice but to listen.''
''But I don't know if he has been successful at explaining what he is doing, particularly that his programs will help potential supporters in the middle class,'' Mr. Roper added. ''If he can't, the Democrats in New Jersey will face very serious trouble.''
Mr. Florio sees his policies as more than a prescription for New Jersey ills; he sees them as the basis for successful Democratic politics. Although some Trenton politicians have reservations about his strategy, they have seen several major themes emerge.
 
Telling Voters the Bad News
First, Mr. Florio contends that the best approach to solving budget deficits is to levy the necessary taxes, make the unavoidable cuts and tell voters all the bad news up front. In the long run, he argues, voters will reward strong leadership.
Second, he says that the problems of public education and poverty must be addressed head on, with large infusions of money to poor and middle-income school districts. More money alone will not solve the problem, he concedes, but without it, poor and working-class districts cannot even begin to improve. The rationale, Mr. Florio maintains, is more than a liberal appeal to compassion. School aid represents economic self-interest in a state increasingly desperate for workers, he says, and patriotism in a nation whose power will increasingly depend on its abilty to compete in world markets.
Third, Democrats can tax the wealthy to invest in schools and infrastructure, he says, if they can put together a coalition of poor, blue-collar and middle-income voters. Mr. Florio crafted his income tax package to that end, placing most of the burden of the income tax increase on the top 17 percent of wage earners - families earning more than $150,000 a year.
As a supporter of the death penalty with a distinctly working-class bearing, Mr. Florio has always done well with such voters. Although many affluent school districts will now howl, Florio aides say they hope that with time middle-income parents will realize their children are better off. Mr. Florio's brand of blue-collar populism sets him apart from Democrats like Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts or Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who have resisted the politics of class. To succeed at the polls, however, Mr. Florio must first prove that his aides have crunched their numbers correctly. In the long run he must also overcome the racial antagonisms that have separated lower- and middle-income whites from minority voters. And he must convince Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan that they were victims, not beneficiaries, of the Republicans who governed in the 1980's.
''The difference between working people in the era of Roosevelt and working people in the era of Reagan is that, although they were suffering hardships in both, in the 1980's Reagan somehow convinced them that government was their enemy,'' Mr. Florio said. ''Our policies cannot be aimed just at the poor.''
Whatever the theory, Republicans were unanimous in the Legislature in decrying the Florio programs, saying that after instituting $2.8 billion in new taxes, Mr. Florio will quickly destroy the pro-business environment that his Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, worked years to create. While Mr. Florio attempts to pit class against class, they say, they stand for economic growth that would benefit all.
Meanwhile, some grimly practical Democrats in the Legislature, who hold a narrow majority and are running for re-election next year, have another criticism: they are not convinced that working-class voters, or anyone else, will re-elect a party that raised their taxes.
Although they ask that their names not appear in print, a number of nervous Senators and Assemblymen point out that it is they who will first bear the brunt of voter wrath, not the Governor. He doesn't face re-election for three more years. If New Jersey is now Mr. Florio's political laboratory, they say, some of his followers are beginning to feel like little white mice.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Jim Florio, who has brought radical changes to New Jersey in his first five months in office. (Associated Press)

LENGTH: 1390 words

HEADLINE: SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Moscow Street Trade Heats Up

BYLINE: By Sarah Ferrell; Sarah Ferrell is the associate editor of The Sophisticated Traveler, a part 2 of The New York Times Magazine, which appears three times a year.

 BODY:
The Intourist bus pulls to a stop at the foot of Red Square and is immediately surrounded by young men hawking military hats, military belts and watches. The prices range from $5 for a belt (pungently scented leather with a handsome brass hammer-and-sickle buckle) or hat (several services are represented, all with colorful badges) to $20 or $25 for a watch (some bear the legend ''Perestroika,'' while others are of the military model). All prices are quoted in dollars.
This is theoretically illegal. For that matter, the sale and export of Soviet military goods is theoretically illegal. But the militiaman on duty in the square doesn't seem to notice - for one thing, he is busy fighting off a pack of aggressively mendicant gypsies who have also descended on the bus, and for another, he probably just doesn't care. Not in Moscow in the late spring of 1990. 
All of this might change momentarily. The militiaman might become interested in the black market (or free enterprise) transactions taking place under his nose, and the customs officials might start examining the luggage of departing visitors for contraband. Visitors to the Soviet Union might once again be restricted to making most of their souvenir purchases in the state-run Beriozka stores or joint-venture ''duty free'' stores that operate in some tourist hotels and airports, where prices are marked in rubles and rubles are computed at a rate of 1 ruble - approximately $1.60. (In Soviet banks, the rate is 6 rubles to the dollar; illegal dealing on the street brings about 10 rubles to $1, and offers of higher rates should be viewed with extreme caution.) While the hucksters at the foot of the bus will probably be the tourist's first experience of freelance souvenir vendors, they can be found at many points in almost any Soviet city. Prices are negotiable, depending upon one's bargaining skills and stamina, but most are so low that they are not worth quibbling about. The proferred wares range from crude to semi-exquisite, from T-shirts with a variety of silly legends ($5; not all of them made in the U.S.S.R.) and mass-produced Matryoshka nesting dolls ($5) to not-quite-museum-quality lacquered boxes ($40 to $60 in Moscow, but the shopper who plans to be in the Suzdal area will find higher quality at lower price).
The entrepreneurs themselves can be pests, ''swarming like flies - you want to swat them away,'' as one woman observed. It's hard even to eat in peace. In some of the grander restaurants the zakuski, or hors d'oeuvres, are accompanied with whispered offers of caviar for hard currency, while patrons departing such establishments can often be seen half concealing what look suspiciously like bottles of wine (the laws concerning the sale of alcohol are particularly strict). Any traveler who does not live to shop can get fed up with all this fairly soon.
A genteel shopping-cum-sightseeing excursion can, however, be managed. Many tourist itineraries now include a stroll along the Arbat, once the chief shopping street of the city, which was transformed into a pedestrian mall five years ago. For those who wish to stroll on their own, the most useful Metro stop is Arbatskaya, which brings you out at Arbat Square, historically (and arguably still) the artistic and cultural heart of Moscow. The Arbat begins with the late 18th-century building housing the Praha Restaurant; from there it runs a crooked course for about half a mile, terminating at the Hotel Belgrade. An hour should be sufficient to sample its amenities.
The Arbat has been tarted up with pretty 19th-century-style street lamps; it is lined with low brick buildings, mostly late 18th and early 19th century, that have been painted in the simultaneously brilliant and pastel colors characteristic of Russian houses and palaces. There are restaurants, cafes, theaters and shops; notable among the last are an antiquarian bookstore and antique and consignment shops whose windows merit attention. (One, in fact, merits a stare, with its prominent display of a large bronze bust, incongruously Art Nouveau in style, of Stalin smiling benignly at some little children.) Even on a rainy afternoon, the scene is animated, with street artists knocking out quick charcoal portraits, more gypsy beggars, impassioned orators and chic Muscovites (black leather jackets and, for the young women, lace-patterned black stockings are much favored) out for a promenade. There are places to have your photograph taken with such props as a bench in the form of a lion or a giant champagne bottle, and an ice cream establishment with outdoor tables - still something of a rarity. A plaque at No. 53, about halfway up the street, commemorates Pushkin's residence there in 1831.
Vendors do not swarm on the Arbat. Rather, their wares are modestly set out on the deep windowsills or, in the case of drawings or paintings, tacked to the walls. Among the goods for sale (it is worth noting that prices are given first in rubles, then in dollars at the black-market rate, and that dollars change hands discreetly) are good-quality boxes painted with fairy tale scenes and delicately painted Matryoshka dolls ($50 to $60). Barrettes painted with folkloric themes are $5, while competent, decorative little watercolors of local scenes are $10. A trio of babushka-ed women, themselves Matryoshka-shaped, clutch coarsely crocheted white table mats to their tummies; at first glance, the mats look like part of the costume, but they, too, are for sale.
One of the surprises of a shopping stroll along the Arbat is the frequency of religious and political imagery in the goods displayed. There is, for example, the set of nesting dolls in which each doll holds an ever more miniature icon. And there are the papier-mache Easter eggs: one ($45) is about the size of an ostrich egg, lacquered a glossy black, with, on one side, an image of Christ painted in the iconic style within a gold oval. (The reverse is decorated with another gold oval bordered with flowers and the legend ''X B,'' for ''He is risen''). Saints and Crucifixion scenes appear among the watercolors and oil paintings - many of which, unfortunately, look as if they should have been executed on velvet instead of canvas.
THE big bronze bust of Stalin aside (and that, after all, is in an antique shop), the political art runs to the sometimes incomprehensible. The satirical intent of a drawing of the Statue of Liberty, set askew, her torch holding the Kremlin, is fairly easy to figure out, but other works in the same genre require a greater familiarity with local figures than the average tourist is apt to have.
Ah, but the average tourist will certainly recognize Gorbachev, and the Arbat is one of several sources for what must surely be the Souvenir of the Year. Yet another variant on the Matryoshka doll, the Souvenir of the Year is a Gorby doll, complete with birthmark and ''Perestroika'' banner, which opens to reveal a beetle-browed and bemedaled Brezhnev, which opens upon a Khrushchev doll, clad in a peasant blouse and carrying an ear of corn, which opens to disclose an avuncular, pipe-smoking Stalin doll, which opens, finally, on a tiny, topcoated Lenin. Read into this what you will, but the object is a giggle, and if the $30 it commands seems stiff in view of the rather crude workmanship, it is a small price to pay for becoming the envy of your friends back home. (Actually, it's not a bad price at all, compared to the 47 rubles, or approximately $75, charged for an identical doll in a Russian-Irish joint venture ''duty free'' shop in a tourist hotel in Leningrad.) There are, to be sure, a few things that are not widely available on the touristic black market, and for these you will have to repair to a Beriozka store. Consider, for instance, the little imitation metal busts of Lenin, which may soon be as exotic a souvenir as anything found on the street. An average-sized one (still small enough to pack conveniently) costs about $8, and each comes with a certificate of authenticity including the name of the sculptor, the name of the art factory and the date upon which it was cast. And they are infinitely exportable. Even if the rules suddenly change and everything else is confiscated, you can be sure of bringing your Beriozka Lenin home. But keep the sales slip, just in case.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A bust of Lenin, on sale in a state-run Beriozka store. Soviet Army hat, and Navy belt. (Bill Aller/The New York Times Studio); lacquered Easter eggs, right; artists on the Arbat selling their paintings, below. (Vladimir Svartzevich/BONA Press)

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1869 words

HEADLINE: What's Doing In;
San Francisco

BYLINE: By Katherine Bishop; Katherine Bishop reports for The Times from San Francisco

 BODY:
While there was an automatic assumption that he would, of course, love it, most people in San Francisco never guessed that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would emerge as the city's biggest booster. But on his visit earlier this month, the Soviet president declared that if he were President George Bush, he would charge a tax for the privilege of living here.
The international attention drawn by President Gorbachev's visit and his comments about the city were an important bench mark in its recovery from last October's devastating earthquake: the official acknowledgement that San Francisco has re-emerged as a prime destination for travelers.
The city has already regained its convention business and diverse groups ranging from the Society for the Preservation and Encouragement of Barber Shop Quartet Singing to the American Council for Polish Culture will be gathering for their annual conventions this summer.
But tourism is still suffering; weekend and daytrip travelers are still exhibiting reluctance to return. While hotel and restaurant trade has been sluggish all over the city, Chinatown, North Beach and Fisherman's Wharf remain especially hard hit because the quake-damaged Embarcadero Freeway around the wharf area and the Fourth Street and Sixth Street offramps of Interstate 280 remain closed. 
This month new signs were placed around town to help visitors find their way to the popular sightseeing spots, each bearing a symbol for the area: a crab for Fisherman's Wharf, a Chinese lantern for Chinatown and a map of Italy for North Beach. A new program that provides free validated parking at a large garage at 250 Clay Street with shuttle vans to North Beach is also aimed at short-term visitors.
One positive result of the earthquake is that San Francisco is taking a careful look at its economic, cultural and architectural future with a willingness to consider fresh ideas about how to tackle old problems. This summer an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art (in the War Memorial Veterans Building at Van Ness Avenue and McAllister Street; 415-863-8800) titled ''Visionary San Francisco'' presents drawings and models of different visions of the city looking toward the 21st century.
 
Coming Events
Summer visitors will be among the first to see the just-opened permanent exhibit at the California Academy of Sciences (415-750-7145) in Golden Gate Park. Titled ''Life Through Time,'' it takes viewers on a journey of more than three billion years of evolution using fossils, reconstructed skeletons, models and living plants. Moving from single-celled organisms in the sea to early land animals, including an automated eight-foot-long model of a millipede and a three-foot scorpion, the exhibit continues through the age of dinosaurs to that of mammals. It includes re-creations of the plant life and the earth's changing topography, such as the tropical swamp that was Wyoming 45 million years ago. The academy, which also includes the Steinhart Aquarium and Morrison Planetarium, is open every day from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $4, $2 for youths aged 12 to 17, $1 for children 6 to 11, free for children 5 and under.
The annual Fourth of July celebration at Crissy Field begins with music from rock and roll to reggae at 2 P.M. with special children's programing from 4 to 7:30 P.M. Fireworks begin at 9:15 P.M. Visitors are advised to dress warmly and bring a flashlight. For parking and other information call 415-556-8483.
The Pacific States Crafts Fair offering the jewelry, clothing, pottery and furniture of 350 craftsmen will be at the Fort Mason Center (415-896-5060) from Aug. 10 to 12. Doors open at 11 A.M.; entry fee: $5, free for children under 12. A separate exhibition of folk art of the Soviet Union will also be at the center until July 29.
The Midsummer Mozart Festival runs through July at the Herbst Theater with a chamber music series on Monday nights and an orchestra series on Wednesday nights. A gala concert with selections from ''Don Giovanni'' takes place July 28 at Davies Symphony Hall. Call 415-552-3656 for ticket information.
The Encore Theater Company will present Shakespeare's ''Pericles'' in July and, throughout August, Howard Korder's ''Boy's Life,'' which was nominated for the Pulitzer Prize. Tickets are $10; call 415-567-6076.
 
Shopping
Two areas outside the usual downtown shopping district offer an array of small, creative shops that are worth an afternoon of browsing. Start with lunch at one of the city's delightful restaurants, the Zuni Cafe (415-552-2522) at 1658 Market Street, which serves food with a Mediterranean influence, before perusing the Art Deco furnishings at Decorum at 1612 Market. Another fascinating shop is Red Desert at 1632 Market; most of its cactus plants can be shipped nationwide.
Across the street at 1645 Market is Shades, which stocks a huge selection of 50's and 60's sunglasses as well as contemporary models.
At this point, one has arrived at one of the tiniest and most intriguing shopping streets in the city - a little alley called Brady. At No. 6 is House Party, crammed with 50's originals, which are in demand here: pink clock radios and chairs covered in furry, leopard-patterned fabric. Next door at No. 6, Vero offers contemporary home furnishings, jewelry and gifts, many of them one-of-a-kind designs by the owners. Bellocchio at No. 8 creates wreaths and other dried flower decorations, sachets, potpourri and brides' wedding headpieces. At No. 10, Telaio sells one-of-a-kind dresses and handmade silk scarves, gloves, handbags and jewelry by some of San Francisco's best young designers.
Next, walk a block or so east to Van Ness Avenue and take any of the several buses going north. Transfer at Sacramento Street to the No. 1 bus going west and get off at Baker Street.
Virginia Breier Contemporary and Traditional Crafts at 3091 Sacramento is a showcase of jewlery and home furnishings. Brava Strada at 3247 Sacramento is spare and sleek with modern Italian leather goods and jewelry. A small, well-chosen collection of Oriental antiques can be found at D'Arcy Collection at 3255 Sacramento while Vignette at 3625 Sacramento has a large selection of gifts and contemporary household decorations. Across the street at 3640 Sacramento, Button Down offers fine wool and linen men's clothing.
 
Where to Eat
Those who find that the names of their favorite dishes all end in vowels will want to seek out risotto or gnocchi at Enoteca Lanzone, a lovely Italian restaurant in the Opera Plaza complex near the Civic Center (601 Van Ness Avenue; 415-928-0400). The rooms house the owner's collection of paintings, sculpture and pottery. Prosciutto with pears and venison-stuffed ravioli in sage butter for two with a bottle of Cinque Terre is $65.
The dynamic new kid on the block is Cityblock just off a charming spot known as South Park in the up-and-coming South of Market Street area (101 South Park; 415-543-3663). The spare concrete and glass interior can make late Saturday night dinner a deafening experience, but the bustling scene is great fun. The inventive food is served in large portions. Two people can split the appetizer of fried wonton skins layered with sashimi and soy-wasabi vinaigrette and then each can go on to roast free-range chicken in a lemon and mustard demi glace with savory bread pudding and grilled squash for $40 plus wine.
For the more adventurous, the trend-setting Miss Pearl's Jam House offers wonderful food amid a campy Caribbean decor on the fringes of the down-at-the-heel Tenderloin District (601 Eddy Street; 415-775-5267). The youthful crowd of artists, models, writers and wannabes eats chicken-mango sausage with beer-basted shallots, salmon in Jamaican curry sauce and grilled duck breast with sweet potato puree. Dinner for two: about $50 plus wine.
For a casual breakfast or lunch within strolling distance of both Chinatown and Fisherman's Wharf, stop at Caffe Freddy's in North Beach (901 Columbus Avenue; 415-922-0151). Morning offerings include warm currant scones or a pizzetta with cheese, spinach, rosemary and roasted potatoes. For lunch there are pizza and sandwiches (roast chicken with basil pesto on herb focaccia bread, for example). About $20 for two; no credit cards accepted. Service is at a laid-back pace.
 
Where to Stay
The plush Portman Hotel has new owners and a new name - the Pan Pacific (500 Post Street; 415-771-8600) - but there are still luxury automobiles to whisk guests to and from the airport and legions of white uniformed young men to open doors and carry luggage. Rooms are decorated in hushed tones of beige, rose, gray and mauve with Oriental-inspired furniture, concealed minibars and televisions and large marble baths with telephones and small TV's. All sorts of extras can be ordered, including exercise bicycles. A minimum-rate room with queen-size bed is $175 for two. Suites begin at $550 and rise into the stratosphere. Parking is an additional $20 a night.
Also downtown, the elegant Four Seasons Clift Hotel (Geary at Taylor Street; 415-775-4700) is one of the city's most beautiful smaller hotels. The lobby combines wood paneling and crystal chandeliers and a small seating area for drinks or tea. The spectacular Art Deco Redwood Room serves as a cocktail lounge while the classic French Room is one of the nicest places in town to have breakfast. Dishes include ginger molasses griddle cakes with fresh raspberry compote, brioche French toast or eggs benedict on buttermilk biscuits. Reduced cholesterol and sodium dishes are available. Rooms are decorated in tones of blue and rose in comfortable, traditional furniture and the staff inquires after the guest's needs by name. Double rooms range from $175 to $285 with some rooms specially priced at $160 to $215 for weekend arrival.
Among less costly hotels, the Chancellor (433 Powell Street; 415-362-2004) offers a superior location one-half block from Union Square. During refurbishing two years ago, the lobby's original arching windows and ornate plaster moldings were uncovered and restored, creating a light, welcoming space. The 140 rooms are traditionally decorated in warm tones of beige and moss green, and nonsmoking rooms are available. Rooms for two are $95 to $105, and a two-room suite is $155.
Those seeking a sense of humor in their accommodations should try the Phoenix Inn (601 Eddy Street; 415-776-1380). The owners have taken an unattractive two-story motel on the fringe of the Civic Center and transformed it into a coral and turquoise 50's fantasy that manages to be both nostalgic and trendy and attracts luminaries like Laurie Anderson and Wim Wenders. Rooms are comfortably furnished, with the work of local artists on the walls and a television channel that plays movies filmed in San Francisco (''Vertigo'' and ''The Maltese Falcon,'' for example). All of the rooms face an oval swimming pool painted in bold graphics by the New York artist Francis Forlenza. Rooms for two are $89. Parking is free in an open lot of questionable security.
Budget choice: Pensione San Francisco (1668 Market Street; 415-864-1271), which charges $49 for two, including Continental breakfast.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia

 BODY:
To the Editor: Robert D. Kaplan's article on Ljubljana, Slovenia (Travel, April 1), paints an inaccurate picture of Yugoslavia's currency situation. His figures of 125,000 dinars or $2.50 for two plum brandies and a cup of coffee probably put his visit in October of last year, when the dollar was valued at 50,000 dinars. 
He is correct in his assessment of the economic situation at the time. Inflation of 2,000 percent a year did indeed render life miserable. Having lived in Zagreb for four months under such conditions, I can attest to the difficulties this imposed on one's daily life.
In one fell swoop, however, inflation was all but eliminated on Jan. 1, 1990. The Yugoslav government at that time instituted a revaluation of the dinar that tied the Yugoslav currency to the West German mark at the rate of 7 dinars to 1 mark. The policy has held; no significant inflation has since occurred. Inflation that had seen prices double every two months now equals West Germany's rate of 2 or 3 percent.
This Yugoslav economic miracle is a fascinating case study. Pity that few have taken notice.
 
ERIC S. BEST
 Chapel Hill, N.C.
 
Robert D. Kaplan replies: The figures I cited were accurate for the time of my visit in late October. The Jan. 1 currency reform was one of many economic reforms in Yugoslavia's recent history. It wasn't apparent until weeks later that this reform would work out as well as it did.

HEADLINE: Staying on the Safe Side

BYLINE: By James Barron

 BODY:
An American woman was enjoying a midday walk on a quiet side street in Florence when a motorcycle roared by, slowing just long enough for the motorcyclist to grab the woman's leather shoulder bag. She clung to the strap, but it broke and the motorcyclist sped off with her passport, her traveler's checks, wallet and camera.
If only it had been an isolated incident. There are no statistics on how many Americans are robbed or assaulted while traveling in foreign countries, but the State Department warned last month that crime was a growing problem worldwide. The Soviet press agency Tass, for example, reported that crime in the Soviet Union rose 32 percent in 1989, compared with 1988. In Rio de Janeiro, murders increased from 2,826 in 1980 to 7,654 last year. And even in Tokyo, which has extremely low crime rates per capita (there were 121 murders last year), police are worried about increasing numbers of larcenies by foreign visitors against foreign visitors. 
Nonetheless, some world cities have enviable safety records. In Tokyo, passers-by leave unattended luggage alone. In Geneva, crime is so rare that purse snatchings are reported in the local papers. And in Vancouver, British Columbia, there is little violent crime , though car thefts have risen markedly. In Hong Kong, the concern is whether or not the pearls are real.
While there are substantial variations in safety from city to city , criminologists at the Rand Corporation, a research organization in Santa Monica, Calif., say that the worldwide crime rise is due in part to drugs. Tourists - and their cash and easily sold cameras and personal stereos - are targets for addicts.
Whatever your destination, there are precautions to take before leaving home, as well as on the road. The American Society of Travel Agents, a trade group representing 21,000 agents in 129 countries, urges travelers to make several copies of passports, traveler's checks, credit cards, and airline tickets and other travel documents. The society says one copy should be left with a relative or friend at home. Another should be stowed in a suitcase away from the originals. Take most of your money in traveler's checks rather than cash; record the serial numbers, denominations and location of the issuing bank or credit agency. Keep this information separate from the checks.
If you carry a shoulder bag, keep it closed when you are on the street and hold it close. Do not carry a wallet in your hip pocket or inside jacket pocket, but in a front pants pocket. If you are driving, carry handbag or camera in the center of the car, out of reach of thieves who reach through windows. Be alert in places like train stations that are full of tourists. At the beach, don't lock clothes and valuables in your rented car.
The State Department suggests booking a hotel room between the second and seventh floors - high enough to deny burglars easy access and low enough for fire equipment to reach.
Following are safety profiles of 22 world cities, arranged by continent, and particular scams to watch out for, as reported by Times correspondents and contributors.

HEADLINE: Libya

 BODY:
To the Editor: Regarding a recent letter (Letters on Travel, April 8), your readers should be advised that travel to Libya is subject to severe restrictions under Federal law.
The use of an American passport to travel to or through Libya has been prohibited since December 1981. Penalties for misuse of a passport include fines of up to $2,000 and imprisonment of up to five years under Title 18 of the United States Code.
Since January 1986, travel-related transactions by United States citizens or residents with regard to Libya have been prohibited by the Libyan Sanctions Regulations, which effectively prohibit all travel by Americans to Libya for employment, recreational or research purposes. It is also illegal for travel agents and airlines to sell or book tickets to Libya in the United States. Violators are subject to both criminal and civil penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.
The only exceptions are for (1) travel and residence by close family members of Libyan nationals when the U.S. citizen or resident has registered with the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control or with the Embassy of Belgium in Tripoli or (2) travel by journalists regularly employed in such capacity by a news-gathering organization.
Questions concerning the Libyan Sanctions Regulations should be addressed to the Office of Foreign Assets Control, U.S. Department of the Treasury, Washington, D.C. 20220; 202-376-0392.
 
R. RICHARD NEWCOMB
Director
Office of Foreign Assets Control
Department of the Treasury

MRS. GORBACHEV and Millie FITGbondedFNMG.'' That good news was the word from Barbara Bush and must have caused much head-scratching at Tass. It has nothing to do, in this sense, with promissory notes, with aging whisky in a warehouse that has been insured, or with Ian Fleming's hero, 007. Nor does it refer to the coating of teeth with adhesive resins, to a sadomasochistic game, or to the FITGbonds of matrimonyFNMG, though that notion of ''ties'' - from FITGbandFNMG, ''something that constricts'' - offers a clue to the new meaning. 
FITGBonding FNMG(the gerund form is the most common) is a word being lifted from psychology. Students of human attachment, who took into account Freud's discussion of the libidinal feelings of baby to mother (which laymen like to call ''love''), seized upon the word FITGbondingFNMG, and that term soon shook FITGattachment FNMGloose.
''FITGBonding FNMGis a relationship,'' Mr. Honaker says, ''in which a person maintains or restores proximity to another individual. Often it involves a tendency to defend that other person, and the attachment is sometimes exclusive or preferential.''
The Longman Dictionary of Psychology and Psychiatry defines the term as ''a close attachment, or affiliation . . . present in normal behavior but absent in . . . the sociopathic personality.''
What about FITGmale bondingFNMG? This is what used to be called ''camaraderie'' or good fellowship, a hearty form of friendship now viewed with amused contempt by some feminists. In a 1979 reference to a Babylonian legend, Elizabeth Fisher wrote that ''Buried within . . . the Gilgamesh epic is an adolescent-male myth of the wonderful world without women, which still surfaces in male writings. It is the earliest extant tale of male bonding and the diabolic influence of women.''
These sinister excesses are no part of what most of us mean by FITGbondingFNMG. Non-psychologist fathers like to take a few days off from work to bond with newborn infants, and owners of just-purchased puppies need bonding time to wean the young dogs away from the alarm clocks placed in their beds, or pallets, to resemble the beat of their mother's heart. (I put an electric clock in the kennel, and the lonely pup howled all night; where do you find a clock that ticks anymore?) It now runs between people as well as between people and animals. SUMMER READING
SUMMER READING FNMGIS A phrase that means ''the sort of book that you take to the beach, which can be suntan oil-stained and sprinkled with sand without making the reader feel anything worthwhile has been destroyed; escapist pap.''
Not always true. Summer vacations or long weekends offer time for reflection and regeneration of the mind cells. Here is a sack of 10 books I have been setting aside for reading on holiday, especially suitable for language mavens with a foreign policy bent.
The trick is to mix the light and heavy, but to stick to the literate or at least provocative - by elevating your reading, you improve your writing or at least tickle your thinking.
''One, by One, by One'' by Judith Miller (Simon & Schuster, $21.95), a stunning report on the ways six countries are handling the memory of the Holocaust.
''The Sooner Spy,'' a breezily comic spy novel narrated by an Oklahoma politician, by Jim Lehrer, the only television anchor who writes funny novels (Putnam, $19.95).
''The Impoverished Superpower,'' this year's bible for foreign-policy hard-liners, Henry S. Rowen and Charles Wolf Jr., eds. (ICS Press, San Francisco, $29.95).
''Jubilee Jim and the Wizard of Wall Street'' by Donald Porter (Dutton, $19.95), a historical novel about Jim Fisk and his partners in greed, power and good fun - a must for today's Trumpniks.
''The Bible and Us: A Priest and a Rabbi Read Scripture Together'' by Andrew M. Greeley and Jacob Neusner, a not-so-odd coupling of prolific iconoclasts who team up to offer a lively entrance to exegesis (Warner, $24.95).
''On Liberty and Liberalism'' by Gertrude Himmelfarb, how the conflicting views inside the head of one man - John Stuart Mill - foreshadowed today's political argument ($10.95 from ICS Press - that's two for these guys, and I never heard of them before).
''Business Buzzwords'' by Michael Johnson, from FITGgolden hello FNMGto FITGgorbasmFNMG, the tough new jargon of British business, published in London by Blackwell; pick one up if you get over there, and achieve a high FITGpass-along rateFNMG.
''The Road to a Free Economy'' by Janos Kornai (Norton, $16.95), a plan for taking Hungary from socialism to a market system, timely enough to enable me to drop the ideas on the heads of visiting apparatchiks.
''Conflicts Unending'' by Richard N. Haass, about the need for ripeness in negotiation by a current National Security Council member (Yale University Press, $22.50).
''Why Blacks, Women and Jews Are Not Mentioned in the Constitution'' by Robert A. Goldwin, who has a Locke on our political history (A.E.I. Press, Washington, $16.95). Some of these authors I don't even know. Clifford Irving has a new novel I want to see, and Letitia Baldrige is taking the fiction plunge, too. But that's for the fall; this bag of 10 will do the trick on the beach. (FITGAt FNMGthe beach? No; the idiom is FITGon FNMGthe beach, FITGat FNMGthe shore and FITGin FNMGthe mountains.)
