HEADLINE: No Safe Way To Dispose of Ash

 BODY:
The Long Island Regional Planning Board has finally discovered the problem and enormous expense of incinerator ash disposal. Proponents of full-scale-recycling have long contended that, besides the critical problem of hazardous emissions created by mass-burn incineration, there is no safe and economical way for disposing of ash.
However, after years of promoting incineration as a solution to Long Island's garbage crisis, the Planning Board has come up with a report on how to ''recycle'' ash (''Study Urges Recycling Ash from Municipal Incineratorws,'' May 6). 
Curiously, the findings of the study belie any endorsement of reusing ash. The study found through laboratory tests that organic toxics, such as dioxins and furans, and heavy metals, such as lead, cadmium and mercury, will leach from ash in concentrations that exceed hazardous waste standards as classified by the U.S. Government. Ash is presently exempt from those standards, although there is pressure in Congress to drop the exemption.
Despite the embarrassing research results, the authors of the study still claim that ash can be safely used for construction of artificial reefs and roadbeds, given the proper mix and restrictions. However, projecting the stability of toxins in ash over a 30-to 300-year time period from one 3-year study seems irresponsible at best, and deceitful at worst. The precarious and dangerous nture of this ash reuse proposal is further underscored by the uncertain classification of ash. If the E.P.A. were to act on the facts, ash would be declared hazardous waste, thereby rendering the entire $1-million study worthless.
The conclusions of the Long Island Regional Planning Board defy logic. Their ash reuse study, conducted at taxpayers' expense, points out the hazards and enormous cost of disposing of the ash presently generated on Long Island - a cost which will dramatically increase if the Planning Board and local municipalities proceed with plans to build an additional four to five incinerators. Logic should lead one to conclude that the solution lies in preventing further creation of ash by halting construction of all new incinerators.
Instead, the Planning Board, eager to justify incineration, has spent $1-million to contrive a solution to a problem that is based on an erroneous assumption in the first place: that Long Island needs more incinerators. The Coalition to Save Hempstead Harbor has developed a widely-acclaimed non-incineration and recycling plan for North Hempstead (which is now the basis for that town's full-scale recycling program) at one-tenth the cost of the ash study! If local citizens' groups had access to a portion of the funds allocated for questionable cover-up studies, many more viable non-incineration proposals would be developed that actually serve the public's best interest.
 
KAY BROMBERG
 Executive Assistant
 
Coalition to Save Hempstead Harbor
 Sea Cliff

HEADLINE: Lower Budget, Lower Spending?

 BODY:
Having spent a good many of my 80 years absorbing the budget talks of a good many politicians, I have just about come to the reluctant conclusion that budgets will never get smaller, and that government agencies will never leave a single budget penny unspent, no matter how unwisely.
So along come the media to confuse me with promises of an imminent reduction in defense spending. A lowered over-all budget? Well, not exactly. A re-allocated budget, then?
I see possibilities in real location: a reduced federal deficit, perhaps, or some help to defense industries in re-tooling for non-military endeavors, or a few dollars spent to correct some glaring social ills.
Grinning again, I turn on the TV for more good news. I hear a familiar voice promising me a landing on Mars in the near future. Mars? Why Mars? And why Mars now, with re-allocation time upon us? I should have known better.
 
BORIS BERGER
 Freeport

HEADLINE: Race Tracks Seek Edge On Rivals

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY is the only state to have all three of the most popular forms of legalized gambling found around the country - horse racing, casino gambling and a state lottery - and at times the competition for the gambling dollar threatens to put one of the industries in the hole.
At the moment, it is the state's $1 billion racing industry, with its hundreds of breeding and training farms and five tracks, that is feeling the pinch, not only from the more recent casino and lottery operations but also from tracks in surrounding states.
The other states, including New York, Pennsylvania, Delaware and Maryland, all allow racing on Sunday while New Jersey does not. Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, the president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, said this had the effect of a ''competitive siege'' that threatened the stability of racing in New Jersey.
A solution, which voters will most likely have a chance to decide on in November, is to allow Sunday racing as long as the tracks shut one other day, and to allow casino patrons to bet on the races through simulcasting hookups to the tracks. 
''More people will attend racing, just as they would any other entertainment opportunity, on a Sunday than they would on an early weekday,'' Mr. Mulcahy said. And he said the fatter purses that would result from the increased attendance would insure that New Jersey could compete for the better horses. ''Our quality of racing will continue to decline as other states' innovations lead to higher purses,'' he said. ''The horsemen will simply move their better horses, and thus the better product, to out-of-state tracks.''
 
'Rising Opposition' Among the Clergy
The Rev. Charles Rawlings, director of the New Jersey Council of Churches, said it was difficult to predict whether the council would take part in the public debate on Sunday racing since the issue had just arisen in the Legislature. ''However, there is a rising opposition among some members of the clergy to what they call 'business as usual' on Sunday, and I anticipate that some of them may have something to say about it later on,'' he said.
Bills to put the two proposals on the Nov. 6 general election ballot are making their way through the Legislature. Changes in casino operations can be made by the Legislature, but any change in parimutuel betting requires a constitutional amendment.
Even though voters approved a proposal to allow simulcasting races from one track to another in 1985 by a vote of 1,040,117 to 533,926, industry officials say there is an ''enough is enough'' mentality in the state when it comes to gambling. They say their job will be to convince voters that the changes do not constitute a significant extension of gambling but a vital restructuring of existing operations.
Oddly enough, races from New Jersey tracks are already simulcast to more than 20 states and Mexico. The casinos in Las Vegas allow their patrons to bet on New Jersey races. That is why, Mr. Mulcahy said, ''it's crazy not to allow simulcasting in our own casinos.''
James Murphy, president of the Atlantic City Racing Association, which supports the changes, told a legislative hearing that patrons of Nevada casinos bet $2 million a day on simulcast races, with $150,000 bet on races from New Jersey.
Mr. Murphy said his association supported both referendums even though he did not believe that Sunday racing would make a big difference at the Atlantic City Raceway because it operated at night.
''I think it will mean more for the daytime tracks, like Freehold Raceway, Monmouth Park in Oceanport and Garden State Racetrack in Camden,'' he said. ''But taken together, the two proposa ls are unquestionably the best thing we can do for racing in New Jersey.''
He said the absence of Sunday racing probably dated back to the state's old blue laws, which also prevented most stores from doing business on Sunday until the prohibition was phased out starting in the 1960's.
 
Proposal Rejected in 1980
Mr. Murphy said it still might be difficult to win voter approval for Sunday racing. A referendum on the question in 1980 was defeated by a vote of 1,285,074 to 996,006.
Mr. Mulcahy said racing experienced a 14 percent drop in business when the state lottery began in 1970 and a 43 percent decline when casinos began operation starting in 1978.
He said that the impact was ameliorated somewhat by the approval of simulcasting, but that there was still a ''staggering'' 26 percent decline from the days when the race tracks provided the only form of legal gambling.
Unless the racing industry wins approval for Sunday racing and simulcasting into the New Jersey casinos, Mr. Mulcahy said, ''the consequences of this simple economic reality are track closings, job losses, breeding farms' being put up for development and the inability of the sports authority to generate enough revenue from racing to meet our bond requirements.''
Mr. Mulcahy said a study by the financial consulting firm of Deloitte and Touche indicated that Sunday racing could bring in $5 million to $6 million more a year for the sports authority and up to $2.5 million in increased purses for the race winners. Simulcasting into the casinos could provide the authority with $7 million more and a similar boost to the purse structure.
 
Supported by Casinos
The New Jersey Casino Association does not believe that simulcasting will mean much to the bottom line as far as the casinos are concerned, but it is supporting the referendums.
''We're trying to support the race tracks on this, even though it's not a big dollar item for us,'' said William C. Murtha, vice president and general counsel of the association. ''There would be capital costs and operating costs, but we're supporting the idea of putting the question before the voter to help the tracks.''
Both Mr. Murtha and Mr. Mulcahy said the details of how the simulcasting would be operated and who would run the operation were yet to be worked out. Mr. Mulcahy said he hoped some plan of operation would be completed by the time the Legislature completed passage of the referendums, perhaps next month.
Leon Zimmerman, a lobbyist for the Standardbred Breeders and Owners Association, said his organization was solidly behind Sunday racing, but had some concern about simulcasting into the casinos that he hoped would be addressed if the referendum passed and the Legislature enacted enabling legislation next year.
''Virtually every other state that has racing allows Sunday racing,'' he said. ''It's a proven big day both in terms of attendance and handle.'' Handle is a racing term for the amount of wagering.
Mr. Zimmerman wants to make sure that the trotters and pacers that his organization represents are included in any casino simulcasting schedule that will probably also include races from thoroughbred tracks in other time zones in order to offer the casino patrons wagering opportunities during most of the hours they are open.
The association is also concerned that the casino simulcasting might reduce attendance and therefore the amount of wagering at the state's harness tracks. ''We're supporting the referendum, but we want to make sure we don't lose fans to the casinos,'' he said.
 
Concern on Compulsive Gambling
Arnie Wexler, the executive director of the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, said he would alert the public to some of his concerns about the proposed gambling, including that it could increase the problem of compulsive gambling. But he said it would be up to the public to decide whether it wanted the changes.
Mr. Wexler has asked the legislative committee studying the changes to amend the bills to provide that 3 percent of the increase in revenue from any changes in the gambling statutes be turned over to the council to provide assistance to gambling addicts.
''People in New Jersey bet more than $5 billion last year, and the state received more than $800 million in tax revenues from gambling,'' Mr. Wexler said. ''But the council receives only $185,000 to run its programs.''
Emma Byrne, a spokeswoman for Gov. Jim Florio, said the Governor was concerned about addiction to gambling and would be willing to consider a proposal like Mr. Wexler's.
Mr. Wexler said that aside from financing, he was worried about the possibility that the simulcasting in the casinos might present another opportunity to increase the credit the casinos allowed gamblers, which he said was a major factor in encouraging people to bet more than they could afford.
He also said there was a study under way to allow people to telephone horse bets to the casinos. ''If we do that,'' he said, ''how do we make sure that minors aren't making bets?''

HEADLINE: LINDEN JOURNAL;
City Officials and Airport Operator Debate Airfield's Future

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: LINDEN

 BODY:
FORTY-FIVE years ago, low-flying aircraft were a welcome sight in this blue-collar industrial city. The Navy fighter planes produced at the General Motors Corporation plant along Route 9 here helped to employ thousands of workers in the name of the war effort. And when the war ended, the city got to keep the airfield across the highway that had been used as a test strip.
For residents, it signaled a postwar boom dependent on assembly plants and an energetic work force. But times have changed in this Union County city. Many of its industrial properties are silent now. The economically threatened G.M. plant no longer produces cars and is retooling for limited truck production. Workers there say they are lucky to have that much.
At Linden Airport, municipal officials have long argued that its 188 acres could best help the city's fiscal woes if it were sold to a developer. While it currently generates some $500,000 a year in revenues, selling the partly developed property, they say, could generate $70 million as well as future tax revenue. 
But the airport's current leaseholder and operator and the Federal Aviation Administration say that the field is serving a decidedly useful purpose as a home base to general aviation, or private, aircraft and that as a designated ''reliever'' field, it helps to take some of the burden away from nearby Newark International Airport.
 
'Multiplying' of Delays Predicted
Ending the airfield's operation, they say, would have a devastating domino effect upon the state's aviation community, forcing many small aircraft owners to move to other already overcrowded airports.
''We are hearing that air traffic delays and other problems at Newark Airport are going to increase some 30 percent over the next 10 years,'' said Paul Dudley, who operates Linden Air Services, which leases the airport. ''Start closing those small airfields like this one across the state, and you can take those delay problems in Newark and other metropolitan airports and start multiplying.''
According to the F.A.A. in Washington, the city is obligated to keep the airfield operating, no matter what. It accepted that condition when the airport was deeded over to Linden in 1947, but particularly since it has been the recipient of nearly $8 million in Federal Airfield Renovation grants over the last decade, the airstrip must technically remain open for the life of the improvements, which in this case last through the year 2002.
''There is still no doubt that the airfield, even though it plays an important role, could best help out the city if the land were used differently,'' Mayor Paul Werkmeister said.
Last year, to appease Government pressure, city officials elected to renew the airfield's lease but at a higher rental fee. The previous tenant had been paying $5,000 a month for use of the field, but the lease expired.
''We took it over by paying $46,000 a month,'' Mr. Dudley said, ''and if we're left alone to make this a viable business, we can make this a profitable venture, both for ourselves and the city.'' He is able to meet the higher rent, he said, because he subleases part of the airfield's hangar space to Trump Air Services, which operates a fleet of helicopters that provides transportation between Manhattan, Linden and Atlantic City.
A compromise may be reached sometime this year if a new municipal administration honors some of its promises, Mr. Dudley said.
In a primary election this month, Mr. Werkmeister lost to a fellow Democrat, John T. Gregorio, himself a former Mayor here, State Senator and State Assemblyman. Since he is running unopposed in November, his election bid is considered assured.
 
Years of Litigation Foreseen
Mr. Gregorio agrees with Mr. Werkmeister that the city would ideally benefit from the sale of the airfield, but the F.A.A. would block such a proposal, and the expensive legal maneuvering in the court system, which could take years, to fight the F.A.A. would essentially be ill advised.
''I do feel that the best route to take would be doing away with the airport altogether,'' Mr. Gregorio said. ''But at this point it is not a practical solution to involve the city in years of litigation.''
What he will propose to the F.A.A. and Mr. Dudley, he said, is to allow the city to develop 100 acres of the airfield adjacent to the highway for a hotel-office complex, while building new airport hangars and an operations building on the opposite side of the field near an oil tank farm. The area is currently used to park light aircraft on what was once a taxiway.
The cost of erecting new hangars and auxiliary buildings would be borne by a developer as a clause in the construction contract, Mr. Gregorio and Mr. Dudley said. Such a project could not be undertaken without direct F.A.A. approval, however.
''If that's what it takes for this airfield to keep operating, I think that we could all live with this kind of compromise,'' Mr. Dudley said, even though such a project would mean the elimination of one of the airfield's two intersecting runways.
While such a solution may seem promising, there is another problem that might lead to Mr. Dudley's ceasing operation.
Trump Air Services is feeling the backlash of its owner's financial problems. Mr. Dudley said, ''Donald Trump's rent to keep his air operation going here is $46,000 a month, which I pay over to the city as part of my rent.''
Mr. Dudley said that when the air services rent came due at the beginning of the month, ''we saw no check from Mr. Trump.'' A two-week extension was offered by Mr. Dudley and payment eventually came through, but ''I don't know if we're going to have to go through this same game next month or the month after that,'' Mr. Dudley said.
In New Jersey, according to the State Department of Transportation's Office of Aviation, the state is losing an average of one general aviation airport a year because of economic hardships. There are currently 58 general and commercial airfields in the state's 21 counties, compared with 69 in 1979.
 
'I'd Have to Relocate to Another State'
Linden Airport is a vital link for both private pilots and business interests, say those who use it.
''Many people based here use their aircraft for business, and its loss would change the way many people make a living,'' said Soloman Kramer of Elizabeth, a monorail company executive and veteran pilot. ''I'd have to relocate to another state and airfield if Linden closes the runways,'' he said, adding that 50 percent of his flying time involves company excursions.
Reuben R. Redfield of Short Hills, a certified public accountant who has been flying out of Linden since 1949, said, ''It saves me and my clients a lot of time and money to fly direct instead of having to rely on the airlines.''
Mr. Dudley said: ''These kinds of airports have a responsibility to stay open because this is where student pilots who eventually become airline pilots learn to fly. Take this away and others like it, and you do damage to an entire industry way down the line, and I sure don't want to be the guy to give the keys back on something as important as this.''

GRAPHIC: Photo; Paul Dudley, who operates Linden Air Services, which leases the 188-acre Linden Airport (F. N. Kinney for the New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 20, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1051 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Let's Go To the Rescue Of the Guard

BYLINE: By Edward J. Kanarkowski; Edward J. Kanarkowski served as a commissioned officer in the Regular Army and the Army National Guard.

 BODY:
THE other night I picked up a newspaper and there it was: an article predicting virtual elimination of the 50th Armored Division, an Army National Guard unit based in New Jersey. Many of the division's fighting battalions have roots that go back to World War II.
The article blamed ''Army cost cutters'' for the impending reduction in National Guard presence. Throughout the Northeast, the article said, undermanned National Guard units, like the 50th Armored (reportedly at 75 percent of its authorized strength of 12,727), seem to be easy targets for Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney's zealous bean counters. 
New Jersey's state and Federal lawmakers should be alarmed at this development for at least two reasons. If the 50th folds its colors, the state stands to lose thousands of trained citizen soldiers, who are now available for state emergencies, and cold hard cash.
The Federal Government currently spends about $153 million annually (primarily for salaries) on the New Jersey National Guard. New Jersey spends only $9.4 million on its National Guard units, yet the state takes in better than $17 million in income taxes from those same Guard members. In other words, the state technically turns a profit of nearly $8 million under the existing National Guard financing plan.
In the cold-war era, New Jersey leaders - Republicans and Democrats alike - milked the state's National Guard arrangement with Uncle Sam. The state has consistently ranked in the bottom quartile of all states for offering state-paid inducements and fringe benefits for Guard membership. Over the long haul, that neglect translated into 3,400 vacancies in the 50th Armored, and now the division's uncertain future.
What can New Jersey do to avoid the loss of its National Guard muscle? Our political officials have to put aside partisan politics and develop an economical, efficient and revolutionary force-structure plan that Mr. Cheney and the Bush Administration simply can't refuse.
As a businessman with 12 years of commissioned service in the infantry under his belt (four of those years on active duty), my assessment is that the Army of the 90's will commit relatively few troops to limited conflicts (e.g., the rid-Panama-of-Noriega mission) and have fewer dollars to achieve its missions, which in turn will demand greater dependence on skilled and motivated reservists, who cost less to keep on the payroll.
How does New Jersey's 50th Division fit into this scenario? In a big way. Here's a plan that deserves careful consideration by decision makers in Trenton and Washington:
* Redesignate the 50th Armored as a ''hybrid light infantry'' (HLI) division. Eliminate its five tank battalions, consolidate all troops into two infantry brigades and train them for limited-conflict missions, including drug-interdiction forays on foreign soil. Infantrymen are the key players in limited-conflict warfare. They also happen to be the least expensive type of soldier to train, equip and maintain.
* Assign one active-duty infantry brigade (medical, transportation) to the reconfigured 50th Division. These elements will fill the approximately 3,400 spaces now vacant in the 50th. The active units will play two roles: handle most limited-conflict active-duty missions and train with the two National Guard ''sister brigades'' for larger-scale contingencies that will demand the effort and resources of the entire division. Under this arrangement, National Guard units also can train sufficiently to accomplish their ''state'' missions, like protecting property in an area hit by a hurricane or other natural disaster.
* Station the division at Fort Dix. The Army spent $160 million on base improvements at Dix over the last 10 years, including $6 million just to modernize firing range facilities. The taxpayers deserve to get their money's worth for dollars already spent. Fort Dix has the capacity and right mix of quarters to house the entire active-duty brigade (and its dependent families), the division headquarters and all support troops right on the base. Fort Dix also has sufficient firing ranges and other training facilities to accommodate active-duty troops during the week, and their National Guard counterparts for weekend drills and two weeks of mandatory annual active-duty training. A revived Fort Dix would give a B-12 shot to New Jersey's slumping economy.
* Train the division to work with Air Force elements at nearby McGuire Air Force Base. The 438th Military Airlift Wing is based at McGuire (which is adjacent to Fort Dix). The wing consists of about 50 huge C-141 jet transports that can take the new division's units virtually anywhere in the world. Most recently, the 438th helped ferry troops and equipment to and from Panama in the expedition to capture the Panamanian strongman, Manuel Noriega.
* Permit the division to provide basic training at Fort Dix for its own active-duty and National Guard recruits. The Army currently consolidates basic training at several Army Training Centers, including Fort Dix. The Pentagon plans to curtail all basic training at Fort Dix in 1991. That shouldn't happen. Basic training should remain on the post - but only for 50th Division recruits, full-timers and National Guard enlistees. This will permit the division's soldiers - particulary the guardsmen - to spend valuable time training on drill weekends with their ''home'' units. Training with one's own unit reinforces a soldier's personal commitment, pride and morale. The Army of the 90's needs to rededicate itself and its people to these values. Camaraderie at times can spell the difference between success and failure. It doesn't belong in a barracks broom closet.
The United States Army, an organization rich in tradition, needs to go back to its ''citizen soldier'' roots as it retools itself to meet the challenges of the 1990's. New Jersey has a unique opportunity to help shape this new Army and preserve the strength of its National Guard by supporting the plan for a hybrid force of active-duty and Guard assets.
The 50th Armored is an excellent candidate for reconfiguration as an HLI unit. The commissioned and noncommissioned officer ranks of the 50th boast a cadre rich in experience and talent.
It's time, once again, to call on the militia.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Tanks of the 50th Armored Division during maneuvers. The division is an Army National Guard unit based in New Jersey (The New Jersey National Guard)

LENGTH: 1913 words

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE

BYLINE: By Roland Foster Miller

 BODY:
Peril and Promise: A Commentary on America By John Chancellor Harper & Row. 176 pages. $17.95.
Something bad is happening in America but it's not too late to fix it.
John Chancellor, the NBC commentator who was that network's anchor from 1970 to 1982, has sat in the front row of history for decades. He has covered every Presidential election since 1956 and has interviewed every President since Harry S. Truman and every British prime minister since Clement Atlee. 
''There were observations I had about the condition of life in the United States that I could not get into minute-and-a-half commentaries on NBC,'' Mr. Chancellor said recently from his house in Pound Ridge, where he and his wife, Barbara, live.
''I had been thinking about writing a book, and then I spotted a Gallup poll that said that 58 percent on a national sample thought that Japan was the strongest economic power in the world,'' he said. ''That was more or less the catalyst, what led me into writing this book.''
The fact is, of course, that the United States remains the world's No. 1 economic power. But there are soft spots and slippages in many areas. Mr. Chancellor addresses those points as a self-described ''frightened optimist'' in this slim but fact-laden volume.
What would it take, Mr. Chancellor was asked, to make him an old-fashioned optimist? ''The first thing that would make me an optimist would be if Americans stopped thinking that we are in a state of decline,'' he said.
What would make him a hard-line pessimist? ''A continuation of the cowardly political system we seem to have been given, a continuation of the poor education system we have foundered into, the continued loss of American technology,'' he said. ''It sounds hokey, but Americans have forgotton to dream, when people all over the world - in Eastern Europe and Russia and China - have just learned to dream.''
Mr. Chancellor's ideal country would have a political system that is answerable to the people but at the same time leads the people. The White House and the Congress would work together on reducing the budget deficit and jointly seek an honest economic base for the country. He would also ''take the tin cup out of American politics'' through public financing of elections.
''If we can get a responsive political system operating on a strong economy, the future is limitless for this country,'' Mr. Chancellor said.
But what today would be the equivalent of a Pearl Harbor, a momentous and galvanizing event that would mobilize the country's leaders and population?
''Men from Mars landing in North Dakota,'' Mr. Chancellor replied. ''It's very hard to get America aroused. I argue in the book that what would be useful would be for the President and the Congress to call for a state of emergency, to go on television and tell the patient what's wrong. The plan, of course, would require that people bleed a little, work harder, pay more taxes. It would not be a Pearl Harbor, but a point of departure, a lot of people working toward a common goal.''
The peril facing the country, Mr. Chancellor says, is in part clouded by a failure to present the case properly: ''It has all been reported, but the problem is that it has not been packaged in a way ordinary viewers and readers can understand it.''
''Peril and Promise'' should be read, Mr. Chancellor said, by ''a woman who is interested in civic affairs, by a husband who serves on the school board and is active in his community.''
''I also wrote it to be accessible to young people,'' he added. ''It's for various activists in various cities and towns. It's a book for those people who are closest to their government and who can cause change.'' If every American read this book, America would benefit. Mr. Chancellor divides his time between an East Side Manhattan apartment, from which he walks to work at NBC to write and deliver his commentaries on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, and his home in the county, ''which makes New York bearable and where I do my non-NBC writing.
The commentator-author said that if ''Peril and Promise'' does well, he could be poised at ''the start of a new career at age 62.'' The book entered The New York Times best-seller list today at No. 9.
 
Empire of Heaven
By Linda Ching Sledge Bantam Books. 576 pages. $19.95.
Originally, Linda Ching Sledge set forth to write a nonfiction book based on her family with a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. But the more she researched her progenitors the more apparent it became that she would not be able to write a book about ''a Chinese-American family and how it had changed throughout history.''
''There had been no other book like that written'' at the time, Mrs. Sledge said. ''I wanted to make it a popular work, but it would be a very authentic one.''
The roots of Mrs. Sledge's ancestors grew deep but they were garden variety. ''My family was ordinary, and when I went around with my tape recorder I was recording ordinary stories from ordinary people,'' she said. ''I love my family very much but I knew this wasn't going to make a book.''
''Empire of Heaven'' draws from her family's history and from family legend nevertheless. ''When I closed the door on the book as a work of nonfiction,'' she said, ''the one thing that I couldn't forget was my great-grandfather. And that was the seed of the novel.''
Her great-grandfather, Ching family lore says, was adopted into a clan during the Taiping Rebellion, which blazed through China from 1847 through 1864. ''Empire of Heaven'' transforms him into a warrior who becomes the lover of Rulan, a Chinese girl who becomes a spirit woman, warrior and healer in the rebellion.
Both of those characters were born of the imagination, but others, like Hung Hsiu Chuan, were culled from history. Hung, who claimed that he was the younger brother of Jesus Christ, attracted a following of hundreds of thousands before he ''locked himself away with his 88 concubines in his palace after ordering the assassination of his top leaders.'' He then went mad.
When Nanking, his capital, fell in 1864, ''those Taiping faithful who were not slain in battle set themselves afire and threw themselves from the walls of the city. An estimated 100,000 perished in this way.''
''It's hard for a Chinese family to expose themselves,'' Mrs. Sledge said. ''Even in fiction it's hard. But they've all taken it very well. It's rather unusual in a Chinese family not to be able to trace your family back scores of generations, because of the worship of ancestors. My father's family was always very embarrassed about it. I wanted to turn that into a source of pride.''
Mrs. Sledge has, indeed, given birth to a vivid adventure, a saga of scale calling to mind a Chinese ''Gone With the Wind.'' ''It's a genre work, a historical work, a piece of popular fiction,'' Mrs. Sledge said. ''My models were Michener and Clavell and Mary Renault. The Taiping Rebellion is, if you like, like the fall of Troy. Even though this is a work of commercial fiction, I wanted to give my family a kind of heroic stature'' in the work.
Mrs. Sledge, who began writing ''Empire of Heaven'' in late 1982 and finished it last year, said the experience meant that ''dreams can come true.''
''Writing a novel is something I've always wanted to do, not from some kind of genius but from just plain hard work,'' she said. ''Even more so after Tienenman Square. It was this horde of people rising, this grass-roots rebellion. The Chinese will always rise up and throw off their leaders. It was the same kinds of seeds of discontent that formed the Taiping Rebellion.''
Mrs. Sledge is also Dr. Sledge of the English department at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. For 15 years, she has lived in Pleasantville with her husband, Gary Allen Sledge, a senior editor at the Reader's Digest. He collaborated with her in writing ''Empire of Heaven.'' The story will continue, Mrs. Sledge said, with a sequel that picks up the family in Hawaii.
 
Survival Skills For College
By Mary C. Starke Prentice Hall. 315 pages. $22.60.
Oh, that a book like this had been around some years ago. High school-age students, of course, think that the accumulated knowledge of humankind resides beneath their hatbands. For that reason, freshman year at college can be a great leveler. The social order is changed, teachers no longer hold students' hands and there is growing apprehension that there are things yet to be learned.
''Survival Skills for College'' by Dr. Mary C. Starke, a Briarcliff resident since 1981, offers solutions to many of the problems facing today's neophyte collegians - who are all too often ill-prepared for the tasks and tests ahead.
''This book is not only for college freshmen,'' Dr. Starke said, ''but also for high school students and people who have been out in the work force, or for homemakers - students entering college for the first time. They don't know how much the personal and social aspects bear on their success in college.''
''Survival Skills'' grew out of Dr. Starke's 20 years of college teaching and her work ''with students at both ends of the spectrum'' at Ramapo College in Mahwah, N.J., a 4,000-student liberal arts institution just over the Rockland County border. This volume grew from an in-house text of hers that was tested at the college, with some interesting results.
''The in-house book has raised the persistence rate 16 percentage points at Ramapo,'' said Dr. Starke, a clinical psychologist who earned her doctorate at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. ''We've also found that students' grade-point averages go up, that they're more satisfied with the college experience, that they have more contact with the faculty, are more involved in extracurricular activities and therefore the ties that help them remain.''
The oversized soft-cover book mixes text with exercises, making students ''active partners rather than having them trying to assimilate the material just by osmosis,'' Dr. Starke said.
With 30 percent of the freshmen in the United States dropping out and fewer than 55 percent of them staying on until graduation, Dr. Starke said, the freshman year - and preparation for it - are all important.
''We are finding,'' she said, ''that students who learn about the benefits of higher education, who learn how to manage their time and cope with stress, who learn how to improve their communication skills and research career options are more likely to remain in college.
''We are teaching freshmen how to do research and write papers, how to interact with students from varied backgrounds, how to perfect their note-taking and study skills, how to examine their values and deal effectively with roommate and dating problems.''
Can reading a book like ''Survival Skills'' really be helpful? ''Yes - not only by reading but by actively practicing what the books says,'' Dr. Starke said. ''That is why those exercises are there. Students can compare their notes with what a really good set of notes are.''
Dr. Starke said that other institutions, including Ohio University, Indiana University and the University of South Carolina - which she said recently ordered 800 of her books - have been reporting success with programs similar to the one at Ramapo.
The author's husband, Charles, is a physician, and the couple have two children, 12 and 13. ''The daughter in junior high school is already using the book,'' Dr. Starke said.

HEADLINE: Rising Party in Italy's North Wants to Get Rome and the South Off Its Back

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CENE, Italy

 BODY:
On a chilly spring evening in this northern Italian town, a dozen leaders of the new local government gathered on the front porch of the Coba Bar, talking about revolution.
They hardly looked like revolutionaries, sitting there over coffee and mineral water at their favorite hangout. They seemed nothing more than a familiar assortment of businessmen and workers, soft-spoken and relaxed, with not a professional politician in the bunch.
But if Cene's leaders get their way, they would overthrow the basic structures that have kept Italy intact since its unification 129 years ago. They are dead serious, and they and their supporters have grown strong enough that the rest of the country is nervously watching them. 
Cene, a small valley town in Lombardy near the foothills of the Alps, stands in the front ranks of a young and increasingly potent regional party called the Lombard League, led by people who are fed up with domination by Rome. In effect, they insist on creating a United States of Italy, a federal system that might be patterned less on an American model than the Swiss, but either way would give full autonomy to Lombardy and other regions in the country's affluent North.
 
Two Italies, North and South
In short, they want a form of divorce from a central Government that they consider bloated and corrupt.
The Lombard League's emergence as a political force is perhaps the most graphic sign in years that one of Italy's oldest problems - the division between its developed North and its sometimes feudal South - may be deeper than ever. Many Italians fear that even as their country moves toward full economic integration with the rest of Western Europe, the so-called two Italys are sliding further apart.
Critics, especially in the South, accuse the Lombard League of being little more than a collection of rich bigots. They cite the group's calls for tougher immigration laws, plus frequent comments from its members that suggest disdain for the South as a backwater where people kill one another, steal public funds and speak incomprehensible Italian.
Luigi Moretti, one of two Lombard League members of the European Parliament, complained in an interview that there were too many southern teachers in Lombard schools, providing an inferior education. ''We want to impart a culture,'' he said, ''not a subculture.''
 
Revolt Against Inefficiency
But league members dismiss racism charges as a smokescreen tactic invented by their opponents. What they are engaged in, they say, is a tax revolt against a Rome-based bureaucracy whose decisions are guided by political patronage and marked by notorious inefficiency.
''The North has been supporting special interests and parties in the South for years, and we say, enough,'' said Senator Umberto Bossi, an intense man in his late 40's who is the Lombard League's guiding spirit.
Mr. Bossi's power to galvanize was displayed a few weeks ago in Pontida, not far from Cene on the outskirts of the postcard-perfect city of Bergamo. There, thousands of league supporters gathered, cheering as their leader denounced ''the centralist Roman underworld, on our backs for the last 40 years.''
The crowd roared back, ''Rome, you thief, the league will not forgive you!''
Their chant has found a responsive chord among the middle class in Lombardy, where the average per-capita income of $12,000 a year is twice that of Sicily's. It also seems to carry a strong appeal for large numbers of youths seeking an outlet for protest.
 
Tax Burden Is Heavier
Lombardy's nine million residents are among Italy's most prosperous. They form 15 percent of the population, but account for 25 percent of the gross national product and pay 25 percent of all taxes.
Only 18 percent comes back in state services, however, and people here complain that too much of the rest winds up in the economically backward but politically skillful South. There, they say, it goes not to help the needy but rather to line the pockets of politicians and Mafiosi. Indeed, there is ample anecdotal evidence to support many of their accusations.
Under the league's federal plan, Rome would take whatever small share of tax money it may need for national defense and foreign policy. The rest would stay where it is collected.
''I'm not saying that we're better or worse than the South,'' said Renato Bazzana, a league member who owns the Coba Bar and who has just become Deputy Mayor of this town of 3,700 residents. ''I'm just telling you that they have a different mentality down there.''
 
Named for 12th-Century Revolt
The Lombard League, formed in 1979 and named after a 12th-century federation of northern cities that rebelled against the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa, might have been dismissed until recently as a band of extremists.
But it recorded remarkable gains in local elections last month, producing expressions of alarm from political leaders and from the Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano. President Francesco Cossiga clearly had the league in mind when he denounced groups intent on dividing the nation with ''raving nonsense'' dictated by ''confused feelings, obscure resentment and forced folklore.''
In Lombardy the league drew nearly 20 percent of the popular vote to become the second largest party behind the Christian Democrats. On a nationwide level, its vote share came to about 5 percent, greater than that won by three of the five parties making up Italy's governing coalition.
It has followed this success with a new labor union of its own to press specific Lombard demands. It has also helped strengthen electoral support for similar leagues demanding autonomy, particularly in the neighboring regions of Piedmont and Veneto, where many people regard themselves as part of Middle Europe and Rome as lying on Africa's northern fringe.
 
Town Governed by League
Here in Cene, the Lombard League was No. 1 by far with 43 percent of the vote. As a result, this town has become Italy's only municipality to be governed by the league.
''There is no question that how we manage our town will be a big test for the league,'' said Mayor Franco Bortolotti, who owns a local transport company.
Although Mr. Bossi and others insist they are not motivated by anti-southern prejudice, others are not convinced. One of them is Ignazio Insisa, a taxi driver from Garbagnate - near the Lombard capital, Milan - who in reaction to the league has formed a group called the Southern Star.
Mr. Insisa was 16 years old in 1950 when he came to Lombardy from Sicily, one of millions of Italian southerners who migrated north in those years in search of a living. His first job was cleaning out barns for a few lire a day.
There was great anti-southern prejudice then, he says, but in time it started to subside. Lately, it has begun to pick up steam again, and he blames Mr. Bossi for ''unleashing this hate.''
 
Disturbing New Trends
For years, southern Italians have been referred to derisively in the North as ''terroni,'' a word that can be most politely translated as ''clodhoppers.'' Now, Mr. Insisa and others see disturbing new trends, like signs outside bars that say, ''Terroni and dogs are not allowed.'' When the Naples soccer team played in Milan one Sunday last winter, local fans displayed a large banner saying, ''Hitler: Do to the Neapolitans What You Did to the Jews.''
All of which leaves many Italians wondering if they have made much progress since the 1860's, when the statesman Massimo D'Azeglio observed after Italy's unification: ''We have made Italy. Now we must make Italians.'' Mr. Bossi has no doubts. ''We have not yet created Italians,'' he said. ''In fact, there is no Italy. There are at least three Italies -North, which is Middle Europe, and the other two, the Center and the South.''

HEADLINE: The Mandela Visit;
Education Is Mighty Force, Boston Teen-Agers Are Told

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 23

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela paused for a moment today in his single-minded concentration on ending South African apartheid to offer some advice to black teen-agers.
''Try as much as possible to remain in school, because education is the most powerful weapon we will need,'' he told an almost worshipful crowd of about 2,000 people packed into the stuffy gymnasium at Madison Park High School in Roxbury, a predominantly black section of Boston.
This city, with its support of divestment from businesses in South Africa and its large South African exile community, was a natural for Nelson and Winnie Mandela's eight-city tour.
In addition, Senator Edward M. Kennedy has been a driving force in anti-apartheid legislation, and his brother, President John F. Kennedy, began this country's first sanctions against South Africa. And there are personal reasons for the visit here: two of Mr. Mandela's daughters live in Boston. 
 
Addressing American Concerns
Black Americans have responded emotionally to Mr. Mandela, the living symbol of the anti-apartheid struggle and deputy president of the African National Congress, hailing him as a hero and a leader reminiscent of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X. But this was the first time Mr. Mandela, who had concentrated his remarks on the South African issue, has addressed concerns of black Americans. At Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn the other day, for example, he launched almost immediately into a fund-raising appeal.
After a triumphant three-day reception in New York that included a ticker-tape parade, a speech to the United Nations, jubilant receptions on the streets of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Harlem and the donning of a New York Yankee jacket and cap, Mr. Mandela arrived here this morning about two hours late, as has become normal.
He will travel Sunday to Washington, where he will meet President Bush in the White House on Monday and speak to Congress on Tuesday. Then he is on to Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland. There are nearly identical schedules along the way, featuring motorcades, welcoming ceremonies with politicians crowding close for the cameras and fund raising at receptions, concerts and rallies.
 
Lunch With Kennedy
In addition to his brief speech in Roxbury, Mr. Mandela had a private lunch with Senator Kennedy and other members of the Kennedy family at the Kennedy Library on the University of Massachusetts campus in the Dorchester neighborhood. He also mingled at a $5,000-a-couple formal dinner for 1,000 people and spoke during a six-hour-long concert.
The concert at the Esplanade on the banks of the Charles River included Paul Simon, whose ''Graceland'' album featured South African singers. At the concert, Mr. Mandela personally thanked Senators Kennedy and John Kerry and Mayor Raymond Flynn for support of divestment.
Sponsors of the events hope to raise $1 million for the Fund for a Free Africa, said Jean M. Mahoney, director of the Reebok Foundation, a principal fund-raiser.
The excitement Mr. Mandela is generating was evident in posters and banners all over the city. Bells pealed this morning from the city's churches in welcome. The police department canceled all days off and put officers on motorcycles, horses, bicycles, boats and in scuba-diving gear.
Outside Madison Park High, T-shirt hawkers displayed their wares with pictures of Mr. Mandela and of Malcolm X, who was once a street hustler in the neighborhood.
 
Prisoners Disciplined
The Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts criticized state prison officials for isolating eight inmates on the eve of Mr. Mandela's visit for wearing leather medallions cut in the shape of Africa and stamped with black, green and yellow, the colors of the African National Congress.
Katherine Robertson, a spokeswoman for the Department of Correction, said, ''That kind of thing cannot be tolerated, for obvious reasons.'' She said other prisoners had been disciplined for wearing shamrocks.
While the Boston area includes a large liberal and academic community that gave considerable support to the anti-apartheid movement, the city was the scene of racial tension in the mid-1970's, when a Federal Court ordered busing for school desegregation.
But the other day, Mayor Flynn, who grew up playing basketball on the all-white playgrounds of his Irish-American South Boston neighborhood, presided over a ceremony in which the flag of the African National Congress was raised at City Hall.
Mr. Mandela was received with chants of ''Free South Africa'' that shook the bleachers in the gym and responded with a clenched fist salute and a cry of ''Amandla,'' Zulu for ''power,'' which was shouted back by the crowd.
Thanking them for their support which, he said, had helped force the white South African Government to remove the ban on the A.N.C. and to release political prisoners, including himself, Mr. Mandela concluded by telling the crowd, ''we respect you, we admire you, and, above all, we love you.''
''We love you, too,'' the cry came back.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Chicago;
Student Group Seeks Closer Ties To Neighborhoods

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Taking their cue from a long-dor mant neighborhood organization, students at the University of Chicago have formed a community action group that aims to dissolve what they see as racial and economic barriers separating the university from surrounding neighborhoods. The group is modeled on the Student Woodlawn Area Project, founded in 1966 with the same objectives. Students in the new organization, called Student Neighborhood Action Project, or SNAP, hope to combine community service with scholarly research and discussion to promote greater understanding between town and gown. 
Rebecca Reuter, a sophomore biology major from Chicago and a founding member of SNAP, said she hoped the group could ''help people change their views about students and help students change their views of the surrounding communities and the people in them.'' Although she was born and raised in Chicago, she said she ''didn't hear anything about the U. of C. - when you go there, you feel separated from the city.''
Another founding member, Naomi Swinton, an anthropology major from Morrisville, Pa., who just completed her first year, said she hoped SNAP's membership would not be limited to college students. ''We want faculty and staff, as well as neighborhood residents, including high school students,'' she said.
 
'We Are Not Bad People'
The group has come up with several projects for the summer and fall, aimed at meeting three goals: improved community relations within the university, closer ties with Chicago's South Side and increased discussion of racial and economic equality.
SNAP intends to work, for example, with local high school students, encouraging them to stay in school and consider attending college. Other projects will be assigning university students to work at nonprofit agencies and sponsoring a neighborhood painting and cleanup day.
SNAP's members have also joined an effort to keep the nearby public library open. They hope to use it as a base for neighborhood tutoring and reading programs.
''We want to spread the word that we are not bad people, we're not these elitists,'' said Ken Kawashima, a freshman East Asian studies major from Bowling Green, Ohio.
Gary Orfield, a political science professor who has agreed to advise SNAP, said efforts like this ultimately have ''a much deeper effect on students'' than the neighborhood problems they sought to remedy. The projects ''give you a much richer understanding of political and social questions,'' he said.
 
Summer Reading List
On campus, members of the group plan to create a supplementary orientation program for incoming freshmen. The current program includes a lecture on personal security that SNAP members say overemphasizes the negative aspects of life on Chicago's South Side.
SNAP members said warnings by administration representatives not to venture out of the area patroled by the campus police had deterred students from becoming involved with the community. The enhanced orientation, Ms. Swinton said, will include a history of the South Side, a discussion of the possibilities for community action and advice about using public transportation safely.
Students have also compiled a summer reading list in consultation with Mr. Orfield. They say they will hold informal study sessions next year at which readings, ranging from Richard Wright's ''Native Son'' to Dan Rose's ''Black Street Life'' to biographies of Chicago's late Mayor Harold Washington, will be discussed.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 5, Column 0; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1816 words

HEADLINE: Quebec Could Easily Prosper On Its Own, Economists Say

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Whatever the outcome of Canada's crisis over Quebec, the French-speaking province has slowly developed an economy strong enough to allow Quebec to separate and become a nation three times the area of France, taking with it nearly a quarter of Canada's wealth.
Few economists challenge the proposition that a new generation of French-speaking business leaders have greatly expanded Quebec's manufacturing base, giving the province the wherewithal to operate on its own. Even those who hope the Canadian union will be saved acknowledge that secession can work, provided that Quebec enjoys the good will of the United States.
''The economic viability of Quebec is no longer in doubt,'' said John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist, himself Canadian-born. ''But this is not the issue. The political and cultural loss to Canadians would be irretrievable.'' 
On Friday night it became apparent that Canada's nine other provinces would not meet the deadline for all of them to approve the Meech Lake Accord, which would have recognized Quebec as a ''distinct society.''
The death of the accord has brought a new stalemate to the political maneuvering over the drive for separatism, a movement that some Quebec officials fear could be damaging to the economy. In a speech in Quebec City yesterday, Robert Bourassa, the Premier of Quebec, said, ''The government will never take risks with the economic security of Quebec .''
Nevertheless, Quebec seems to be moving toward de facto autonomy anyway, propelled by French-speaking executives, men mostly in their late 40's. In interviews last week in Montreal, several of the executives made it clear that they see greater autonomy not so much as an ideological goal but as good in the long run for their businesses and for the province's economy. Over the last 15 years, French-speaking executives have gained control of Quebec's industries, replacing English-speaking managers who had held sway for generations.
They now own or control companies that employ 61 percent of the province's work force, up from less than 50 percent in the early 1970's, according to Government data. And as Quebec's manufacturing base grows and diversifies, they speak restlessly of Montreal as the vibrant commercial center of a province whose main growth in the future will be through exports to the United States and Europe. Seventeen percent of Canada's exports, or nearly $23 billion, comes from Quebec.
Rene Pelletier, president of Barometer, a polling company whose public opinion surveys in the province show a majority favoring separation, said, ''People here know that to be independent tomorrow morning would have a price, but businessmen say that it would be easier to operate as a trading center if Quebec were independent.''
There is indeed some handwringing over the prospect of separation. Ghislain DuFour, head of Quebec's Employer Council, which represents more than 500 companies, worries that the province's economy might not yet be strong enough to prosper during a period of transition and uncertainty -an uncertainty that has already reduced investment in the province and pushed up interest rates on Quebec's bonds.
What is more, even the most ardent separatists, among them Jacques Parizeau, leader of the Parti Quebecois, acknowledge that a breakaway Quebec could run into difficulty without the good will of the United States and neighboring Ontario. In virtually everyone's view, the United States would have to extend to Quebec the free trade agreement now in effect for all of Canada, and Ontario would have to continue to purchase huge quantities of Quebec's output.
Ontario is Canada's wealthiest province, turning out 38.5 percent of the nation's gross domestic product, followed by Quebec, with 23.6 percent. Quebec's G.D.P. alone is roughly $129 billion in United States dollars, and the two provinces sell to each other more than 20 percent of their total output.
Mr. Parizeau argues that Ontario could not afford to give up the Quebec market, and he says that American business executives would not want to exclude Quebec, with its nearly seven million people, from the free trade zone. Canada's total population is about 27 million.
 
Daily Life Is Not Impeded
Aside from these concerns, the people of Quebec have dealt with the debate over the province's status almost as spectators. Life proceeds routinely and many Quebecois, as the residents are called, seemed last week to view the breakdown of the Meech Lake effort as simply another step on a very long road to greater autonomy.
Francois Lebrun, executive director of the Meech Lake Business Association, an organization of 3,000 mostly French-speaking businessmen who favor the Meech Lake Accord, said: ''We have been negotiating the issue of separation for more than 100 years, and the negotiations will keep on. Nothing will be noticeably different here on Monday.''
Even as they negotiated, the Quebecois were expanding their high-technology manufacturing sector, quintupling since 1979 the number of companies established in the province each year. The change makes Quebec less dependent on textiles and apparel, two dying traditional industries, and on the sale of natural resources, particularly cheap hydroelectric power.
The natural markets for the new production of flight simulators, snowmobiles, subway cars, plastics, electronic devices, engineering services, telecommunications equipment and the like are the United States and Europe, rather than Canada, with its sparse population. This new emphasis on trade comes just as the 18-month-old free trade agreement with the United States is beginning to bring down tariff barriers, a huge encouragement for Quebec business executives to see the province as part of a North American economy.
 
A Stronger Identity
The secession crisis in the 1970's strengthened the business community's identity with Quebec. The crisis prompted thousands of English-speaking business people to migrate with their families from Montreal to Toronto, shifting many enterprises and some 14,000 management jobs to that rival and bigger commercial center. The English-speaking business community that remains is mostly bilingual and more often than not it shares management posts with French-speaking executives, said Alex Harper, executive director of the Montreal Board of Trade, an association of 3,000 companies.
Until 1967, English only was spoken in the board's dining room and bar for members. Now French and English intermingle, and Mr. Harper said, ''I think that the Anglophones here today identify more with the Francophones than with the rest of English-speaking Canada.''
But for all the new confidence and bravado about going it alone, there is much bracing for what economists describe as the short-term impact of the failure to ratify Meech Lake - a failure that would breed uncertainty about Quebec's future.
Already, new capital investment, both foreign and domestic, has declined and the interest rates on the bonds sold by Quebec's huge government-owned hydroelectric company, Hydro-Quebec, are running one-half to one percentage point above their usual levels. The utility has $18.7 billion in debt outstanding, much of it held in the United States, and it plans to borrow nearly $50 billion in this decade.
Still, three preliminary estimates -from Merrill Lynch & Company, the Bank of Montreal and the Toronto-Dominion Bank - all argue that the Quebec economy could survive separation, or much greater autonomy, with minimum damage. ''Given the economic strengths of the province, one could argue that a 'sovereign' rating on Quebec would not be much different from its rating as a province,'' Merrill Lynch said.
The Merrill report, although written in New York, undoubtedly reflected the thinking of Pierre Laurin, vice chairman of Merrill's Canadian operation and a leader of the new French-speaking executives.
''Business in Quebec is increasingly internationally oriented and Merrill Lynch is positioning itself to be the interface with American investors,'' said Mr. Laurin, who tells of plunging into Harvard Business School in the 1960's, barely able to speak English, because he did not want to spend his life working for English-speaking bosses, as his father had.
''You have to look at this with perspective,'' said Mr. Laurin, who is 50 years old. ''We have spent years negotiating separation and I am sure that compromises will keep developing.''
 
The Reins of Power
Mr. Laurin's generation of French-speaking businessmen now run such powerhouse corporations as Bombardier, the aerospace manufacturer; Bell Canada, the national phone company, and Steinberg's, a huge discount store chain.
Mr. Lebrun, who is also vice president of Raymond, Chabot, Martin, Pare, Quebec's biggest accounting firm, is a spokesman for this group. He is a lawyer who never practiced, instead pushing his way into business instead 20 years ago.
''Independence for Quebec was unthinkable in the business community a decade ago, and now sovereignty is a serious option,'' he said, recalling that his father had worked for the English-speaking managers of a fur company and had been forced to operate in English at work.
''I cannot imagine losing my language and culture and we cannot maintain it unless we do business in French,''Mr. Lebrun said.
 
Quebec's Distinctions
Other factors are also separating the Quebec economy from the rest of Canada. Alone among the provinces, Quebec manages its own Social Security and public pension funds, investing billions of dollars in Quebec companies.
The province also sends to the federal Government in Ottawa roughly as much as it gets back in various social payments, government contracts, military spending and the like, according to the Frazier Institute, an economic research organization in Vancouver, British Columbia.
The net flow from Ottawa, is a negligible $300 a year for each of the province's 6.7 million people, says Michael Walker, the institute's director. ''If you had a referendum on autonomy in Quebec, the people would say, 'well, that's three or four meals out and a movie. What's the big deal','' Mr. Walker said. Quebec businessmen are also dissatisfied with the Bank of Canada's monetary policy, which has pushed up interest rates to control inflation, which is now running about 5 percent a year. As Mr. Laurin and others see it, the inflation is mostly in Ontario.
In Quebec, the high interest rates are discouraging investment and slowing economic activity at a time when Quebec's unemployment rate is 9.3 percent, almost twice the national average, mostly because of layoffs in the dying textile and apparel industries.
''It's an irritant,'' Mr. Laurin said, arguing that a separate Quebec would get a bigger say in Canadian monetary policy, assuming that Quebec keeps the Canadian dollar as its currency.

LENGTH: 1966 words

HEADLINE: Island Feeling Effects of Slump In City Economy

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ

 BODY:
AS New York City's financial problems deepen, Long Island, an important source of labor for the city and a major market for its products, is beginning to feel the effects.
Cutbacks in financial services and related industries have curtailed spending on the Island, contributing to a sharp decline in the growth of retail sales and softenings in the residential and commercial real-estate markets, business leaders, planners and economists say.
New York City's shortfall in tax revenues, budget deficits and impending service cuts are raising doubts in the minds of some Long Islanders about the future of the city's financial affairs.
''When New York City is in trouble, all attention focuses on the city, if for no other reason than that there are so many Long Islanders working there,'' said Arthur J. Kremer, a former Assemblyman and a partner in the law firm of Rivkin, Radler, Bayh, Hart & Kremer of Uniondale. ''The service industry in the city is turning, and Long Island is strongly impacted by it.'' 
No one has estimated how many of the 29,000 financial-services workers who have lost their jobs since the October 1987 stock-market crash live on the Island. Nor is anyone estimating how many commuters have had their bonuses cut or been otherwise affected by the slowdown. Experts agreed that both groups were well represented among Nassau and Suffolk residents.
 
Shrinking but Prosperous
Although the 20 percent of Long Island workers who commute to Manhattan represent a shrinking part of Long Island's work force, the number has remained at 200,000 for 10 years. And their jobs are among the higher paying. Nearly 4 in 10 are executives or professionals, according to the Census.
The commuters wield 30 percent of the purchasing power on Long Island, and their losses in income have a greater effect proportionally.
''The impact,'' said Thomas Conoscenti, program director of the management department at Polytechnic University in Farmingdale, ''really has come forth in the last year or so in terms of the disposable income declining.
''Instead of making $100,000 a year, people in the financial markets are making, say, $60,000. Their income was reduced by $40,000. So their proportionate expenditure patterns are going to be reduced. That gets reflected in retail sales, which are reflected in sales-tax revenue.''
The effect on retail sales is not directly measurable. But leading retailers say it is unmistakable, especially for luxuries.
 
Declining Sales Growth
''A lot of our customers, especially those who spend significant money, were involved in Wall Street and certainly still are,'' said Alan Fortunoff, president of the Fortunoff stores in Westbury, probably best known for the sale of jewelry. ''The significant amount of people who lost their jobs has had an effect. There's no question about it.''
Commuters' loss of purchasing power is a major factor in sharply declining sales growth in the last year, said Pearl Kamer, chief economist of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. Retail sales of $25.4 billion last year represented an increase of 2.2 percent over 1988, when sales increased 8.2 percent over 1987.
For big-ticket items, the most sensitive indicator of spending among upper-income groups, the fall-off was more dramatic. Sales grew 2.5 percent between 1988 and 1989, down from 18.6 percent the year before.
Beyond the effect on retail sales, ''financial services is an important specialty in the city and the region, and since these people earn so much there has been a big spillover effect,'' said Matthew P. Drennan, professor of economics and director of the public administration program at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. ''Real estate, both residential and commercial, has felt the effects of the layoffs on Wall Street.''
 
Changes in Second Homes
The market for second homes on the East End ''has kind of dried up, mostly because the extra money isn't there,'' said Justine Aleschus, owner of Aleschus Realty in Ronkonkoma.
''If they're not making the money, they don't even need the tax deduction from a second home,'' the agent said.
Neil B. Sweig, a senior analyst with a Manhattan brokerage company who has spent summers on the East End for 10 years, cited as an example a couple living in Manhattan and working in the securities industry who had changed their plans to buy a home in the Hamptons.
''The prices have come way down,'' he said. ''They could have gotten a mortgage. But their own incomes were just insecure enough for them not to go through with it.''
Insecurity in his business, Mr. Sweig said, is at its highest level in years, prompting some of his colleagues to choose an East End vacation rather than one farther from home and work.
Partly as a result, said Irene D'Agostino, president of the Montauk Chamber of Commerce and the owner of Martha Greene Real Estate, summer rentals in the Hamptons have improved this year. But home buying, she said, is down.
 
Office Building Boom in 80's
Commercial real estate on the Island has also been affected. Much of the increase in office construction in the 1980's, when nearly 10 million square feet of office space was built on the Island, was fueled by the expansion of bank back-office operations. But that kind of activity has slowed.
''Banks who are not going to come here to increase their back-office space because their business is in a downturn - that will definitely have an impact,'' said Joseph A. Logano, senior vice president at Cushman & Wakefield and branch manager of the realty company's Uniondale office.
Financial-services companies have also vacated large blocks of space in Manhattan. And while Long Island buildings do not always compete for the same tenants that would occupy these Manhattan buildings, vacancy rates on the Island are mirroring the rise in the city.
''Some of the banks giving up space and subleasing space doesn't help, certainly,'' Mr. Logano said.
Cutbacks by Manhattan-based financial-services companies contributed to the slowing of commercial real estate on Long Island, said Joel Bergstein, director of marketing at P. J. R. Construction Corporation in Brooklyn.In one of the largest real-estate transactions of the 1980's, principals of P. J. R., under the name Atria West Associates, sold the Atria West Building on Stewart Avenue in Garden City to Chase Manhattan Bank for $33 million.
''You had Manny Hanny, you had Chase and you had Dime out here,'' he said. ''But banks have had their own headaches lately.''
Even more important than banks to the real-estate market, Mr. Bergstein said, have been cutbacks in another financial-services industry, insurance.
 
A Building Half Occupied
The volume of commercial real-estate deals ''has diminished significantly,'' Mr. Bergstein said. ''There are deals, but there aren't the quantity of deals there were last year at this time. The mood has not shaken everyone but made them take a breath.''
Commercial vacancy is at an all-time high on Long Island, having risen to 16.6 percent for the first quarter of 1990 from 12.5 percent in 1988, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Vacancy in Melville, which has Long Island's greatest concentration of office space, is at 22.4 percent, partly because of the 267,000-square-foot Norstar Bank Building completed last July.
The building, dubbed the ''new Taj Mahal,'' Mr. Conoscenti of Polytechnic University said, is on one of the most visible sites on the Island, at the northwest corner of Route 110 on the Long Island Expressway. It has become perhaps the most prominent symbol of how the commercial real-estate market is faring.
Although the building was completed nearly a year ago, Norstar, which uses half the structure for its regional headquarters, has attracted only one tenant, which occupies 10,000 square feet. The rest of the building is vacant, said Valery Locascio, market research supervisor for Cushman & Wakefield, agent for the building.
''They were interested in building a corporate headquarters that had an image, and that building has an image,'' Mr. Conoscenti said. ''They could have built it anyplace; they probably would have been better off building it someplace else. But they wanted to have that exposure on that corner so people driving down the Long Island Expressway would say, 'There's Norstar Bank.' In order to do that they had to build a building of a certain size. Now they're stuck.''
 
'Sailed Right Through'
In the 1970's, before the building boom that culminated in the construction of Norstar's headquarters, Long Island's economy was less developed and therefore it was affected less by New York City's fiscal crisis of that period, some say.
''From 1945,' said Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, ''Long Island has had the dubious distinction of being referred to as recession-proof. That was actually incorrect but, by and large, statistically that was true. When the city and the state went through their first fiscal crises, Long Island sailed right through as though it wasn't part of the New York scene.''
In 1975, Mr. Kremer said, a 1 percent to 2 percent increase in employment on Long Island ''was generated primarily by businesses that decided to come out from the city.''
This time, however, employment on the Island is not benefitting from the city's troubles, said Professor Drennan of N.Y.U. Although employment on Long Island grew an average 4 percent annually from 1982 to 1987, it grew by only 1.2 percent from September 1987, the month before the stock-market crash, to September 1988, he said.
And the next year employment declined by 0.3 percent.
 
Bailing Out the City
Also declining is the growth in sales-tax revenue. Traditionally increasing by about 10 percent a year, receipts are now growing at perhaps half that rate, nearing the rate of inflation.
''Sales taxes is where New York City is hurting,'' said Mr. Kremer, the former Assemblyman. ''As a result of New York City needing the money, Long Island will wind up getting the same sales-tax increases. The city's fiscal needs spill over onto Long Island, and Long Islanders wind up paying, indirectly or directly, to bail out the city.''
Michael LoGrande, executive director of the Association for a Better Long Island and a former Suffolk County Executive, said Long Island's ability to borrow money could be affected by New York City's declining bonding strength.
''Whenever New York City has financial problems, the entire state has problems because of bonding capacity,'' he said. ''New York City leads the way with respect to bond ratings.''
Earlier this month, a major credit agency, Moody's Investors Services, lowered the state's long-term credit rating one notch, despite the adoption of a budget that the state deemed solid. According to convention, localities' bond ratings may not exceed those of the state.
 
A Shared Fate
Despite the assertions of some Long Islanders that the Island has come a long way toward its goal of economic independence from New York City, some economic forecasts, especially those produced by organizations based in Manhattan, stress the interdependence of two areas.
A December 1988 draft of a forecast package produced by the Regional Plan Association and released in edited form this year tied the Island's fate to the city's in an least two areas, transportation and housing.
The result of commuting difficulties, the study said, ''was to depress projected employment in New York City and on Long Island in favor of the mid-Hudson and New Jersey.'' And the impact of unaffordable housing was one ''favoring New Jersey and the mid-Hudson at the expense of Long Island and New York City.''
