The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 24, 1990

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1558 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Oakwood

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
A stroll down tree-lined Oak Avenue is all a visitor needs to see how Oakwood got its name. But some residents say the name could also apply to the town's solid family life; three and four generations of some families live on the same streets. The Oakwood Girls, a group of 20 women who grew up in the Staten Island community and have known each other for more than 50 years, meet monthly.
''Everyone is related to everyone else,'' said the Rev. Thomas Bergin, principal of Monsignor Farrell High School in Oakwood and a 29-year resident of the town. ''Brothers and sisters buy homes next to each other. Children take over their parents' homes when the parents move to retirement communities or die. Many Oakwood boys marry the girl next door.''
''It's a place where you can knock on a neighbor's door anytime, day or night, and ask for a box of pasta,'' said Frances Sisto, chairwoman of the Oakwood Civic Association, a community group. Mrs. Sisto lives in the house her husband's late grandfather once owned, next door to her in-laws' house, on Amherst Avenue. 
The first section of the two-square-mile community to be settled was the Fox Beach area, established in 1912 by Emiel R. Fox, inventor of the Fox Police Lock, an antiburglary device. At the time, he built 12 bungalows and sold or rented them to wealthy New York City residents for summer homes. By 1930, he had created a swimming beach on Lower New York Bay, built a pier that extended 250 feet into the water, several hundred bungalows, a hotel and a dance pavilion.
Then a fire consumed more than 100 bungalows and the pier, bankrupting him. The beach has since eroded and is unusable.
Many Fox bungalows remain on Kissam Avenue, Fox Lane, Foxbeach Avenue and Tarlton Street, near the beach. During the Depression, some bungalows were winterized and made permanent residences. Others became permanent homes after World War II, when returning servicemen sought inexpensive houses. Today, winterized one- to two-bedroom bungalows on lots of 40 by 80 feet sell for $80,000 to $100,000.
Most of Oakwood's housing stock was built between 1955 and 1975. It consists mainly of small single-family homes and duplexes - two-family houses in which each unit is owned separately - with neat lawns.
Raymond A. Volmaro, a local realtor, said most one-families sell for $180,000 to $250,000 and duplex units sell for $115,000 to $135,000. The most expensive homes are on Tysens Lane and Currie Avenue, where some four-bedroom brick colonials go for up to $350,000.
There are fewer than two dozen town-house condominiums. Most are on Guyon Avenue and sell for about $170,000, according to Mr. Volmaro. The only large apartment complex is the 176-unit Carolina Gardens, on Hylan Boulevard and Tysens Lane, completed in 1950 for returning servicemen. Rents range from $425 for a one-bedroom to $550 for a two-bedroom. Oakwood has fewer than a dozen stores, among them a bagel bakery, a newsdealer, a dry cleaner, a video store and several inexpensive eating places. They are clustered near the Staten Island Rapid Transit station on Guyon Avenue. Most residents shop at supermarkets at the Masters Shopping Mall in neighboring New Dorp or in the Staten Island Mall, four miles away.
Among the popular restaurants in Oakwood are Canlon's Oak Room, which has a continental menu, and La Fontana, with offerings from both the northern and southern Italian traditions.
Oakwood has two Catholic churches, two protestant churches and one synagogue. It is also home to the Frederick Douglass Memorial Park, a cemetery opened exclusively for blacks in 1935, named after a 19th-century black abolitionist.
The public schools servicing Oakwood are P.S. 50, I.S. 24, and New Dorp High School. According to Deputy School Superintendent Christy Cugini of District 31, those schools consistently score among the top 25 percent of New York City schools in standardized reading and mathematics tests.
Most Oakwood students go on to New Dorp High School in neighboring New Dorp. It has one of the lowest dropout rates in New York State - 4.7 percent. Eighty-seven percent of its graduates go on to higher education, according to the principal, Renato L. DeMaria. The school has 34 athletic teams. This year, its girls' soccer and tennis teams were Public School Athletic League champions and its boys' baseball team made the P.S.A.L. semifinals.
Computers are introduced in kindergarten. By sixth grade, the students are programming and word processing. Computers are integrated into all phases of the school's program, including drawing, science, English and even auto shop.
At least a third of the staff, including Mr. DeMaria, are alumni of the high school. ''That means that we are committed to our community and our students, not only professionally, but also emotionally,'' said Mr. DeMaria.
Besides academics, the school stresses racial harmony. Its International Club, which has 180 members and is the school's largest club, organizes a theater and food festival each March to celebrate the ethnic diversity of the student body - 73 percent white (mostly Italian-American), 18 percent black and 9 percent Hispanic and Asian. All leftover food is donated to Project Hospitality, to feed homeless families.
Also in Oakwood is the 1,148-student Monsignor Farrell High School, the largest all-boys Roman Catholic school in New York City. According to Father Bergin, the school consistently wins the largest number of Regents Scholarships in New York City. (This year's graduating class won 70.) The school is also known as a sports powerhouse, having won many championships in football, baseball, track and field, golf, bowling, soccer and tennis.
The Oakwood schools attracted Margaret and Leonard DiBitetto to the town from Flatbush in 1987. ''We investigated the schools, the shopping and looked at the people and felt this was a good place to raise our children,'' said Mrs. DiBitetto. ''And we've been very warmly received by the people here. Everyone is hard-working and dedicated to preserving their area.''
Mrs. Dibitetto and several of her neighbors are running an informal campaign to encourage their children - she has two: Kathryn, 7, and Lisa, 3 - to pick up any litter they see on the streets. ''Just because Staten Island has a large garbage dump, that doesn't mean our area has to look like one,'' she said.
Two issues that residents complain about are flooding and traffic. ''When I was a child, we used to know it was Sunday, because a few cars passed,'' said Marie Cotter, 70 years old. ''Now the roads are full.''
During the recent rains, many bungalows near the beach were flooded. The backyard of one of them, on Tarlton Street, looked like a rice paddy.
''If you think the flooding is bad today,'' said Mr. Volmaro, ''you should have been here in 1950 and 1953. The floods lifted some of the bungalows off their foundations and they were just floating around.''
The borough has since created a sand embankment along the beach front, to keep the floodwaters back, and has built a floodgate across a creek near the shore.
Oakwood residents jealously guard the wetlands, which comprise close to one third of the community. In 1983, when a Brooklyn developer sought to build 450 town houses on wetlands near Kissam Avenue, the Oakwood Civic Association raised $12,000 and successfully fought a court battle against the project. And in June 1988, when Project Hospitality applied for permits to build housing for homeless families on a wetlands tract, community residents swamped a meeting of Community Board 3 to protest. The applications were denied.
Today, the residents are fighting a proposal to build a yeshiva on six acres of wetlands. The matter is before the state's Fresh Water Wetlands Appeal Board.
''We have bad drainage problems already, and any more building on the wetlands will only make matters worse,'' said Mrs. Sisto of the civic association.
Although there are no parks in Oakwood, the town abuts the Great Kills Park, which has a marina, picnic areas and jogging trails. The residents also use the athletic fields in the Miller Field complex in neighboring New Dorp.
''Stability in the face of overwhelming change,'' is the way Ms. Cotter describes Oakwood.

Explorer's Monument: A stone slab at the Amundsen Circle, at the intersection of two major roads - Guyon Avenue and Amboy Road - honors Capt. Roald Amundsen. He was the Norwegian explorer who first negotiated the Northwest Passage (1903-6) and who flew over the North Pole by dirigible in 1928. Although Oakwood is now predominantly Italian, most residents were of Norwegian ancestry when the monument was erected in 1933.

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: SUSAN MERROW;
PROTECTING THE WORLD'S 'SPECIAL PLACES'

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SUSAN MERROW, of Colchester, was recently elected president of the Sierra Club, one of the nation's oldest and largest environmental groups. Founded by John Muir in 1898, the club has grown to 560,000 members from 182,000 in 1981.
Ms. Merrow, 43 years old, joined the club in 1972 and worked her way up through the ranks until she ran for the board in 1984. She is a part-time lobbyist for the Connecticut Clean Water Coalition and a part-time administrator for Common Cause in Connecticut. She was elected to a one-year term as Sierra Club president in May and will be on the road at least 25 weekends in the coming year, she said, dividing her time between the club's national office in San Francisco and various regional meetings.
In an interview at the Connecticut Environmental Center in Hartford, Ms. Merrow discussed some of the challenges facing the club. Here are some excerpts from the conversation. 
Q. If we have a cool summer, with no syringes on the beach or oil spills in Alaska, can you maintain the current interest in the environment?
A. Some of it will wane, but we have anticipated it. Even after the first Earth Day, not all those people stuck around, but some of them did. There are plenty of issues to go around, and a lot of people are going to stick with it.
Q. The Sierra Club has had a reputation as a club for the upper class. Is that going to continue to be the case?
A. In the early part of its history, the Sierra Club membership recruitment was largely done person to person, so highly literate hikers recruited highly literate hikers. But at the same time James Watt came along, the Sierra Club and a lot of other not-for-profit organizations got a court ruling that allowed them to mail at a lower bulk rate. So more of our members today are recruited by mail. We don't have a real clear sense of where that's taking us demographically.
I suspect most Sierra Club people are upper class, fairly well educated. But in the long run, we're waking up to the fact that if we want to be relevant to the 21st century, this cannot continue to be a lily-white organization. So there are discussions going on now about minorities and how to meet the needs of the ethnic communities, to try to accommodate their perspectives and their ideas.
Q. Was there any moment of environmental epiphany for you?
A. I spent every summer when I was growing up with my grandmother on the coast of Maine, a little place on the St. George Peninsula. I suppose I had a feeling then, and still have a feeling, there are some special places in the world, some special, natural places, that are almost sacred, they shouldn't be changed, that humans cannot improve on, they can only probably harm.
So I suppose I was sort of ripe for environmental issues. And then around the first Earth Day in 1970 I became aware of the message that these special places are finite, that species are becoming extinct. I woke up to the fact that we had to do something, although when I first joined I had no notion that I would get personally involved. I thought I would make my yearly donation, and then I got a postcard inviting me to a meeting, and the next meeting I made the cookies, and I kept getting drawn further in. I've always said there's nothing you can't do in the Sierra Club if you never say no.
Q. What do you hope to accomplish in your one-year term?
A. One thing that I've been involved with in the last year that is just coming to fruition is that the Sierra Club has been devoting more and more of its resources into state-level lobbying. Most chapters have some presence at their state capitol, but it's been sort of catch as catch can. But the Sierra Club is responding to the idea that if you're going to be a real player, you have to be an insider at the state capitol.
The action on environmental issues is shifting to the state, and if you can put together environmental victories in a few key legislatures you can roll environmental legislation across the country. As an example, California passed some tough laws on tailpipe emissions, and now the Council of Northeast Governors has passed the same restrictions. We've put about $370,000 into a fund for state-level lobbying.
Q. When George Bush campaigned, he said he would be the environmental President. Has that happened?
A. The jury is still seriously out on that. I think he discovered the promises were a lot easier to make than to keep. The first disappointment was the Clean Air Act. It didn't keep his promises, particularly in the area of automobiles. Recently he spoke against helping other countries curb their use of chlorofluorocarbons, which damage the earth's ozone layer, and he's been pretty wishy-washy on global warming. There was a wonderful cartoon around about Earth Day that showed a couple of protesters holding up signs that said ''Save the Earth,'' and someone that looked like George Bush holding up a sign that said, ''Seriously Consider Further Study.'' We wish he would move more decisively.
Q. With so many states facing an economic slowdown, are environmental initiatives going to suffer?
A. There are actually a number of things that can be done that have no fiscal impact. Pollution prevention is sort of the wave of the future. After spending years figuring out what to do with toxic and hazardous materials that come out of the end of the pipeline we realize we have to have people go around to the front door of the factory and figure out how to reduce what's going in.
Q. What was the biggest environmental achievement of the 1990 Connecticut legislature?
A. The bill that passed that, for the first time, gives us dedicated funds for the environment. The fees raised in that bill will allow the State Department of Environmental Protection to keep 83 positions that would have been cut, but more important it set up a task force that will look at long-term, stable sources of funding for environmental protection.
The business community, which will pay many of those fees, was actually cautiously cooperative with that bill. In the long run, what the positions are going to do is help get rid of some of the permit backlogs. If you are a business applying for a permit and it takes two years to get it, that's just poor economics.
Q. What was your biggest disappointment of the session?
A. We were disappointed that the chlorofluorocarbon bill failed. It was sort of an innocent bystander that became a victim of the Republican budget amendments. They tried to amend their budget onto the bill, as sort of a ploy to get it raised and onto the floor. And it never came back. It was sacrificed to the budget process.
But other than that it was a fascinating session. We finally got a bill prohibiting sewage dumping from boats. Three years ago that bill started out giving the commissioner authority to prohibit it in sensitive zones, but the regulated community, which is the marinas, wanted those no-discharge zones named.
So we named eight very specific, highly vulnerable areas where marinas are close to shellfish beds. We fought about that last year, and everyone seemed on board, but at the last minute the bill died.
This year the bill came along, came through the Judiciary Committee, and finally got to the floor, and legislators who in the past were worried about their marina operators didn't want to go home this year without a no-discharge area in their town. It was amended to include, besides the eight areas, no-discharge areas in Stratford, in New London, along the Connecticut River and so on.
Q. What can you do to overcome the frustration of people who see it as impossible to individually address overwhelming international environmental problems, like global warming?
A. The message around Earth Day 20 was, ''you can make a difference.'' You can separate the trash, you can car pool, and that's important even if only to cheer yourself up.
But the most important thing we have to do, quick, is empower these people in the political process. When I got involved in 1972, it took me until 1976 to discover grass-roots lobbying. We worked on the Bottle Bill in 1976 and 1977, which taught us how to make public policy.
It took us until 1980 to discover electoral politics. That was the year we worked on the campaign of Mary Mushinsky from Wallingford, who is now the House chairwoman of the Environment Committee. She had a four-way primary, and we learned about phone banking, about door to door, about getting out the vote.
We can't wait 10 years for the next crop of activists to learn those skills. The 20th anniversary of Earth Day brought us a lot of support. A lot of the born-again environmentalists will drop away, but a lot of the people like Mary Mushinsky and Senator John Atkin from Norwalk and I were the product of the first Earth Day, and a lot of the leaders of tomorrow are in this new crop, and they're here to stay.
Q. You've got a reputation as being soft spoken. Can you get things done for the environment without being more aggressive?
A. My job is not to push my compatriots around. My job is not to make the decisions. It's to see good decisions get made. People have to feel they own the agenda, and you don't get that by pushing them around.
But when we need to, we push around our opponents. I don't get mad easily. Sometimes it takes me until the next day to get mad about something. But there's a place for deliberate thinkers. There are enough people around who get mad quick, but if you take the time to think sometimes you can come up with a solution more people can live with.''

GRAPHIC: PHoto; Susan Merrow, the new president of the Sierra Club (Steve Miller for the New York Times)

HEADLINE: Adoption Of Cats Increasing

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
CATS are becoming the pet of choice on Long Island. Because of economics, convenience and housing regulations, officials of the Island's pet adoption centers say, the percentage of cat adoptions is rising.
At the North Shore Animal League, a nonprofit adoption center in Port Washington, cat adoptions increased from 39 percent of total pet adoptions in 1985 to 44 percent in 1989. The numbers are rising steadily, and cat adoption is definitely a trend, said Marge Stein, manager of adoption services. The reason is mainly one of economics, she said. ''In the majority of families on the Island today, both parents are working, and taking care of a kitten or cat is a lot easier than a dog or puppy,'' Ms. Stein said. ''There's no walking or training, and many dog lovers have become cat converts.'' 
The image of cats has changed in recent years, said Deborah Glasco, shelter manager of Bide-a-Wee in Wantagh, a nonprofit animal shelter and adoption center. (Other Bide-A-Wee shelters are in Westhampton and Manhattan).
Years ago, people were afraid of cats and associated them with strays, she said, adding: ''But cats are excellent pets. They are lovable, affectionate and easier pets than dogs when no one is home all day.''
 
More Adaptable
Adoptions of cats and kittens is rising at Bide-a-Wee, Ms. Glasco said. In March 1989, 59 dogs and puppies were adopted and 35 cats and kittens. This past March, 61 canines were adopted and 41 felines, showing a more significant rise in cats and kittens.
Unlike dogs, cats do not require licenses in New York State, so comparative numbers on pet ownership are not available. But according to Andrew Hajdu, a veterinarian at the East Norwich Veterinarian Clinic, cats have increased steadily over the past 10 years, going from one-third to one-half of the clinic's practice.
''My idea why cats have become more popular is that they are easier, neater and cleaner,'' Dr. Hajdu said. ''They require less training and time, eat less and are less expensive to maintain. Cats have gotten a raw deal as being aloof, but most are affectionate and provide the human bond that people want in a pet.''
 
Taking More Than One
Aside from their ease, cats have become more popular because of housing restrictions for pets, Ms. Stein said. Many landlords say no to dogs, but are more lenient toward cats because they are clean and quiet animals, she said.
The rise in cat adoptions can also be attributed to multi-cat households, Ms. Stein said, adding that many cat owners take more than one cat to keep each other company.
The kitten season is just starting, and runs from June through November, Ms. Stein said. These are the months when more kittens are born than any other time of the year.
An excess of unadopted kittens is a serious problem on Long Island, said Ann Sergio, a pet consultant and retired American Kennel Club dog judge. Too many people are not educated about the importance of neutering or spaying their cats, she said, adding that a pet should not be let outside until it is neutered or spayed, at about six months.
 
Free Spaying
Both the North Shore Animal League and Bide-a-Wee provide free neutering and spaying for all adopted animals. But overpopulation persists, said Ms. Stein, and there are still many unwanted animals on Long Island.
Some shelters destroy unwanted animals or send them to adoption centers like North Shore Animal League or Bide-a-Wee, whose policy is to keep unadopted animals until homes are found for them.
North Shore has space for about 400 animals, and there is always a waiting list for unadopted or unwanted pets, Ms. Stein said.
One of the worst problems, Mrs. Sergio said, is antisocial behavior in dogs who are dropped off at shelters. They have been left alone too much, have not become socialized and many have become biters, she said.
 
Rabies on the Rise
''Abandonment of adult cats because of antisocial behavior,'' Mrs. Sergio said, ''is not as big a problem as with adult dogs. This is because an antisocial cat will be content to sit alone on a windowsill, while an antisocial dog might bite a child.
''We have become a society in which people don't have time for dogs. Young couples are working and often like to go away for weekends. Older couples with grown kids are going back to work, and people who are gone all day should not have dogs.
''Cats don't need as much socializing as dogs, and fit into situations that dogs don't.''
But cats are not without problems, Dr. Hajdu said. Cat rabies has become a growing problem along the East Coast, he said, adding that many people do not vaccinate their cats and, because they are outside so much, are prone to pick up rabies.
Increasing cases of cat rabies have been reported in New Jersey, Dr. Hajdu said. Although the problem has not yet reached Long Island, it is expected to in the future.
Cats also carry toxoplasmosis, a protozoa disease of the intestines, which can be transmitted to humans through stools, Dr. Hajdu said.
Although treatable and curable, toxoplasmosis is most dangerous for pregnant women, who should not clean a cat's litter box, he said. This is because the eggs can be released into the air from the litter box and inhaled by a human.
Dogs can also get toxoplasmosis, but do not spread the disease.

HEADLINE: THE BROWN-RICING OF AMERICA

BYLINE: By LAURA SHAPIRO; Laura Shapiro, the author of ''Perfection Salad: Women and Cooking at the Turn of the Century,'' writes about food, books and dance for Newsweek.

 BODY:

APPETITE FOR CHANGE %How the Counterculture Took On the Food Industry, 1966-1988.
By Warren J. Belasco.
311 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95.
Granola, as Warren J. Belasco points out in ''Appetite for Change,'' used to be good for you. It was created to be a vegetarian health food in the 19th century, hippies spooned it up in the 1960's and the food industry got hold of it in the 70's. But that first wave of cereals with names evoking sunrise over the cow pasture didn't do very well in the supermarket. Kids didn't like the stuff, and grown-ups were still eating doughnuts for breakfast. By the 80's, a new crop of fitness cereals for adults would be flourishing, but in the meantime the industry took another look at granola - and came up with granola bars. Lavished with chocolate and peanut butter, granola was a hit. Americans who couldn't face a healthful breakfast welcomed a healthful snack, or at least a snack with a healthful image, especially if all that virtue tasted a lot like a candy bar. In 1986 granola bars brought in over $450 million. 
Mr. Belasco, the author of ''Americans on the Road: From Autocamp to Motel, 1910-1945,'' traces the rise and fall of what he calls the ''countercuisine'' from its beginnings in the 60's to the culinary confusions of today. The countercuisine - chiefly fruits and vegetables, unprocessed foods, little or no meat, and grains in huge quantities - didn't really get rolling until the late 60's and early 70's, when political activism began splintering into ecology, feminism, small farming, arts and crafts and other modes of conscientious self-expression. Food came to the forefront relatively late; as Mr. Belasco remarks, even in 1968 the underground press was printing a recipe for ''bologna knish enchiladas'' - white bread and bologna wrapped around eggs and onions, with canned cheddar cheese soup over all. But bologna didn't last long. In 1969 Frances Moore Lappe began her research into the political and economic implications of eating meat, and her ''Diet for a Small Planet'' (1971) became an enormously influential guide to new ways of thinking about food. Soon a torrent of ethical cookbooks appeared, with recipes printed in flowing script and much warmhearted advice about sound living and complementary proteins. (''These books were fun!'' Mr. Belasco writes, comparing them with the drab vegetarian guides of the past; has he ever tried to follow a recipe written in script?) As yogurt and brown rice began making minor forays into mainstream eating habits, they were accompanied by a critique of the food industry that made some of its giants nervous. ''Preservative'' became a bad word, ''pesticide'' followed; and the industry geared up for a counterattack. In concert with the nutritionists and academic researchers it supported financially, the industry put forth an argument still heard today: the chemicals used on produce and in packaged foods are not only safe, they're safer than the chemicals occurring naturally in foods. Moreover, additives and preservatives protect us against everything from botulism to boredom. ''Almost as dangerous as Mother Nature was the human mother,'' Mr. Belasco adds. ''Home-canned beans were potentially more deadly than anything concocted by Del Monte; moldy home-baked brown bread could not compare in safety with store-bought, plastic-wrapped, artificially preserved white.''
But the industry didn't just argue, it went into action. If people were entranced by so-called natural food, they would get natural food, and they'd get it from the same food companies that brought them Twinkies and Oreos. Rather than investigate ways to reduce chemical use in their products, companies concentrated on new slogans, new advertisements and new packages. When consumers proved delighted at the chance to buy ''lite,'' ''all-natural'' versions of the same food they had been eating for years, even when little had changed but the labels, the battle was over.
Mr. Belasco tells a far more comprehensive and complex story than this recap suggests; indeed, one of the problems with this useful book is that it gropes in many more directions than any single writer or reader could possibly follow. At the same time, the book deals only sketchily with the subject at the heart of Mr. Belasco's argument: food and cooking. We never learn the details of what was in all those earthenware serving dishes; rather, he writes at length about the ''oppositional language'' and ''symbolic aspects'' of hippie food. His purpose may not be gastronomy per se, but to serve up the symbols without the reality makes a thin soup. Similarly, Mr. Belasco leaves out the people who cooked. With the exception of a few cursory portraits, this history is carried by disembodied ideas and influences, not by men and women. It seems a peculiar and misleading way to write about the counterculture, particularly since Mr. Belasco's sympathies are so clearly with the people he affectionately calls ''the freaks.'' Finally, Mr. Belasco's graceless writing style, dense and jaunty at the same time, makes ''Appetite for Change'' much harder to read than it should be. His story is important and his politics are refreshing, but every sentence needs a comb.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1288 words

HEADLINE: SOUTHWEST TO GET ECONOMIC BENEFITS IN SAVINGS BAILOUT

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The Federal cleanup of the savings and loan disaster will result in a significant transfer of wealth from the Northeast and Middle West to Texas and other states in the Southwest, many economists and politicians have concluded.
As a consequence, they say, the economy in Texas and its neighboring states, where most of the cost of the savings and loan failures was incurred, will be stronger in the years ahead and the economy in most other states will be weaker.
This shift of resources reignites an old political controversy.
For years, Eastern and Northern lawmakers complained that their regions did not get their fair share of Federal money because of the prevalence of military installations in the South and West. The rapid growth of Government social programs in the 1970's went a long way toward correcting the balance, because the Northern industrial states are the main beneficiaries of Federal grants for the poor. 
 
Balance of Payments
''At just the time when we had got our balance of payments situation into a reasonable relationship, which is to say we do about as well as we could expect on Federal outlays, along comes this,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat.
How much money will be shifted is difficult to estimate, but some experts have tried. For example, Prof. Edward W. Hill of Cleveland State University, who has been studying the situation for the last two years, has calculated that wealth will be transferred from 37 states and the District of Columbia to the 13 states where the savings and loan failures are concentrated.
The cost of the bailout to Connecticut residents, he figures, will be up to $1,237 a person and to New Yorkers up to $972. That is money that would have been available for investment in those states, creating more jobs and better business conditions. $4,774 per Texan The additional money flowing to Texas will amount to as much as $4,775 a resident, Professor Hill estimates.
Many economists do not accept Professor Hill's numbers or his methodology, but most subscribe to the thesis that the bailout will lead to a regional redistribution of wealth to one degree or another. Donald F. Kettl, a political scientist at Vanderbilt University, suggested that the shift would be as large as it was in the 1970's, when higher oil prices caused by the Arab boycott created large profits in Texas at the expense of Northern consumers.
Some experts, like Bernard L. Weinstein, director of the Center for Economic Development and Research at the University of North Texas, question even the premise.
''You're going to have to wait 20 years to see how the dust settles,'' Mr. Weinstein said. ''You're going to have to look at who ends up owning the assets. The ownership is going to shift outside of Texas and the Southwest because we don't have any money here to buy them.''
Lawmakers from the states who feel especially disadvantaged by the bailout program acknowledge that the Government has no alternative but to use general tax revenues collected in all the states to cover the depositors at the institutions that went under. But they suggest that to offset the situation, Congress should give special attention to their states when money is allocated for other programs.
 
Correcting the Balance
''It's hard within the system to right the balance,'' said Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, the second-ranking Republican on the House Banking Committee. ''But because of this enormous transfer of wealth, Congress ought to go out of its way in future programming to give breaks to the regions that are footing the bill for the Southwest.''
Representative Howard Wolpe, a Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Northeast-Midwest Coalition, an organization of lawmakers from 18 states, said he and his colleagues were ''especially galled'' because they feel Texas and its neighboring states brought the savings and loan mess on themselves.
Most failures, their argument goes, occurred in states like Texas where the savings and loans were state-chartered and state-regulated, and the regulation was even more lax than it was in states where the institutions were subject to Federal supervision.
''This is not a natural disaster like a hurricane or an earthquake,'' Mr. Wolpe said in an interview. ''This is a man-made disaster.''
 
Healthier Institutions
Through the end of last year, no savings institutions in New England had failed, and relatively few had gone under in the other Northern and Eastern states.
On the other hand, the cost of rescuing depositors in Texas is expected to be five or six times greater than that in any other state. And when the cost in Arkansas, Louisiana, New Mexico and Arizona is added to the Texas total, it will account for the bulk of the Government's outlays.
The Government's cost will be high in California and Florida also, but those states are so populous that the outlays will be only a tiny fraction of the Federal taxes collected there.
In an interview this week, Representative Michael A. Andrews, a Texas Democrat who heads a caucus of lawmakers from Sunbelt states, acknowledged that Texas would get a big share of the bailout money at the expense of other states.
But he took issue with Mr. Wolpe and others who maintain that Texans should bear a bigger burden of the cost or that special benefits should accrue to Northern states to compensate them for their outlays for the savings and loan rescue.
 
'A National Problem'
''That's not the way this Government works,'' Mr. Andrews said. ''This is a national problem, and we've never played by those rules before.''
Because the deposits in the savings associations that collapsed were insured by the Federal Government, the Government, using general revenue, is obligated to make good on every dime. In some instances, the depositors are paid off directly. But normally, to save money, the Government takes over the repossessed property and other assets of the failed institutions, sells them for as much as possible and pays a fee to a healthy bank in the area to assume the deposits.
That has two effects in regional economic terms. It means that deposits stay in the locale of the institutions that failed and are more likely to be reinvested there. And it means that the empty office buildings, new houses and other structures built over the last decade with money supplied by the savings and loans that have failed will be on the market at a relatively low price for businesses that want to relocate there.
 
Infusions of Cash
Professor Hill, the Cleveland State economist, wrote in the May-June issue of Challenge magazine: ''Those states and regions with large numbers of problem thrifts will be receiving infusions of cash to support their assets and secure their liabilities. This injection of money will help hold off regional recessions, while other states and regions will be footing the bill.''
In one respect, that situation is offset by the fact that some deposits in the failed savings and loans were lured from out of state by the higher rates. But academic studies suggest that the average figure is probably less than 25 percent. In regional terms, the effect of the out-of-state deposits may be canceled out by the fact that some Northern savings associations failed because of unwise investments they made in the Southwest.
The residents of the Northeast are actually paying twice for the mistakes in the Southwest, in the view of Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts. First, Mr. Kerry says, the Northeasterners' tax money will finance the bailout. And second, he maintains, credit is tighter now in his region because regulators want to avoid the mistakes made in Texas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CITY: NASHVILLE, TN, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: German Unity Revives Hopes on War Claims

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
German reunification has raised the hopes of thousands of people who have claims against East Germany arising from crimes of the Nazi era and the confiscation of property during the four decades of Communist rule.
Until its recent democratic changes, East Germany had refused to recognize such claims. But now as East Germany prepares to merge with West Germany, Bonn officials say they will honor East German obligations.
''The fact that we unite doesn't make these claims obsolete,'' said Hans-Henning Horstmann, spokesman at the West German Embassy. ''On the contrary, as we unite we will make sure these claims are honored.'' But he said some ''difficult procedures ahead'' before settlements are reached. 
At a meeting in East Berlin tomorrow, the East German authorities will sit down for the first time with representatives of Jews around the world to begin negotiations on compensation.
West Germany sought to resolve claims from the Jews under an agreement signed in Luxembourg in 1952. Since then an estimated $40 billion has flowed to Israel, Jewish institutions and individual Jewish survivors. Elan Steinberg, executive director of the World Jewish Congress, a representative body of Jews in 70 countries, said reparations involve moral redress and material amends. Most payments by Bonn have gone to indemnify survivors and their families. Hundreds of thousands of individuals have received monthly stipends.
Bonn also made a direct payment of $715 million to Israel in 1952 for resettlement of refugees from Europe and a payment of $107 million to Jewish institutions for refugees outside Israel.
In addition to the prewar victims of the Third Reich are property owners whose factories, stores, houses, apartments and other real estate were seized by the Communist Government. East Germany also owes about $20 billion to foreign creditors, chiefly European and Japanese banks.
''I have no doubt that this debt will become the debt of West Germany,'' said Horst Schulmann, a former senior Bonn economist who heads the Institute of International Finance, representing banks in 60 countries.
Some indication of the size of the indemnification issue arises from the claims that a million West Germans have asserted to property in East Germany. In many cases, East Germans have been living on the sites for decades. There are thousands of claims as well from citizens of other countries.
In the United States, the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission, a 36-year-old agency, formally recognizes 1,899 claims of property expropriated in East Germany from American citizens and corporations like Woolworth, I.T.T., General Motors and Singer.
Initially valued at $78 million, based on low prewar assessments, the claims today, as a result of 6 percent annual compound interest, have mushroomed to $370 million. A State Department official said the United States was pursuing the claims. ''We're discussing the situation with both German states,'' the official said. Unification Hurdle? Washington is not pressing the matter with any urgency. ''Nobody wants the claims issue to complicate the unification process,'' the State Department official pointed out.
Some Eastern European governments settled property claims for much less when they came to terms with the United States earlier in the postwar period. Poland paid only $40 million on $107.7 million claimed. Hungary paid $21.1 million of $61.9 million.
East Germany is the only Eastern European nation that has refused to pay compensation. Martina Greenwood of Burke, Va., a claimant, owned an apartment building assessed at $150,000 near the center of Leipzig, in East Germany. She inherited the building from her grandmother.
''We feel the Germans should honor 100 cents on the dollar,'' said Alfred R. Greenwood, Martina's husband. ''As a result of reunification, Germany's economic well-being and economic power will grow dramatically.'' The Greenwoods now have a choice of repossessing the property or waiting months, perhaps years, for a settlement.

HEADLINE: Small Towns Losing Their Leaders

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DERBY, Vt.

 BODY:
In March, after 18 years as a selectman in this small town on the Canadian border, Carl Hackett resigned his office.
Mr. Hackett, who is 59 years old, said he left the part-time administrative post midway through his sixth term because the pressures of small town government had become unbearable.
''When I joined the board, a little bit of arithmetic, some good common sense and a sense of honesty made you a good candidate for selectman,'' said Mr. Hackett, who runs a trailer park. ''Now, it's preferable you're a lawyer.'' Mr. Hackett is not alone. Across the country, officials in small towns, cities and villages say the tradition of private citizens overseeing small municipalities in their spare time is dying. 
 
Governing in Complex Times
With the growing complexity of issues, like new environmental protection standards and burgeoning budget responsibilities, fewer citizens are seeking the part-time, largely volunteer positions that have run small towns. Officials say that the jobs now require professional skills they do not possess and that town administration steals too many hours from their lives.
The increasing complexity, also a concern of professional organizations and political scientists, could lead to fundamental changes in the ways towns govern themselves, experts say.
''When you dry up that supply to the point where there are few willing candidates, sometimes no candidates at all, you strike at the very heart of self-government,'' said Alvin Sokolow, a professor of political science at the University of California at Davis.
Officials of municipalities, in telephone interviews from around the country, said several factors are responsible for the changes in government. They cited an avalanche of new Federal and state regulations, budgets that have been pushed above $1 million by rising costs and responsibilities and economic hardships that require more sophisticated stewardship.
Several towns have buckled under the pressure and transferred their responsibilities to state governments. Most have taken less severe measures: They hire professional managers, collaborate with neighboring towns on large projects, and use a little arm-twisting to remind residents that theyhave a civic duty to serve.
 
Strains Bring Change
Experts who study rural government say there is a paucity of data on the subject, largely because of the high cost of polling thousands of town officials across the country. Nevertheless, they point to a number of examples of what they say is a clear trend.
The towns feeling the most strain are those with populations of less than 10,000, and those represent 86 percent of the governments in the United States.
For every small town growing in population, there is a small town shrinking said Jeffrey Schiff, executive director of the National Association of Towns and Townships, an organization of small governments. Both situations present complications, either in demands for new, costly services or in shrinking tax bases and revenue.
Derby, a rural Vermont town with about 4,500 residents, was a different place in 1972, when Carl Hackett was appointed to a vacancy on its three-member board of selectmen. At that time, the town was dominated by 100 dairy farms.
Now, 75 of those farms are gone and much of the land has been sold to developers, who built modern homes for new residents on large lots with scenic views of the Green Mountains. There are also a number of new businesses here, including a McDonald's restaurant and a General Motors automobile dealership.
 
New Citizens, New Demands
And, Mr. Hackett said, new residents make new demands, like asking the town to plow snow off the streets before they leave for their 9-to-5 jobs. Mr. Hackett said he had neither the energy nor the time to tackle those new requests because of a litany of directives from the Federal and state governments on everything from solid waste disposal to personnel management.
''There is just no way a person having a reasonable full-time job could possibly read the amount of material that flows into the town office weekly,'' he said.
In some small towns, a diminishing population and an increased workload have made it difficult to fill elected positions.
In Matherville, Ill., population 814, no one ran for mayor, and only two residents sought six seats on the village board of trustees in the most recent municipal election.
The residential community, located in the northwestern part of the state, used to have strong candidates to fill government posts. But that was before the local economy slumped, causing a number of area factories to close and a number of people to move away, said Kevin J. Basala, who became the town's mayor last April as a result of write-in votes.
 
'I'm Busy'
''I'm like everyone else - I'm busy,'' said Mr. Basala, a full-time ironworker. ''But I'd really have felt bad if somewhere down the line this town fell apart, and I had the chance to do something about it, and I didn't do it.''
In response to the problem of finding willing volunteers, but more often to cope with the complexity of government, a rising number of small towns are hiring professional managers, said Mark Lapping, dean of the Faculty of Planning at Rutgers University.
Large cities and towns began writing positions for professional managers into their charters in the 1920's to clean up the corruption and inefficiency that were rampant in municipal government, Mr. Lapping said. But in recent years, smaller towns in strong financial shape have been hiring managers for a different purpose: to do most of the chores of government, including labor negotiations, budget planning and applying for grants.
Last November, residents in Kalispell, a small Montana city near Glacier National Park, voted to replace their mayor-city council form of government with one made up of a city council and headed by a professional manager.
Roger Hopkins, who was elected interim Mayor last fall, said the city Government had been unable to handle a population that had swelled to 12,000, a city budget that had risen to $8 million and a town staff that had grown to 150.
''I think we're ready for an outside perspective on our problems,'' Mr. Hopkins said.
 
Legacy of Reagan Years
The problems of small towns across the country multiplied during the Reagan Administration, when the Federal Government shifted responsibility for many of its programs to local governments, said Mr. Schiff of the National Association of Towns and Townships. During the same period, the Federal and state governments asked local governments to meet new standards in environmental protection, waste management, road maintenance, civil rights and other areas.
But as the Federal Government increased the workload of local governments, it took away much of the money needed to carry out its directives, Mr. Lapping said.
In 1986, Congress did not re-enact the General Revenue Sharing Act, under which the governments had split Federal tax money annually since 1972. In 1986, that amount was $4.5 billion. And for 80 percent of the nation's governments, it was the sole source of Federal money, Mr. Schiff said.
There are signs that some solutions are being found.
Last fall, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, introduced a bill that calls on Federal agencies to protect small governments from excessive regulation.
And over the past few years, many towns have been joining with neighboring communities to share the costs of government.
 
One Region's Response
North Carolina's governments, for example, have expanded 18 regional planning agencies that they created in the 1960s to promote economic development.
Some towns have decided that the most cost-efficient option is to quit rather than fight.
Towns in Maine, Kansas and Missouri, for example, have ceased in recent years to govern themselves.
It is not known how many more such cases might exist nationwide. But Frederick Todd, who takes up governmental functions of towns in Maine that surrender their autonomy, said he does not anticipate an epidemic of municipalities giving up their authority, and he added that the state could support only so many. ''At some point the state will have to increase the rate at which it taxes unorganized towns,'' said Mr. Todd, planning supervisor for the Maine Land Use Regulation Commission.
In light of recent world events, stories of towns disbanding are disturbing to one expert - Mr. Lapping, the Rutgers University planning professor.
''Here we are working to promote democracy all over the world,'' Mr. Lapping said, ''and in our own country, we're seeing communities giving up local autonomy and self-government.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Across the country, officials in small towns, cities and villages say the tradition of private citizens overseeing small municipalities in their spare time is dying. Carl Hackett recently resigned as a selectman in Derby, Vt., because the pressures of small town government had become unbearable. (Paul O. Boisvert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Help the Koreas In From the Cold

 BODY:
Forty years after the cold war turned hot, North and South Korea are about to engage again -at the conference table. New warmth between the U.S. and the Soviet Union is thawing relations between the Koreas. That's a hopeful development. It could, among other benefits, allow the U.S. to bring more troops home. 
A get-together Thursday may lead to a meeting of prime ministers. Informal talks between the Koreas have proceeded fitfully between military officers, parliamentarians, even senior government aides, but never between prime ministers.
Enduring mistrust has led both sides to exploit past talks for propaganda purposes. But if Washington and Moscow, along with Tokyo and Beijing, can keep coaxing the two Koreas into military disengagement and political re-engagement, this time there could be a widely welcomed result.
The Korean War exacted a terrible price on both sides of the 38th parallel. Three million Koreans died, most of them civilians. The U.S. and its allies rallied to the South's defense under the United Nations flag. Stalin sent Soviet MIG's and pilots to help the North and when Gen. Douglas MacArthur marched north to the Yalu River, China joined the war.
Later sacked for insubordination, MacArthur electrified Americans with a famous speech to Congress concluding, ''Old soldiers never die; they just fade away.'' MacArthur faded away, sooner than he wished. By the time this ''police action'' ended, 54,000 American, 5,000 allied and possibly 900,000 Chinese troops had died.
After the war, South and North went their separate ways. The South has speedily made itself one of the world's more prosperous countries; the North stolidly makes even Communism work.
Now others try to reconcile them. The 1988 Seoul Olympics led to a budding relationship between the Soviet Union and South Korea. Then Beijing provided a discreet point of contact between the U.S. and North Korea. When President Gorbachev met President Roh in San Francisco earlier this month, Washington worked to reach out to Pyongyang. And Japan, with a million Korean residents, remains an influential economic and political go-between.
Seoul pundits refer to the outside involvement as the ''four-plus-two'' talks, a twist on the ''two-plus-four'' talks in Germany. If the four succeed in drawing Pyongyang out of self-imposed isolation, the two Koreas could establish diplomatic relations and seek dual seating at the U.N. That would open the way for family visits, increased trade, investment and cultural exchanges and, eventually, one Korea. Two Koreas are anathema to the North but as the South says, two Yemens are already one, and two Germanys soon will be.
North Korea may accept international nuclear safeguards and is proposing new arms cuts. These steps could ease the military confrontation on the peninsula and allow the U.S. to reduce its force of 45,000 troops in the South. And there would be no reason to keep U.S. nuclear weapons there.
Bringing Koreans back together is so obviously in Korean and American interest that Washington would be wise to do what it can to encourage these talks. And, beyond maintaining diplomatic channels to the North, the United States can show its willingness to make further troop withdrawals and curtail military exercises, on land and at sea. Gradual disarming can strengthen diplomacy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Fall of Great Fortunes Is an American Story

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Cornelius Vanderbilt died in 1877 at the age of 82, the world's richest man, leaving an estate that topped the size of the United States Treasury. Within 30 years of the Commodore's death, no member of his family was among the richest people in the United States. 
Forty-eight years after his death, one of his descendants died penniless. Within 70 years of his death, the last of the 10 great Vanderbilt mansions that had once lined Fifth Avenue was broken to rubble. When 120 of the Commodore's descendants gathered at Vanderbilt University in 1973 for the first family reunion, there was not a millionaire among them.
The fast rise, and often equally fast fall, of our great fortunes seems to be a peculiarly American phenomenon, a special part of our history, the latest chapter of which is unfolding with the saga of Donald J. Trump, whose fortune began with the old Commodore Hotel and whose ''glittering towers, plazas, palaces and hotels'' occupy the old Vanderbilt neighborhood (''Up, and Down, With Donald Trump'' editorial, June 9).
Last year, a review of my book, ''Fortune's Children: The Fall of the House of Vanderbilt,'' a four-generation saga of the decline of what was once the nation's most conspicuous family of millionaires, noted with percipience that this book ''could give Donald Trump nightmares.'' The Commodore even painted his name on all his acquisitions as avidly as Mr. Trump.
 
ARTHUR T. VANDERBILT 2D
Summit, N.J., June 11, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Worth A Mention?

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
When the Great Scorer comes to write your name, as everybody knows, it doesn't matter whether you won or lost, ''it's how you played the game.'' Or so Americans like to delude themselves.
In politics, however, when the Great Mentioner comes to say your name, it matters indeed whether you won or lost. And that's the biggest question hanging over a certain Northeastern liberal governor, a Democrat whose name ends in a vowel. 
No, not Mario Cuomo of New York. It's so nearly certain that Mr. Cuomo will win overwhelming re-election this year that many in his party are more interested, at least for now, in the fate of Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey. Even the Great Mentioner may be reading the news from Trenton.
The G.M., whose work was first detected by my esteemed colleague Russell Baker, is the mysterious arbiter of who gets ''mentioned'' as a possibility for the next open Presidential nomination, sure to be Democratic in 1992.
Jim Florio? Six months ago the only thing most political buffs - save fellow members of the House of Representatives - knew about him was that in 1981 he had lost the race for governor to Tom Kean, a Republican, returned to the House, then eight years later defeated James Courter, another Republican, for governor.
Better still, or maybe worse, he won in 1989 not least because he struck first and hardest in a reciprocal campaign of nasty advertising. Mr. Florio, a Roman Catholic, is pro-choice, too, but for the death penalty - a combination some Democrats might like to see in their next Presidential candidate.
Now Mr. Florio has pushed through the New Jersey Legislature a program that might be called liberalism brought up to date and adjusted for the 90's:
* Cutting state aid to wealthy school districts to equalize education spending in poor and middle-class districts.
* Tougher penalties for companies despoiling New Jersey's environment.
* The ban on assault weapons that President Bush, with 70 percent popularity, doesn't have the nerve to seek.
* Automobile insurance revamped for consumers.
* Property tax relief for the middle class.
On the other hand, New Jersey's new Governor did some brutal budget-cutting, to cope with an estimated budget shortfall of nearly $1 billion. He also backed significant tax increases, particularly in the higher brackets; but the sales tax went up, too, from 6 to 7 percent, and will be newly levied on some popular items like liquor and cigarettes.
With the passage last week of the tax increases and the hotly contested education reform package, Mr. Florio and the Legislature completed this program in just six months from his inauguration in January. That's what Congressional Democrats moan they can't do - pass a social program in the teeth of a huge deficit. The bold Florio tax increases also put to shame those Democratic and White House negotiators bowing like Alphonse and Gaston in front of the Federal budget mess.
The New Jersey school reforms -enacted over the fervent opposition of a state teachers' union worried about members' pensions - directly assault the inferior educational system that plagues not only that state but most of the nation, and threatens to further disadvantage the U.S. in international competition in the high-tech future. The Florio plan will add $1 billion to support for about 360 districts, but cut aid to 220 others - the most affluent, so potentially the most influential politically.
The question is how New Jersey will react when the higher income tax hits the well-to-do, an increased sales tax raises prices to middle-class voters, and fat-cat districts lose favored programs to help pay for a chemistry lab in a slum school.
Will the economy turn down, as some predict? Will the Legislature go Republican? Will more money poured into classrooms for the poor really pay off in educational improvement? It will take time to find out, and Mr. Florio concedes that money is only the first necessity.
He's also convinced, he told Peter Kerr of The New York Times, that the voters can take bad news, particularly when they understand their own self-interest, and will reward strong leadership that tackles the real problems of American life. Not many politicians either believe that, or act on it if they do.
That is why Democrats are keeping an eye on the way New Jersey responds to Jim Florio's temerity - and why the Great Mentioner may yet whisper another name that ends in a vowel.

HEADLINE: Steelmakers' Foreign Push Hurt by Decline in Exports

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
American steel exports, which increased sharply last year, are receding, partly because of fluctuating currency rates and heavy international price competition.
The decline in exports also reflects a recent increase in domestic demand from the auto industry, as well as limited production capacity. Over all, sales and profits are down but better than expected.
In the first quarter of 1990, the most recent period for which figures are available, steel exports slid 4.4 percent, compared with the similar period last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported. 
 
Counter to Expectations
Many economists and steel analysts said the decline was disappointing because exports had been expected to be a growing source of additional business for the steel industry. They were also disappointed that American steel companies in general had failed to establish sales and marketing networks overseas, despite a weakened dollar and increased demand that had made American-made steel more attractive to overseas buyers over the last two years.
The most significant gain in that area came two years ago when the USX Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, reopened its long-dormant export subsidiary, United States Steel International Inc., with the aim of increasing its exports. And others, including Armco Inc, a steel producer based in Parsippany, N.J., said they would devote more attention to exporting steel.
But Thomas Graham, the president of USX's steel division, said recently that the company expected exports to be down slightly for the entire year from the 1.3 million tons USX shipped overseas last year, largely as a result of the decline of the dollar in relation to the Japanese yen. A weak dollar helps American exports by reducing the prices of those goods in other currencies. USX, based in Pittsburgh, last year increased its exports sharply and won a large contract to provide tubular steel to the Soviet Union.
Robert R. Toothman, a spokesman for the National Steel Corporation, said the Pittsburgh-based company's exports had dropped because of increased demand from automobile manufacturers in the last few months. ''The auto companies have gotten back in the swing of things and construction demand is higher,'' Mr. Toothman said. ''We like to export steel, but we serve our domestic customers first because they are in it for the long run. When demand is strong, we don't have the capacity to do both.''
Other United States steelmakers report a similar increase in demand from auto makers.
 
Production Capacity Down
That sentiment is prevalent among steel industry executives who say that after years of slashing their capacity in the lean years of the early 1980's, they have little if any production capacity to dedicate to exports during times of higher demand.
John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia, criticized steel companies for not developing marketing and sales ties with steel customers in other countries. ''That's one area in which U.S. steel companies are remiss versus their international competitors,'' he said. ''They don't take advantage of the opportunity to expand. You develop competitive intellegence about what's going on with pricing, market opportunities and ongoing customer relationships. And the United States steel industry is largely left out of that.''
Historically, the American steel industry has shipped relatively little overseas. Although exports accounted for 4.8 million tons, or about 5 percent of total shipments last year, that figure is far lower than the peak of 7.1 million tons shipped in 1970. For most of the 1980's American steel companies essentially ceded the export market while they sought to preserve their domestic business. Exports declined during most of the 1980's, from 4.1 million tons at the beginning of the decade, until 1988, when they began to climb again.
 
Overseas Consumption
Christopher Plummer, an analyst with the WEFA Group, said China and the Soviet Union had decreased their purchases of American-made steel in the first quarter of this year. ''With China, there are economic and foreign exchange problems, and the Government has made an effort to reduce imports,'' Mr. Plummer said, adding that shipments to China plunged to about 2,000 tons in the first quarter, compared with 150,000 tons in the similar period last year. Also, he noted, shipments to the Soviet Union dropped to 31,000 tons in the first quarter, from 44,000 in the similar period last year. ''They are having severe currency shortages,'' Mr. Plummer said, ''which has discouraged purchases of American-made steel.''
But shipments to some countries have increased. Exports to Japan rose to 155,000 tons in the first quarter, compared with 100,000 tons in the comparable period last year. Similarly, shipments to Canada grew to 311,000 tons in the first quarter, from 129,000 tons in 1989 period. Also, exports to Mexico increased to 125,000 tons, from 117,000 tons in last year's period.
At the same time, steelmakers say the export market has remained vigorous for higher-quality products, like stainless steel and the various coated steels used in aircraft and engines. ''We are experiencing a good year,'' said Paul C. Walker, the general manager of international business for Armco. ''Demand has been strong and our exports were up in the first five months of this year by about 10 to 15 percent.''

HEADLINE: A Debate In Japan on Its Surplus

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 24

 BODY:
In negotiations that begin here on Monday, Japan and the United States will square off on one of the thorniest issues blocking conclusion of a key trade agreement - how much the Japanese Government will invest at home on sewerage plants, airports, bridges and other projects to use up savings that have been buying foreign assets, from factories to Picassos.
But a battle that had seemed a dipand eventual compromise has taken on a different cast in recent weeks. An important Finance Ministry study outlined the arguments for Japan's maintaining, rather than eliminating, its trade surpluses.
At stake, in the eyes of some people here, is not a few billion yen or some new roads, but whether the huge horde of savings in Japanese hands after a decade of large surpluses will become a tool to advance Japanese policies abroad or simply a means to satisfy American demands. 
 
Developed Into a Struggle
For the Japanese, particularly the powerful Ministry of Finance, this has developed into a struggle over Japan's attempts to define an independent financial strategy, one key aim of which would be to expand the nation's economic clout abroad.
The United States has insisted that the Government commit up to 10 percent of its annual budget for public investment, from 6.7 percent last year. The Japanese have resisted setting a percentage, preferring to negotiate a set amount, a figure that some Japanese officials feel could be reduced in the future. There are other sticking points, but this one has drawn out the deepest philosophical differences between the sides.
''Japan faces a very important choice,'' said Tomomitsu Oba, a former vice finance minister for international affairs and a key advocate and architect of the emerging strategy. ''It is between more public investment domestically or increased international cooperation to help developing countries grow and to revitalize Eastern Europe. If our surpluses keep shrinking, I do not think Japan can do both.''
On the one hand, as many have pointed out, the comments can be seen as a negotiating ploy - holding increases in Japanese foreign aid hostage to the American demand that Japan sharply increase its public investment at home.
But in the longer run, the comments also carry the outlines of the new strategy, which could have an effect not just on the current negotiations, but on Japan's influence over the third world's debt crisis, the success of Japanese companies expanding into poor countries, and the policies of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, where Japan's voice has grown as it has raised its financial commitments.
Mr. Oba is the chairman of the Finance Ministry advisory group that began to outline publicly the arguments for maintaining Japan's trade surpluses. His advisory group also urged that Japan use its foreign aid as a tool to make it more attractive for Japanese industry to invest and expand in the developing world.
 
'Great Deal of Influence'
A senior Finance Ministry official said the advisory group's report was a proposal, not policy. But he added, ''This report is a significant part of the consensus-building process, and it will have a great deal of influence on our thinking.''
The official went so far as to call it a ''vision,'' borrowing the term applied to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry's papers that define Japan's industrial policy. In essence, Japan is creating an international financial policy.
Makoto Utsumi, the current vice foreign minister for international affairs, tried to quell the controversy on the report by Mr. Oba's advisory group by saying there was no attempt to justify Japan's surpluses.
Nonetheless, he also stressed the need for Japan and other countries to encourage savings. As Mr. Oba explained, the Japanese see savings as a product of the country's surplus. When another senior ministry official was asked afterward if that meant the policy was to eliminate Japan's yawning surpluses completely, he denied that that was so.
In a lengthy interview in his large, cluttered office, Mr. Oba, who is 60 years old, forcefully stated the case for a more assertive Japanese policy that would require the maintenance of a trade surplus and a relative decline in the amount of Japanese capital flowing into the United States. He said one of the biggest problems in Japan's capital exports was that too much went to the United States now, where it has only created friction. He asserted that Japan should channel more capital exports to developing countries, where he felt the money would be more productive.
He called Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's plan for lowering the debt of third world countries a failure because it called for Japanese banks to offer new loans to these countries without any concomitant increase in their ability to influence the borrowers' national policies.
''The Brady proposal amounts to an American initiative, Japanese money,'' Mr. Oba said disapprovingly. ''We have to express a new philosophy for dispensing aid, so that it really achieves something.''
He suggested instead that Japan's official aid be used to make those countries more attractive to direct investment from Japanese companies. He said the investment would not burden the countries with debt payments and would bring to them new technology and job growth. It would also make Japanese companies more efficient and potentially wealthier by giving them access to low-cost labor and new markets.
He described the strategy using a Japanese proverb that translates roughly as ''using a small shrimp to catch a big fish.'' It would amount to a Government-industry partnership. For example, building a good airport, good roads and schools in a country with Government aid might attract Japanese manufacturers.
For the most part, this is a Finance Ministry strategy that has not gained full acceptance from the other ministries involved in the trade talks, the Foreign Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. Some officials of other ministries have bitterly criticized their Finance Ministry counterparts because of their resistance to compromise on the issue of public investment.
There has also been sharp criticism of the emerging strategy. Yoichi Funabashi, an influential columnist for the Asahi Shimbun newspaper, flatly called the Finance Ministry insistence on maintaining a trade surplus ''absurd'' and the product of ''narrow, turf interests.'' He pointed out that the United States remained one of the largest donors of foreign aid, even though it had huge deficits and debts in the last decade.
 
Japan's Status as Donor
TOKYO, June 24 (AP) - Japan has surpassed the United States to become the world's largest donor of foreign aid in 1989, providing nearly $9 billion in official development assistance, the Foreign Ministry says.
The $8.96 billion that Japan supplied to poor nations was down 1.9 percent from the previous year in dollar terms but still put Japan in the No. 1 position, the ministry said on Friday, citing statistics compiled by the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development.
The United States, previously the top donor, provided $7.66 billion in foreign aid in 1989.

HEADLINE: In Canada, An Appeal For Calm

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, June 24

 BODY:
As anxiety spread among Canadians about a possible push for independence by Quebec, Finance Minister Michael H. Wilson of Canada today appealed to investors in the United States and elsewhere to recognize the ''basic strength'' of the country's economy and not to overreact to the political concerns of the moment.
After the collapse on Friday night of an agreement that many feared was the last chance to secure Quebec's commitment to the Canadian confederation, Mr. Wilson and his top aides spent the weekend in his suite on the 21st floor of the Finance Ministry building here. Aides to the minister said he was seeking to calm investors' jitters when the world's financial markets open on Monday.
''People outside Canada can have confidence that the underlying strengths of this country will continue,'' Mr. Wilson said in an interview arranged at his request. 
In a statement issued this afternoon, Mr. Wilson stressed that the uncertainties about Quebec's future that arose when a constitutional agreement collapsed on Friday would not disrupt Government economic policies. He said Canada's commitment to the free-trade agreement with the United States, which relaxed restraints on American investments in Canada and lowered tariffs when it took effect on Jan. 1, 1989, would remain strong.
 
The U.S.-Canada Partnership
With more than $150 billion in trade last year, Canada and the United States are each other's largest trading partners. The nations' investments in each other's economy are also the largest in the world.
Support for the free-trade pact has has come from the current Quebec Government of Premier Robert Bourassa and from the opposition Parti Quebecois, which favors independence for the province.
Mr. Wilson spent the day calling on people he has met during 20 years in corporate and government finance on Bay Street, Toronto's financial district, as well as on the relationships he has developed since becoming Finance Minister in 1984.
He said Daniel Johnson, Quebec's Finance Minister, had agreed in a telephone conversation today that both Governments would do everything possible to insure a continuation of their normal working relationships on matters affecting the economy.
 
Talks With Officials
Mr. Wilson and his aides also spoke with top officials in the financial markets in New York, Montreal and Toronto, among others.
Mr. Wilson said he was encouraged by a conversation with a man he described as ''one of the most senior people on Wall Street.'' He said that man had told him of recent discussions in Europe and the United States that had indicated broad confidence in Canada's economic future among investors, despite the constitutional problems.
''He told me that Canada's prospects, with or without this agreement with Quebec, looked pretty good,'' the minister said.
The Finance Minister also made his case in interviews with reporters from the United States, Europe and Asia, and in a statement issued this afternoon he sought to counter suggestions that the demise of an agreement that would have given Quebec special constitutional status reflected widespread animosities between Quebec and English-speaking Canada.
 
An Implied Preference
In one interview, Mr. Wilson avoided discussing the economic effects on Canada or Quebec of the province gaining independence, saying that Mr. Bourassa, the Quebec Premier, had implied a preference for working out a solution that kept the province part of Canada when, at a Quebec news conference on Saturday, he said the province would continue to discuss the constitutional future with the Ottawa Government.
Mr. Wilson also cited with approval Mr. Bourassa's statement that the province's eventual choice would be based on what was best for Quebec's ''economic security'' and for its prospects of attracting foreign investment.
''We're not talking about Quebec independence,'' Mr. Wilson said. Seated in an office with a view across the Ottawa River to Quebec, whose western boundary meets Ontario's here, he added: ''We're talking about how we can maintain the existence of this country, with Quebec as part of it.''
In light of Mr. Bourassa's remarks, Mr. Wilson said, foreigners trading in the Canadian currency and in other Canadian financial instruments, as well as those making decisions on investments here, should pay attention not to the constitutional problems but to the soundness of the Canadian economy.

HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE CHANGES

 BODY:
* Audits and Surveys Inc., New York, a marketing research company, promoted William Liebman to senior vice president and senior administrative officer, and Anthony Timiraos to senior vice president for finance, chief financial officer and head of the company's legal matters.
