HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Trading Hits Summer Doldrums

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
As the second quarter comes to a close, summer languor is beginning to envelop the credit markets.
The chances that bond yields will move in a narrow trading range around 8.50 percent appear even more likely this year than in previous summers.
Fundamentally, the economy is losing momentum, very slowly. Inflationary pressures are receding, but only gradually. Mindful of these conditions, the Federal Reserve Board, intent on controlling inflation without inducing a recession, is showing little interest in altering the equation now by easing monetary policy. 
''I am still bullish longer term, and think that interest rates will move below 8 percent by the end of the year,'' said William H. Gross, a managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif.
''But things will probably be pretty sleepy until the end of the summer,'' he said. ''Over the next few months there seems to be no substantial risk of higher interest rates.''
The most recent data seem to confirm additional softness in the economy, particularly in the consumer sector, which accounts for two-thirds of all activity.
 
Consumption is Weakening
After seven straight months of gains, consumer spending was flat in May, the Government reported Friday. Those numbers, which followed a revised report on economic growth in the first quarter that included a big downward revision in personal spending, prompted analysts to pare their second-quarter growth estimates.
''The industrial sector is beginning to rise modestly, but consumption is definitely on the weak side,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''I think growth in the second quarter will be between 1.5 percent and 1 percent, but right now I am leaning closer to the lower number.''
Growth of around 1 percent would put the economy on the brink of stalling, but Mr. Fine and others said the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee would resist an easing of monetary policy when it meets in Washington on July 2.
''The latest statements from policy makers imply that a move now would be premature,'' said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc.
 
Early Debt-Ceiling Rise Possible
With no significant economic information to be released until the first week in July, market participants are likely to focus on auctions of two- and four-year Treasury notes this week, as well as on how the Treasury Department resolves an accounting problem that could force the Federal Government's $3.12 trillion debt ceiling to be raised earlier than anticipated.
Late last week, the two-year notes, to be auctioned on Tuesday, were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.34 percent. The four-year notes, which will be sold a day later, were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.43 percent.
The potential problem with the debt ceiling revolves around the way the Government accounts for $30 billion worth of zero-coupon bonds sold earlier this year to Mexico.
The Wall Street Journal said Friday that $27 billion of these bonds fail to qualify for a new method of calculating zero-coupon bonds subject to the debt ceiling. The Treasury Department had been calculating that the Mexican bonds would add about $3 billion to the amount of debt subject to the debt ceiling, The Journal reported.
 
Treasury's Temporary Silence
Robert Levine, a Treasury spokesman, said late last week that the department would not confirm or deny ''to what extent the zero-coupon bonds are affecting the debt ceiling.'' He added that a clarification of the Treasury's position would be issued soon.
''We will have to say something soon about the debt ceiling in any case,'' Mr. Levine said.
If the full $27 billion is counted against the debt ceiling, Congress will have to raise the debt ceiling before adjourning for its August recess, weeks earlier than had been anticipated, analysts said. .
Struggling with the debt ceiling would not only add a new, urgent twist to the continuing budget negotiations, but also would cast doubt on the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions in early August.
''There is a feeling that a number much smaller than that $27 billion figure will be put out there,'' said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. ''Raising the debt ceiling is being used as a vehicle for various budget reform proposals that are going around. But there is virtually no chance that Congress will be able to act by the end of July on the budget and other financial matters.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Sweden's New Breed Of Corporate Raider

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM

 BODY:
Sven-Olof Johansson is a hero and a villain in Sweden. He is a villain to the Swedes who think that aspiring to be rich is a sin - and there are many in this welfare state. And he is a hero to many young Swedes who like the idea of having money and the Ferraris that often go with it.
Mr. Johansson is one of a new breed of deal makers who made their fortune in Sweden's booming stock and real estate markets in the 1980's. They are now buying stakes in the country's biggest companies - putting them on the defensive at a time when they are scrambling to adjust to the single market that their biggest customer, the European Community, is creating.
Mr. Johansson, who rose from a humble background to become one of Sweden's richest men - and the owner of three Ferraris - recently tweaked the nose of Peter Wallenberg, the head of Sweden's most powerful family. He spent 3.2 billion kronor ($525 million) to acquire a 22 percent voting stake in Saab-Scania A.B., the big truck, aircraft and car manufacturer that the Wallenbergs control with a 36 percent voting stake. 
 
Viewed as a 'Greenmailer'
Viewing the overture as unfriendly, Mr. Wallenberg agreed to buy Mr. Johansson's stake for nearly 4.5 billion kronor ($738 million). That deal makes Mr. Johansson about $213 million richer and in the view of many Swedes something of an American-style ''greenmailer'' - someone who buys a stake in a company, hoping to force the company to buy it back at an above-market premium. The ramifications of that perception horrify the establishment here.
''The rise of raiders like Mr. Johansson could in the long run be detrimental to the Swedish economy,'' said Erik Belfrage, a senior vice president of Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken, a big Swedish bank, and an adviser to Mr. Wallenberg. ''My real worry is that we will move to a situation where companies are forced to place too much importance on short-term profits like in the United States.''
Mr. Johansson has not lost interest in the Wallenberg empire. He says he has paid about 150 million kronor ($25 million) for a 1 percent stake in A.B. Investor, one of the three main holding companies through which the Wallenbergs control most of Sweden's blue-chip companies, including Electrolux, Asea Brown Boveri, Stora Kopparbergs Bergslags, Saab-Scania, L. M. Ericsson and Atlas Copco. The two other holding companies are Export Invest and Forvaltnings A.B. Providentia.
 
Wallenberg Stock Portfolio
At the end of last year, the Wallenberg family's stock portfolio was worth about $5.9 billion, said Jan Dworsky, an analyst at Barclays de Zoette Wedd, the London-based securities firm.
With a couple of exceptions, the family has controlled companies with only 30 percent or less of their shares through a combination of special voting shares and sheer influence. But challengers like Mr. Johansson threaten the power of others in the old guard, which include Svenska Handelsbanken, one of Sweden's oldest and largest banks, and Volvo A.B.
Besides Mr. Johansson, who is 44 years old, new financial powers in Sweden include Erik Penser, who controls Nobel Industrier Sverige, a chemicals, weapons and consumer-goods company; Robert Weil, who controls Gotabanken, Sweden's fourth-largest bank; Peter Gyllenhammar, whose interests include a big securities firm, and Gustaf Douglas, who owns a big stake in Trelleborg, the minerals giant.
 
How Fortunes Were Amassed
Despite Sweden's sky-high taxes -the top marginal income tax rate was 72 percent as recently as 1989 - these deal makers were able to amass fortunes in the 1980's, when the value of Swedish stocks grew tenfold and real estate two- to threefold. They built empires by borrowing against their appreciating real estate and by exploiting tax loopholes and Sweden's favorable treatment of capital gains, which have enabled them to keep as much as 90 percent of their profits.
Under the tax reform that the Social Democratic Government is now carrying out, the top marginal income tax rate will drop to 50 percent next year (it fell to 65 percent this year), and most people will have to pay a flat 30 percent tax on capital gains.
In response, members of the old guard are taking steps to protect themselves. They are increasing their stakes in some of their companies, are increasing the size of others through mergers and are forging cross-ownership links with other concerns.
For instance, come August, when Mr. Wallenberg completes the purchase of Mr. Johansson's holdings in Saab-Scania, the family will own a 58 percent stake in the company. Stora, the pulp and paper giant controlled by the Wallenbergs, paid $2.4 billion to acquire Feldmuhle Nobel, the West German paper company. Volvo has struck complex business and equity deals in food and pharmaceuticals with Procordia, a Swedish Government-controlled concern, and in cars and trucks with France's Renault.
 
Tough Lesson in Mid-1970's
Mr. Johansson learned at an early age that playing with the big boys can be rough. In the mid-1970's, he and some friends failed in their bid to buy control of a steel company in the Handelsbanken sphere. The company outmaneuvered him by issuing new stock in the form of a rights offering to shareholders. Mr. Johansson's group did not have the money to buy its entitled portion and its position was diluted. It had to sell at a loss.
''It took me almost five years to get back to zero,'' he said.
Since the steel company fiasco, Mr. Johansson has done a series of leveraged buyouts of troubled small and medium-size industrial and trading companies, which he fixed up and then sold at a profit.
He claims to have a net worth of more than $500 million. The $213 million for his Saab stock, he says, will give him about $328 million in cash.
Barkman & Company, his holding company with about $230 million in revenues, owns four Apple Computer retail centers, electronics distribution operations, a process control concern and makers of prefabricated buildings and construction supplies.
 
Real Estate Holdings
Mr. Johansson said his real estate portfolio is worth about $1.13 billion, with about 60 percent of that in Sweden. His holdings include about 150 properties - offices, shopping centers, hotels and apartments. Tough building restrictions in many Swedish cities promise to keep occupancy rates, rentals and real estate prices high, he says.
He would like to expand his holdings in France, where he sees real estate prices continuing to rise. He is also interested in New York, where he is building an exclusive 180-suite hotel on First Avenue near the United Nations, and he owns other properties on the block. ''The market is terrible and I think it is going to get even worse before it turns up again,'' he said.
 
Contrast to Trump
Mr. Johansson's longish hair and deal making make it tempting to dub him Sweden's Donald J. Trump. But the personalities of the two are notably dissimilar. Mr. Johansson lives in a relatively modest apartment, bought his Ferraris as collector's items and does not flash them, and comes across as unpretentious and down to earth.
But he shares Mr. Trump's big ambitions. Had he succeeded in buying all or half of Saab-Scania, he said, he would have sold the company's half interest in Saab Automobile, the other half of which was bought by the General Motors Corporation for $600 million. And he said he would have tried to form an alliance in civil aircraft with Daimler-Benz A.G., the West German company.
He still hopes to buy a major industrial company, he said, not trying to hide his envy of the Wallenbergs. ''They have a tremendous impact,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
15 'Mega-Cities' Joining to Learn From Each Other

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
If you can make it here, the song says, you can make it anywhere.
New York City government has helped pioneer innovations from slippery water, which gushed through fire hoses more efficiently, to ''glassphalt,'' which recycles broken bottles into the stuff of which streets are paved.
Yet New Yorkers are often smugly resistant to adopting ideas that were spawned out-of-town. Broadway has no reservations about importing a play; government has often seemed reluctant to embrace even indigenous programs that work, let alone those that made it anywhere else. 
A city whose largest tangible export is now waste paper and whose leeway for providing routine municipal services, much less frills, has been crimped by declining tax revenue can ill afford to be blinded by boosterism.
In that spirit, representatives from New York and from 14 of the world's other big cities have joined to learn from each other's mistakes, to share the lessons of creative problem-solving and to replicate their successes.
The Mega-Cities Project, based at New York University's Urban Research Center, draws on experiences of grass-roots groups, entrepreneurs and bureaucrats in Bangkok, Beijing, Bombay, Buenos Aires, Lagos, London, Los Angeles, Mexico City, Nairobi, New Delhi, Rio de Janeiro, Sao Paulo, Tokyo and, beginning this summer, in Moscow.
''Cities have always been the crucible for the advancement of civilization,'' says Dr. Janice E. Perlman, the project's founder and director. ''We're sometimes overpowered by despair rather than finding in cities the seeds for solutions.''
By the millennium, it is estimated, more than half of the world's population will be city dwellers. Dr. Perlman suggests that seemingly diverse metropolitan areas - 23 of which are expected to be home to 10 million or more people each by the year 2000 - have more in common with each other than with their respective hinterlands.
''Moving people around, moving garbage around, housing low-income people and matching people with jobs are universal problems,'' she said. ''Every third-world city has a first-world city in it; every first-world city has a third-world city in it.''
Some catalysts already culled by the Mega-Cities project may seem modest or deceptively simple.
But they represent a bargain, common-sensical approach to problems for which there no longer seem to be panaceas, only mitigation. Among those that seem promising:
* An experimental Brazilian ''surface metro'' system. Bus riders pay to enter an off-the-street loading zone. They board through doors on one side of specially designed buses; exiting passengers leave from the other side.
* A Mexico City self-help program for the homeless. Squatters have been organized to construct their own housing and to recycle garbage into fertilizer.
* A Brazilian network of police station houses staffed exclusively by women. Its purpose is to make the criminal-justice system more sensitive to women who might otherwise be reluctant to lodge charges of rape or abuse.
* A New Delhi system of ''mobile creches.'' The combined schools and day-care centers encamp at construction sites to offer migrant workers' children a continuing education and to free their mothers for jobs or school.
* A Bangkok anti-littering campaign called Magic Eyes. The imaginative, privately financed effort, which combines classroom teaching, television commercials, posters and other tools, targets still-impressionable youngsters with the warning: ''Magic eyes are watching you.''
Other efforts range from citizens' tree-planting programs in Los Angeles to meticulously coordinated nighttime road repairs in Tokyo (commended to New York officials during an exchange program managed by the Fund for the City of New York).
New York City itself has already generated 230 entries for the Mega-Cities index - ideas that might seem commonplace to New Yorkers but are considered revolutionary overseas.
They include glassphalt, the Nehemiah program to build affordable privately financed housing on publicly donated land; the policy role granted to community boards; the New York City Partnership's focus of private resources on public problems, and a Bronx cash-for-trash recycling center, which produces jobs and a cleaner neighborhood.
If financial support is forthcoming, Mega-Cities also hopes to hunt for untested prototypes and to regularly share information on which programs succeed.
''We're trying to find projects that are socially just, ecologically sustainable, economically viable and participatory,'' Dr. Perlman said, ''and then to see if the seeds are transferable.''

HEADLINE: The Mandela Visit;
Mandela Assails U.S. Aid to Savimbi

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
On the eve of his meeting with President Bush, Nelson Mandela condemned one of the President's African policies, support for Jonas Savimbi's rightist rebels in Angola.
Speaking to a group of black journalists tonight, Mr. Mandela said that only the United States and South Africa were supporting Mr. Savimbi's guerrillas, ''and we strongly condemn that.''
Mr. Mandela, referring to the possibility that his organization, the African National Congress, will achieve a share of power in the government, then ''of course, we would not tolerate any further support.''
The Bush Administration is expected to bring a request for an additional $8 million to $10 million in aid for Mr Savimbi's group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita from its initials in Portuguese, for consideration by the Intelligence Commmittees of both houses of Congress in the next few weeks. 
One of Mr. Bush's first foreign policy acts on assuming the Presidency was to send a letter of support to Mr. Savimbi.
 
Huge Turnout in Boston
Today, buoyed by tumultuous receptions in Boston and New York, Mr. Mandela arrived in the capital for a crucial series of meetings with President Bush and other United States officials.
The cheering throngs along the way, Mr. Mandela said as he arrived at National Airport this afternoon, ''have left us with the distinct impression that in this country we have our brothers and sisters who are committed to the fight against racial oppression in our country.''
On Saturday night, the leader of the African National Congress was cheered by a largely white crowd numbering about 250,000 in Boston that gathered along the banks of the Charles River on folding chairs, picnic blankets and even a few canoes for a concert and rally.
Mr. Mandela himself exuberantly danced the toyi-toyi, a traditional African dance used in demonstrations, and pumping a clenched fist into the air to Hugh Masekela's song, repeated throughout the evening, ''Free Nelson Mandela.''
 
Kennedy, Dukakis and Festivity
The area's top public officials, Senators Edward M. Kennedy and John F. Kerry, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, all of whom have pressed for economic sanctions against South Africa, stood with him on the platform as strips of yellow banners and the African National Congress's green, black and yellow flags waved in the crowd.
His reception in Boston, Mr. Mandela told reporters as he left that city at midday, ''exceeded our wildest dreams. The support has been very warm and very encouraging.''
Mr. Mandela is to meet with President Bush in the White House on Monday morning. Later, he will meet with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other State Department officials.
On Tuesday, he will publicly press his case for continued, indeed, increased economic sanctions to keep pressure for change on the white South African Government of President F. W. de Klerk.
 
Some Credit to de Klerk
In his remarks on arriving today, Mr. Mandela conceded that concessions made thus far by Mr. de Klerk ''have raised the hope for peace.''
But, he insisted, the Government was yielding ''not because of a change of heart but because of the pressure put on the Government inside the country and by the international community.''
While in other cities politicians have crowded about Mr. Mandela, Washington's most prominent black politican, Mayor Marion Barry, who is on trial on drug charges, was nowhere to be seen.
Organizers privately said that this will continue to be the practice. ''Marion's been very understanding about this,'' one said.
 
Miami's Cuban-Americans Upset
In Miami, where Mr. Mandela will make a brief appearance to give a speech to the union representing state, county and municipal workers on Thursday, the City Commission decided to forgo a welcoming resolution because Cuban-Americans there were angered at his remarks supporting the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.
This morning, Mr. Mandela spent some private time with his daughter, Zenani Mandela Dlamini, who is married to Prince Thumbumuzi Dlamini of Swaziland. Both are students at Boston University, and Mr. Mandela's wife, Winnie, took an hour out to see their home in Brookline.
However, a daughter by Mr. Mandela's first marriage, Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah, a graduate student at the University of Massachusetts, did not show up for what had been described as a reunion this morning. She has not seen or talked to her father since he has been released.
''I don't know anything about a reunion. There was no reunion on the program. They did send me a program,'' she told The Boston Globe.
 
Winnie Mandela's Day
As Mr. Mandela rested in his hotel room, his wife made an appearance at the nearby Metropolitan African Methodist Episcopal Church, which has had a long history of involvement in liberation movements, since the days slaves used it as a stop on the underground railroad.
''Winnie and Nelson Mandela mean everything to us,'' said Jesse B. Mason, as she waited with other women from the church wearing red carnations. ''We are just overjoyed she would be at our church.''
Because of a delay in the Mandelas' flight to Washington, the program began without Mrs. Mandela, catching the organizers off guard. But within minutes, participants in the all-female program took their turn at the lectern to pay tribute not only to the Mandelas but to all women struggling for equality.
When Effie Barry, the wife of the embattled Mayor, approached the microphone she raised her right hand in a clenched fist. ''Your fight is our fight,'' said Mrs. Barry.
Molly Yard, the president of the National Organization for Women, and other speakers insisted that the United States continue sanctions against the South African Government.
 
Pacing Himself
Mr. Mandela has been dropping appointments as he goes, canceling a number of meetings including some with South African exiles and congress members working here, much to their disappointment.
This morning, Masilo Mabeta, an African National Congress member who went into exile 10 years ago, was pacing the lobby of the Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston, holding a sleeping baby, while his two other small sons ran about. They had driven down that morning from Newmarket, N.H.
After two hours, his wife asked if they should just leave. ''No, no, no, no, no.'' Mr. Mabeta said. The family went to the sixth floor where Mr. Mandela and his party were staying but could not get a glimpse of him. They went back to the lobby for several more hours and finally went home without having seen their hero.
''We are just honored that he is here,'' Mr. Mabeta said.

HEADLINE: China Lets Dissident Leave Haven In U.S. Embassy to Fly to England

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 25

 BODY:
China allowed its most prominent dissident, Fang Lizhi, to leave his refuge in the United States Embassy in Beijing today and board an American military transport plane for a new life in England.
The departure of Mr. Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, marked the removal of what was generally regarded as the single greatest obstacle to improved ties between the United States and China. The White House welcomed the release as an ''important contribution toward improving our relations.'' 
The development came a month after President Bush recommended extension of China's most-favored-nation trade status and after weeks of intense secret negotiations between Chinese and American representatives. [Page A8.] A Letter of Admission Mr. Fang and Miss Li were allowed to leave the country after writing a letter to the Chinese Government in which they admitted that their views violated the Chinese Constitution and made a somewhat ambiguous pledge not to engage in anti-Chinese activity while abroad. [Texts of the letter and of a statement by Beijing, page A9.] [After changing planes at Elmendorf Air Force Base in Anchorage, Alaska, the couple arrived tonight at an American military base at Upper Heyford in southern England, The Associated Press reported, quoting an Air Force spokesman.] While Fang Lizhi, whose name is pronounced fahng lee-jur (rhyming with burr) was his country's leading advocate of human rights, it is not clear whether his release marks the beginning of a more lenient policy toward ordinary Chinese who played important roles in last year's democracy movement. Many Chinese intellectuals continue to complain of repression, and hundreds or thousands of people remain in prison for conducting peaceful protests.
 
A Leading Astrophysicist
An ebullient man with a disarming habit of laughing when relating the punishments that he endured beginning in 1957, Mr. Fang came to be revered by many university students and intellectuals throughout the country. Partly protected by his international academic reputation as an astrophysicist, he was for several years virtually the only Chinese willing to say openly that Marxism had failed in China and to call for greater democracy.
While he did not play any obvious role in organizing last year's democracy movement, he was regarded by many Chinese students as an inspiration - as an example of a brilliant intellectual who took personal risks out of concern for saving the motherland - and the Chinese leadership accused him of being one of the movement's behind-the-scenes instigators.
Shortly after the army's attack on pro-democracy protesters in June 1989, Mr. Fang and Miss Li, whose name is pronounced lee shu-shyen, fled to the Embassy, and they have been kept out of sight in the compound that includes the American Ambassador's residence. Mr. Fang is said to have remarked that he is an astrophysicist but could not even see the sky. An expert in fundamental questions about the universe and its origins, Mr. Fang is to resume his research in England, possibly at Cambridge University, the British Foreign Office said. He is a close friend and collaborator of Stephen W. Hawking, Cambridge's Lucasian professor of mathematics and author of the book ''A Brief History of Time.''
''In view of the signs of repentance by Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian and their illness and out of humanitarian considerations, the Beijing Public Security Bureau has decided to allow them to go abroad for medical treatment in line with China's policy of leniency toward those who participated in the disturbances,'' an announcer said near the end of tonight's national television news.
There is no indication that Mr. Fang or Miss Li is seriously ill. But Mr. Fang is believed to have had some heart problems while in the embassy, and he is scheduled to check into a hospital for an examination in England.
 
'The Only Way Out'
In the past, China had said ''the only way out'' for Mr. Fang and Miss Li was for them to plead guilty and submit to Chinese law. It was unclear today exactly what deal was arranged for their release.
The official New China News Agency, in a brief dispatch, said that Mr. Fang and Miss Li had written to the Government and admitted that they opposed what are called the Four Cardinal Principles: the socialist road, the people's democratic dictatorship, leadership of the Communist Party, and Marxism-Leninism and the teachings of Mao Zedong. The letter acknowledged that by opposing these principles, the couple had violated the preamble to the Chinese Constitution.
The agency also said they had asked to go abroad for medical treatment and had promised that after leaving the country they would ''not engage in activities directed against China.''
Mr. Fang and Miss Li, who said they opposed the Four Cardinal Principles because the purpose of those ideas ''is to uphold a political system of class struggle,'' have expressed similar views previously. Likewise, Mr. Fang and Miss Li have never considered themselves opposed to China as a nation, so it should not have been difficult for them to pledge not to engage in anti-China activities.
 
Gentler Treatment Promised
In an apparent reference to the release of Mr. Fang and Miss Li, Prime Minister Li Peng suggested today that China would deal more gently with its dissidents, but he went out of his way to stress that this was not because of foreign sanctions.
''Due to growing political and economic stability in China, the Chinese Government has taken a more lenient policy toward the people who participated in the turmoil last year,'' Mr. Li said, according to paraphrased remarks by the New China News Agency. ''These moves did not result from the pressure from the West.''
The move to England rather than the United States seemed to reflect China's preferences. Beijing is believed to have insisted that Mr. Fang and Miss Li go to a country other than the United States, and Italy and Australia reportedly also were considered.
From what is now known, the authorities seem to have made most of the concessions. The leadership is known in particular to have sought a much more extensive self-criticism and acknowledgement of guilt, as well as a pledge not to criticize the Government from abroad.
Beijing's concessions may have been intended to gain support for the extension of most-favored-nation trade status for China. Mr. Bush has already recommended the extension, but some members of Congress have vowed a fight on the issue. The release also makes it more likely that the seven major industrialized nations will agree at their summit meeting next month to resume lending to China.
The departure of Mr. Fang and Miss Li comes about a week after the expulsion to Taiwan of a folk singer, Hou Dejian, who after the crackdown had inherited the mantle of the most outspoken critic of the Government. Linda Jaivin, a China specialist at the Contemporary China Center at Australian National University, said in a telephone interview that the authorities probably were trying to get rid of their critics before the Asian Games are held in Beijing in September.
Mr. Fang and Miss Li, who are both 54 years old, met in the early 1950's at Beijing University, where they were both outstanding students in the physics department. Both were chosen to join the Communist Party, but both were then expelled in 1957 during the anti-rightist campaign.
After the death of Mao and the rise of Deng Xiaoping to power at the end of the 1970's, Mr. Fang and Miss Li automatically regained their party membership.
 
Protests at His University
In 1986, students at his university -the University of Science and Technology, in the central Chinese city of Hefei - set off a nationwide wave of student protests, prompting a brief crackdown, and Mr. Fang was expelled again from the Communist Party.
Transferred to Beijing in early 1987 so the central authorities could keep a closer eye on him, Mr. Fang began to give interviews in which he said publicly what many intellectuals said privately. ''Marxism is no longer of much use,'' he told an interviewer in the spring of that year.
Miss Li was less prominent, but as an associate professor at Beijing University, she also had considerable contact with students and was no less biting in her criticism of the Communist Party and in her demands for change.
Mr. Fang and Miss Li were at the center of a major embarrassment in February 1989, when Mr. Bush visited Beijing and invited them to a banquet. Chinese security officials forcibly prevented the couple from attending.
 
Fear for Their Lives
Some intellectuals were critical of the couple for fleeing to the United States Embassy after the crackdown, citing the historic Chinese sensitivity to foreigners treating themselves as above national law. But most people interviewed casually about the subject over the last year expressed sympathy, saying Mr. Fang and Miss Li feared for their lives and felt they had no choice.
While in hiding in the American Embassy, Mr. Fang and Miss Li continued their scientific work and conducted a vigorous correspondence with friends abroad. Mr. Fang also wrote one essay, to accept in abstentia the Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award.
''Like all members of the human race, the Chinese are born with a body and a brain, with passions and a soul,'' Mr. Fang wrote. ''Therefore they can and must enjoy the same inalienable rights, dignity and liberty as other human beings.''
He added, ''Remember that in the current climate of terror, it may well be that those who are most terrified are those who have just finished killing their fellow human beings.''

HEADLINE: THE MANDELA VISIT;
MANDELA DECLINES TO RULE OUT FORCE

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela told President Bush today that he could not completely renounce the use of violence and armed struggles to achieve racial equality in South Africa. But he said the African National Congress would cease hostilities once the South African Government accepted all conditions for talks on a new constitution.
President Bush assured Mr. Mandela, who wants foreign powers to keep up the pressure of sanctions on the Government of President F. W. de Klerk, that American sanctions would not be lifted until all the conditions set by Congress for doing so were met. Those conditions include the complete lifting of the state of emergency in South Africa and the release of about a thousand political prisoners.
Just as democracy has liberated Eastern Europe, Mr. Bush said in a welcoming ceremony on the sunny South Lawn, ''so, too, South Africa's time will come.'' 
After a three-hour meeting with President Bush, including a working lunch at the White House, Mr. Mandela said that the two men had narrowed their differences and that ''even at the White House our mission succeeded beyond our wildest expectations.''
On the third leg of his tour of the United States, the 71-year-old Mr. Mandela moved from a celebratory mood to a more businesslike one. Although he is not a head of state, he was honored with the South Lawn ceremony and with a White House luncheon, events usually accorded only to foreign leaders.
Mr. Mandela, who is deputy President of the African National Congress, the leading anti-apartheid coalition in South Africa, also met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at the State Department and with labor leaders at A.F.L.-C.I.O. headquarters here. He attended a dinner at the Senate organized by Senators David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, and Terry Sanford, Democrat of North Carolina.
 
'The Hopes of Millions'
In his opening statement at the White House, President Bush described Mr. Mandela, who spent 27 1/2 years in prison for his advocacy of black majority rights, as ''a man who embodies the hopes of millions.'' But the President, who tries customarily to please both sides in disputes, was eager to give a pat on the back to President de Klerk as well.
As Mr. Mandela stared straight ahead without expression, Mr. Bush praised the South African Government for steps ''to expand the rights and freedoms of South Africans.''
Mr. Bush called apartheid ''repugnant'' but added that all sides in the South African struggle should renounce violence and repression.
''In the words of the great Martin Luther King Jr., 'Let us not seek to satisfy our thirst for freedom by drinking from the cup of bitterness and hatred,' '' Mr. Bush said.
When it was his turn, Mr. Mandela politely but firmly noted that when a repressive government intensifies oppression, ''the people have no alternative but to resort to violence.''
''We made it clear that once the government removed all the obstacles to negotiation, we would consider the cessation of hostilities,'' Mr. Mandela said.
He said that for negotiations to begin, the South African Government must release 1,000 political prisoners, return 20,000 political exiles, repeal what he called repressive legislation and end the state of emergency in Natal province, the only province where it is still in existence.
 
'We Are Hopeful'
''We are hopeful that in our next meeting these obstacles will be completely removed'' with the exception of the legislation repeal, Mr. Mandela said.
Mr. Mandela said the African National Congress, which was outlawed for years until President de Klerk lifted the ban in February, has ''a total commitment to peace'' as long as the South African Government continues to move toward equality. But if the Government reneges, the commitment to peace can be revoked, he indicated.
''If we are forced to resort to violence,'' Mr. Mandela said, as he stood at Mr. Bush's side, ''it is because we have no other alternative whatsoever.'' He said that the group had scaled down its military operations since 1986 to promote negotiations.
Mr. Mandela suggested that the reason that President Bush had made such a request about violence was because he did not understand the situation and had not yet had ''a proper briefing.''
President Bush did not seem offended. Pumping the South African leader's hand as the two went off to their meeting, Mr. Bush marveled at his guest's ability to speak off the cuff, with his deep voice rolling out ''r's'' and his arms resting quietly at his side.
''No notes!'' exclaimed Mr. Bush, who had relied on index cards and his usual range of hand gestures. ''That's wonderful!''
Mr. Bush has been eager to reward President de Klerk for the changes in South Africa, and the Administration has noted that the South African Government is close to meeting conditions under which it could ask Congress to relax or lift the sanctions.
Today, Mr. Bush said, ''Our sanctions have been designed to support change, and when the conditions laid down in our law have been met, then and only then, we will consider, in consulation with Congress, whether a change in course will promote further progress through peaceful negotiations.''
As Mr. Mandela made his remarks on the South Lawn, a crowd of several hundred looked on, sometimes applauding. Mr. Mandela, wearing a blue suit and silvery blue tie, waved, and Winnie Mandela, who wore a black-and-gold traditional African dress with a wrap-around skirt with matching head wrap. raised a clenched fist in salute.
After a three-hour meeting with the President, including lunch, Mr. Mandela said that their differences had narrowed and he had been able to explain to Mr. Bush that violence was ''no longer an issue.''
''From 1986, when we launched this initiative and started urging the government to sit down and talk to us, we deliberately scaled down our armed operations in order to contribute toward an atmosphere which is conducive to a negotiated settlement,'' he said.
 
Mandela's Conditions
Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said that Mr. Bush had encouraged Mr. Mandela to ''go all the way'' and renounce violence, but that Mr. Mandela had been noncommittal. He did pledge to suspend hostilities as long as negotiations continued with the Government in Pretoria.
''The President encouraged him to go beyond that, to renounce the armed struggle,'' Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Mandela said at a news conference that to get negotiations under way, the South African Government must release 1,000 political prisoners, return 20,000 political exiles, repeal ''repressive'' legislation and lift the state of emergency in Natal.
''We are hopeful that in our next meeting these obstacles will be completely removed,'' said Mr. Mandela, who added that he knew that the repeal legislation would take some time.
Even though Mr. Mandela garnered some criticism from Capitol Hill today for his support of Fidel Castro of Cuba, Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, his visits to the White House and State Department were cordial.
 
Channel for Assistance
Mr. Cohen said Mr. Mandela had asked for money for the African National Congress. Mr. Bush said that no money would go directly to any political organization, but that the South African group could receive money channeled through the National Endowment for Democracy, an autonomous agency funded by the Government.
One of the conditions for this money would be a suspension of violence in the context of negotiations. About $32 million has already been allocated by Congress and $10 million more would be available to the South Africans if they met the conditions.
Although Mr. Mandela said at his news conference that Mr. Bush appeared ''sympathetic'' to his request for money, Administration officials said no final commitments were imminent because the Administration was ''at loggerheads'' with Mr. Mandela on ''the role of violence'' in that country, because of the South African leader's strong statement on the South Lawn.
''There are narrowing differences on the issue of violence,'' said an Administration official, ''But they need to continue to be examined by both sides.''
 
Criticism Over Savimbi
Mr. Mandela had criticized the United States to a group of journalists on Sunday night on the issue of aid to the Angolan guerrilla leader, Jonas Savimbi. Today, Mr. Mandela and Mr. Bush agreed that this was an area of disagreement that they could not immediately narrow. The American President also was at odds with Mr. Mandela on his support of Cuba, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
But Mr. Mandela said he was encouraged by the meeting. In the South Lawn ceremony, he said the black majority in South Africa was grateful to the United States for imposing sanctions and for denouncing apartheid. ''To receive the support of any government is, in our situation, something of enormous importance,'' Mr. Mandela said. ''But to receive the support of the government of the United States of America, the leader of the West, is something beyond words.''
On Capitol Hill, a leading Congressional supporter of Mr. Mandela said he regretted the South African's need to continue to praise the leaders of Cuba, Libya and the P.L.O.
''I wish he had not said those things, very frankly,'' said Rep. Howard Wolpe, a Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa. ''They were not very helpful.''
Representative William Dannemeyer, Republican of California, said that because of Mr. Mandela's revolutionary past, it was ''a national disgrace'' that he was invited to address Congress.

HEADLINE: Science Fiction Nears Reality: Pocket Phone for Global Calls

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The small and portable telephone that can be used anywhere on earth has been a staple of science fiction and a Holy Grail of telephone engineers for several decades. Today Motorola Inc. will become the first company in the world to announce plans to build and operate such a phone system.
Company officials say Motorola intends to charge less than $3,500 for a 25-ounce handset that would fit in an overcoat pocket and could allow the user to make and receive calls from the North Pole to Antarctica. Current portable phones can be used only where radio antennas on towers and office buildings are close enough to relay the signal. They are of no use in many rural areas of the United States or outside major cities in the rest of the world.
Motorola's system, which it hopes to be operating in six years, calls for the company to supplement conventional radio antennas with a constellation of 77 satellites that would relay the calls, which would cost an estimated $1 to $3 a minute, said Durrell W. Hillis, general manager of the company's satellite communications division. 
 
Broad Use Expected
Potential users of the handsets are expected to include vacationers, business people and engineers traveling in places where phone service is not available or where an international call can take hours to complete. Other users would include passengers aboard ships and planes, and disaster relief crews working in places where all other communications had been disrupted. On planes, the Motorola system would compete with a system offered by the GTE Corporation, but would have the advantage of being able to receive calls.
All of the technologies for the system have already been developed and need only to be adapted for use aboard satellites, Mr. Hillis said. But the plan faces significant financial and regulatory obstacles. Motorola estimates that putting the system in service will cost $2.3 billion over six years and is seeking partners to help in the project. But space experts caution that the economics of a project like Motorola's are harder to forecast than the technical issues.
Other companies have found that the initial investment and the operating costs of satellite systems tend to exceed expectations, said Kenneth A. Homon, the former vice president of planning for Satellite Business Systems, a failed effort by the International Business Machines Corporation to offer satellite-based telephone communications between fixed sites.
And while Motorola has an advantage in developing a satellite system for portable telephones because it is the world's largest and most technologically advanced producer of such telephones and equipment, it could face competition. The American Telephone and Telegraph Company declined to discuss whether it had any plans to offer such service, but is said to have had some discussions along these lines with other companies.
But Motorola said it has filed patent applications in 55 countries to prevent other companies from developing similar systems. And it has agreed to work with three organizations that control over much of the earth's surface the broadcast frequencies needed for the system.
 
Handsets to Be Licensed
Motorola has determined that at least 77 low-orbiting satellites will be needed to insure that one is within a line of sight anywhere on the planet and that a second comes over the horizon before the first disappears. The company plans in 1994 to begin launching inexpensive 700-pound satellites, up to 11 per rocket, that are built to last five years; it will own the satellites but will license the right to build handsets that use them.
Motorola has named the project Iridium, after the element iridium, which has 77 electrons orbiting the atomic nucleus.
Although calls could be made from one handset to another, Motorola expects that most users would place calls to conventional wire-line telephones or cellular phones served by ground radio towers.
Motorola says it will need at least 700,000 users to break even. After having consulted many international organizations about the proposed venture, company officials forecast that the system could attract as many as five million subscribers worldwide paying at least $100 a month by the year 2000.
 
Partners Sought
While Motorola plans to build much of the system itself, including almost all of the electronics, it is looking for partners to help finance Iridium and to operate it. The company is negotiating with British Telecom in London and companies in Japan, Australia, and Hong Kong, Mr. Hillis said.
Besides the commercial challenges, Iridium will need the permission of many governments to receive calls from their soil.
''Whether it'll be delivered on time, I'm not sure,'' said Michael J. Zuliani, the president of Telesat Mobile Inc., a Canadian satellite company that has agreed to work with Motorola on the system. The technical issues represent ''a challenge, but we're up to it,'' he said.
Mr. Zuliani said that A.T.&T. had also approached Telesat Mobile to discuss a possible alliance to establish satellite-based mobile communications, but that the discussions had not been detailed and did not result in any agreement. Telesat Mobile controls the most readily usable microwave frequencies for such a system in Canada.
 
An Electronics Wizard
The technical problems involved in Iridium's construction may be the smallest of the obstacles facing Motorola, analysts said. Motorola is the nation's third-largest electronics company and the world's largest producer of cellular telephone equipment, and is known for its technological wizardry in developing mobile communications products.
The company envisions Iridium as a worldwide cellular telephone system that supplements conventional radio antennas. Cellular telephones acquired that name because the service areas are divided into cells a few miles across, each with a low-power radio transmitter. A motorist moving from one area to the next is automatically transferred from one transmitter to the next, usually without interruption because computers tell the transmitter when to pass along a call to the next transmitter.
Each Iridium satellite will cover 37 cells on earth, said Bary R. Bertiger, the chief engineer and assistant general manager of Motorola's satellite communications division. Each cell will be 400 miles across and have a capacity of 336 simultaneous conversations if Motorola uses only those microwave frequencies already set aside for sea-to-shore and air-to-ground satellite communications; that number could be increased substantially if other frequencies are obtained. Because of the limited capacity, the handsets will also be compatible with terrestrial cellular service and are intended to send signals to satellites only in remote areas, he said. #3 1/2-Inch Antenna The handsets will be 7 1/2 inches long and thicker than conventional handsets, with a 3 1/2 inch antenna. Sending a signal to a low-orbit satellite requires a tiny fraction of the power to send a signal to current communications satellites, which orbit 50 times higher above the earth's surface.
Motorola's strategic electronics division, which Mr. Hillis used to run, has produced communications equipment for virtually all NASA space programs. The company's equipment helped relay the first words from the Moon to the earth in 1969.
Motorola has not assembled a working handset because none of the necessary satellites have been launched, but the company says it has no doubt that it can mass produce the handsets, Mr. Bertiger said. It is common practice for Motorola and other communications companies not to miniaturize components for working handsets until the equipment to use them has been built..
 
Confident on Costs
Motorola has held discussions with three companies that build satellites and with satellite launching companies like the Orbital Sciences Corporation in Fairfax, Va., he added, and has confidence in its cost estimates. Depending on the rockets chosen, the satellites will be launched individually or in groups of 11.
Regulatory decisions will be crucial in determining the number of subscribers that Iridium can reach. It will require certain frequencies and will need permission from a number of governments to receive - although not to send - calls from their soil, Mr. Hillis said.
Motorola has signed joint study agreements with three major institutions that control the necessary frequencies over much of the earth's surface: the International Maritime Satellite Organization, better known as Inmarsat; the American Mobile Satellite Corporation in Washington, which controls these frequencies over the United States, and Telesat Mobile in Ottawa.

HEADLINE: Quebec and Ottawa Forage for a New Relationship

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, June 25

 BODY:
With the collapse of a deal that would have given special constitutional status to Quebec, the national Government and its provincial counterpart in Quebec City have begun to develop a new working relationship, although no one in either capital is prepared to say where it may lead.
Premier Robert Bourassa of Quebec said today that he expected a ''period of reflection'' over the province's future in Canada to end next March, when Quebec's ruling Liberal Party is to hold a convention and adopt a new constitutional program.
Many in Canada expect that program to involve a far-reaching loosening of the Canadian confederation, possibly a pursuit by Quebec of a form of political sovereignty that would allow it to maintain economic ties with the rest of Canada.
But in the meantime, Mr. Bourassa has made it clear that his Government intends to approach Ottawa less as a province dealing with a national Government than as an equal partner with common interests. 
 
A More Relaxed View
Although the annual St. Jean-Baptiste parade through Montreal's streets turned into a march for independence today, with some in the crowd trampling on Canadian flags, Canadians generally seemed to be taking a more relaxed view of the failure of the constitutional accord.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney had warned of serious economic consequences if the pact were not ratified, but the financial markets took the development in stride, with the Canadian dollar slipping only slightly today against the United States currency.
Helping to ease some of the strain were remarks by Mr. Bourassa, who indicated that he intends to make no further challenge to the province's constitutional status before his party completes its review.
But the Quebec Premier continued to suggest that Canada was unlikely ever to be offered a settlement as ''open-minded and flexible'' as the one it had rejected. The major concession by the other nine provinces would have been a constitutional amendment designating Quebec as a ''distinct society,'' but two provinces, Manitoba and Newfoundland, withheld the unanimous consent required before a Saturday deadline.
 
Halt to Meetings of the 10
The first step in remolding the relationship between the federal Government and Quebec was signaled on Saturday, when Mr. Bourassa announced that the province would no longer routinely attend the so-called first ministers' conferences in which the leaders of the central Government and the 10 provinces decide issues of national importance.
Mr. Bourassa said his Government would in the future deal with such issues only in direct contacts with the national Government. Quebec will also be seeking ''additional powers'' on questions of immigration, communications and labor, he said, as part of ''the preparation of our future.''
To many here in the capital, the remarks suggested that Mr. Bourassa is subtly aligning himself with what is known as the two-nation concept of Canada, which envisions a partnership between predominantly French-speaking Quebec and an ''English'' Canada comprising the other nine provinces.
This view has historically been at odds with the prevailing vision of the English-speaking provinces and of traditional federalists in Quebec like former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau. They have viewed Canada as a country of 10 broadly equal provinces, with a national Government representing the interests of all citizens.
 
Mulroney Accepts Quebec's Stand
Although leaders of the national Government have in the past been wary of anything implying a special relationship with Quebec, Mr. Mulroney quickly accepted Mr. Bourassa's stand. The Prime Minister's chief aide on constitutional matters, Senator Lowell Murray, described Quebec's position as ''pretty moderate and constructive under the circumstances.''
As if to emphasize the national Government's readiness to accommodate the province, Mr. Mulroney told reporters in Quebec over the weekend that he had spoken with Mr. Bourassa and ''made important progress'' in turning over to the Quebec government some powers concerning immigration.
For opponents of the constitutional amendment that died over the weekend, Mr. Bourassa's latest moves seemed to confirm their fears of what designating Quebec as a ''distinct society'' would have meant. Nothing in the amendment ever specified what was meant by that phrase. Nor were any limits set in how far Quebec might have gone in seeking additional powers.
The uncertainty undermined the amendment's prospects in English-speaking Canada. While Mr. Mulroney argued that the amendment would not affect the powers of the national Government, Mr. Bourassa and his ministers had predicted that they would assume significant new authority from Ottawa.
 
Doing Without the Accord
In his remarks over the weekend, Mr. Bourassa made it clear that Quebec intends to seek those additional powers without the benefit of the amendment, first of all by seeking some ''administrative'' arrangements with the Mulroney Government.
In another expression of his sympathy with Quebec over the collapse of the accord, Mr. Mulroney said that he was canceling all of his meetings with the 10 premiers, including one scheduled for August in Winnipeg, the capital of Manitoba.
He acknowledged that indefinitely postponing the meetings would mean halting progress on issues that are considered crucial by the rest of Canada, including demands for reform of the Canadian Senate and for broader rights for Indians and Eskimos.
Some of Mr. Mulroney's aides suggested privately that Indian leaders in Manitoba should have foreseen this blow when they blocked passage of the accord containing constitutional concessions to Quebec.
There has been speculation that Newfoundland may be punished for its role in killing the accord by a further delay in the national Government's support for a $4 billion development project in the Hibernia oilfield off the coast of the relatively poor island province.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Quebecers favoring independence from Canada waving provincial flags yesterday in the annual St. Jean-Baptiste parade in Montreal. (Shaney Komulaninen for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Quebec Official Tells Americans Investment in the Province Is Safe

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The Quebec provincial Government made a special effort yesterday to reassure American investors that the French-speaking province is a safe place for their money, despite the new uncertainty over Quebec's status in the Canadian federation.
The reassurance came from John Ciaccia, Quebec's Minister of International Affairs, who told investment bankers and corporate executives in New York that ''in terms of the economy, there really is no reason for Quebec to change what it has been doing.''
Among other gestures, Mr. Ciaccia was the host at a luncheon at the Americas Society in Manhattan at which he said Quebec remained dependent on markets in the United States and in neighboring Ontario. He said Quebec would still pursue an aggressive policy of increasing exports to the United States, including exports of its abundant hydroelectric power to New York and other states. 
The minister essentially brought the same calming message that Robert Bourassa, Quebec's Premier, had issued on Saturday, hours after the Meech Lake accord had failed to win ratification by all of Canada's nine other provinces. The accord would have recognized Quebec as a distinct society within Canada.
 
A Stronger Canadian Dollar
The bond, stock and currency markets also reacted yesterday as if the Meech Lake accord had been expected to fail. The Canadian dollar strengthened slightly from last Friday, to 84.95 United States cents. The prices of bonds issued by the Province of Quebec and by Hydro-Quebec, the huge hydroelectrical company owned by the province, closed essentially unchanged, and the Toronto Stock Exchange index fell just 16.56 points, to 3,474.16.
''The expectation that Meech Lake would fail was already so built into the market psychology that not much was likely to happen,'' said Robert Minion of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
But interest rates on the $60 billion in Quebec public bonds have risen by less than a percentage point above what they would have been if the Meech Lake controversy had never occurred, in the view of market experts. They now trade at nearly a percentage point above similar United States Treasury securities. The 10-year Quebec bond closed yesterday with a yield of about 9.45 percent.
 
Quebec's Credit Reaffirmed
Separately, Moody's Investors Service Inc., the bond-rating agency, issued a statement reaffirming the credit rating for Quebec Province, which has $27 billion in bonds outstanding, and for Hydro-Quebec, with $23 billion in publicly held debt, a big chunk of it in the United States.
The high-grade Aa3 rating has been in effect since 1986, and William Streeter, a Canadian specialist at Moody's, said, ''The province is on target with its financial objectives and its budget deficit has been shrinking.''

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Cheney Says Western Aid to Moscow Is a Mistake

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that it would be a mistake for Western nations to provide major economic assistance to Moscow because such aid would subsidize the Soviet military.
The West German Government announced on Friday that it would extend about $3 billion in bank credits to help bolster the Kremlin's faltering economic reforms. President Francois Mitterrand of France also suggested last week that Western aid would help Moscow deal with desperate economic problems. 
Although Mr. Cheney did not specifically criticize any nation, he assailed the idea of using economic aid to prop up Soviet reforms. His comments were generally consistent with current Administration policy but more pointed than remarks made by President Bush.
Mr. Bush indicated last week that the United States was not planning a major aid package, but he did not invoke the specter of the Soviet military.
 
A Growing Debate
Mr. Cheney's comments add to a growing debate in the West over aid to the Soviet Union. A senior Administration official said the issue would be taken up at the NATO summit meeting next week in London.
Meeting with reporters, Mr. Cheney argued that Moscow is still spending ''enormous amounts of its national wealth on military hardware'' despite a decline last year in its overall military spending. It is an argument that the Defense Secretary has made repeatedly in seeking to head off Congressional moves for sharp reductions in American military spending.
''If you get the West in the business of providing economic assistance while they are still engaged in this massive military expenditure, to some extent you are subsidizing that,'' Mr. Cheney said. ''I do not think that is very good policy.''
In their annual report to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, the C.I.A. and the Defense Intelligence Agency estimated that Moscow had cut military spending by 4 to 5 percent last year, the first such reduction since Mikhail S. Gorbachev became the Soviet leader. Mr. Gorbachev has said that Moscow plans to reduce military spending by 14.2 percent by January 1991.
 
A Pledge to Keep Cutting
The Soviet leader's personal adviser on military matters, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, recently told a Bush Administration official that Moscow would achieve the cuts by January and might even make greater reductions over that period. But even after such cuts, Soviet military spending will remain substantial.
Mr. Cheney argued today that providing economic assistance to the Soviet Union would ease pressure on the Kremlin to scale back the military. Such aid might also enable Moscow to delay painful economic reforms, he said, by temporarily improving the lot of Soviet consumers.

HEADLINE: Disposal of Mild Radioactive Waste To be Less Restricted in New Policy

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Mildly radioactive waste could be disposed of in municipal dumps or ordinary incinerators or even recycled into consumer products, under a new policy that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, plans to announce tomorrow.
Under current rules, most waste with detectable levels of radiation must be handled with special precautions and shipped to one of three licensed landfills in the country. The new policy would classify as ''below regulatory concern'' materials like gloves of laboratory workers, parts from decommissioned power plants and the carcasses of laboratory animals after experiments in which radioactive tracer elements were used.
Environmental groups and some scientists say that adopting a uniform policy is unwise and could result in public exposure to radiation if waste is recycled into toys, jewelry and other common objects. The Environmental Protection Agency says the new policy is too lenient and plans to issue a rule in two years that could override portions of it, adding stricter criteria on the maximum permissible dose from material recycled or disposed of without controls. 
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission says that the new policy will allow Federal and state inspectors to concentrate on more highly radioactive materials, resulting in increased safety. The policy would also cover how much radiation could remain after a nuclear plant is retired, which will be a common activity in decades to come.
 
More Time for 'Real Problems'
Kenneth M. Carr, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, has made the policy a high priority. ''If we are able to establish a list of things that we don't need to worry about as regulators, this would obviously give us more time to worry about - and deal with -real problems,'' he said in a speech this year to the American Nuclear Society, which includes industry and academic experts. If some activities carry a risk that is acceptably low, he said, it would be wasteful to add regulation to make it safer. ''Why pay for something one doesn't need?'' he said.
But he added that the new policy was sure to face opposition. ''We already have one strike against us,'' he said. ''The general public isn't comfortable with the notion of radioactivity.''
But opponents say that the commission is taking the wrong approach. ''They're making decisions about how to deal with radioactive waste on an economic basis, and not on grounds on what would be best for public health and safety,'' said Jonathan Becker of Public Citizen, an environmental group founded by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate.
Much of the argument comes down to philosophy, in a field in which it is assumed that no exposure is so small that it is harmless. In an early draft of the new policy, the commission said that an activity that increases the risk of death by one in 100,000 would be ''of little concern to most members of society.'' But, Public Citizen pointed out, if this were extrapolated to the entire population of the United States, it would come to 2,500 deaths.
 
Ambivalence in Nuclear Industry
Public Citizen and other groups have also expressed fear that once waste generators are allowed to send some material to municipal landfills without controls, it will be impossible to know what they are sending.
Experts say the policy could end the regulation of 30 percent of the waste volume, although it would contain under 1 percent of the radioactivity.
The nuclear utility industry, which is an intended beneficiary of the proposed policy, is ambivalent. It already has the right, under a 1985 law regulating low level waste, to petition the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for permission to dispose of slightly radioactive material in unregulated or less-regulated ways, but no utility has done so, in part for fear of public criticism.
''The proposal has a lot of technical merit,'' said Michael A. Mullen, a spokesman for the Duke Power Corporation, which operates seven nuclear reactors, ''but we also realize there are a lot of political and public relations considerations.''
In addition, said Mr. Mullen, the policy might not save much money, because licensed burial sites have high fixed costs. If less waste was dumped there, the cost per cubic foot would rise, he said.
 
Some Special Cases
Duke, however, has successfully petitioned North Carolina and South Carolina to bury two categories of waste inside the fence at its reactors. One covers filters that have accumulated small amounts of radioactivity and pieces of lightly contaminated metal. The other is sewage sludge from the plant, which has trace amounts of radioactive elements not found in municipal sewage, he said.
And in Texas, the Bureau of Radiation Control has allowed some radioactive materials that decay in a few months to go to sanitary landfills.
The Conference of radiation Control Program Directors, a national organization of state and local officials, has conditionally endorsed the new policy, but has said that ''unnecessary exposures from frivolous uses of radioactive material can be prevented.'' Uses in consumer products, including food, drugs, cosmetics, jewelry and toys, are ''without justification,'' the conference said.
 
E.P.A. More Cautious
The new policy, according to people who follow the Nuclear Regulatory Commission closely, is likely to state that disposal or reuses are permissible if they do not give any individual an annual dose above 10 millirem. A millirem is a measure of radiation absorbed by tissue, taking into account the difference in damage produced by various kinds of radiation. The average American gets a dose of about 360 millirem a year, most of it from radon gas, and some from man-made sources like X-rays, bomb fallout and airline flights. One coast-to-coast round-trip flight results in about 5 millirem of exposure.
The goal is that the sum of all exposures resulting from the new policy not exceed 100 millirem a year, but opponents say that if the activities are unregulated, this will be difficult to ascertain.
But the Environmental Protection Agency has proposed a standard from any given source of 4 millirem per year, rather than 10. And the National Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements, a panel of scientists that publishes radiation guides that are closely followed by radiologists, recommends that only activities producing a dose of 1 millirem be regarded as being too small to worry about. The chairman of the council, Dr. Warren Sinclair, said in an interview that adopting the new level as a blanket policy was unwise.

HEADLINE: Two Votes Show Public Is Wary of Tax Increases

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
When voters in California approved higher taxes on gasoline earlier this month, some political analysts said that the vote in the home state of the tax revolt signaled a shift in the national mood toward a new willingness to pay more for services.
But a week later, North Dakotans soundly rejected higher taxes for education. And measures to repeal, restrict or limit taxes will be on the ballot in at least seven states in November.
''People are still very wary about taxes,'' said Robert D. Ebel, director of public finance for the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, a nonpartisan group appointed by the President and Congress. ''I'd be very cautious about reading too much into the California gas tax vote.'' 
Indeed the votes in both states demonstrate the complicated and difficult landscape politicians must walk when the subject is taxes.
Mr. Ebel and others said the California vote, which approved higher gasoline taxes for highway improvements, was shaped by a specific concern, frustration over congested highways, and did not necessarily reflect a new attitude about taxes.
Some analysts said the California vote demonstrated that voters would approve higher taxes if the use was deemed worthy. Others said any effort to increase taxes must swim upstream, no matter what the program is.
 
Taxpayers 'Riled Up'
Kevin P. Phillips, a conservative political analyst, said there had been times when voters were willing to spend more on taxes, but not now.
''There is a sense among average Americans that, whatever the overall tax is, he or she is paying too much,'' Mr. Phillips said, adding that the common view is: '' 'If somebody can come up with a tax that falls on somebody else, fine. But not me.' ''
''What gets people further riled up,'' he added, ''is that not only does the average guy have to pay too much, but then they can't stand what the politicians do with the money. And then they read about the billions lost in this savings and loan business. How can anybody have any respect for a managerial process that involves that?''
Despite a perception that taxes have decreased since Ronald Reagan took office, taxes as a percentage of the gross national product have increased, to 36.4 percent from 34.1 percent since 1980, according to the Intergovernmental Advisory Commission. The percentage taken by the Federal Government has remained stable: 20.6 percent in 1980 as against 20.7 percent last year.
But the percentage of state and local taxes has grown, a consequence of the Reagan Administration's shifting many responsibilities from the Federal level. Since 1980, state and local taxes have risen to 15.7 percent of the G.N.P., from 13.5 percent.
''We're coming to the limit of what people can pay for government,'' said Marshall Taylor, a spokesman for the National Taxpayers Union Foundation, a conservative anti-tax group. ''Politicians will be making a mistake if they read the California vote as an indication that people want higher taxes.''
''Let's look at the evidence,'' he said. ''Five states rejected tax increases last November'' - North Dakota, Michigan, Washington, Louisiana and Pennsylvania - ''and none approved one.''
Mr. Taylor said North Dakota's vote against higher sales taxes last week reflected the nation's mood more closely than did California's. North Dakota, whose three representatives are Democrats, is a comparatively high tax state.
 
Ballot Issues in November
States that are expected to have ballot questions on tax limitation measures this November include Illinois, Colorado, Massachusetts, Nevada, Oregon, California and Utah.
The Massachusetts measure would repeal a 15 percent state income tax increase imposed last year.
In Colorado, voters will be asked whether to set ceilings on property taxes. Nevadans, who do not have a personal income tax, will vote on a proposed constitutional amendment to ban such a tax.
An Oregon proposal would cap property tax assessments at $15 per $1,000 of assessed valuation to finance public schools and at $10 per $1,000 for all other government functions.
In California, a proposed measure would require that all state or local taxes earmarked for a specific purpose receive a two-thirds vote of the people or a two-thirds vote of both houses of the Legislature to become law. Taxes for general use would have to get a majority vote of the people or a two-thirds vote of both houses of the Legislature.
In Utah, a measure would exempt food from the state sales tax. In Illinois, an amendment would require a 60 percent vote in both chambers of the State Legislature to raise any taxes.
 
Politicians Wary of Reactions
Mr. Taylor said few politicians in Washington or elsewhere were willing to call for higher taxes, in part because they fear the wrath of voters and fear giving their opponents ammunition against them.
In Illinois, for example, both the Republican and Democratic nominees for governor have endorsed the proposed measure to limit taxes.
''People seem to be more willing to pay taxes when they know exactly what it's going for - sewers, parks,'' said Mr. Ebel. ''On the other hand, they are not so willing to pay taxes without strings attatched.''
Property taxes are now viewed as the least fair tax, according to a survey by the Intergovernmental Commission. Because Federal aid has been cut so deeply, local and state governments have had to raise taxes, even to maintain the status quo in terms of services.
''People aren't stupid,'' said Mr. Ebel. ''On the state and local level, they are aware that they are paying for more, but not getting more.

HEADLINE: Stinginess on Baby Food Will Cost Dearly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Cutting off the food supply of pregnant women and babies, as is happening now to the WIC program (which stands for women, infants and children) is most repugnant (editorial, June 5).
The program has reached only half the eligible population anyway. The 7.4 million high-risk mothers and babies who do not receive the milk, cheese, orange juice and cereal they need are being joined now by people dropped from the rolls as a result of the increase in cost of baby-food supplements that Ross Laboratories, Mead Johnson and Wyeth have enacted almost simultaneously. This increase is not compensated for by an increase in Federal or state funds.
Work done at Tufts University and elsewhere shows that every dollar not spent on the WIC program costs at least $3 in health expenditures ultimately. WIC costs $30 a month per mother. A day in intensive care for a baby born below weight as a result of undernutrition costs $1,000. If complications arise, the cost skyrockets. The lifetime care costs of a retarded person (more likely among babies born below weight) is more than $2 million.
Underfunding WIC is morally revolting and also economically stupid.
 
JEAN MAYER, J. LARRY BROWN
 Medford, Mass., June 6, 1990
The writer are, respectively, president of Tufts University and board chairman of Oxfam America.
