HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
European Watershed

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
The European Community is off and running, after nearly a generation of ''stagnation,'' to use Mikhail Gorbachev's word for an unproductive era.
The momentum began with the Single Act in 1987, after Mr. Gorbachev's arrival but before any clarity about the impact of his changes. Even then, there was a sense of a race against time, whether the Community could coalesce into an effective power before its magnetism brought so many applicants that it would dissolve into a mere club of nations.
Last year the collapse of the Soviet empire and the inevitable reunification of Germany threatened to leave Western Europe on the slow track. But the very threat, especially the question of whither a big new Germany, acted as a spur. Now the Community is catching up. 
Even Britain's recalcitrant Margaret Thatcher has implicitly conceded that she can't stop the rush to ''European Union.'' It's still taboo to call it a united states of Europe, Jean Monnet's vision when he promoted the Common Market two generations ago. But President Mitterrand of France now says flatly the goal is ''federal.''
With the push here for political and economic union by 1993, including foreign policy, security policy, currency and a central bank, Europe is moving from the stage of America's Continental Congress toward a constitutional convention.
It's breathtaking, even though it's coming in technical accords without the soaring rhetoric of America's Founding Fathers. The Europeans will have to write their preamble after they've haggled out the articles and clauses of their future constitution. But that's the way they're going.
Disintegration of the East has been a major influence. Distinct internal factors in East and West created the conditions for this new tide of history, but they have reinforced each other. There's even a risk of tidal wave. West Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, seems to be carried away. There's no question of his dedication to integration in the European Community and NATO, to make a ''European Germany'' and not a ''German Europe,'' as his Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, puts it.
But he has got the idea that it requires him and his allies to be Mikhail Gorbachev's safety net in the Soviet leader's high-wire dance to economic reform. Mr. Kohl's argument, supported by Mr. Mitterrand, is that Mr. Gorbachev's will to reform made everything else possible, so he should be rewarded and supported lest a failure put all the gains into question.
Mr. Mitterrand calls it a chicken and egg question, arguing that the reforms won't work without Western help, so the West would defeat its own interest by telling Mr. Gorbachev to reform first and collect later. This is a highly dubious proposition on many counts, including the simple notion that a pledge of widespread Western aid would bring Mr. Gorbachev safe transit across his perils.
Even if the sentiment appeals, there is little idea how Western aid could be absorbed in the way Mr. Kohl insists is necessary. Soviet economists who are reformers say their system isn't yet capable of digesting huge inflows productively.
The profound economic and social changes the Soviets need are certainly painful. But it will do them no service to help postpone the hard decisions. It's understandable that Mr. Gorbachev appealed to Mr. Kohl for sympathy, as the German Chancellor informed his European partners. And, as he said with surprising candor, it's understandable and reasonable that Mr. Kohl decided Bonn should pay up to win Moscow's support for a Germany in NATO.
But delay is now Mr. Gorbachev's main enemy. He shouldn't be encouraged to waffle any longer. The aid issue will come up at the seven-nation summit meeting in Houston next month. On that, President Bush will be right to side with Mrs. Thatcher against throwing money at the Soviet morass until there is better evidence it can be properly used.
The Soviets must not be excluded from Europe, but neither can they simply be bought in. Conditions for Eastern Europe on aid to make sure investment works also must apply to Moscow. And every success in Eastern Europe will add hope, impetus and opportunity to the Soviets.
Nobody outside can assure Mr. Gorbachev's success, let alone the transformation of the Soviet Union, which is much more important. The construction of a solid Western Europe is the best assurance that the Continent won't revert to the self-destructive fragments of its past, and the way to give heart and example to the East. History can move.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: A Poll Shows Less Pessimism Among Blacks

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
Six months after David N. Dinkins was inaugurated as Mayor, black New Yorkers are sharply less pessimistic than white or Hispanic New Yorkers about their city's future, according to a New York Times/ WCBS-TV News Poll.
The divergence of views since Mr. Dinkins's election contrasts starkly with 17 years of results of polls on New York City's future. Not since the end of the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay in the early 1970's have blacks been less pessimistic than whites about the city's future.
Now, the poll shows, white and Hispanic residents are growing more pessimistic in their vision of New York after the turn of the next century, but blacks have adopted a more hopeful view.
 
Most Important Issues
Despite the divergence among blacks and whites about the city's prospects, for the first time in nearly a decade New Yorkers mentioned race relations as the second most important issue facing their Mayor, rivaling crime and homelessness. Drugs were seen as the most important issue for the second year in a row. 
Fifty-six percent of all New Yorkers polled approved of Mayor Dinkins's job performance, according to the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points and was based on telephone interviews with 1,047 adults from June 17 to June 20. Virtually all the interviews were completed before the enthusiastic reception in New York for Nelson Mandela.
Mayor Dinkins's approval rating is significantly higher than the rating that former Mayor Edward I. Koch received at this time last year, but is not as high as Mr. Koch's peak rating a month after he was elected to a second term in 1981.
 
'Would Like to Do Better'
In an interview at City Hall yesterday, Mayor Dinkins characterized the outlook of New Yorkers as ''gloomy'' but predicted that the pessimism would diminish as his administration worked to improve economic conditions and race relations.
''I would like to do better,'' the Mayor said when told that 56 percent of those polled approved of his performance. ''I'm pleased that the assessment of our efforts has met with this much approval.''
More than three-fourths of blacks, half of the Hispanic respondents and slightly less than half of the whites rated Mr. Dinkins's job performance favorably. In comparison, 59 percent of New York City residents approved of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's performance.
While the poll could not conclusively connect the divergence in pessimism among blacks and others to the election of Mayor Dinkins, there were indications that general attitudes can be influenced by the occupant of Gracie Mansion.
Blacks who approved of Mayor Dinkins were almost twice as likely to be optimistic about the city's future as whites who approved of him. And in follow-up interviews after the poll was concluded, some black New Yorkers attributed their rosier view of the city's future to the election of Mr. Dinkins. But others cited world events ranging from the decline of Communism in Eastern Europe to the release of Mr. Mandela after 27 years in prison in South Africa.
While the presence of a black mayor seemed to have some influence on general feelings about the future, the poll also disclosed skepticism about whether a black mayor makes a difference in the way black people are treated. Two-thirds or more of each race said it did not have much effect.
Last year, when New Yorkers were asked in a similar poll which issues they wanted the city to concentrate on first, race relations was barely mentioned as a critical issue. But in the aftermath of the murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Bensonhurst, the boycott of a Korean grocer and other well-publicized racial incidents in the region, problems caused by such tensions clearly worry New Yorkers.
 
'I'm Frightened'
''Black and white, that's all you hear all day long, and I'm frightened,'' said a 56-year-old white woman from Staten Island who asked not to be identified by name. In a follow-up interview after the poll, she added: ''I'm frightened to go out the door. Blacks hate us. The city will be worse in 10 or 15 years, and I feel that race relations is the thing doing it.''
A black retired Housing Authority police officer said: ''Each race is guilty of disliking another race for no basic reason. We've got to stop. It will take a long time, but I think we are learning.''
Almost three-fifths of those polled said they would, if it were entirely up to them, move out of the city in the next four years. The reasons cited are crime, congestion, expense and the needs of children.
 
'No Improvement'
''I have made up my mind that I am leaving New York,'' said a retired professor at a New York City college who was among those polled and identified himself as white. ''I came here as a student in the 1950's and I loved New York for many years.''
''But I've been mugged four times,'' said the professor, who gave Mayor Dinkins a favorable job rating. ''I've seen no improvement in the quality of life in the last five to six years. I don't think Dinkins is going to help.''
When asked about Mr. Dinkins's handling of relations between blacks and whites, more than two-thirds of all New Yorkers polled approved of his actions. While both white and Hispanic New Yorkers gave the Mayor high marks for race relations, blacks gave him the highest rating, with 83 percent.
''We so seldom get into a position to be mayor of a big city,'' said a black woman polled who supports the Mayor. ''Some of our people are so relieved and glad that he's in, they expect magic. The Mayor tried to bring people together in Bensonhurst, and while it didn't work, he tried.
 
'To Make Things Better'
''There are so many people out there who are trying to do good things for their communities, for their neighborhoods, to make things better, and Mayor Dinkins is one of them,'' she said.
Among blacks interviewed, poor race relations were seen as underpinning problems facing blacks and others in the city, ranging from crime to drugs to housing shortages to poor education.
''If we get race relations settled, then we will solve the crime problem settled because a lot of what is going on is economic,'' said the retired Housing Authority police officer.
Not all blacks said it was the Mayor's election that caused greater optimism. A part-time teacher who is black said her optimism was based on dramatic changes in human rights that she has seen around the world.
 
'Gives Me Hope'
''The destruction of the Berlin Wall, Nelson Mandela's release, this all gives me hope that things I thought would never change can change,'' she said.
But another city resident who was polled disagreed and also disapproved of Mayor Dinkins's performance. The man, a white marketing manager for a publishing company, said he believed that Mr. Dinkins had given in to political and special interests, especially concerning blacks.
''I think he has buckled under to political interests,'' the marketing manager said. ''Take the visit of Mandela to New York. When the Puerto Rican extremists were denied a place in the proceedings, there was criticism of the Mayor, and he knuckled under.''
The poll cited areas of agreement among racial groups as well. By a 2-to-1 ratio, both black and white New Yorkers said they preferred cuts in city spending to increases in taxes.
 
How Poll was Conducted
The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from June 17 to June 20 with 1,047 adults in all parts of New York City. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The basic sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
To reach a larger number of black New Yorkers and make possible more reliable analysis of their opinions, additional random telephone numbers were also screened and additional black respondents were interviewed. The results were then weighted to reflect the actual racial composition of the city's adult population.
The results were also weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, sex and age.
In theory, in 19 of 20 cases the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by interviewing all adult New Yorkers.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for the 484 whites it is plus or minus 4 percentage points. For the 408 blacks, it is plus or minus 5 percentage points. For the 183 Hispanic respondents it is plus or minus 7 percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Black Men: Are They Imperiled?

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
One by one they took the microphone yesterday. Men and women, academicians and politicians, entrepreneurs and former convicts, they told the Harlem audience the same thing: black men are an endangered species.
The occasion was the first of several planned statewide public hearings about black men sponsored by the New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus. 
The caucus formed a task force focusing on black men after a study released in February showed that almost one of every four young black males is behind bars or on probation or parole. The study, based on Justice Department data, was done by a group called the Sentencing Project.
The hearing attracted more than 700 people to the Apollo Theater and explored a laundry list of problems including high rates of homicide, incarceration and joblessness. The hearing, which was broadcast live on WLIB-AM, also looked at solutions like alternative schools and job training.
''We're being broadcast all over the metropolitan area today and I think it will generate in the minds of black men that they have to be more involved in saving themselves and the black family,'' said Assemblyman Albert Vann, Democrat of Brooklyn, chairman of the 25-member legislative caucus.
 
'Devastating Our Men'
Vivian Gordon, a professor of African-American studies at the State University of New York in Albany and a specialist on the black family, said: ''I believe black men are a hunted and endangered species. You kill off the male and leave the woman vulnerable and without a partner. They have done everything to devastate us by devastating our men.''
In New York State, the number of black men in prison grew by 80 percent between 1970 and 1986, nine points higher than the national average. In New York City, black men have an unemployment rate 2.5 times higher than white men.
Other studies show that homicide is the leading cause of death among black men under 25 - 10 times higher than for white men - and that the suicide rate among young black men has increased yearly. Black men under 45 years old are 10 times more likely than whites to die of hypertension and have a 45 percent higher rate of lung cancer.
Walter W. Stafford, a professor of urban planning and public administration at New York University, said he found it ''astounding'' that in the last decade six black men in New York City have died from race-related violence.
''Today's meeting was a beginning,'' Dr. Stafford said. ''Blacks have been in New York since 1626 and these problems are not new but no one has been addressing them.''

HEADLINE: The Struggle to Revise Hospital Reimbursements

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 25

 BODY:
Few people in Albany truly understand, or want to understand, the complex formula that regulates the financing of New York's struggling hospitals.
But buried beneath the technocratic lingo about diagnostic related groups and service intensity weights lies a critical debate about how the state should use its significant regulatory power to speed the evolution of its crippled health-care system.
To that end, legislative negotiators have been struggling to devise a new hospital reimbursement formula to replace the one that expires at the end of the year.
The current reimbursement formula, which controls the rates hospitals are paid by Medicaid, Blue Cross/Blue Shield and private insurers, has contributed to hospital deficits estimated at more than $1 billion last year. In its three-year lifetime, it has done little to offset the fiscal burdens caused by AIDS, crack, a severe nursing shortage and increasing labor costs. 
 
Carrot and Stick
In recent years, New York State has used its hospital reimbursement formula as both a carrot and a stick to prod the state's medical institutions into shifting the delivery of primary and preventive care from crowded hospital emergency rooms to outpatient clinics. But if the red ink and chaotic conditions at many New York hospitals is any indication, the health-care system is not changing quickly enough.
The State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, concedes that ''there have been more failures than successes'' in the state's effort to redesign the health-care system.
''We have depended on the willingness of the institutions to initiate what we perceive to be in their interests without having a lot of governmental intervention,'' he said. ''But I don't think the incentives have been sufficient to force the change in behavior.''
Few lawmakers, or even hospital executives, say they disagree with Dr. Axelrod's vision of a decentralized health-care system in which primary and preventive care is provided in the community by family physicians and storefront clinics.
But many in Albany believe the Commissioner's vision is utopian. They argue that the hospital system has been bleeding to death while Dr. Axelrod battles to change it. And with the Bush Administration pushing for substantial cuts in Medicare financing, they warn that the system could collapse without immediate help.
''We can't stop investing in hospitals while waiting for paradise,'' the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, said earlier this year. ''Paradise is still lost.''
When translated into the nitty-gritty of legislative negotiation, the debate outlined by Dr. Axelrod and Mr. Miller has become an issue of dollars.
With the Legislature expected to adjourn early next week, negotiators must reach an agreement on how much money should be used to bail out the hospitals with an infusion of inpatient dollars and how much should be used as an incentive for the hospitals to expand outpatient services.
The negotiators, mostly aides to Mr. Miller and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, already know how much money will be spent on the reimbursement system. The question is where it will go.
Included in this year's budget is $13 million for a new reimbursement formula that will cover the last quarter of the state's fiscal year. Because that money determines how much is spent by the Federal and local governments on Medicaid financing, and because it determines reimbursement rates paid by private insurers, the $13 million actually translates into an annual infusion of about $500 million.
 
Making Technical Adjustments
That money comes in addition to $500 million the hospitals will receive from a normal inflationary adjustment.
The state can direct that money where it wants by making technical adjustments in the reimbursement formula. For instance, it can compensate hospitals that have the most challenging caseloads of AIDS patients or the most difficulty recruiting nurses. To encourage hospitals to provide more outpatient care, it can raise the inadequate $60-a-visit reimbursement cap for trips by Medicaid recipients to outpatient clinics.
Because less than half of New York's hospitals lost money last year, those on all sides of the reimbursement debate believe the money should be directed to the hospitals in the worst condition, rather than distributed equally across the board.
Dr. Axelrod and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have led the charge for significant increases in outpatient rates, suggesting that the $13 million be divided by allocating $7 million for inpatient services and $6 million for outpatient services. Both houses of the Legislature prefer a formula that directs more money to inpatient services.
Because hospital employees and patients form vital constituent groups in most legislative districts, their political influence can be great. The state's hospital associations have mounted sophisticated lobbying campaigns and have supplied much of the technical know-how to the negotiators. Health-care workers pitched in two weeks ago by staging the largest rally in Albany since the Vietnam War.
The business community has used newspaper advertisements and mailings to argue that the bulk of the money should go to outpatient services, which would lessen the cost to private insurers.

HEADLINE: Japan Eyes Space With Uncertainty, And Confusion

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
TWENTY years after its first tentative steps into space, Japan has formulated ambitious plans but remains mired in confusion over whether it wants to seek a world leadership role in space.
In the laboratories of Japan's biggest space research center, scientists are already putting together mock-ups of a proposed compact space shuttle named Hope, an unmanned, reusable and low-cost vehicle to shuttle equipment between Earth and the American space station.
At a competing space agency devoted to scientific experiments, scientists are putting the final touches on a plan, to be proposed this month, to burrow seismic probes into the crust of the Moon, part of a broad study into the makeup of the Moon's core.
Next month some of this country's biggest industrial powers are forming a consortium to get Japan into the commercial launching business, betting that Japan will finally straighten out the problems that have plagued its powerful new H-II rocket, the first to be developed here without American help.
Industrial visionaries have their own grand dreams: a Japanese-built lunar base camp, complete with its own concrete manufacturing plant, or - for Japanese tourists who are tiring of Hawaii - the solar system's first space resort, a hotel that would spin 200 miles above the Earth. 
But the announcements and ideas, Japanese scientists concede, are closer to a wish list than a national project. Despite its remarkable technological powers and ability to launch enormously successful government-industry projects, Japan is entering its third decade of space activities more confused than ever about where to proceed next, and deeply uncertain whether it wants to commit the money or scarce talent needed to turn the world's second-largest economy into a spacefaring nation.
When Japan announces similarly futuristic plans in electronics, supercomputing, automobiles and pharmaceuticals, they become instant grist for anxious Congressional hearings about American competitiveness and books about Japanese industrial conspiracies. But space remains what one senior Government official here calls ''the Japanese anomaly.''
Unable to define its goals clearly, the space program has largely failed to fire the imagination of the technologically literate Japanese public. Over the last nine years, the country's $900 million space budget has barely budged; last year the Sony Corporation alone spent more on research and development than the entire country spent on space activities. Although the Government last year endorsed for the first time the goal of starting a Japanese manned space program, politicians and scientists alike are deeply reluctant. Too Close to the U.S.? And increasingly, there are questions, seldom voiced publicly, but never far from the surface, about whether Japan made a major error when it decided to link its own fortunes in space so deeply with the American plan to build a space station, a project that now appears troubled.
Officially, Japan's position is that the country owes the United States a tremendous debt for the technology that has gotten the country into space at all, and could hardly turn away now. ''When we began we were quite behind the United States and the Soviet Union, and in many ways we still are,'' said Masato Yamano, the president of the National Space Development Agency of Japan, known here as Nasda and closely patterned after its near-namesake in the United States. ''It would have been too time consuming, too money consuming and too manpower consuming to develop our program without international help.''
But now, Mr. Yamano said in a recent interview at the agency's offices in central Tokyo, ''we are at something of a crossroads, and we have a lot of decisions ahead of us.''
To many Japanese, the country's space program is another example of Japan's continuing trouble with big research projects that have no immediate industrial application and a symbol of its reluctance to pour money into science for science's sake.
But to some Americans who monitor Japan's technological efforts, the Japanese space effort's cautious, plodding approach is deceptively innocuous. Over time, they say, Japan may turn its aversion to manned space exploration into a commercial strength, using its growing expertise in satellite electronics, low-cost launchings and unmanned space experiments to profitable ends.
It was exactly such fears that led the United States to demand an end earlier this year to a Japanese Government-sponsored project to develop Japanese communication satellites. The American objection was that the satellite project, which Japan described as an experimental effort to improve technology, would turn into a commercial product that would compete with private satellite makers in the United States.
 
Confusion and Competition
Americans and Japanese both seem confused over the goals and structure of Japan's space effort. From the start, there has been not one space program here, but two. The biggest, commanding over 80 percent of the budget, is run by Nasda, an arm of the Science and Technology Agency. It is responsible for launching Japan's communication satellites and building its biggest space vehicles, from the H-II liquid-fuel rocket to the Japan Experiment Module, an orbital laboratory and prototype manufacturing facility that is Tokyo's main contribution to the space station Freedom.
Nonetheless, the program that has attracted the most praise in recent years was mounted by Nasda's rival, the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science, a 35-year-old scientific center that began as an offshoot of the University of Tokyo. Today it is financed by the powerful Education Ministry, though by law its work is restricted to purely scientific research, and even the size of its rockets is limited by legislation passed in the Japanese Parliament in a roundabout effort to keep the institute from competing in rocketry with Nasda.
It was the institute that launched a successful probe in 1986 to meet Halley's Comet, a feat the United States never attempted. And it was the institute that, to Nasda's chagrin, attracted big headlines here three months ago when it made Japan the third nation, after the United States and the Soviet Union, to launch a Moon mission.
As Moon missions go, it was extraordinarily modest, befitting an agency with a budget of only $150 million a year. A satellite not much bigger than a football was propelled into lunar orbit by one of the small, inexpensive Nissan solid-fuel rockets that have become a symbol of the institute's no-frills approach to space science. In the enthusiasm over the launching, people hardly noticed that the probe's data transmitter died mysteriously as soon as it got within range of the Moon.
 
Leaner, Lighter, Brighter
''It didn't really matter,'' said Jun Nishimura, the institute's president. ''The mission proved that we will be able to put sensors on the Moon.''
Under a new accord struck last year, the institute will be allowed to slightly increase the diameter, and thus the thrust, of its rockets to 2.5 meters, or eight feet. That can propel a payload of roughly 1,200 pounds to the Moon. But Dr. Nishimura and others say that such restrictions, while seemingly ridiculous, have actually forced the institute to stay lean and efficient.
''We should take a lesson from the Japanese who are now flying one space science mission every year,'' Freeman Dyson, a noted physicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., wrote not long ago. ''Their resources are limited, their spacecraft are small, and they are doing good science.''
Dr. Nishimura argues that in an age dominated by big science, the institute's path is an attractive alternative. ''We have been able to preserve our university nature and do advanced missions, with advanced technology,'' said Dr. Nishimura. ''Unlike Nasda, we are not tied to the American space program, so we can be more flexible.''
 
Weighed Down by Space Station
Flexible is hardly the word to describe Nasda, and that is the biggest problem facing Japan's space program today. A huge portion of the agency's funds over the next decade is committed to the Japan Experiment Module, and thus to the fate of the American space station. Meanwhile, the rest of Nasda's budget is virtually frozen as the country struggles with the question of whether to abandon its step-by-step approach and plunge into manned space flight.
''The agency itself is very enthusaistic,'' said Professor Atsuhiro Nishida, a top official of the Institute of Space and Astronautical Science and one of Japan's leading space scientists. ''But without manned activity, the amount of money that can be spent is limited. And everyone is very cautious about manned activity.''
The initial idea was that the Japan Experiment Module would ease Japan's entry into manned space. Three astronauts, two men and one woman, have been intensively trained here in recent years. Several months ago the oldest of them, 42-year-old Mamoru Mohri, was chosen to fly a future mission aboard the American space shuttle.
 
U.S. Actions 'Quite Annoying'
But Japan's participation in the space station program has been rocky at best. Though the United States officially refers to Japan as one of its international partners, Japanese officials say they have been repeatedly surprised by American announcements that the station was being re-designed or ''rephased.''
Part of Japan's discomfort arises from the fact that almost all of Nasda's plans are dependent on the success of the American space station. The Hope shuttle, which would be launched atop the new H-II rocket, is designed to fly to a space station in need of regular resupply. It would dock with the station, and astronauts or robotic arms aboard the station would unload it. Under commands from the ground, the shuttle would return and land like a plane operating on automatic pilot.
The H-II rocket itself has been the source of continuing troubles for Nasda, problems that in many ways grow out of the country's constitutional ban on offensive weapons. The United States, the Soviet Union and China got their start in heavy-lift rockets by developing intercontinental ballistic missiles. Japan has none, and until the H-II, it licensed most technology from the United States.
 
Problems With the H-II Rocket
Now that they are finally building their own rockets, the Japanese are discovering technological problems that other nations worked out long ago. Until a few months ago no one could make the complex turbopump on the liquid-fuel engine of the H-II work properly; twice it blew up in static tests at Nasda's space launching facilities on Tanegashima Island. The problem appears solved, but the H-II has been delayed at least a year, to 1993.
By that time, Japan will probably be too late toenter the commercial space launching business successfully, as some countries did after the 1986 Challenger disaster grounded payloads headed for the space shuttle. Moreover, tiny production volumes make the H-II very expensive. Japan expects to launch only one or two a year, in part because local fishermen at Tanegashima Island have barred launchings for all but 90 days each year. Rockets, they say, endanger their boats and scare the fish.

HEADLINE: In Marks of Ancient Bit, Clues to Earliest Riders

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
STRAIGHT from the horse's mouth, archeologists have learned that humans probably became equestrians at least 6,000 years ago, much earlier than previously thought. The finding could mean that horseback riding, not the invention of the wheel as most scholars have thought, was the first significant innovation in human land transport.
An analysis of the wear made by ancient bridle bits on a stallion's tooth has led Dr. David W. Anthony, an archeologist at Hartwick College in Oneonta, N.Y., to conclude that the partnership between horse and human that made possible the exploits of the feudal knights, Mongols and American Plains Indians, not to mention Secretariat, began on the steppes of the Ukraine in about 4000 B.C. The first known horsemen, he said, came from a Copper Age society called the Sredni Stog culture that lived on the grasslands along the Dnieper River.
Using a scanning electron microscope, Dr. Anthony and his colleague, Dorcas R. Brown, another archeologist, detected distinctive beveling and some tiny scratches on premolar teeth from a horse found buried at a Sredni Stog site 120 miles south of Kiev. The dental marks, he concluded, were identical to the wear on teeth of modern horses that are ridden, but not among wild horses. 
This is the first direct evidence for horseback riding by such an ancient human society, Dr. Anthony reported recently at the International Conference of Archeozoology in Washington. He said the early horsemen used a rope bit. Four radiocarbon dates show the site, known as Dereivka, to be 6,000 years old. ''I don't see how I could be wrong,'' Dr. Anthony said in an interview. ''One horse - that's our evidence. But it's very clearly been ridden.''
Kathleen Ryan, an archeozoologist at the University of Pennsylvania, said Dr. Anthony's conclusions were plausible and based on ''a very careful study.'' She said some other experts would probably not accept the interpretation until it can be corroborated by evidence from more than a single horse.
Anthropologists said the dental evidence, if confirmed, represented strong support for Soviet scholars who have for several decades contended that people were riding horses on the Eurasian steppes as early as 4000 B.C., about 2,500 years earlier than usually assumed. They based their belief on indirect evidence at Sredni Stog sites, such as perforated antler tines that could have been cheek pieces for a horse's bit and carved horse-head effigies with indications of a bridle.
Most scholars in Europe and the United States have adhered to the standard view that horseback riding began some 3,500 years ago in Central Asia and was introduced soon after into the civilization of Mesopotamia. Their interpretations were derived from clay figurines of riders on horses and horse-drawn war chariots.
Examination of skeletons indicated that the horse was domesticated even earlier but was initially used only as a source of food. Cuneiform texts show that the wheel, at first only solid wooden disks, was introduced in Mesopotamia about 5,000 years ago. Its first use was in ox-drawn carts.
 
The Horse in Human History
Fixing the time and place of the earliest horseback riding is considered important in the study of human culture, Ms. Ryan said, because it gave people ''much greater mobility, which made big differences in military tactics and where people settled.'' Dr. Andrew Sherratt of Oxford University's Ashmolean Museum and Dr. Sandor Bokonyi of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences recently described the profound changes the innovation had on trade and settlement patterns, communications and warfare.
''Horses can double or triple the distances humans can travel in a day,'' Dr. Anthony said. ''So this changes economic and social distances by a factor of three. Resources, markets, allies and enemies that had previously been beyond effective reach became reachable.''
With the cooperation of the Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, Dr. Anthony last year studied horse skeletons excavated at Dereivka. The telltale teeth were found with the skull, lower jaw and forelimbs of a stallion that had been buried in what archeologists call a ''ritual assemblage.''
The horse had been buried with two dogs and some ceramic human figurines, possibly indicating that this was no ordinary horse. Some antler pieces, similar to the cheek pieces used 2,000 years later as part of a Bronze Age horse harness, were found among the remains.
 
Strong Enough to Carry Men
The wear Dr. Anthony detected on the premolar teeth resembled that shown in recent X-ray studies of horses ridden with metal bits. A horse that habitually fights the bit will move it repeatedly onto the forward part of the chewing surface of its second premolar tooth. The slippage back and forth across the prow of the tooth causes the observed wear marks.
Soviet studies show that the Dereivka horses were stocky, large-headed animals that stood more than 12 hands high at the withers and had thick, robust legs. They probably resembled today's Przewalski horses and would certainly have been strong enough to bear a human's weight.
The teeth from some other horses at Dereivka had no such wear marks. But those skeletons were found in garbage mounds at the site and so were probably from animals that had been eaten, the archeologist concluded.
The teeth of wild horses from Nevada and the barrier islands off Virginia were also examined and found to have no comparable beveling and scratches, Dr. Anthony said.
 
Next, a Re-creation
As the next step, Dr. Anthony plans this summer to simulate primitive riding conditions with an unbroken horse using a bridle and rope bit crafted with materials similar to what might have existed 6,000 years ago. He will then take casts of the horse's teeth, examine them under a scanning electron microscope and compare them with teeth he has collected from several Eurasian sites.
Since the wear found on the Dereivka teeth corresponds to metal bit wear, Dr. Anthony said, it may be possible that a rope bit produces the same marks. Or it could be that the Sredni Stog people had copper bits. Some copper tools and ornaments have been excavated there.
If the Copper Age cultures of the Ukraine developed horseback riding, Dr. Anthony speculated, the horse could have been an agent in the spread of Indo-European, the mother tongue of nearly all European languages, from its supposed place of origin, which was probably on the Eurasian steppes about 6,000 years ago.

HEADLINE: Big Lessor Of Aircraft To Be Sold

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 25

 BODY:
The International Lease Finance Corporation, one of the largest airplane leasing companies, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by the American International Group Inc., an insurance company, in a $1.3 billion deal.
According to the agreement, shareholders of International Lease could receive $32.50 in cash for each of their shares or 50 cents in cash plus three-tenths of one American International common share.The company said the principals in International Lease, who own about 55 percent of outstanding shares, would elect to receive the stock to make their deal largely tax-free. Outside shareholders are expected to take the cash, which would be a taxable transaction. 
International Lease is the world's second-largest airplane leasing company, after the GPA Group Ltd. of Shannon, Ireland. The company has enjoyed tremendous growth in recent years as airlines have scrambled to obtain planes to replace aging fleets and to take advantage of a booming air-travel market.
 
Concern Over Financing
Company executives and industry analysts said International Lease, which is based in Beverly Hills, Calif., decided to sell because it was no longer confident it could raise the money it needed to expand.
''Having, as we call it, a 'Big Daddy' such as A.I.G. behind us solidifies the future of the company and results in a good transaction for all shareholders,'' said Louis L. Gonda, International Lease's executive vice president.
''We will be able to fulfill all of the acquisition plans we have without having to be very concerned about additional equity,'' Mr. Gonda added. ''The stock market has its uncertainties and our stock has historically fluctuated depending on factors that are entirely outside of our control, such as interest rates or issues that might affect the airline or aircraft or leasing industry.''
Daniel A. Hersh, an analyst at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles said that despite consistently good earnings, the company's stock has been trading at a low ebb recently, and the executives who control it, including Mr. Gonda; his father, Leslie L. Gonda, who is chairman, and Steven F. Udvar-Hazy, the president, had grown frustrated with the company's equity valuation.
''It's a high-debt company, and nobody wants those anymore,'' Mr. Hersh said. ''Also, a large short position had developed over fears of a credit crunch. Since only 45 percent of the company is in public hands, why not go with an institution that can bring them a low cost of funds?''
In over-the-counter trading today, the shares of International Lease closed down 50 cents each, to $27.125. American International shares dropped $2.375 each, to $96.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. The announcement of the deal was made here after the markets closed on the East Coast.
 
Aid to Diversification
In a statement, American International, which is based in New York, said the acquisition of International Lease would help it diversify.
''We think this is a superb addition to our range of financial services,'' said Edward E. Matthews, vice chairman of finance. ''With its worldwide business and our international focus, it's a very natural partnership.''
In addition, he said: ''Our equity will enhance International Lease's ability to raise funds. For any company that is relatively small and fast-growing, the question is always whether they can raise the equity they need to sustain growth.''
American International said it would finance the cash portion of the deal from internal sources. It said it would provide up to $125 million of new financing for International Lease.
International Lease said its management would remain in place and would continue to be based in California. $3 Billion in Planes The company's fleet of planes, which are typically leased to airlines for six to eight years, is worth more than $3 billion and includes about 100 aircraft, up from about 60 three years ago. The company's target is to build its portfolio to 350 aircraft by the middle of the decade.
At the moment, the company's backlog of orders from manufacturers is about $14 billion, and it has firm orders from airlines to lease its craft through 1995.

HEADLINE: BRIEFS

 BODY:
* Airbus Industrie, Paris, the European aircraft consortium, said Iraqi Airways would buy five of its A310-300 jets and would take options on five additional planes, for an undisclosed price.
* Apple Bancorp Inc., New York, said shareholders have been given until July 25 to tender their shares under the $38-a-share offer by Stanley Stahl. The offer had been due to expire yesterday. 
* Aviation Education Systems Inc., Huntington, L.I., an aviation career recruitment and training center, said it would purchase Barton ATC Inc., Murfreesboro, Tenn., an air control tower company, for an undisclosed amount.
* Centaur Partners Group, , said it had begun to solicit the proxies of stockholders of National Intergroup, Inc., Pittsburgh, a holding company, to elect Centaur's nominees as directors.
* C. Itoh & Co., Tokyo, a trading company, said it would set up a joint venture in Tokyo with PPG Industries of Pittsburgh, a glass manufacturer, in late July to market PPG's glass sheets in Japan. PPG-CI Co. Ltd., the joint venture, will be owned 51 percent by PPG and 49 percent by Itoh.
* Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, said Texas Instruments Inc., Dallas, planned to acquire its insurance investment business and related technology. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Texas Instruments said it was not a large transaction.
* Integrated Resources Inc., New York, said it had completed the sale of Learjet Corp., Wichita, Kan., an aircraft manufacturer, to a U.S. subsidiary of Bombardier Inc., Montreal, a maker of trains and train parts, for $75 million.
* Loewen Group Inc., Canada, a funeral services company, said it would buy the shares of Paragon Family Services Inc., Houston, an owner and operator of funeral homes, for $65.5 million.
* Material Sciences Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., a holding company, said it had hired William Blair & Co., Chicago, an investment banking firm, to investigate a possible sale of the company.
* Microsoft Corp., Redmond, Wash., said that sales of its Microsoft Windows Version 3.0 software had surpassed the company's sales projections and that it would extend and enhance its customer support services. Itoh, C.(C. Itoh)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Founder of Century Joins Citizens Utilities

 BODY:
The Citizens Utilities Company said yesterday that Leonard Tow had been named chairman and chief executive.
Mr. Tow, 60 years old, replaces two Citizens officials, Ishier Jacobson, the chief executive, who will step down on Sunday, and the former chairman, Richard L. Rosenthal, who retired last year.
Mr. Tow will keep his current position as chairman and chief executive of the Century Communications Corporation, which owns 65 cable television systems and 11 cellular telephone networks. Mr. Tow founded the company, which is based in New Canaan, Conn., in 1973. 
Since last year, when Mr. Rosenthal sold 2.2 percent of his Citizens stock to Century, Mr. Tow has been a member of the Citizens board.
Citizens, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is a diversified public utilities company with annual revenues of more than $320 million. Its established bases are gas, water and electric utilities, but it has recently entered into two cellular telephone partnerships.
Mr. Tow said in an interview yesterday that he would have no problem handling the job of head of both companies. He said he would act primarily as a guide for Citizens as it enters the telecommunications field.
''I don't intend to get my hands on all the details,'' he said. ''I believe Citizens has a tremendous future and has the capacity to grow, not only at its pace to date but at an even faster rate.''
Executives from both companies praised Mr. Tow. ''He has an extraordinary sense of business and a vision for what the company should do,'' said Century's president, Bernard Gallagher.
Mr. Tow said he had been tracking Citizens with great interest for 26 years and even applied to be Mr. Rosenthal's assistant in 1965. ''I didn't get the job,'' he said. ''I guess I wasn't qualified.''
Mr. Tow graduated from Brooklyn College and earned a master's degree and doctorate in economics and economic geography from Columbia University. Before entering the telecommunications industry, he taught at Brooklyn and Hunter colleges and at the school of business at Columbia. He has been married for 38 years and has three children, all of whom work in the cable television business.

HEADLINE: Mid-June Vehicle Sales Dropped 3.9%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 25

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks fell 3.9 percent in mid-June, as demand for new vehicles failed to break out of the sluggish pattern that began last fall.
Manufacturers reported selling 212,655 cars in the mid-June period, a decline of 4.6 percent from a year earlier. Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.7 million, ahead of the 6.4 million rate posted for early June, but lagging behind the rate of 6.8 million for the period a year ago. 
In the last 30 days, cars have sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.8 million; for the last 60 days, the rate was 6.6 million. Auto makers sold 128,752 light trucks during the period, a decline of 2.6 percent from last year.
There were nine selling days in the mid-June period this year, and eight days last year.
 
Chrysler At Bottom
Sales of the Chrysler Corporation's cars, light trucks and mini-vans declined significantly more than those of the other domestic auto companies.
Charles Brady, an auto industry analyst with Oppenheimer & Company in New York, attributed the sluggish sales ''to a lack of confidence among consumers'' about the economy. ''Customers have the money to make the purchase,'' Mr. Brady said.
Despite an overall decline in sales, the Japanese auto makers operating plants in the United States continued to gain market share, posting a collective gain of 46 percent in sales of domestically built cars and trucks. The Big Three, meanwhile, saw their overall market share fall to 91 percent from 94 percent, as their total sales for the period slumped 6.8 percent.
The General Motors Corporation and Chrysler accounted for all of the loss in market share, while the Ford Motor Company gained slightly.
Ford was helped by a 4 percent increase in sales of its light trucks, led by the Explorer, a new sport utility vehicle. Analysts and auto executives regard the Ford vehicle as a direct challenger to Chysler's profitable Jeeps.
Chrysler's car sales dropped 18.3 percent. Company officials attributed the decline to the discontinuation of several Chrysler models, including the Omni and the Horizon.
Sales of Chrysler mini-vans and light trucks also fell 12.9 percent, a decline that is especially significant for the No. 3 auto maker because it sells more of those vehicles than cars.
Tom Jakobowski, a spokesman for Chrysler, said the largest sales declines were for Jeep models, which were off 35 percent for the period and 18 percent for the model year.
G.M. sold 102,381 cars in mid-June, a decline of 7.8 percent from a year earlier, while its light-truck sales fell 3 percent to 51,278.
Ford posted a 7.4 percent drop in car sales, to 59,974, while sales of Ford's light trucks rose 4 percent, to 46,415.
 
Japanese Gains
The Honda Motor Company sold 11,280 cars made at the company's plant in Marysville, Ohio, an increase of 61.7 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales rose 63.3 percent, to 7,936, while the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation posted a 51.7 percent increase in sales of its cars, to 1,492.
Both Toyota and Mitsubishi have added production capacity at their respective plants, in Georgetown, Ky., and Normal, Ill.
The Mazda Motor Corporation, which manufactures cars in Flat Rock, Mich., sold 1,562 cars in mid-June, an increase of 36.8 percent.
The Nissan Motor Company reported an increase of 19.5 percent in sales of its cars, to 3,162, while Nissan's light-truck sales rose 8.5 percent, to 3,468. The company manufactures both cars and light trucks at its plant in Smyrna, Tenn.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Expects Profits to Plunge

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 25

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of earth-moving equipment, said today that it expected earnings to plunge because of poor results at its Brazilian unit and high costs from its revamping program and its upgrading of factories.
The opening of trading in Caterpillar shares was delayed pending the announcement. Caterpillar's stock later dropped $5 a share, to close at $58.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Sales of the company, based in Peoria, Ill., have been hurt by a slowdown in the United States construction industry. Caterpillar said its earnings would likely plummet in the second quarter by more than 50 percent from the first quarter, when income totaled $99 million, or 97 cents a share.
 
Outlook for the Year
In addition, Caterpillar said it expected full-year profits to be substantially lower than its 1989 earnings of $497 million, or $4.90 a share.
Caterpillar's markets include road building, mining, logging, agriculture, petroleum and general construction. Its products include tractors, pipe layers, trucks and compactors.
The company said its dimmer 1990 earnings outlook was mostly a result of a sharp decline in results for its Caterpillar Brazil subsidiary.
''When the Brazilian Government announced its new economic plan late last March, it was almost impossible to predict what effect it would have on Caterpillar,'' a company spokesman said. ''The effect on our results became very clear when May results became available late last week.''
 
A Lack of Capital
Analysts said the Brazilian Government's effort to reduce inflation had dried up much of that country's available capital, severely crimping Caterpillar's operations there. The program has similarly dented earnings at many American companies with large Brazilian operations.
Caterpillar's losses in Brazil are expected to be most severe in the second quarter, the company said, with smaller losses in the second half of the year. The Brazilian unit, which was profitable in 1989 and in the first quarter of 1990, is expected to report a loss for the 1990 year.
Other reasons for the forecast, the company said, are lower sales volume and costs stemming from its seven-year, $2.1 billion factory modernization program and a revamping plan announced in January.
A weaker Japanese yen has also hurt Caterpillar, giving the company's Asian rival, Komatsu, a substantial competitive edge, analysts said.
 
Hurt by Tight Money
In the United States, the company said its sales volume was down mostly because of a tight monetary policy and high interest rates, which have slowed construction activity.
In response, industry analysts said they expected to reduce 1990 earnings estimates on Caterpillar.
''I'm definitely reassessing my estimates,'' said Alexander Blanton, a research analyst with Merrill Lynch Inc.
Mr. Blanton said his 1990 per-share earnings estimate was $6.50. He said he had been expecting second-quarter earnings ''to be flat with last year's $1.39 a share.''
But in one show of confidence for the longer-term outlook for the company, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reaffirmed its ratings on Caterpillar's $3.3 billion debt. It affirmed the A- senior debt and A-1 commercial paper ratings for Caterpillar and its Caterpillar Financial Services subsidiary.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of U.S. Securities Tumble

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply in light trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in advance of a heavy schedule of new debt offerings this week.
''Unless we get some new, positive information, the Street has a real problem,'' one government bond trader said. ''It is quarter end, customers are on the sidelines, and the auctions are at hand. That is bad news for the market.'' 
The Treasury auctions, which are all of record size, began yesterday with the weekly sale of three-month and six-month bills. They continue today and on Wednesday and Thursday, when auctions of two-year notes, four-year notes and one-year bills will be held.
At the bill auction, where a total of $17.2 billion worth of securities were sold, three-month bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 7.78 percent, up slightly from an average rate of 7.74 percent a week ago.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average bid of 7.67 percent, compared with last week's average rate of 7.64 percent.
Some dealers said the attitude about the coming note auctions was so poor that yields would have to rise further to attract interest in the new securities. But others said the recent backup should be sufficient to generate demand.
''At current yield levels, I think the two-year sale will be a fairly strong auction,'' said Joe Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg Securities Inc. ''But the reality of all the new supply staring us in the face gave the market a very sour tone. The supply problem was the focus of the day.''
In advance of today's auction of $11.25 billion of two-year notes, the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.43 percent, up sharply from late Friday, when the notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.34 percent.
The four-year notes to be auctioned on Thursday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.53 percent, up 10 basis points, or hundredths of a point, from late Friday.
To prepare for the auctions, Treasury dealers, who may end up holding the bulk of the new issues, sold bonds and notes in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
As a consequence, by late yesterday the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 1/32, down 30/32, to yield 8.56 percent. Late Friday the benchmark bond was offered at a price to yield 8.48 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 101 29/32, down 19/32, to yield 8.58 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 26/ 32, down 14/32, to yield 8.53 percent.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of most actively-traded issues fell by anywhere from three-quarters of a point to a full point in sympathy with the price decline in Treasury issues.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said prices of most issues dipped by one-eighth point to one-quarter point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed as Gold Rises; Mark Is Put Under Pressure

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday as dealers directed their attention to trading other major currencies.
Gold prices rose on domestic and overseas markets.
Much of the movement in the dollar came as a byproduct of trades involving the West German mark against the Japanese yen and Swiss franc. There was also renewed buying of Canadian dollars after a recent slide. 
Currency trading was expected to be restrained because of the start of the European holiday season, as well as the absence of significant economic reports.
Continuing uncertainty over the economic consequences of German unification put pressure on the mark. Concerns have resurfaced as the day of German monetary union, July 2, approaches.
The dollar began its trading day in Tokyo by rising to 155.62 yen at the close from 154.75 on Friday. Later, in London, it was quoted at 155.35 yen. The dollar traded at 155.40 yen late in New York, up from 154.90 on Friday.
The British pound fell in London to $1.7300, from $1.7330 late Friday. A pound brought $1.7305 later in New York, weaker than late Friday's level of $1.7330.
Selected late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.6775 West German marks, up from 1.6740; 1.4100 Swiss francs, down from 1.4110; 5.6315 French francs, up from 5.6215; 1,225.25 Italian lire, down from 1,226.75, and 1.17705 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17855.
The Canadian dollar rebounded modestly from a selloff sparked by the failure of a plan designed to preserve the country's unity by recognizing French-speaking Quebec as a ''distinct society.''
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels, were: 1.6775 West German marks, up from 1.6737; 1.4110 Swiss francs, up from 1.4085; 5.6335 French francs, up from 5.6220; 1.8830 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8835; 1,228.50 Italian lire, up from 1,227.25, and 1.1792 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1816.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for June delivery rose $3.40, to $353.80 an ounce. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold bullion at $352.80, $3.30 higher than Friday's late bid.
In New York silver trading, silver for June delivery closed at $4.816 an ounce on the Comex, compared with $4.81 on Friday. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.85 an ounce, from $4.83 late Friday.

HEADLINE: House Sales Off 1.2% in May

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing houses slipped 1.2 percent in May, a real estate trade group reported today.
The National Association of Realtors said resales of single-family houses totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.29 million, down from 3.33 million in April. The April sales were down 2.1 percent from the previous month.
Sales of existing houses hit their 1989 peak of 3.56 million units in November and December and then fell in January, February and April as mortgage rates posted double-digit figures. Sales were unchanged in March.
The national commitment rate for 30-year conventional fixed-rate mortgages fell to 10.33 percent at the end of the month from 10.67 percent at the beginning of May, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
The median price of a house fell $800, to $94,800, in May. The median price means half of the homes cost more, half less.
Existing house sales rose 1.7 percent, to an annual rate of 590,000 in the West, where the median price was $135,300. Sales inched up eight-tenths of a percent, to 1.31 million units, in the South, which posted an $85,200 median price. Sales in the recently sluggish Northeast were unchanged at 520,000 and the median price was $141,300.
In the Midwest, where the median price was $73,100, sales of existing houses fell 4.4 percent to 880,000 units.

HEADLINE: Argentine Officials Open Bids on Phone System

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 25

 BODY:
Taking their first big step in the long-debated privatization of state-owned companies, Argentine officials opened bids today from American, Italian and Spanish concerns for the sale of a controlling interest in the national telephone company, Entel.
In addition to offering Argentines the hope of modernizing and expanding what is considered one of the worst telephone systems on a continent known for bad telephones, the sale of Entel will allow the Government to eliminate some $4 billion of its $62 billion foreign debt quickly, as well as nearly $1 billion in overdue interest because most of the purchase will be made with discounted debt paper.
Maria Julia Alsogaray, a former Congresswoman who is directing the Entel privatization, said the offers ''exceed our expectations'' and that the sale will be ''a clear signal to the outside world that Argentina is going to honor its debt.''
 
Interest Payments Resumed
Argentina interrupted interest payments on its debt more than two years ago during the Government of Raul Alfonsin, but the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem recently resumed interest payments, with a first payment of $40 million. Argentina has the third-largest debt in Latin America, after Mexico and Brazil. 
A consortium led by the Spanish telephone company, Telefonica de Espana, and including Citicorp, made the high bid for 60 percent of each of the two new companies into which Entel is to be divided. Other bids came from the Bell Atlantic Corporation in a consortium that includes the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and from the Italian telecommunications company STET S.p.A. in a consortium that includes France Telecom and J. P. Morgan & Company.
For control of the company that will serve the southern part of the country, the Telefonica group offered $114 million in cash plus $2.18 billion in debt paper and $540 million in forgiven interest on that debt. For the northern territory, it offered $100 million in cash plus $1.85 billion in debt paper and $458 million in forgiven interest.
The cash portion was fixed in the bidding documents, with the debt paper being the only area of competition in the bidding.
 
The Other Two Bids
The Bell Atlantic group bid only for the northern region, offering, in addition to $100 million in cash, $1.86 billion in debt paper, and $371 million in forgiven interest.
The STET group, in addition to the required cash, offered $1.75 billion in debt paper and $350 million in forgiven interest for the northern region and and $1.94 billion in debt paper and $389 million in forgiven interest for the southern region.
Argentine debt paper now trades on the secondary market in New York at 13 to 14 cents per dollar of face value, which would make the Telefonica bid of $4.03 billion in debt paper for the two regions worth something more than $500 million. Financial experts dealing with the privatization, however, say a substantial purchase of Argentine debt would drive up the price.
The banks in the three consortiums all hold portions of the Argentine foreign debt, but it is not clear whether they have enough to make the purchases without acquiring additional debt paper.
 
Telefonica to Get a Choice
The Government has said it will not award the two new companies to the same group, so Telefonica is expected to be given its choice of the two regions. Then the other bidders would be given the chance to equal Telefonica's bid for the remaining region.
Buenos Aires, which has more than half of the 3.2 million telephone lines in Argentina, is divided between the two regions.
The remaining 40 percent share of each of the two new companies will be apportioned as follows: 25 percent to be auctioned through the Buenos Aires stock exchange, 10 percent to be sold to Entel employees and 5 percent to be sold by 200 small-town cooperatives that now operate their own telephone companies.
Argentina has a long history of state domination of the economy through a network of immense state companies like Entel that distributed contracts to hundreds of private supplier companies and subsidized services to private and state industries while serving as an employer of last resort to keep unemployment low. In recent years, however, the system has broken down. Entel, for example, has been running deficits of $50 million a month, and the vast majority of its switchboards are decades out of date.
Although there is still political support in Argentina for a large state role in the economy, President Menem has driven through the privatization program because the nearly bankrupt state lacks the money to modernize the communications system or to continue making up the deficits. Morgan, J. P.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
European Leaders Back Kohl's Plea to Aid Soviets

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, June 26

 BODY:
Leaders of the European Community, under pressure from Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany to help speed German unification, agreed today on steps that he requested to reassure the Soviet Union.
Giving qualified endorsement to the Chancellor's appeal for billions of dollars in aid to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev transform the Soviet Union from Communism to a market economy, the 12 leaders called for more detailed proposals for short-term credits and long-term economic aid.
They said they would consider the proposals at another meeting of European leaders expected to be held by October.
They also decided to propose Nov. 19 for a gathering in Paris of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a meeting of leaders from East and West that Moscow wanted this year. 
The United States has opposed using economic aid to prop up Soviet reforms. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said on Monday that substantial economic aid would subsidize the Soviet military.
Mr. Kohl, announcing the decision today, said negotiations on the terms of German unity would have to be completed before the Paris meeting, a position supported by the United States and other members of the NATO alliance.
Mr. Kohl, who with the help of President Francois Mitterrand of France was the most insistent backer of the Soviet aid proposal, pronounced himself ''very, very satisfied'' at the end of the two-day meeting.
He made little secret of West Germany's reason for deciding last week to guarantee up to $2.9 billion in German private bank credits to the Soviet Union.
''In this connection,'' he wrote to the President of the European Community's executive commission, Jacques Delors, ''I would urge the Soviet Union, for its part, to adopt a constructive approach to questions arising on the path toward German unity - and this applies in particular to anchoring a future united Germany within the North Atlantic Alliance and the European Community.''
At a news conference after the meeting today, Mr. Kohl dismissed the idea of a link between his proposal for further aid and the goal of ending Soviet objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. But his spokesman, Hans Klein, said the Chancellor had raised the possibility of Western aid amounting to many billions of dollars with Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow last winter and by telephone several times since. The Soviets had suggested a figure of $15 billion, he said.
The decision today did not commit the 12 European Community countries to pledging specific amounts.
But it confronted the United States, Japan and the other industrial democracies who will be meeting in Houston early next month with momentum and a growing European sense of urgency about the need to help Mr. Gorbachev before he and his policies go down in failure. The issue is also likely to come up at the NATO summit in London on July 5 and 6.
Last July, in an atmosphere of gathering change in Eastern Europe, President Bush and the other leaders made the European Commission their coordinating agent for aid to Poland and Hungary.
 
Thatcher's Misgivings
Part of Mr. Kohl's message to the other European leaders here was that without Mr. Gorbachev and the attraction of a closely integrated European Community, the revolutions in Eastern Europe would not have succeeded last year.
But Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain argued forcefully at a dinner in Malahide Castle here on Monday night for careful study of what the Soviet Union needed before any decision to throw money at it.
''We are very ready to consider financial assistance provided it is clearly linked to economic restructuring so that we know it will actually be effective,'' she said today. ''I favor support for economic reform but there has to be reform to support.''
In their communique today, the leaders ''underlined the interest of the community in the success of the political and economic changes initiated by President Gorbachev.'' They asked Mr. Delors's commission to consult with the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and other international economic institutions and to prepare aid proposals urgently.
 
A Symbol of 'No More War'
Mr. Delors is expected to visit Moscow in mid-July, and he will take with him a Dutch proposal for a European Energy Community including the Soviet Union. The Dutch Prime Minister, Ruud Lubbers, compared the idea to the European Coal and Steel Community created after World War II. He described it to his colleagues here as a symbol and instrument of the principle of ''no more war,'' as well as a means of greater European independence from imported oil.
The European leaders also agreed today to set Dec. 13 and 14 as the opening dates for conferences on greater economic and political union. These could lead to institutional and structural changes bringing community members closer together by 1993, when they have already pledged to create a barrier-free single market of 336 million people.
The leaders agreed on a sweeping statement of support for more effective protection of the environment, but could not agree on the location of a new European Environment Agency because of French insistence that Strasbourg be declared the permanent site of the European Parliament first. The Irish Prime Minister, Charles J. Haughey, said today that his successor in the six-month presidency of the European Community, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy, would have to resolve the impasse by October.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Charles Haughey leading members of the European Community in an Irish song yesterday in Dublin. With him were President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A6)
