HEADLINE: Republicans Fear a Kiss of Death As Bush Moves His Lips on Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
In the eyes of many Republicans, President Bush abandoned much more today than his campaign pledge not to raise taxes. With just a few words, he holstered his party's best tactical weapon in Congressional campaigns this year, a weapon that the Republicans had used to distinguish themselves since the dawn of the Reagan era.
Conservatives complained loudly, and even moderate Republicans worried that Mr. Bush had crippled a party already suffering from the diminished emotional impact of issues like the Communist threat and protecting the American flag.
''I'm upset, I really am,'' said Jim Dingeman, a Republican businessman who has made resistance to new taxes the centerpiece of his campaign for Congress in a district northeast of Detroit. ''But there's not much I can do except to continue to urge the President to maintain his original promise.'' 
David A. Keene, a conservative consultant, worried that Mr. Bush had taken a ''very dangerous'' step by giving up a ''key defining issue without what might be viewed as a significant explanation.''
Still, while some Republicans viewed Mr. Bush's announcement as a serious tactical blunder, others said he had simply been forced to choose between two painful alternatives: breaking a pledge that was a principal element of his 1988 campaign, or risking a recession if he took no decisive steps to cut a 1991 budget deficit that is now projected at $160 billion.
In this view, Mr. Bush has wisely seized a final chance to save the economy, in the process saving the Republicans from future political damage and himself from a threat to his re-election in 1992.
But for Republican members of Congress, the unmistakable message today was that their party leader was trading away their political advantage in 1990 to strengthen himself two years from now.
 
Trying for Damage Control
On Capitol Hill, Representative Robert S. Walker of Pennsylvania said more than 90 of his Republican colleagues had signed a letter he circulated today with this terse message for Mr. Bush: ''We were stunned by your announcement that you would be willing to accept tax revenue increases as a part of a budget summit pacakge. A tax increase is unacceptable.''
Party leaders expressed confidence that they could keep this discontent from growing into what was rapidly becoming a full-scale revolt. ''No one's panicking or freaking out,'' said Mary Matalin, chief of staff to the Republican National Committee. ''We're trying to see it in the context of a serious deficit-reduction plan. And people will ultimately see it as Bush being a leader and trying to solve a difficult problem.''
Other prices that Mr. Bush must pay in the short term are scathing cartoons about his newly movable lips, and a lot of partisan razzing. For this year, at least, Democrats believe that the phrase ''tax-and-spend Democrats'' can no longer be a staple of the Republican vocabulary.
 
The High Road, for Now
The Democratic leadership was taking the high road today, forswearing any impulse to gloat. But Representative Beryl Anthony Jr. of Arkansas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, gave a clear picture of what lies ahead. ''I'm chairman of the campaign committee,'' he said, ''and we'll make it a political issue.''
While opinion polls and election returns have long confirmed that people do not like higher taxes, Mr. Bush may in some ways be ahead of his party. A New York Times/CBS News Poll last month found that Americans overwhelmingly expected their taxes to rise to reduce the Federal deficit, and that they had become more resigned to the idea.
Not all Republicans were critical of Mr. Bush today. The White House had done a good job of extracting vows of silence or non-aggression from some predictably vocal Republicans. One prominent defender of the no-new-taxes faith, Edward J. Rollins, was noticeably unavailable. Mr. Rollins is head of the National Republican Congressional Committee, the organization responsible for getting Republicans elected to the House.
''He won't show up anywhere,'' said Gary Koops, a spokesman for the committee. He said Mr. Rollins was at his cabin somewhere in West Virginia and could not be reached.
 
Solace in Semantics
Even Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the combative Republican whip and a leading opponent of tax increases, offered an uncharacteristically tepid response, pinning his defense of the President on a semantic argument that Mr. Bush was not really breaking his pledge.
''He very explicitly didn't say, 'Raise taxes,' '' Mr. Gingrich said. ''He said, 'Seek new revenues.' ''
House Democrats, after months of being pummeled on the tax issue, were having none of that interpretation. ''George Bush has announced that he is raising taxes,'' Representative Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey told the House. ''The charade is finally over.''
By the end of the day, the main focus of the tax battle had clearly shifted to Capitol Hill. When the budget negotiations resume Wednesday, the big questions will be whether the White House can contain a Republican revolt and whether the Democrats can use the opportunity Mr. Bush handed them.
 
Hunkering Down at Sunset
Sunset found the House Republican leadership hunkered down behind Mr. Gingrich's argument that Mr. Bush had said it but didn't really mean it, or maybe hadn't said it at all.
Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said, ''The President hasn't done anything except restate what he said when he opened the budget negotiations.''
But speaking of the political ramifications, he conceded: ''We're a little nervous about this. It's certainly going to make life more difficult.''
Once again, the Hill Democrats and their national party chairman were slightly out of synch among themselves. Smelling blood by late afternoon, Mr. Anthony, the Arkansas Democrat, was saying that the Republicans had a right to be agitated because Mr. Bush ''cut the legs out from them politically.''
But Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, decreed: ''It's no time for partisan gloating. The President's statement is candid, sober and tells the American people that something has gone seriously wrong with the projections and predictions about budget policy and the U.S. economy.''
 
Comment in Massachusetts
Fittingly, the last word of what was, on balance, a rough day for the President went to a Democrat who two years ago seemed to have a hard time figuring out when to strike back at George Bush. In Boston, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, the Democratic Presidential nominee who failed two years ago to counter Mr. Bush's repeated vow of no new taxes, said he had too many budget problems in his own state to take much pleasure in the President's turnabout.
Then he added with relish: ''I told the truth, and I paid the price. Mr. Bush did not tell the truth, and now we must all pay the price.''

HEADLINE: BUSH NOW CONCEDES A NEED FOR 'TAX REVENUE INCREASES' TO REDUCE DEFICIT IN BUDGET

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
With negotiations on cutting the budget deficit stalled, President Bush today broke with his vow to oppose new taxes and said any agreement with Congress would require ''tax revenue increases.''
While a boom in the economy alone could theoretically produce more revenue, Mr. Bush's statement was greeted by Democrats and Republicans as a break from the central ''Read my lips: No new taxes'' pledge of his 1988 Presidential campaign and as a watershed in the battle over the Federal budget for the 1991 fiscal year.
 
No Specific Plan Was Offered
Mr. Bush did not offer a specific tax increase proposal, and he said any increase would have to be part of a package including cuts in both domestic and military spending; ''growth incentives,'' a reference to his longstanding proposal to cut the tax rate on capital gains, and changes in the budget process. He did not refer directly to specific taxes but many lawmakers involved in the budget negotiations have said an income tax rise is unlikely. Possible tax increases under discussion include a rise in the gasoline tax and higher taxes on cigarettes and alcohol. 
The President made the announcement in a written statement rather than delivering it in person, in an apparent effort to minimize political embarrassment. He avoided talking to reporters throughout the day, and when he was asked during one brief Rose Garden appearance to expand on his written words, he replied, ''I'll let the statement speak for itself.''
 
First to Broach the Issue
After weeks of maneuvering, Mr. Bush's statement, which was negotiated with the Democratic leaders in Congress, gave in to their insistence that he be the first to broach the subject of tax increases publicly. It was a position toward which he had been inching since May, when he initiated deficit-reduction talks with Congress by saying all subjects were ''on the table'' without any preconditions.
The earlier statement had been widely seen as an implicit agreement at least to discuss tax increases, but the Democrats had held out for today's more explicit language, saying that the Republicans could otherwise savage them as tax raisers in the Congressional campaigns this fall.
Congressional Democrats welcomed the statement, and the leadership tried with mixed success to be restrained in the first efforts to saddle Mr. Bush with the tax issue. ''The President has concluded that tax increases are necessary, along with other changes as specified in the statement, and we share the President's view,'' said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader.
The Congressional Democratic leaders seemed to be under at least a tacit agreement to help Mr. Bush sell the tax issue. ''Someone who is complaining about taxes being raised in the budget summit will have to complain against both parties and the President,'' said Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley.
With a sharper political edge, Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said: ''We decided we're not going to stand around and beat him on the head and shoulders. He made the pledge, and now he's rethought it. I learned from George Bush. He told us, 'Gorbachev lost the cold war, and we don't want any gloating here.' ''
Democratic and Republican lawmakers said they had warned Mr. Bush in recent days that the stalemate over taxes was threatening to scuttle the budget negotiations. Those talks have been stalled for weeks on a discussion of the budget process and the size of the deficit, now estimated at $160 billion, for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
 
A Move to Allay Doubts
In addition to meeting Democratic concerns, today's statement was aimed, in part, at Wall Street and the Federal Reserve, to allay doubts about Washington's ability to reduce the deficit, White House officials said. They added that it also reflected two major problems looming before Mr. Bush: Unless a budget agreement is reached, Federal law will mandate automatic spending cuts larger than either he or Congress wants. In addition, Republican analysts have warned that failure to deal with the budget problems could leave Mr. Bush facing a recession during his 1992 re-election campaign.
In what appeared to be another effort to mitigate immediate political fallout from the announcement on taxes, the statement was issued on an extraordinarily busy day in Washington: Nelson Mandela was addressing a joint meeting of Congress, the Interior Department was announcing Mr. Bush's long-awaited decision to ban some offshore oil drilling, and the Agriculture and Interior Departments were announcing measures to protect the northern spotted owl's habitats among the lucrative forests of the Northwest.
The three-paragraph statement seemed to have been intended to provide only the minimum gesture demanded by the Democrats. There were vague passages, and White House officials anxiously pointed out that the statement did not commit Mr. Bush to anything.
Some Republican lawmakers insisted that it was just an effort to give Democrats enough confidence to propose a tax increase themselves.
But Mr. Bush immediately came under pressure from conservative Republicans and Democrats, who said they would urge him to make a more detailed statement to the American people about why budget cuts and tax increases were needed.
''There's a feeling that there is no pressure out there'' to raise taxes, said a senior Congressional official who has attended the budget negotiations. ''Are the people in Des Moines calling for major sacrifices? What has changed from six months ago? Why should their taxes be raised?''
 
Year Brought Reassessment
Mr. Bush began the year saying that economic growth would allow the Federal Government to cut the 1991 budget deficit to $64 billion, the ceiling set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law, without raising taxes.
Since then, higher-than-expected interest rates, lower-than-projected corporate profits and other factors have forced the Administration to reassess its position. White House and Congressional negotiators now agree that unless steps are taken to trim the 1991 deficit, it will total about $160 billion, not counting the cost of bailing out the savings and loan industry.
''It is clear to me,'' Mr. Bush said in his statement, ''that both the size of the deficit problem and the need for a package that can be enacted require all of the following: entitlement and mandatory program reform, tax revenue increases, growth incentives, discretionary spending reductions, orderly reductions in defense expenditures and budget process reform, to assure that any bipartisan agreement is enforceable and that the deficit problem is brought under responsible control.''
 
Pledge of 1988 Campaign
With those words, Mr. Bush departed from the statement that was the linchpin of his 1988 campaign. ''The Congress will push me to raise taxes,'' he said during his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, ''and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again, and I'll say to them, 'Read my lips: No new taxes.' ''
It was not clear from his statement how far Mr. Bush was willing to go, but he touched on these issues:
* ''Entitlement and mandatory program reform,'' presumably reductions and other changes in the programs that pay benefits automatically and not at Congressional discretion. These include Medicare and Social Security, but neither Mr. Bush nor Democratic lawmakers talked about specific programs today. Retirement benefits are unlikely to be reduced, but more of the benefits could be subject to income taxes.
* ''Tax revenue increases,'' which Democrats took to mean tax rate increases. The White House did not dispute that, although some Republicans suggested that the term could simply mean an increase in revenues from economic growth.
* ''Growth incentives'' - code for a cut in the capital gains tax rate - a proposal that Mr. Bush has been pushing since the 1988 campaign. Its inclusion in the statement could reflect a willingness among the Democratic leadership to pass such a reduction.
* ''Discretionary spending reductions'' - cuts in programs other than Medicare, Social Security and the like.
* ''Budget process reform'' - Mr. Bush's proposals for multiyear spending agreements, the line-item veto and a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, refused to be pinned down on any point. ''Are you crazy?'' he responded when asked whether he could say that Mr. Bush ''has agreed to break his pledge of 'no new taxes.' ''
Asked whether Mr. Bush regretted his campaign pledge, Mr. Fitzwater said: ''We feel he said the right thing then. He's saying the right thing now.''
 
Bush's Latest On the Budget
WASHINGTON, June 26 - Following is the statement issued by President Bush today on deficit-reduction efforts:
I met this morning with the bipartisan leadership - the Speaker, the Senate majority leader, the Senate Republican leader, the House majority leader and the House Republican leader - to review the status of the deficit-reduction negotiations.
It is clear to me that both the size of the deficit problem and the need for a package that can be enacted require all of the follwoing: entitlement and mandatory program reform, tax revenue increases, growth incentives, discretionary spending reductions, orderly reductions in defense expenditures and budget process reform, to assure that any bipartisan agreement is enforceable and that the deficit problem is brought under responsible control. The bipartisan leadership agree with me on these points.
The budget negotiations will resume promptly with a view toward reaching substantive agreement as quickly as possible.

HEADLINE: Banks Approve Loans for Trump, But Take Control of His Finances

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Wrapping up a hard-fought deal with bankers yesterday, Donald J. Trump narrowly avoided missing a payment deadline that could have led to personal bankruptcy.
But for the developer, who once seemed nearly invincible, the deal comes at a humbling cost: He has been forced to cede management control over his multibillion-dollar empire, at least temporarily, to the bankers who came to his rescue, and he must learn to live on $450,000 a month, and even less in future years.
Yesterday morning, in the first part of a two-stage rescue for the 44-year-old developer, some of the nation's largest banks wired $20 million to a Trump bank account to help him meet a midnight deadline to make a $43 million payment to holders of some high-yield ''junk bonds'' backing one of his Atlantic City casinos. Mr. Trump provided the remaining $23 million in cash and bonds. 
The cost for Mr. Trump is that his bankers, who in the past had eagerly backed his grand visions, now have him on a short leash. His every move, including his personal expenditures, will be scrutinized. But he has maintained ownership of his empire, and in that small victory could lie the seeds of a comeback - if the real estate and casino markets cooperate. [Page D5.] If he had missed yesterday's payment, he would have defaulted on loans backed by Trump's Castle and probably would have lost that casino to creditors. Such a default would have set off a chain of defaults that could have forced him to seek bankruptcy protection.
About 70 banks, with one German holdout, also approved a $65 million loan package for the developer yesterday that will defer much of his bank debt for up to five years.
The banks may seem lenient, but their decision to rescue Mr. Trump is partly an attempt to try to recoup as much as possible of what they have lent to him. Yesterday's deal includes incentives for Mr. Trump to sell many of his major holdings to raise cash. That cash would then be used to pay back the new loans and to pay some interest and return some principal on the loans they have made to him over the last decade.
The banks justified lending Mr. Trump more money by saying they would be hurt if the developer was forced to sell his assets at fire-sale prices because he would not be able to repay them fully. They also wanted to avoid a bankruptcy filing because the sale of assets would then be determined by a bankruptcy court judge. The banks hope the new cash will give Mr. Trump time to oversee the orderly sale of many of his assets at prices that would allow him to meet his obligations.
 
Name Put on Large Properties
In exchange for the $65 million loan package and the deferral of interest and principal payments on nearly $850 million in debt, Mr. Trump must give up control of his personal and business finances. The flamboyant developer, who has put his name on almost all his large properties, has been told by the banks that he cannot spend more than $450,000 a month on personal and household expenses for the rest of the year. Next year, he will be limited to $375,000 a month, and in 1992 to $300,000.
Moreover, he has had to submit a monthly business plan for the bankers' approval. That plan has projections on the income and expenses of each of Mr. Trump's assets. Lawyers involved in the negotiations said the banks will regularly require detailed explanations of every aspect of Mr. Trump's various businesses and will review, item by item, every receipt and disbursement.
''He will have to give monthly, quarterly and yearly reports on each asset,'' said an attorney involved in the talks, ''and he will have to explain any significant variances from the business plan.''
Mr. Trump, whose $29 million yacht and $365 million Trump Shuttle airline are both up for sale, said in an interview yesterday that the trouble he has had meeting his debt obligations has actually been good for his name and the mystique some attach to it. ''I think it has greatly enhanced it,'' he said of the name's aura. ''There was a media stampede, but when you come through adversity, I think people respect that.''
 
'Credit Crunch' Cited
He also asserted that a nationwide credit squeeze was one cause of his problems. ''If the United States doesn't do something about the credit crunch,'' he said, ''you will have far worse than a bad recession.''
The $65 million loan package, which will immediately pay back yesterday's $20 million short-term loan once the documentation is made final, received the approval of all Mr. Trump's bank lenders except one West German bank, Dresdner A.G.. For several weeks now a few major Japanese and European banks had balked at lending Mr. Trump more money and rolling over much of the mountain of debt he has amassed, but as of yesterday all the banks except Dresdner joined in the agreement, and bankers said the German bank would probably join next month.
A banker close to the talks said the larger loan package would go ahead despite the refusal of Dresdner to approve it. ''On re-reading the documents, the lawyers have said that it is not necessary to get every single lender to approve a subordinated lien on the property, and there is also a sense that over the next 30 days Dresdner might come on board,'' he added.
Although Mr. Trump will remain chief executive of the Trump Organization, the company that oversees most of his various businesses, much of his authority to make the large decisions that direct the course of that company and its subsidiaries has been taken from him.
 
Tight Rein by Banks
By accepting or rejecting parts of the business plan drawn up by the Trump Organization and by bringing in a chief financial officer approved by them, the banks will keep a tight rein on the Trump empire.
Mr. Trump, who according to his own best-selling book has mastered the art of the deal, has for several weeks faced what was probably the most important deal of his career. Bankers said that when the developer told them he would not be able to make all the interest payments on his nearly $2 billion of bank debts this year, weeks of arduous international negotiations began that resulted in the loan agreements.
A victim of both the downturn of the Northeastern real estate market as well as the softening of the gaming business in Atlantic City, Mr. Trump's vast holdings could not generate the income necessary to make interest and principal payments on $2 billion of bank debt and about $1 billion in junk bond debt.
On June 15, Mr. Trump failed to make a $43 million payment on bonds issued to finance Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, and a $30 million payment on a personally guaranteed loan due to Manufacturers Hanover. That put the developer in technical default on those bonds, but a grace period allowed him until midnight Tuesday to make the payment. $60 Million Credit Line To avoid the losses they would suffer if Mr. Trump filed for bankruptcy protection, the major New York banks that were his largest lenders -Citibank, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover - came up with a plan to provide him with a $60 million credit line. That credit line was eventually raised to $65 million.
Over the last two weeks several Japanese and European banks in bank syndicates holding loans to Mr. Trump refused to participate in the new loan package, which will be backed by additional liens on almost every one of the developer's assets.
These banks, which included many of the world's largest commercial banks, initially refused to allow additional liens on the properties that were securing their loans. Many of them delayed approving the deal in hopes that the large American banks would take them out of the deal entirely by buying the chunks of loans to Mr. Trump that they had originally bought from the New York banks.
As part of the larger loan package, Mr. Trump will be allowed to buy back securities that represent the interest on his debt that has been rolled over. The banks are encouraging the developer to buy back these securities with the proceeds he gains from selling his assets. If he sells the assets quickly and purchases the securities then he will get discounted rates.
After he has sold a certain amount of assets, the banks will allow him to keep for himself some of the proceeds from the sales, but initially all the money from the sales will be used to service Mr. Trump's debts.
 
First Big Deal in 1976
For a man who has amassed such wealth and become such a national celebrity, Mr. Trump has been in business for a relatively short time. Donald John Trump, one of five children born to a Queens housing developer, made his first big deal in 1976 when New York was in the throes of one of its worst fiscal crises.
Mr. Trump, then 30 years old, persuaded the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to sell him the dilapidated Commodore Hotel, which adjoins Grand Central Terminal, for $10 million, and he then won a $120 million tax abatement from the city. He persuaded bankers to lend him about $80 million and went on to build, along with partners, the glittering Grand Hyatt Hotel.
It was the Grand Hyatt, which opened in 1980, that made the young developer a presence in the New York real estate market, and he used his 50 percent interest in that project to borrow more money from the banks to build other projects.
 
Demand for Luxury Housing
Mr. Trump went on to build a fortune by catering to the demand for New York City luxury housing. One of his most well-known projects, Trump Tower, a glitzy Fifth Avenue residential and commercial skyscraper next to Tiffany & Company that he built in 1982 at a cost of about $200 million, has become a tourist attraction.
The young developer, whose name became synonymous with flamboyant wealth and glittering extravagance, became extremely wealthy throughout the 1980's. He eventually went into the Atlantic City casino business, in 1984 buying what became the Trump Plaza.

HEADLINE: BUSH CUTS BACK AREAS OFF COASTS OPEN FOR DRILLING

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Seeking to break a long deadlock with Congress over offshore oil and gas drilling, President Bush today sharply reduced the offshore acreage available to the industry for at least the next decade.
Mr. Bush blocked new drilling off the coasts of much of California, Florida, Washington, Oregon and New England until at least the year 2000. He also permanently blocked any drilling in a marine sanctuary he created in California and ordered a delay on new leases until 1996 for an area of Southern California where drilling is already under way.
His decision is a significant departure from the offshore leasing policies of the Reagan Administration, which tried to make the entire 1.4-million-acre outer continental shelf available to industry. That plan has largely been stalled in Congress. 
 
Politics Seen as Consideration
By making some areas off limits, particularly those off California and Florida, the Administration seemed to be hoping that it would get approval from Congress for opening up oil exploration on the North Carolina coast and Alaska and leave open the possibility of future leasing in Florida and California. The plan requires no Congressional approval, but Congress has power over it by controlling the appropriation of money for it.
Today's proposal also seemed to serve a political purpose, because many voters in Florida and California fear that drilling poses a potential threat to marine life.
The Republican Party is eager win the governors' races in California and Florida, since the winners will play an important role in Congressional reapportionment and both states stand to gain seats. Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican, is seeking re-election in Florida and Senator Pete Wilson, also a Republican, is trying to become California's next governor.
A substantial amount of drilling is already going on in the Gulf of Mexico, off California and off Alaska.
The President's long-awaited decision did not please environmentalists and coastal communities, who are seeking permanent protection of the coastal areas. Nor did it please the oil industry, which called the new policy a ''serious mistake'' that would cost the nation millions of barrels of oil and billions of dollars in revenues.
 
In a 'Sound Manner'
In a statement issued at the White House, Mr. Bush said the decision reflected his belief ''that the development of oil and gas on the outer continental shelf should occur in an environmentally sound manner.''
In his announcement, Mr. Bush said the sale of leases off Florida and Southern California would be put off until at least the year 2000. About 87 tracts off San Luis Obispo in Southern California will be put up for sale after 1995, but only if studies find that they will not harm the environment or local economies.
The President also said he was creating a national marine sanctuary in central California's Monterey Bay that would be permanently off limits to drilling or other development.
In a surprise, the President also announced he is cancelling lease sales on the Georges Bank off New England and off the coasts of Oregon and Washington.
The new policy will not stop development in areas of the outer continental shelf that already are being drilled. But it does affect a number of areas that the Interior Department has scheduled to be leased to industry and, in the case of Florida, to a number of tracts that have already been leased but not yet explored and drilled.
Lease sales may also proceed in areas not covered by the President's announcement, including waters off Alaska, the Gulf Coast, North Carolina and the Mid-Atlantic off New York and New Jersey.
Since the Reagan Administration announced plans for opening the entire outer continental shelf to oil and gas development, Congress has effectively blocked drilling in many sensitive coastal areas, including Florida and California, by denying the Interior Department the money for conducting lease sales.
The Congressional moratorium reflected the concerns of coastal communities and environmentalists, who feared that offshore development on the scale envisioned by former Interior Secretary James G. Watt would seriously threaten the environment and local economies dependent on fishing and tourism.
Mr. Watt and other Reagan Administration officials insisted that rapid development of the energy resources of the outer continental shelf was needed to protect national security and the nation's economy from excessive dependence on foreign oil. The United States imports 50 percent of its oil.
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., whose department oversees the offshore leasing program said at a news conference today, ''At the heart of President Bush's announcement is this Administration's commitment to prohibit offshore drilling in areas where environmental risks outweigh the potential energy benefits to the nation.''
But Mr. Lujan also indicated that the President's action was intended to break the the deadlock with Congress when he said that ''recent tanker accidents underscore the need to produce as much oil as posssible in the United States, onshore and offshore.''
Mr. Lujan said that today's decision is ''the all-important first step'' in reshaping the Government program for developing the oil and gas resources of the outer continental shelf.
 
'Areas of Critical Concern'
But environmentalists and other critics of the President's decision said Congressional action was still needed to protect areas not covered by today's decision. Lisa Speer, a senior scientist for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the many ''areas of critical concern'' were still vulnerable, including Alaska's Bristol Bay, the northern Gulf coast of Florida and the Mid-Atlantic region.
Environmentalists complained that the President left himself a loophole in his decision to cancel the leases by stating that leasing could resume in case oil supplies from foreign sources was interrupted. They considered the decision a step in the right direction but were disappointed that it did not offer permanent protection to sensitive areas.
Robert Sulnick, executive director of the National Oceans Campaign, a nonprofit group dedicated to protecting the marine environment, said: ''While the President's decision moves in the right direction, we are concerned it was based on political motivation rather than environmental sensitivity. What the nation needs is not a temporary reprieve from offshore oil drilling, but a national energy policy based on conservation and renewable fuels.''
Oil industry officials said the President's decision would substantially reduce the total amount of oil that would be taken from the outer continental shelf at least until well into the next century. The American Petroleum Institute, a trade group of major oil companies, estimated that as a result of the policy the country will lose about two million barrels of oil a day, about a fourth of current domestic production.
In a statement made public today, the institute complained: ''These decisions on offshore oil and natural gas leasing are harmful to our country and economy. They will lead to decreased domestic production, more imports , more dependency on OPEC, more tanker traffic, and the export of jobs and investment overseas.''
''Locking up these energy-rich lands at a time when our dependency on foreign energy is escalating,'' the statement said, ''is a serious mistake.''

HEADLINE: Softening Stand on Spotted Owl, Administration Delays Protection

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, June 26

 BODY:
Just four days after the Federal Government declared that the northern spotted owl was a threatened species, the Bush Administration announced today that it was delaying action on a broad plan for protecting the birds and the ancient forests that are their home.
While Government officials had been expected today to release detailed plans for managing the owls' habitat, in fact the only plan announced affected just a small part of the forest at issue, that part overseen by the Bureau of Land Management. And while bureau officials said they could protect the owl on their land at a cost of only 1,000 logging jobs, they gave no specifics on how they would do this.
The much larger part of the owls' habitat is Forest Service land, and a new study group will be formed to report to President Bush by Sept. 1 on how to manage that habitat. Federal officials have consistently said that broad protection for the owl would cost up to 28,000 jobs in the timber industry in the next 10 years by reducing the amount of logging allowed on up to 4 million acres of forest. 
 
Change in Act to Be Sought
The Administration also said today that it would seek changes in the Endangered Species Act, including provisions that would make it easier to allow some species to diminish if preserving them would cause severe economic disruption. Any effort to revise the 1973 act is expected to face an uphill battle in Congress.
Administration officials said that they supported the idea of saving wildlife but that they wanted more balance in the law.
''We take the Endangered Species Act seriously and will implement the law faithfully,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, whose department oversees the Forest Service. ''We have set in motion a process to balance our responsibility in preserving the owl and the forests while protecting the economic lives of American men and women who live and work in the region.''
The Administration actions today followed the widely expected decision on Friday by the Fish and Wildlife Service to formally list the owl as a threatened species. That action, which takes effect July 23, makes it a violation of Federal law to do anything that contributes to the owl's decline and Federal officials said today that any logging they approve in the next three months will not reduce the owl habitat.
There was immediate criticism in Congress of the announcement, by Mr. Yeutter and Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., that they would set up a group to study how to balance the conflicts of logging and about 3,000 pairs of owls.
''By putting off the tough decision now a difficult problem will only get worse,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, who is chairman of a committee that oversees forestry.
The announcement also angered environmentalists, who said the Administration was retreating from an agreement that has bipartisan support. And they were particularly critical of the proposal to revise the Endangered Species Act.
''The Bush Administration proposal would be the Tiananmen Square for American wildlife,'' said Andy Kerr, conservation director of the Oregon Natural Resources Council, which has sought protection of the owl for the last decade.
Nor did the announcement today satisfy leaders of the timber industry, who said any further delay in devising a long-term plan for managing the forests would increase the economic uncertainty in timber towns of the Northwest.
''There are many unanswered questions, and we need these answers as soon as possible,'' said Pat Amedo, a consultant for several timber companies that cut trees on national forest land.
This is the second time in as many months that the Administration has suggested modifying the Endangered Species Act.
Last month, when Mr. Lujan first raised the issue, he was widely criticized by leaders of both parties in Congress. But his suggestions have support in Western states where jobs have been pared or developments held up to save rare species.
Since passage of the act, 577 species have been declared threatened or endangered. Both classifications mandate remedies to save the species, but endangered is considered a more critical status. The last time Congress reauthorized the act, in 1988, the House voted in favor of renewing the bill by a vote of 399 to 16, and the Senate voted in favor by 93 to 2.
Right now the only way that Federal officials can get around the restrictions of the Endangered Species Act is to take the difficult and time-consuming step of convening what some officials refer to as the ''God Committee.'' This panel, made up of officials from several Federal agencies, got its nickname because its members control the fate of a species in a given area. The changes proposed today would make it easier to invoke economic considerations without going to the step of calling together the committee.
 
Committee May Be Called
But because it is likely to take some time for Congress to consider changing the law, the Bush Admininstration today indicated it would probably call together the special committee to determine the fate of the owl in certain parts of the Northwest.
''It looks to me like the President has declare war on the Endangered Species Act,'' said George Frampton, director of the Wilderness Society, one of the leaders in the fight to curtail Federal logging that is responsible for the cutting of 70,000 acres of ancient forests a year.
The environmental groups indicated that they might refile lawsuits that held up logging in half the national forests of the Northwest last year unless the new committee comes up with an adequate plan.
Environmentalists say that the owl is their best weapon for preserving the fragile ecosystem of the forest. The bird has been found to live exclusively in the centuries-old stands of Douglas fir, cedar, redwoods and spruce of the Pacific Northwest.

HEADLINE: The Mandela Visit;
Mandela Invokes Struggles Of U.S., Rousing Congress

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Frequently interrupted by applause, Nelson Mandela invoked the names of American heroes as his revolutionary inspiration at a joint meeting of Congress today, warning that South Africa ''continues to bleed and suffer pain'' under apartheid.
''We would be fools to believe that the road ahead of us is without major hurdles,'' despite belief in the personal integrity of President F. W. de Klerk, Mr. Mandela said as he pressed his whirlwind tour of America through a second day in official Washington.
''Our people continue to die to this day, victims of armed agents of the state who are still determined to turn their guns against the very idea of a racial democracy,'' he told the packed, rapt chamber of the House of Representatives.
 
Calls Some Whites Intransigent
''Too many among our white compatriots are steeped in the ideology of racism to admit easily that change must come,'' said Mr. Mandela, who is deputy president of the African National Congress. 
He added, in a pointed reference to his rebuff on Monday of President Bush's call for his organization to renounce violence, ''For those who care about violence in our country, as we do, it is at these forces that they should focus their attention.''
But on the issue of sanctions against the current Government of South Africa, Mr. Mandela said he was happy with what he said was an understanding with the Bush Administration and Congress that sanctions would remain in effect. He said that ''the purpose for which they were imposed has not been achieved'' and urged that ''the people of South Africa'' be allowed to decide when they should be lifted.
The galleries overhead were jammed, as was the standing room at the back of the House. An overflow crowd sat in 250 seats in the Statuary Hall and watched on four large television sets.
The House chamber is rarely filled for joint meetings receiving visitors, but today was an exception, with even jaded lawmakers reacting as fans in the presence of a celebrity, reaching out to touch Mr. Mandela and, more important, to be photographed with him.
Trying to provide tickets for all who wanted to come was a logistical headache for the Democratic leaders, who called the handful of Republicans who had vowed not to attend to see if they could sponge tickets for some of the minor political and show-business figures who wanted to be part of the scene. Many lawmakers brought spouses or children.
 
He Follows Havel and Walesa
Mr. Mandela was the first black private citizen to address Congress, and the third recent revolutionary leader and former political prisoner - after President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslavakia and Lech Walesa of Poland. For the 24 black Representatives, his visit was an emotional moment.
Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Democrat from Baltimore, who was born Frizzell Gray, stood proudly on an aisle wearing a black sash with gold and red African embroidery over the left shoulder of his dark business suit.
''This has been an extraordinary day,'' said Representative Ron Dellums, Democrat of California, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus and a leader in the fight to impose sanctions, who was visibly moved.
A standing ovation lasting three and a half minutes greeted the tall, dignified Mr. Mandela as he strode into chamber in a dark gray suit, and his 45-minute speech was interrupted 16 times for bursts of applause, three of which turned into standing ovations.
He waved to the crowd with an open hand; no clenched fists today.
Perhaps Mr. Mandela's deftest touch was evoking a litany of white and black Americans - a kind of wrapping himself in the American flag - to justify a revolutionary tradition. As the names rolled off in his lilting accent, there were first a few whoops and cries of ''Right on!'' from the gallery, and as he wound up the passage, the lawmakers rose in applause.
''We could not have made an acquaintance through literature with human giants such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson and not been moved to act,'' Mr. Mandela said. ''We could not have heard of and admired John Brown, Sojourner Truth, Frederick Douglass, W. E. B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King Jr. and others . . . and not be moved to act as they were moved to act.
''We could not have known of your Declaration of Independence and not elected to join in the struggle to guarantee the people's life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness,'' he said to thunderous applause.
Mr. Mandela sought to ease fears that the African National Congress would seek to impose a Marxist economy but emphasized that political change ''must and will also entail the transformation of its economy.''
''The A.N.C. holds no ideological postions which dictate that it must adopt a policy of nationalization,'' Mr. Mandela said. ''But the A.N.C. also holds the view that there is no self-regulating mechanism within the South African economy which will on its own insure growth with equity.''
Mr. Mandela went on to say that ''the private sector is an engine of growth and development which is critical to the success of the mixed economy we hope to see,'' offering assurances that foreign and South African business people would ''have confidence in the security of their investments,'' a fair rate of return and ''conditions of stability and peace.''
 
Indictment of Present System
But, with characteristic bluntness, he said it was ''inevitable that the democratic government will intervene in this economy, acting through the elected parliament,'' and he eloquently indicted the present system.
''The extent of the deprivation of millions of people has to be seen to be believed,'' he said. ''The injury is made that much more intolerable by the opulence of our white compatriots and the deliberate distorion of the economy to feed that opulence.''
In the evening, Mr. Mandela gave a rousing sermon to more than 20,000 people at the Washington Convention Center. The crowd began arriving in the midday heat and was held up by heavy security for several hours.
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who is on trial in a drug case that is vying with the Mandela visit for attention in Washington, was cheered when he reached the speaker's platform.
Mr. Mandela looked tired and appeared to nod off occasionally during a speech by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nelson Mandela with members of the House and the Senate after addressing a joint meeting of Congress yesterday morning. ''Too many among our white compatriots are slaves in the ideologoy of recism to admit easily that change must come,'' he said. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 11, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1536 words

HEADLINE: The Mandel Visit;
Excerpts From Mandela Speech to Joint Meeting of Congress

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Nelson Mandela's speech to a joint meeting of Congress yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
It is a fact of the human condition that it shall - like a meteor, a mere brief passing moment in time and space - flit across the human stage and pass out of existence. . . . And so we have come to Washington in the District of Columbia, and into these hallowed chambers of the United States Congress, not as pretenders to greatness but as a particle of a people whom we know to be noble and heroic, enduring, multiplying, permanent, rejoicing in the expectation and knowledge that their humanity will be reaffirmed and enlarged by open and unfettered communion with the nations of the world.
 
A Call for Democracy
Our people demand democracy. Our country, which continues to bleed and suffer pain, needs democracy. It cries out for the situation where the law will decree that freedom to speak of freedom constitutes the very essence of legality and the very thing that makes for the legitimacy of the constitutional order. . . . We fight for and visualize a future in which all shall, without regard to race, color, creed or sex, have the right to vote and to be voted into all elective organs of state. 
To deny any person their human rights is to challenge their very humanity. To impose on them a wretched life of hunger and deprivation is to dehumanize them. But such has been the terrible fate of all black persons in our country under the system of apartheid.
The extent of the deprivation of millions of people has to be seen to be believed. The injury is made that more intolerable by the opulence of our white compatriots and the deliberate distortion of the economy to feed that opulence.
 
A Change in the Economy
The process of the reconstruction of South African society must and will also entail the transformation of its economy. We need a strong and growing economy. We require an economy that is able to address the needs of all the people of our country; that can provide food, houses, education, health services, social security and everything that makes human life human; that makes life joyful and not a protracted encounter with hopelessness and despair.
We believe that the fact of the apartheid structure of the South African economy and the enormous and pressing needs of the people make it inevitable that the democratic government will intervene in this economy, acting through the elected parliament.
We are accordingly committed to the creation of the situation in which business people, both South African and foreign, have confidence in the security of their investments, are assured of a fair rate of return on their capital, and do business in conditions of stability and peace.
 
An Economic Cooperation
We would like to approach the issue of our economic cooperation, not as a relationship between donor and recipient, between a dependent and a benefactor. We would like to believe that there is a way in which we could structure this relationship so that we do indeed benefit from your enormous resources in terms of your capital, technology, all-round expertise, your enterprising spirit and your markets.
This relationship should, however, be one from which your people should also derive benefit so that we, who are fighting to liberate the very spirit of an entire people from the bondage of the arrogance of the ideology and practice of white supremacy, do not build a relationship of subservient dependency and fawning gratitude. One of the benefits that should accrue to both our peoples and to the rest of the world should surely be that this complex South African society, which has known nothing but racism for three centuries, should be transformed into an oasis of good race relations where the black shall to the white be sister and brother, a fellow South African, and equal human being, both citizens of the world.
 
A Means to Negotiate
In a sense, we do not know the meaning of peace except in the imagination. But because we have not known true peace in its real meaning, because for centuries generations have had to bury the victims of state violence, we have fought for the right to experience peace.
On the initiative of the A.N.C., the process toward the conclusion of a peaceful settlement has started. According to a logic dictated by our situation, we are engaged in an effort which includes the removal of obstacles to negotiations.
This will be followed by a negotiated determination of the mechanism which will draw up the new constitution. This should lead to the formation of this constitution-making institution and, therefore, the elaboration and adoption of a democratic constitution.
Elections would then be held on the basis of this constitution. And, for the first time, South Africa would have a body of lawmakers which would, like yourselves, be mandated by the whole people.
Despite the admitted commitment of President de Klerk to walk this road with us, and despite our acceptance of his integrity and honesty of his purposes, we would be fools to believe that the road ahead of us is without major hurdles. Too many among our white compatriots are steeped in the ideology of racism to admit easily that change must come.
 
The Economic Sanctions
For those who care to worry about violence in our country, as we do, it is at these forces that they should focus their attention, a process in which we are engaged. We must contend still with the reality that South Africa is a country in the grip of the apartheid crime against humanity. . . .
Therefore, we say we still have a struggle on our hands; our common and noble efforts to abolish the system of white minority domination must continue. We are encouraged and strengthened by the fact of the agreement between ourselves and this Congress, as well as President Bush and his Administration, that sanctions will remain in place. Sanctions should remain in place because the purpose for which they were imposed has not yet been achieved.
We would like to take this opportunity to thank you all for the principled struggle you waged which resulted in the adoption of the historic, comprehensive anti-apartheid act which made such a decisive contribution to the process of moving our country forward toward negotiations. We request that you go further and assist us with the material resources which will enable us to promote the peace process, and meet other needs which arise from the changing situation you have helped to bring about.
 
Champions of Freedom
Mr. Speaker, Mr. President, Senators and Representatives, we went to jail because it was impossible to still - to sit still while the obscenity of the apartheid system was being imposed on our people.
It would have been immoral to keep quiet while a racist tyranny sought to reduce an entire people into a status worse than that of the beasts of the forest. It would have been an act of treason against the people and against our conscience to allow fear and the drive toward self-preservation to dominate our behavior, obliging us to absent ourselves from the struggle for democracy and human rights, not only in our country, but throughout the world.
We could not have made an acquaintance through literature with human giants such as George Washington, Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson and not been moved to act, as they were moved to act.
We could not have heard of and admired John Brown, Sojourner Truth, Frederick Douglass, W. E. B. Du Bois, Marcus Garvey, Martin Luther King Jr. and others.
We could not have heard of these and not be moved to act as they were moved to act. We could not have known of your Declaration of Independence and not elected to join in the struggle to guarantee the people's life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.
We are grateful to you all that you persisted in your resolve to help us and other political prisoners released from jail. You have given us the gift and privilege to rejoin our people, yourselves and the rest of the international community in the common effort to transform South Africa into a united, a democratic and nonracial country.
You have given us the power to join hands with all people of conscience to fight for the victory of democracy and human rights throughout the world.
We are glad that you merged with our own people to make it possible for us to emerge from the darkness of the prison cell and join the contemporary process of the renewal of the world. We thank you most sincerely for all you have done and count on you to persist in your noble endeavor to free the rest of our political prisoners and to emancipate our people from the larger prison that is apartheid South Africa.
The day may not be far when we will borrow the words of Thomas Jefferson and speak of the will of the South African nation in the exercise of that will by this united nation of black and white people it must surely be that there will be born a country on the southern tip of Africa which you will be proud to call a friend and an ally because of its contribution to the universal striving towards liberty, human rights, prosperity and peace among the people.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Spectators watching Nelson Mandela's motorcade yesterday as it moved along Pennsylvania Avenue from Capitol Hill. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Approves Heart Drug Made by Soviets

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The Food and Drug Administration has approved a drug developed in the Soviet Union to treat potentially fatal irregular heart rhythms, and experts said today that the medicine was likely to become a primary treatment for the condition because of its low rate of adverse effects.
The Du Pont Company of Wilmington, Del., which will market the drug worldwide under the name Ethmozine, said the medicine was the first licensed to an American company by the Soviets. The drug, discovered in 1964 and widely used in the Soviet Union, was approved by the F.D.A. last week but the announcement was withheld until today, said Kurt Landgraf, a Du Pont pharmaceutical official.
 
Worldwide Sales Planned
Du Pont said that Ethmozine should be available for wide use in September and that the company would market the drug throughout the world except in the Soviet Union and countries that are its economic partners. The drug, which Du Pont said is expensive to make, should cost patients $2 to $4 daily, a price similar to other drugs in its class. 
Under the licensing agreement, the Soviet Government is to receive a 4 percent royalty on worldwide sales revenue, Mr. Landgraf said.
Heart specialists said the drug, which is used to treat ventricular arrhythmia, a condition that can lead to a heart attack, appears to have far fewer adverse side effects than similar drugs, which are widely used but are not well tolerated by patients.
The heart drug, also known by its generic name moricizine, remains the centerpiece of a major Government study of treating arrhythmia that was disrupted last year when scientists found that two other medicines in the test increased fatalities by two to three times among participants.
Use of the two drugs, Tambocor and Enkaid, was suspended for mild or moderate heart rhythm irregularities. The study, the Cardiac Arrhythmia Suppression Trial, has continued using only moricizine.
Dr. Craig Pratt of the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, an expert on the drug, said there were eight other anti-arrhythmia drugs in the same class as moricizine, but all were reported to have more common adverse side effects. With the new drug, about 7 percent of the patients have stopped using it because of dizziness, stomach upset or other problems. But with the other drugs, he said, discontinuation rates vary from 30 percent to 50 percent because of a variety of adverse reactions, including severe diarrhea and nausea. About 10 million Americans suffer from various kinds of ventricular arrhythmias, experts said, and the condition leads to 300,000 fatal heart attacks annually. People who survive a heart attack are at increased risk of suffering a subsequent attack if they have irregular heart rhythms. These are the higher-risk patients who are the subject of the Government study, which is expected to continue until 1994.
 
Erratic Signals Suppressed
The cause of arrhythmia is largely unknown, experts said, but scientists believe medicine that controls the condition suppresses the erratic signals that initiate beats and slows the electrical conduction in heart tissue.
Dr. Joel Morganroth of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, who is involved in the Federal study, told a news briefing that if medication failed to control severe arrhythmia, doctors tried to control the heartbeats by implanting small electical devices that shock the heart back into a normal beat pattern, a procedure that can cost up to $50,000.
''Medication is always preferable, and the drugs we have are all effective in certain groups of patients'' Dr. Morganroth said. But the other drugs in moricizine's class can also increase the risk of death by starting wild irregular heart beats or congestive heart failure over time by weakening the heart muscle, he said.
''Ethmozine is uncommon in not causing worse heart function, a possibility with the other drugs,'' Dr. Morganroth added. ''Its long-term safety looks good.''

LENGTH: 410 words

HEADLINE: Antitrusts Break for Insurers Helps Consumers;
Industry Is Sound

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There is no comparison between the savings and loan industry disaster and a modest increase in the number of insolvencies in the insurance industry (''Insurer Insolvencies: Next Mega-Crisis?'' by Melvin L. Schweitzer, Op-Ed, June 8). This kind of worrisome talk causes unnecessary concern to the policyholders of insurance companies.
Granted, one could find similarities among individual insolvencies of savings and loans and of insurers: mismanagement, underreserving and competitive pressures. But it is ludicrous to parallel the two industries. 
Mr. Schweitzer acknowledges there have been only 150 insurer insolvencies since 1970, a rate dwarfed by failures in savings and loans and indeed in commercial banking. In 1989 alone, 328 savings and loans were taken over by the Government.
The cost of insolvencies to the insurance industry in the 1980's is estimated at $7 billion. Compare that with the $500 billion cost to taxpayers Mr. Schweitzer says is needed to bail out the savings and loans. In effect, they have created a separate national debt.
The insurance industry, despite the pressures on it, is fundamentally sound. The crucial indicator is the extremely strong overall capital position of the industry. For example, the frequently cited premium-to-surplus ratio now stands at 1.6 to 1, well below the generally accepted regulatory standard of 3 to 1.
And the industry's assets are secure. Property-casualty companies have less than 1 percent of their assets in junk bonds and life companies less than 5 percent.
Mr. Schweitzer's views, however, reinforce a point the insurance business has been making for years: This industry faces the political manipulation of its prices in direct contradiction to the laws of economics that say rates must be adequate to pay costs. Laws such as California's Proposition 103, which cut prices without cutting costs, only worsen the situation. And part of the insurance industry's financial condition is not of its own making. The system is threatened by a litigation morass, with more than 50 cents on the dollar in litigation expenditures going to lawyers, rather than claimants.
The insurance industry supports strong regulation: a system that maintains solvency and sees that unethical operators - and there are some of those in every business - are removed.
 
SEAN MOONEY
Senior Vice President and Economist
Insurance Information Institute
 New York, June 8, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Japan's Military Machine

BYLINE: By Dov S. Zakheim; Dov S. Zakheim is chief executive officer of SPC International, a high-technology consulting firm.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
The flap over the illegal transfer of ''Star Wars''-related software to four Japanese companies, all of them tied into the Japanese aerospace sector, underscores the growing pressures on the longstanding U.S.-Japanese security relationship.
For 45 years, Washington has been happy to underwrite the primary defense needs of both countries while Tokyo has gone about its business of becoming an economic giant. But now, with the U.S. struggling with budget deficits and Japan burgeoning with trade surpluses, this arrangement is crumbling.
Unless the U.S. confirms in the strongest terms its commitment to maintaining a military presence in Asia, Japan - and its rapidly expanding military-industrial complex -will fill the power vacuum. 
After years of prodding by the U.S., the logic of Japanese military economics has become inexorable: the 1990-'91 Japanese military budget, already the sixth largest in the world, is slated to increase by 6.1 per cent, the highest rate in five years. This expansion in military spending is breeding an industrial appetite for the high-tech that fuels research, development and especially sales.
The four Japanese companies have stated that they had no intention of using the software for military purposes, and deny any complicity in obtaining the software illegally.
The first contention is beside the point. The software can indeed be used for military research, and it would be foolhardy for the purchasers - which include Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japan's largest military contractor, and Ishikawa-Harima, a missile manufacturer - to own such a valuable resource and not exploit it. Certainly, such behavior would be out of character for efficiency-conscious Japanese corporations.
The Japanese denial of complicity is perfectly valid on its face. Nevertheless, as anyone who has sought to export high-tech products can attest, potential recipients (other than rogue governments) will rarely commit funds until an export license has been obtained. In their eagerness to acquire the software in question, four highly sophisticated companies appear to have jettisoned the caution for which Japanese firms are noted.
What does all this mean for the U.S.-Japan relationship? In one respect, it is more grist for the Japan-bashers' mill. Those who seek to restrict Japanese imports, or to ''punish'' Japan for trade violations, will see in this case another Toshiba affair, in which U.S. technology-transfer rules were cynically violated.
But the Star Wars software incident more closely resembles the arrangements for technology-sharing in the U.S.-Japan joint venture to build the FSX fighter plane. As such, it goes to the heart of the security relationship, which needs to be disentangled from the trade issue.
Diminishing budget resources, and the collapse of the Soviet empire, are calling into question the permanence of the U.S. military presence in East Asia. At the same time, the allure of the international arms market, growing Japanese political and diplomatic assertiveness and the continuing Japanese military buildup are creating a momentum for military expansion that Japanese industry has no desire to resist. Ultimately, it may sweep up the Government as well.
No one, least of all the vast majority of Japanese citizens, shows any enthusiasm for a revival of even a shadow of the militarism of the 1930's. Moreover, Japan has taken a more skeptical view of perestroika than any major Western powers. It continues to seek American support for its security.
Nevertheless, only Japan is in a position to fill any power vacuum that a drawdown of U.S. and Soviet forces might create. Japanese industry can therefore be viewed as responding to current military economic realities and anticipating political realities. In these circumstances, a punitive approach to Japan's military industry will be doomed to failure.
The U.S. must signal its resolve to maintain its military role in East Asia and in the defense of Japan. It must resist applying the lessons of European arms reductions to a region where alliance structures and local rivalries are radically different.
At the same time, Washington must facilitate cooperation, rather than brutal competition, between Japan's emerging military-industrial powerhouse and our shrinking military-industrial base. Moreover, given the intimate ties between the Japanese Government and its industrial giants, Washington could look to Tokyo for still greater scrutiny of commercial technology transactions.
Only in this way can both governments expect to curb the natural impulse of Japan's expanding military-oriented businesses and industries to overlook long-term national security consequences in favor of short-term economic and technology gains.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Talks Taxes And Anxiety

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
At train stations, barber shops, pizza parlors and on street corners, wherever New Jerseyans gather, the talk has turned to taxes, and the largest tax increase in the state's history.
For some, the $2.8 billion in higher taxes passed last week by the Legislature - and the new Governor who proposed them - represent the return of an ever-hungry and avaricious government after the hiatus of the 1980's.
To others, the new sales and income taxes, as well as a host of new policies by Gov. Jim Florio, represent an unfortunate but necessary new direction for the state. At a time of regionwide fiscal problems, those taxpayers say they are willing to accept higher taxes, if leaders can convince them that they will ultimately receive something worthwhile in return.
Perhaps the anxious tone of the electorate, reflected in dozens of random interviews this week, was best expressed by Lea Forst of Scotch Plains, who waited at the Westfield train station Monday afternoon for her husband's commuter train to arrive from Manhattan. 
 
'Emotionally, I am Resentful'
''I realize that government has problems,'' said Ms. Forst, a Republican who voted for Mr. Florio last year. ''Intellectually, I realize that the state needs more money. But emotionally, I am resentful. Why do I have to subsidize the whole system when I can't afford it?''
Interviews in more than a dozen towns and cities around the state found that many people were confused by Mr. Florio's complex agenda and clearly understood only that taxes were going up. In addition, most expressed anxiety about living in a state where a combination of property taxes, insurance costs and a weak economy will make it harder for average people to pay all their bills.
Many were still trying to discern in all this whether Mr. Florio was an enemy or a friend. Perhaps most of all, people were confused by the flood of numbers out of Trenton, and by unclear explanations of how much they eventually will have to pay.
''Everybody's complaining because all the taxes are going up,'' said Russ Gibson, a barber at the Tip Top Barber Shop in the Borough of Freehold. ''It's disgusting, it's disgraceful; it really is.'' He said he did not understand Mr. Florio's reasoning, adding, ''Everybody's hurting.''
Another barber, Norm Kramer, said he believed the new taxes on cigarettes, which will raise the cost of a pack by nearly a quarter, would spur a new and unneeded black market in bootleg cigarettes.
''Businesses in New York now will think twice about coming to New Jersey,'' Mr. Kramer added.
But Brian Mallon, a young man waiting for one of the chairs to open up, suddenly grew tired of the attacks on Mr. Florio.
''He was left a big dump,'' Mr. Mallon interupted. ''There is only so much he can cut, so he's got to raise taxes. Kean left a big mess.'' But if the Governor could gather some solace from Mr. Mallon's support, it might be dashed by a talk with Steven Cohen, the proprietor of Jilly's Deli on West Main Street, a short distance away. Mr. Cohen was vexed at Mr. Florio's explanation for the tax increases, and said he felt a foreboding, as a New Yorker who fled to New Jersey 23 years ago, ''when taxes were one-third of what I pay now.''
 
Test Case for New Taxes
''I don't think the Governor has come clean on what he's trying to do,'' Mr. Cohen added. ''Between paying more and having more taken away, the Governor is creating an incentive for people to move, and that's a shame because this is clean state, a beautiful state.''
Last week, the Democrat-controlled Legislature in Trenton turned the state into something of a test case for how an electorate, which supported the anti-tax campaigns of Ronald Reagan in the 1980's, will respond to new taxes.
The Legislature passed a series of bills that will raise the income tax next Jan. 1 for more affluent New Jerseyans, raise the sales tax next week to 7 percent from 6 percent and extend the sales tax to a number of new items. Mr. Florio's program will also pump more than a billion dollars into the public schools of 360 poor and middle-income districts and remove state aid over several years to 220 of the most affluent.
Mr. Florio has said the voters of New Jersey will eventually accept the higher sales tax to make up for budget difficulties that he says were left him by his predecessor, the Republican governor, Thomas H. Kean.
 
Waiting for Public's Reaction
The Democratic Governor, who took office in January, has also wagered that he will win the support of voters of the lower and middle classes. Some of the money from the $1.2 billion in new income tax revenue is intended for property tax rebates for homeowers and renters with taxable income of less than $100,000.
Republicans have attacked the Florio program as a return of high-tax liberalism of the 1960's, which they say will destroy the pro-business environment created by Mr. Kean and chase businesses and jobs from the state.
Both Democrats and Republicans in Trenton are waiting to see just how the public reacts to all this: whether they understand what Mr. Florio has done, and whether they will rebel against more taxes or embrace what they see as strong leadership.
''A lot of new Jerseyans are upset that Florio is going to raise taxes,'' said Jacqueline C. Ramdial, a 26-year-old home health aide who lives and works in Newark. ''It didn't make me happy either but I saw the reason for doing it.''
 
Rage in Ridgewood
Standing outside Newark City Hall at lunchtime, Ms. Ramdial said she understood that Mr. Florio's plan was intended to bring aid to the Newark schools, which she said were very bad and in need of help. ''I think it's time the system was changed,'' she said. ''Some middle-class New Jerseyans see it as a threat to their lifestyle but I don't think he's doing it to leave out anybody.''
''In order to make society work as a whole, you need everybody.''
But in one of the wealthiest suburbs of Northern New Jersey, Ridgewood, in Bergen County, people along the main thoroughfare, Ridgewood Avenue, described themselves as enraged. Under the Florio plan the state aid to Ridgewood schools would drop to $5.5 million from $8.3 million between the summer of 1992 and 1996.
''I can't believe this is happening in New Jersey, particularly after Governor Kean did so much for education,'' said Anita Kusy, a Ridgewood resident, who has a daughter entering kindergarten. ''Governor Florio wants to give everyone equal opportunity, but everybody has individual differences. You just can't say equality is going to make everybody the same.''
''All you're doing is lowering the level of education to mediocrity,'' she said.
Her husband, Richard Kusy, meanwhile, said that the new taxes might spur an exodus of New Jersey residents.
''You start to consider, 'Why New Jersey?' '' Mr. Kusy said. ''You start thinking about other states - Connecticut, Pennsylvania. Houses are cheaper there, taxes are cheaper and you're getting more for your money. Here, you'll get taxed to death.'' Katherine Bolender, a 22-year-old recent college graduate working behind the counter of the Alchemist and Barrister croissant shop in Princeton, said she very well might leave the state where she grew up.
''Its ridiculous for me to pay 20 percent of what I make in taxes when the government isn't willing to make cutbacks,'' Ms. Bolender said. ''I have no problem with a tax increase if the government can explain where it is going and why it is necessary.''
Hasbrouck Heights is a conservative town where most residents regard themselves as middle-class New Jerseyans, whose famililes have worked hard and never been flush with cash. James V. Longo Jr., owner of Lovey's Pizzeria on the Boulevard, had both praise and criticism for Governor Florio. The Governor's decision to raise taxes was understandable, Mr. Longo said, to fix budget problems left him by Mr. Kean.
''I don't see any other way to bail ourselves out,'' Mr. Longo said from behind the counter as he prepared pizza for the evening rush. ''I don't see anybody else coming in with contributions. Do you?''
But Mr. Longo, who owns the two-story building that houses his pizzeria and lives in a single-famliy home in Saddle Brook, said he could not accept raising taxes on the middle classes to pay for poor urban schools. And although Mr. Florio argues that his plan aids many middle-class communities, Mr. Longo is unconvinced.
''He's trying to send all the money to the poor areas,'' Mr. Longo said. ''Half of the folks there are not interested in going to school anyway.''
Nearby in the same Bergen County town, Leonard J. Wisse, a self-employed advertising and public relations specialist, said that he understood enough of the Florio plan last week to go out and buy a new Buick before the sales tax went into effect. He said he saved about $300.
''The world has been good to me,'' Mr. Wisse said. ''I don't mind paying taxes. But I want to see it spent wisely.''
