HEADLINE: Marcos Was Not a Thief, Defense Says in Summation

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
Imelda Marcos ''has committed no crime except the crime of loving a man for 35 years, of raising his children, of being his First Lady, of being his ardent supporter, of taking his lavish gifts,'' Mrs. Marcos's lawyer told the jury in his closing statement at her racketeering trial yesterday.
In a riveting closing argument, Mrs. Marcos's chief lawyer, Gerry Spence, portrayed his client as he always has -as a wife who was unfamiliar with her husband's dealings and who, while a big spender, was not a thief.
''She's a world-class shopper,'' Mr. Spence said. ''But she's a world-class decent human being.'' 
Mr. Spence spoke for more than four hours at the United States Court House on Foley Square, striking at the testimony of 95 Government witnesses and the implications of thousands of documents. Mrs. Marcos, the widow of Ferdinand Marcos, the late President of the Philippines, is charged with stealing more than $200 million from her homeland and then secretly buying artwork, jewelry and four buildings in Manhattan.
 
Seemed More Focused
The defense team had not called any witnesses, and this was the chance for Mr. Spence - a Wyoming lawyer who has a reputation as a shrewd master at swaying juries, but who has clashed with the judge during his first New York trial - to return to center stage.
Yesterday, pacing and using water pitchers and his cowboy hat as props, he seemed more focused than he has during the trial. He turned the pages of a book filled with the Government's evidence and addressed them one by one.
Mr. Spence portrayed all of the building purchases in Manhattan as three-way investments by Mr. Marcos, the Philippine Government and Benedicto and Gliceria Tantoco, department store owners who were friends of the Marcoses.
Citing testimony from Rolando Gapud, a former financial adviser to Mr. Marcos, Mr. Spence said that Mrs. Marcos had not been told anything about ''commissions'' that the President had received on Government contracts, and that he had specifically instructed his staff not to inform her.
 
'A Good Investment'
The money was sent into foreign accounts, Mr. Spence said, as protection against declining economic conditions in the Philippines at the time. The buildings, he said, were bought as ''a good investment against inflation.
''This doesn't sound like Mrs. Marcos's operation,'' Mr. Spence said. ''It sounds like the official operation of a Government.''
''One document out of 300,000 has her signature after the date of the alleged wrongdoing, and that is $700,000 from a Swiss account to pay for her jewels,'' he said. Mrs. Marcos's signature, Mr. Spence said, appeared on only one of the documents dated after 1972, when the prosecution says the crimes began.
Mr. Spence ridiculed prosecutors for basing their case on the words they so often repeated in their summation: ''''Of course she knew.''
''It's a hole so big you could drive a truck through it,'' he said.
Mr. Marcos was ousted from power by Corazon Aquino, and Mr. Spence argued that the case had a political foundation.
''Mrs. Aquino used this trial for political leverage - no prosecution, no bases,'' he said, referring to American military bases in the Philippines.
Today the lawyer for Mrs. Marcos's co-defendant, Adnan Khashoggi, will deliver his summation.

HEADLINE: Minorities Lead in Work Force but Lag in Pay

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Blacks and members of other minorities now account for more than half of New York City's resident labor force, but they continue to lag behind whites in higher paying jobs, a Labor Department report released yesterday showed.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said at a briefing that the new status of minorities underscored the importance the groups would play in determining the health of the city's economy in the 1990's.
He said the number of minority-group members in the labor force -defined as those who have a job or are looking for one - rose by 400,000 in the 1980's, while the number of whites in the labor force declined by 100,000. 
The net gain of 300,000 brought the city's resident labor force to 3.36 million, with 1.69 million of them from minorities, including blacks, Hispanic groups, Asians, American Indians and others not classified as white.
 
Major Share in Growth
In part because of higher birth rates and immigration, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, minorities are likely to comprise an ''overwhelming'' share of the growth in the city's resident labor force in the 1990's. Assuring that workers will have sufficient skills for the increasingly demanding jobs that the local economy is generating will be critical as the city copes with what many expect will be a labor shortage.
Yesterday's report indicated that the recent economic experience of minorities in the city had been mixed.
In 1989, 24 percent of black workers had managerial, professional or technical jobs, up from 19 percent in 1983 and significantly above the national average for blacks in 1989, also 19 percent. But the level was still substantially below the 36 percent of whites employed in those higher-paying jobs.
Although information on Hispanic workers is limited, only 15 percent are employed in managerial positions while 23 percent are dependent on manufacturing, a rapidly shrinking part of the city economy.
Employment of minorities in the city rose by more than 200,000 since 1980, to about 1 million, but they have twice the unemployment rate of whites, 9.6 percent as against 4.1 percent.
 
Occupational Disparities
''The occupational disparities continue to be major,'' Mr. Ehrenhalt said. ''The direction of the city economy and the occupational profile of the rapidly growing minority work force are substantially out of alignment.''
The report focused on the city's resident labor force, which does not include commuters, most of whom are white. Still, Mr. Ehrenhalt said the majority status of minorities in the labor force ''should be sending some signals'' about problems the groups face, including an educational system with a high dropout rate.

HEADLINE: Movement on the Budget But a Big Gulf to Cross

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
President Bush's statement today backing away from his ''no new taxes'' pledge may have been the political icebreaker needed to get the budget talks with Congress moving.
But it still left a wide gulf between the President and Congressional Democrats over which taxes to raise, which programs to cut, how big the military budget should be and how to change the budget law.
''The toughest questions are still ahead of them, no doubt about it,'' said Stanley E. Collender, a Government budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm.
Both sides agree that the deficit in the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, will be about $160 billion, not counting Government spending for the savings and loan bailout. They also agree that the deficit figure should be reduced by $50 billion to $60 billion next year and by $400 billion to $600 billion cumulatively over the next five years. 
 
Budget Strategies
The Democrats want about a third of the deficit reduction to come from tax increases, a third from military spending and a third from domestic programs. The White House and Republican lawmakers would like somewhat more to come from domestic programs and somewhat less from taxes and the military. But the fundamental issue involves the specific components, not the proportions.
These individual elements, whether they involve taxes or spending, are so unpopular politically that they could not be enacted on their own. But a package might be palatable. ''The general principle has always applied that nothing is agreed to until all elements have been agreed to,'' the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, said today.
The most difficult question, of course, is taxes. Mr. Bush and most Republican lawmakers want to cut the tax rate on capital gains, which under current law are treated like ordinary income, and that is what the President meant in his statement today when he said a budget agreement should include ''growth incentives.''
Everyone agrees that a capital gains tax cut would raise several billion dollars next year as investors sold stocks and bonds to take advantage of the new rate.
 
Disagreement Over Tax Cut
Republicans say it would continue to raise money forever. Democrats maintain that after the initial spurt, it would cost billions a year in lost revenue. Moreover, the Democrats say the benefits from such a tax change would go almost entirely to the rich.
The Democrats might be willing to accept a capital gains tax cut if the President agreed to raise the income tax rate paid by the wealthiest Americans to at least 33 percent from 28 percent. But Mr. Bush can be expected to oppose vigorously any change in income tax rates, at least at the outset of the tax negotiations.
Beyond the income and capital gains taxes, the negotiators could probably raise about $10 billion a year, without causing much political strain, from increased taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages. Higher taxes on gasoline and imported oil would be somewhat more difficult politically but are perhaps possible. Steep new taxes in this area could raise as much as $20 billion to $30 billion a year.
Finding $20 billion or so to cut in spending for domestic programs might be as difficult as agreeing on which taxes to raise. Democrats and Republicans agree that the cuts will have to come in automatic benefit programs, the rapidly growing sector of the budget in which meeting eligibility requirements automatically entitles a person to Government benefits.
 
Taxing Some Benefits
The biggest entitlement program is Social Security. No one expects retirement benefits to be reduced, but the negotiators might agree to subject a larger part of Social Security benefits to income taxes.
Some economists have suggested a one-year freeze in cost-of-living increases in Social Security payments and in adjustment of income-tax brackets for inflation. That would raise a large amount of money but is probably not practical politically.
Other ways of cutting spending for entitlement programs would be to reduce Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals, lower crop-support payments to farmers and reduce benefits to retired Federal workers.
In military spending, Mr. Bush and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney have so far agreed to cuts of about $3 billion below the spending that would be needed next year to keep pace with inflation. Congress is talking about $12 billion to $15 billion.
 
Hints at Compromise
Many Republicans believe that the President has been too timid about cuts at the Pentagon and that he will surely have to raise his offer. But Democrats may accept somewhat smaller military cuts next year if much larger ones are promised for subsequent years.
Whatever else they agree to, the negotiators will have to rewrite the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. That law requires a deficit in the next fiscal year not exceeding $64 billion and across-the-board spending reductions in most programs if the official Government projection does not meet that target.
Failure by the President and Congress to agree to any deficit reduction at all, leaving the deficit figure about $100 billion above the target, would mean automatic cuts of 25 percent in military outlays and 37 percent in all domestic programs except Social Security and grants to the poor.
That would be politically and economically unacceptable. ''What would you do,'' asked Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, ''with the Federal prison system, the border patrol, vital safety programs, food inspection, air traffic control, customs agents at Kennedy Airport?''
Even if the negotiators find a way to reduce the deficit by $50 billion to $60 billion, the amount they and most economists agree can be cut without seriously damaging the economy, they will still miss the target by $40 billion or so.
Furthermore, the Gramm-Rudman law will have to be raised to accommodate spending for the savings and loan bailout, which will amount to about $75 billion next year.

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1853 words

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Matching Those Who Need Guidance With Those Who Have Been There

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
For at least part of a day, Tacuma Russell will escape the somber shambles of his struggling neighborhood in the Roxbury section of Boston. Today, to celebrate the boy's 14th birthday, a Boston University sophomore will drive him two hours along Interstate 90 to an amusement park, where the two plan to enjoy roller coaster rides and blue clouds of cotton candy.
The college student, James Spearman Stewart, is not related to Tacuma. Through a joint program of the Boston public school system and his university, for which Mr. Stewart volunteered, he was assigned to be Tacuma's mentor.
For the last nine months, Mr. Stewart has been involved with the boy, in hopes of improving life for Tacuma, whose mother was 16 when he was born. ''We all have doubts about where we want to go and how we're going to get there,'' said Mr. Stewart. 
The 1980's saw an enormous surge in the number of programs similar to the one that regularly brings Mr. Stewart and Tacuma together. In recent years, the idea of directly contributing to a youngster's chances of success has found great appeal among educators, business leaders and others who are increasingly frustrated with bureaucracies that appear too sluggish to offer much help.
Across the United States, mentor programs aim to match adults with young people who may need help in school, in making career decisions, or just in coping with the complexities of life in the late 20th century. There are mentors who are corporate executives, college students, journalists, retired nuns and electrical workers. Some programs link mentors to young people who are in trouble with the juvenile justice system; others match adults with college students. There are even mentors for mentors. ''They are springing up every day, popping up like daisies in the meadow,'' Michael A. Bailin, president of Public/Private Ventures, a youth advocate group, said of the crop of new programs. ''Much of this is out of desperation. People are looking for something that makes sense.''
Lisa Nehus, a project coordinator for the National Media Outreach Center in Pittsburgh, has been trying for the last five months to establish a national network of mentor programs.
''There is really no way of knowing how many programs there are out there,'' she said, estimating there are ''thousand and thousands.'' So far, Ms. Nehus said, she has 126 mentor program contacts and expects nearly 500 more by the end of next year.
Shayne Schneider, founder and president of Mentors Inc., a private, nonprofit group in Washington, D.C., said if the last decade's growth of mentor programs was charted, it would appear as a sweeping upward curve.
''There were twice as many programs last year and twice as many programs the year before and the year before,'' she said. ''It's been a phenomenon mostly of the late 80's.'' 'Point of Light' In Eyes of Backers With roots firmly planted in volunteerism, mentor programs appear to have ascended to President Bush's ''thousand points of light,'' their supporters say. Carol Farroe, a youth coordinator for Mentors Inc., proudly points out that Barbara Bush was chairperson for her group's first graduation banquet last month.
Only in their broadest outlines do these new mentor programs resemble their 85-year-old ancestor, Big Brothers/Big Sisters of America, many experts agree. Mentor programs, particularly those spawned on college campuses and corporate offices, concentrate less on creating surrogate relatives and more on offering friendly and trusted advisers.
Many programs are designed to help poor black and Hispanic students, educators and social scientists say, primarily because minority youths generally face greater risk of being locked out of opportunities. A number of mentor programs are being used to help attract black and Hispanic students to college and then help them once they enter.
Program organizers, however, are quick to add that much of America's youth, regardless of color, could benefit from mentoring in an era of mounting numbers of single-parent households and latch-key children and schools overburdened with crime, violence and drugs.
''This is not rocket science that we are talking about here,'' said Brooke Beaird, director of Campus Partners in Learning, a mentor program operating at 14 colleges across the country. ''Kids need warm, adult relationships to give them a lift. It is not very complex.'' Pitfalls in Matching Generosity and Need But within what some supporters call ''the mentoring movement,'' there is considerable disagreement about precisely what should constitute a mentor relationship and whether such relationships can be fostered on a mass scale. Some critics have likened the difficulty of successfully pairing mentors with young people, usually of vastly different backgrounds, to blind dating.
In some cases, administrators of mentor programs believe, mentor and youngster should be of the same race or ethnic group.
At the University of Washington, for instance, officials say they have had great success with matching university graduates who are American Indian with freshmen who are Indian.
''It's one of the first things we do unless the student says no,'' said Bill Baker, the university's vice president of minority affairs. ''Through that same experience, they know about the problems of homesickness.''
Others, such as Jerome Grossman, chairman of the advisory committee for the country's largest mentor group, the 10,000-member Career Beginnings Program, said there is no evidence that the race of a mentor makes any difference.
''It has much more to do with a mentor's sense of being outgoing, his sense of patience,'' said Dr. Grossman, chief of the New England Medical Center in Boston. Counting the Ways They Have Benefited The Commonwealth Fund, a national philanthropy based in New York that operates Career Beginnings in 16 cities around the country, recently commissioned a Louis Harris study of program participants.
In a sample of 400 teen-agers across the country, the study found that 57 percent of them said their mentors helped them get along better with teachers; 59 percent said their grades improved, and 53 percent said their mentors helped them resist illegal drugs.
Public/Private Ventures, a Philadelphia-based nonprofit group that conducts and researches programs for youths with disadvantages, is beginning a more extensive $4 million study of mentoring programs this summer. Its officials said it will be the first comprehensive examination of how effective mentoring is when used on a large scale.
''It's important to understand what these programs are doing and how they're doing it,'' said the group's president, Mr. Bailin. ''We want to prevent what might be a good thing from becoming a vanishing fad, or being misused.''
Among the questions the study will try to answer, he said, are whether mentoring makes a genuine difference in improving young people's lives or ability to achieve; whether it can be duplicated by large institutions such as welfare and juvenile-justice agencies, and whether there are enough adults willing to participate.
For years, relationships based on nurturing, between teachers and students, supervisors and their charges - between those who know and those who do not - have occurred naturally, without outside intervention. The attempt to create such relationships, experts and mentors say, is at the center of the new popularity of mentor programs.
Philip M. Butterfield, a 49-year-old vice president at Citibank, said he volunteered for the company's mentor program because he believed it was ''by far the best opportunity to make a change in someone's life.''
''I enjoy this so much,'' he said in an interview from his midtown Manhattan office. ''It's really a painless way to give back.''
In 1982, Citicorp created its Fellows Program, offering students an annual $3,200 college scholarship and a Citicorp executive to serve as the student's mentor.
The students are selected from member schools of the United Negro College Fund, and they are teamed with their mentors for the four years they are undergraduate students. Connecticut Banker Guides a Freshman Jeffrey Parker was a freshman engineering major at Morehouse University in Atlanta when he began meeting with Mr. Butterfield. The following fall, after campus visits, long talks and stays with Mr. Butterfield and his family in suburban Connecticut, Mr. Parker changed his major to business. Now he dreams of pursuing a law degee upon graduation.
''He's an unlimited knowledge base,'' Mr. Parker said of his mentor. ''What I want to know, he knows. What I want to see, he's seen. What I want to do, he's done.''
Mr. Parker, 21 years old, comes from a black middle-class family. His father is a civil engineer for the Air Force. For the last two summers, Mr. Butterfield has been able to get Jeffrey a summer job at the bank.
''It's been a great experience,'' Mr. Parker said. ''My father is really happy. I'm working, and that helps me to contribute to my undergraduate costs.''
In New York City, where the annual Hispanic high school dropout rate is 33 percent, a mentor program exclusively for Hispanic children who are doing poorly in school was started in March, under the auspices of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Office for Hispanic Affairs. The purpose of the program, which matches fifth- through seventh-graders with Hispanic mentors employed at Nynex Corporation, is to persuade the children to stay in school.
The program is part of the New York State Mentoring Committee, which was founded by the state's First Lady, Matilda Raffa Cuomo, who is also the group's chairwoman. Great Expectations, Or Realistic Ones? Marc Freedman, a senior associate for Public/Private Ventures, has received a $90,000 grant from the Ford Foundation to write a book about mentoring. After recently completing his research, he is concerned that the concept, while good, is perhaps being oversold. As a consequence, he said, he is afraid it ''will be rejected because it does live up to these unrealistic expectations.''
Speaking recently at the National Mentoring Conference in Washington, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said mentoring can ''keep kids in school, turn young lives around, impact on the social problems of our time, improve the quality of our work force, and insure America's continued economic competitiveness.''
Along the way, emotional, almost familial, ties sometimes develop between mentors and the people they try to help. And sometimes they don't.
Despite hours of school visits, shared study sessions, movies and hamburgers, some walls stand between James Stewart and Tacuma Russell. When Mr. Stewart hugs him goodbye, Tacuma refuses to hug him back.
''He's just not used to affection, and when you're not used to it it's hard to give it back,'' said Mr. Stewart, his voice betraying disappointment. ''I think that's especially true when it comes to men.
''He has a hard perception of black men due to his background,'' said Mr. Stewart who, like Tacuma, is black. Thinking of his own childhood, he said, ''I was very fortunate.''

Butterfield, left, a vice president at Citibank in Manhattan, is participating in a Citicorp Fellows program, as a mentor to Jeffrey Parker, right, a student at Morehouse University in Atlanta. HEADLINE: Chrysler, in Shift, to Buy Dollar Car Rental

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 26

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation agreed today to buy Dollar Rent A Car Systems Inc., one of the last large rental-car companies not already owned by an auto maker.
The move represents an apparent reversal from an earlier decision by the nation's No. 3 auto maker to reduce sales to rental-car companies. Owning part or all of a rental company gives an auto maker a captive market for its vehicles.
Chrylser declined to say how much it would be paying for Dollar, the nation's fifth-largest car-rental agency. Chrysler also owns the Thrifty and Snappy rental-car systems, but neither has outlets on airport property, as Dollar does for most of its operations. 
Less than six months ago, Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said the auto maker was bypassing opportunities to sell vehicles to rental-car fleets because the discounts expected by fleet operators cut too deeply into profit margins.
Moreover, the sales to the rental fleets have become so competitive that auto makers must agree to buy back the vehicles at a set price. Indeed, Chrysler said the recent steep drop in its share of the automotive market was partly because of its deliberate reduction of sales to fleets.
Referring to the sales of cars to rental fleets, Mr. Iacocca told the National Automobile Dealers Association Convention in February that there were ''too many buybacks, pouring too many low-mileage current model cars through the distribution system at prices that undercut new cars and destroy resale values.''
Explaining Mr. Iacocca's statement in light of the company's decision today to buy Dollar, a Chrysler spokesman said, ''Mr. Iacocca was addressing the situation at the time.''
The purchase of Dollar is expected to be completed by Aug. 15.
Aggressive sales of vehicles to rental-car fleets in the past few years have come about as a result of an overcapacity in United States and Canadian auto-making market. In addition, auto makers have been buying interests in rental-car companies to insure that they will have an outlet for their products.
The General Motors Corporation has minority interests in both Avis Inc. and National Car Rental System, the nation's second and third-largest car rental agencies. And the Ford Motor Company owns a minority interest in the Hertz Corporation and provides financing for the Budget Rent-A-Car and fourth-largest agencies in the country.
Chrysler and General Motors are the domestic auto makers with the biggest over-capacity problems, so they have the greatest need to sell to rental-car fleets as a means of widening their customer base.
 
'A Rock and a Hard Place'
''Chrysler's caught between a rock and a hard place,'' said Maryann Keller, an automotive analyst for Furman, Selz, Mager, Dietz & Birney. ''Either their profits are going to be hurt by the discounts, or their volume is going to be hurt because they can't sell enough cars.''
Some economists are concerned that the overcapacity in new cars and the discounts being granted to promote their sales have been driving down trade-in values on used cars, which ultimately will hurt new-car sales, Ms. Keller said.
Japanese auto makers, to some degree, have also become more interested in selling to fleets. Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America on Tuesday became the first importer to buy a rental fleet when it completed the acquisition of Value Rent-A-Car Inc. of Deerfield, Fla., a small operator.
Dollar has about 1,000 locations worldwide and a fleet of about 80,000 vehicles, 51,000 in the United States and Canada. About 95 percent of the locations are owned by franchisees, a spokeswoman said.
Chrysler's Thrifty fleet has about 750 outlets and 45,000 cars, serving airports from locations some distance from the terminal. Snappy has 250 locations and 20,000 cars and specializes in providing rental cars for people whose cars have been damaged or stolen, usually paid for by insurance companies.
Henry J. Caruso, who founded Dollar in 1966 in Los Angeles and is currently the company's president and owner, will continue to work for Dollar as a consultant, Chrysler said. Rental revenue for Dollar and its franchises in 1989 topped $600 million, the auto maker said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Rally on Tax Vow

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell in nervous trading yesterday, as dealers juggled a promise from President Bush and the onset of a flood of new Treasury issues.
The President's statement that ''tax revenue increases'' would have to be part of a budget compromise package sent bond prices up by a full point early in the session. Mr. Bush had previously indicated he would oppose new taxes, but his statement yesterday offered the possibility of relief for the nation's burdensome budget deficit.
Stock prices and the dollar also strengthened on the President's statement, but both markets later retreated as investors decided to wait for further action. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 2.72 points, to 2,842.33, and the dollar ended the day down against most major currencies. [Pages D8 and D15.] In the credit markets, the positive long-term implications of the President's remarks were outweighed by the weight of the new supply of Government issues, and prices that had jumped slipped back somewhat. 
 
'Shorts' Pushed Out
Market participants bid on more than $11 billion worth of two-year notes yesterday, and will bid on an additional $8.25 billion of four-year notes today. According to traders, the President's comments made it very difficult for them to position themselves for those auctions.
''The President's remarks pushed all the shorts out of the market,'' one Government bond trader said.
On Monday, traders had set up ''short'' positions by agreeing to sell securities they did not own on the expectation that prices would fall further yesterday before the two-year note auction.
Had the strategy worked, the securities could have been bought back at lower prices. But Mr. Bush's remarks in the morning about possible tax increases, which are viewed as fundamentally positive for the bond market, caused prices to rise in the early afternoon sale.
''The fundamental picture is bullish, but right now we have a little problem finding buyers,'' another trader said. ''A lot of our traditional customers have cash and are positive on the market, but they don't want to screw up their books by taking on new positions at the end of the quarter.''
When buy orders from retail investors failed to materialize after Mr. Bush's comments, the problems of coping with the new supply of Treasury issues began to prey on dealers' minds, and prices receded from their highs.
Traders said the two-year note auction went fairly well even though the bulk of the issue was purchased by Wall Street firms. When the bulk of a debt sale remains in the hands of primary securities dealers, those firms are at risk because their objective is to resell the Treasury issues to the investing public.
 
Average Yield at 8.41%
At the auction, the new notes were sold at an average yield of 8.41 percent, down from an average yield of 8.52 percent at the last two-year note sale on May 23.
Demand from small investors was weak.
Non-competitive bids, a good indicator of demand from individual investors and small banks, amounted to just $1.5 billion for the $11.25 billion in securities that were sold.
Although dealers said they were wary of today's four-year note auction, late yesterday the securities were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.49 percent, down from 8.53 percent late Monday. In times of uncertain demand, yields on new securities tend to rise in advance of when they are auctioned.
Analysts said they were heartened by Mr. Bush's comments, especially by the fact that the President said he was willing to talk about curbing spending on politically sensitive entitlement programs in addition to looking at possible tax increases.
Entitlement programs pay benefits automatically. They include Medicare and Social Security, though Mr. Bush did not mention any specific programs yesterday.
''Bush's statement was very carefully crafted; he kept things deliberately vague,'' said Charles Lieberman, a managing director at the Manufacturers Hanover Securities Corporation. ''But mentioning the 'E' word is just as important as talking about taxes.''
Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at First Fidelity Bancorporation in Newark, said that ''in the past there have always been obstacles to meaningful negotiations on cutting the budget deficit. I see those logjams breaking up.''
Mr. Levy said that a $50 billion deficit-reduction package, in conjunction with a weak economic activity and continued moderation in inflation would push interest rates down significantly over the next 12 months.
''If a budget package of that sort passes, if the Fed remains moderately restrictive and the economy grows at around 1 percent, the overnight Federal funds rate will fall to 7 percent and bond yields will drop sharply, maybe down to as low as 7.25 percent,'' he said.
The Federal funds rate, the money market rate most closely controlled by the Federal Reserve Board, has traded in a very narrow band around 8.25 percent since mid-December.
 
Secondary Market Gains
Those sorts of hopes were reflected in the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday.
Although prices retreated from their early morning highs, by late yesterday the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 102 1/2, up 17/32, to yield 8.50 percent. Late Monday, the closely watched benchmark issue was offered at a price to yield 8.56 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 9/32 late yesterday, up one-quarter of a point, to yield 8.52 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 1/32, up 6/32, to yield 8.47 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.78 percent, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by 3 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 7.68 percent. But one-year bill rates fell by 2 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 7.59 percent.
 
Other Offerings
Elsewhere, the BankAmerica Corporation priced a new $100 million issue of 10-year subordinated notes in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
The 9 3/4 percent notes, which mature July 1, 2000, were priced at $99.28 to yield 9.865 percent, 1.30 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Arizona Transportation Board priced a $175 million negotiated offering of Highway Revenue Bonds through a syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation. The issue consists of serial and term bonds.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6.25 percent on bonds maturing in 1994 to 7.00 percent on bonds that mature in 2003. Term bonds that mature in 2010 carry a 6 percent coupon and were priced to yield 7.10 percent.
The issue is rated Aa by Moody's. S.& P.is expected rate the issue AAA. Following are the results of yesterday's auction of two-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Broader Medicaid: Who Would Pay?

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
A RECENT Supreme Court decision is expected to add to growing pressure for changes in Medicaid. The Court ruled on June 14 that hospitals and nursing homes can file lawsuits to demand ''reasonable and adequate reimbursement'' for their services to Medicaid patients.
Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people, is already straining budgets in most states, and the financially pressed programs have not kept pace with sharp increases in hospital and other medical costs.
Any increases in Medicaid spending would inevitably collide with Federal and state budget limitations, and the Bush Administration seems far from ready for such increases, at least this year. Indeed, in budget talks last week with Congressional leaders, Administration officials proposed $800 million in Medicaid cuts in 1991. Medicaid spends about $60 billion a year, of which about $26 billion comes from states and localities and $34 billion is Federal money. 
But a White House working group is looking hard at Medicaid as part of a review of the quality, accessibility and cost of the health-care system. President Bush announced the review in his State of the Union address in January.
''Everyone believes that we need to look at the design of Medicaid, who it covers and does not cover, and how it is paid for,'' said Constance J. Horner, the Under Secretary of Health and Human Services, who heads the group. ''Medicaid does not cover everyone who is poor.'' The group will make recommendations to the President's Domestic Policy Council at the end of the year.
Most experts say that expanding Medicaid would be the quickest way to assure medical care for many of the 35 million Americans who do not have health insurance. But before adding to the costs of such a big-ticket program, the President and Congress would obviously have to make important decisions about spending priorities and taxes.
Indeed, a recent study by the Urban Institute, a private research group in Washington, estimated that about $10 billion more would be needed each year to cover the poor fully, including those who work but are not insured.
This would be the case, the study found, even under Medicaid ceilings that would restrict eligibility to those earning less than 75 percent of the $10,560 for a family of three that the Federal Government considers the poverty threshhold. To go further and bring in everyone below the poverty line would cost about $14 billion, John F. Holahan and Sheila R. Zedlewski estimated in the study.
Congress recently relaxed the income restrictions to make it easier for pregnant mothers, children up to 6, and the elderly and disabled to get Medicaid. But the extra costs of allowing still more people to become eligible could more than absorb the hoped-for peace dividends from cutbacks in military spending. And the added costs would be even higher if Medicaid payments to doctors and hospitals were raised to the higher levels of the Federal Medicare program for the elderly and disabled, as is also being discussed.
Connecticut has gone somewhat further in easing Medicaid requirements by adopting a package that would also make private insurance more affordable to small businesses with 25 or fewer employees. The many insurance companies based in Hartford hope that the Connecticut plan will be a precedent. They are fighting proposals in California and other states that would turn much of their business over to a government-controlled system like that of Canada.
But Connecticut is hardly typical. ''Connecticut is essentially a very wealthy state with a reasonably good Medicaid program, fewer unemployed, more large employers who provide health coverage, and very responsible insurance leaders,'' said Lawrence S. Lewin, president of Lewin/ICF, a Washington consulting firm.
He likes a proposal by Paul H. O'Neill, chairman of the Aluminum Company of America, which would eliminate employer-paid health benefits and raise wages instead. Under the plan, which Mr. O'Neill recently sketched to the Federal Advisory Council on Social Security and Health Care, employees would have to buy their own health insurance with help, initially, from a tax break.
Ann Labelle, executive director of the advisory council, said Mr. O'Neill's ideas, which are still being developed, would be studied along with a number of other proposals, such as ''nationalizing'' the Connecticut approach, making Medicare a universal benefit, and establishing a Federal reinsurance pool for catastrophic illnesses so private insurance rates could be lowered.
The council is also reviewing a proposal by the Pepper Commission, a bipartisan group headed by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, to replace Medicaid with a new Federal program. Under the Pepper plan, employers would be required to provide health benefits for their workers or pay into state and regional pools to cover the uninsured.
The Pepper proposals would cost $23.4 billion in added Government spending, plus $20 billion from employers. But expanding Medicaid without a plan to make employers pay would cost ''about 50 percent more and cover only about half of the uninsured,'' said Judith Feder, staff director of the Pepper group.

HEADLINE: For Trump, Seeds of a Comeback

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump has lost his aura, and a substantial amount of management freedom. But he has maintained his ownership of 100 percent of his empire. And in that small victory could lie the seeds of a comeback for the battered developer.
Yesterday's 30-day loan by a group of banks provides only a brief respite, but in a longer five-year deal, agreed to in principle, Mr. Trump will have time to maneuver and reason to hope that he can rebound. 
By not giving up any ownership of assets, Mr. Trump could find himself in a position to benefit if the New York real estate and Atlantic City casino markets again show rising values.
 
Might Have It Both Ways
If that happens, Mr. Trump might have it both ways: He could end up having paid less to the banks than he would have if he had been able to meet his bills, but still get the entire benefit of rising asset prices.
On the other hand, if those markets do not turn around, and if cash flows from Mr. Trump's assets, which include the largest strip of vacant land in Manhattan and three casinos in New Jersey, are not sufficient, both he and the banks could end up with substantial losses.
In the five-year deal, Mr. Trump has won lower interest rates from the banks and a deferral of cash interest payments on many of his loans. In return, he has given up control over some of the cash flow in the Trump empire, and has agreed to bring in a new top financial executive and provide the banks with detailed financial information on his businesses.
 
Incentives Provided
The deal with the banks provides incentives - in the form of interest rate rebates - if Mr. Trump is able to pay back his loans sooner rather than later. Such a repayment would almost certainly come from selling one or more major assets, and if such sales are made the cash would go first to the banks, with Mr. Trump having no opportunity to reinvest the money. But Mr. Trump appears to retain control over the decisions of what assets to sell, and when to sell them.
Even if all works out financially for Mr. Trump, he has lost a large part of his image as a larger-than-life entrepreneur of untold wealth, and has been subjected to mocking commentary from around the world. ''The value of the Trump name,'' said Clive Chejet, president of Lippincott & Margulies, a consulting firm in New York, ''is no longer associated with glittering success; it is associated, at the very least, with serious financial difficulties.'' Reviving the Trump gloss, he added, would be ''extremely difficult.''
Mr. Trump, ebullient as ever, sees a different result, with the value of the name ''greatly enhanced'' by the deal. ''There was a media stampede,'' he said yesterday, ''but when you come through adversity, I think people respect that.''
 
No Longer Seems So Paltry
It was only a few months ago, when Mr. Trump's marital problems were making news, that the general opinion was that his wife, Ivana, had made a bad deal when she agreed to take only $25 million in case of a divorce. That no longer seems so paltry.
His aura as a big spender was certainly enhanced by the final leak from the talks, that the banks had insisted his family get by on $450,000 a month - not counting expenses like mortgage payments and the costs of running his yacht and private plane - for the rest of this year, and gradually scale back that spending to $300,000 a month by 1992.
Mr. Trump is far from the only Northeastern real estate developer who has run into financial problems, although he has received the most publicity. That partly stems from the attention he sought and craved when he was riding high. But it also stemmed from the fact that his three Atlantic City casinos had sold ''junk bonds'' to the public, making detailed financial records on them available to the public.
 
Bond Issues Provoked Crisis
It was two of those bond issues that provoked the crisis that led to yesterday's loan of $20 million, which went to meet obligations to owners of bonds issued by Trump's Castle, the least successful of his three casinos.
While the casino has not earned enough to meet the obligations on those bonds, the bonds were well secured, having a first mortgage on the casino. By contrast, some of the bank loans had much less protection, creating an incentive for the banks to avoid an early liquidation, which could have led to big losses.
That situation is not usual. In most cases, the junk bonds have much less standing than the bank loans, and as a result the banks are less willing to bail out junk bond holders when a crisis arises.
 
No Equity for Bankers
The fact that Mr. Trump was negotiating with bankers, rather than bondholders, may also account for his success in not giving up any partial ownership of his assets. ''Bondholders might demand equity,'' said one money manager, Thomas S. Drumm, the director of the fixed income group at the Keystone Group, a mutual fund organization that has the country's oldest junk bond fund. ''But bankers don't want any equity, and may question whether there is any there.''
Whether or not there is any equity in the Trump Organization depends on how much the assets are worth, which will only be clear with time. But for Mr. Trump, the best feature of yesterday's deal with the banks is that if there is any, he gets to keep it.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in a Broad Decline; Gold Prices Down in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined against all leading currencies yesterday after the markets became pessimistic about Congress reaching a budget accord, traders said.
Gold prices fell domestically and overseas on unconfirmed reports of selling in the Middle East.
Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar rose earlier in the day on reports that President Bush might be ready to ease his opposition to raising taxes to gain a compromise on reducing the Federal budget deficit. 
But the market learned later that Mr. Bush's comments were vague, sending the dollar down, said Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York.
''What appeared to first be positive turned out negative,'' he said.
Mr. Simon said the major movement in the currency markets was toward the mark, which gained on a statement by the West German central bank that it would accept higher domestic interest rates. Higher rates tend to make a currency more valuable relative to other currencies.
The mark has also been supported by optimism about the outcome of the plan to unify the currencies of the two Germanys in July, traders said.
In Tokyo, the dollar eased to 155.40 yen from 155.62 late Monday. In London, the dollar was lower at 155.20 yen. Later, in New York, the dollar closed at 154.55 yen, down from 155.40.
In London, one pound cost $1.7360 late yesterday, more expensive for buyers than Monday's late rate of $1.7300. In New York, a pound cost $1.7430, more than the $1.7305 late Monday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with Monday's late quotes, included: 1.6618 West German marks, down from 1.6775; 1.3975 Swiss francs, down from 1.4100; 5.5770 French francs, down from 5.6315; 1,217.50 Italian lire, down from 1,228.25; and 1.1719 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17705.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for June delivery closed at $350.40 an ounce, off $3.40. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold at $350.10, off $2.70.
In gold trading, dealers in Zurich said the metal appeared to have fallen into a lower trading range of $348 to $353.
The late bid price for gold in London was $349.50 an ounce, down from $353.50 late Monday. The late bid price in Zurich was $350.00, down from $353.50.
Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $4.79 an ounce, down from $4.85. In New York trading, silver for June delivery closed at $4.820 an ounce on the Comex, up from $4.816 Monday.

HEADLINE: House Approves More Assistance for East Europe

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
The House of Representatives approved a $15.6 billion foreign aid package today that would reduce United States military assistance to its allies for the 1991 fiscal year and would increase spending on the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe.
The vote was 308 to 117. The bill now advances to the Senate. 
The legislation, reflecting the easing of East-West tensions, provides $4.6 billion for foreign military assistance for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. That is $213 million less than current spending levels, and $412 million less than what the Administration had requested.
In a belt-tightening gesture more symbolic than substantive, lawmakers approved by voice vote an amendment to cut foreign aid across the board by 2 percent. The measure, however, exempted many of the largest components of the bill, including $3 billion in aid to Israel, and yielded reductions totaling about $140 million.
The debate today centered on assistance to the guerrilla alliance in Cambodia and aid to international family planning organizations in Romania.
In a major battle that injected a domestic political dispute into the international arena, lawmakers approved $1.5 million for voluntary family planning in Romania. Lawmakers did not question the need for family planning in Romania, just which organizations would deliver it.
Abortion opponents defeated an amendment that would have earmarked the family planning aid for two organizations that critics said advocate abortions, the International Planned Parenthood Federation and the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.
Supporters of the amendment, who emphasized that the bill prohibited any money for abortions, argued that Planned Parenthood and the United Nations agency were the only family planning organizations now operating in Romania. Under the Government of President Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown six months ago, abortions were subject to heavy penalties and birth control aids were available only on the black market.
Opponents of the measure said that a coalition of health organizations created by the Agency for International Development could deliver that assistance.
In another hotly contested issue, lawmakers approved an amendment offered by Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, to send $7 million in ''non-lethal'' aid to the coalition fighting the Vietnam-backed Cambodian Government.
Mr. Solarz argued that the measure prohibited any direct or indirect aid to the Khmer Rouge, the most powerful faction in the three-party coalition, and was the best way to insure that United States can influence a political settlement.
Opponents of the measure contend that assistance to the coalition's two other members, non-Communist groups led by Prince Sihanouk and Son Sann, ultimately supports the Khmer Rouge, and could lead to the re-emergence of the brutal regime that was responsible for the deaths of more than one million Cambodians in the 1970's.
Contrary to expectations, a floor fight over military aid to El Salvador did not materialize, reflecting the fact that discussions are continuing between the Administration and House leaders.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
U.S. Said to Mute Opposition To European Aid to Soviets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
Under pressure from some NATO allies, the Bush Administration appears to be softening its opposition to Western European financial support for the Soviet Union and is considering expanding its own technical aid to Moscow.
President Bush and the State Department remain reluctant to give American cash aid directly to the Soviet Union in the absence of major economic changes in which the centrally planned economy would be put firmly on a free-market path.
But the Administration has begun looking for more ways to provide technical economic assistance, particularly in the form of experts to help transform Soviet economic institutions.
For instance, the Administration is considering a proposal to send experts to help the Soviets develop and operate a private housing industry. Other proposals include technical help on private banking, a stock market, management training, accounting programs, various forms of entrepreneurial advice, and support for Soviet membership in the International Monetary Fund. 
The Administratioon is also adopting a more tolerant attitude toward West Germany and other European countries that are prepared to grant or loan Moscow some of the $15 billion to $20 billion it is seeking.
 
Behind the Change in Attitude
Behind the Administration's shift, officials said, are pressures from West Germany to give Moscow economic aid in return for its accepting the idea of a united Germany joining NATO and pressures from other European allies for the West to back its professions of good will for Mr. Gorbachev's liberalization program with cash.
Mounting concern in Washington that a collapse of the Soviet economy could weaken the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe has also contributed to the Administration's change in attitude, the officials said.
Last March, when the House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, suggested that the United States consider economic aid to the Soviet Union, President Bush dismissed both the proposal and Mr. Gephardt by saying, ''Maybe he'll come on a good idea one of these days.'' Three months later, though, the Bush Administration is no longer dismissing such proposals out of hand.
 
'The West Can Help'
The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said today, ''We believe the success of perestroika depends fundamentally on Soviet choices, but the West can help the Soviets through this difficult period.''
The West, she said, shares ''a common interest in the success of political and economic reform in the Soviet Union.''
''We expect there will be a discussion on this subject'' with the European Community and at the July 9 economic summit meeting in Houston, she added.
With that in mind, discussions have begun within the Administration on whether the Western allies can reach understandings that allow West Germany and France to give financial aid or credits to Moscow while the United States and others limit their help to technical assistance.
Administration officials want to avoid a split within the Western alliance on this issue and take the attitude that if the Germans are prepared to give cash aid in return for Soviet backing for their membership in NATO, then why not? as one official put it.
A senior Administration official remarked, ''The United States cannot be in a position of being isolated on this issue'' or it could lose its leadership position in the alliance.
 
Differences in Attitude
There already appear to be subtle differences among senior Administration officials on the issue.
Secretary of State James A. Baker and the President have cited the political and economic difficulties of granting aid to Moscow, but have clearly gone out of their way not to rule anything out. On the other hand, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has emphasized that as long as Moscow is spending ''enormous amounts of its national wealth on military hardware'' it would be a mistake for the West to give economic assistance.
The Germans and French disagree. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany asked his 11 colleagues in the European Economic Community Tuesday to consider a $15 billion Western aid package to help Mr. Gorbachev get through his current political and economic crisis. He was backed by President Francois Mitterrand of France, but strongly opposed by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.
The European leaders decided to study Soviet needs and make proposals for short-term credits and longer-term support for economic restructuring.
In the United States, however, there is less political support for aid at a time when the Administration is under pressure to hold down spending. Also, until the Soviets enact legislation freeing emigration, various American laws prevent the government from providing trade benefits, government guaranteed credits or Export-Import Bank loans to Moscow.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Forget the Missing Medieval Artworks! East Germans Treasure the Marks

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QUEDLINBURG, East Germany, June 21

 BODY:
If they didn't have so much to cheer at and worry about, perhaps the 30,000 people of this townwould be rejoicing that some of its greatest treasures have been found in Texas.
An American lieutenant apparently carried them off in 1945, after the United States Army conquered the town and occupied it for six weeks.
But medieval manuscripts, even if they are gloriously illuminated and bound in gold, ivory and jewels, or a comb for a king's beard can hardly compete for the attention of people who in less than two weeks will pass from poverty into Europe's most prosperous economy, with a currency that for the first time will allow them to buy what they want.
And when they are not voicing their elation at the prospect of the economic union of East and West Germany, the people of Quedlinburg, like the rest of the citizens of this rapidly ebbing country, talk agitatedly about the risky waters they are embarking on. They wonder what they will have to do to acquire as many of the admired West German marks as they long for. 
 
Ownership Is Disputed
But if the finding of the treasures has excited only the few people directly concerned, as the Mayor, Rudolf Rohricht said, among those few there is dissension.
The director of the town's museums, Uta Wagner, is not sure that the artworks should come into the possession of the Lutheran church that claims them because, she said, the church was secularized in the 19th century and its property transferred to the Prussian state and hence to East Germany.
It is a viewpoint that does not sit well with the pastor of the church, the Rev. Friedemann Gosslau, and his custodian, Werner Bley. Angrily, Mr. Bley told a reporter not even to talk to officials like Mrs. Wagner because in his and Mr. Gosslau's view the state had no claim to the missing treasures.
The Mayor, who said he had been a Communist Party member for 26 years, said: ''We support the church. We shouldn't fight over it.'' The main thing, he said, is to bring the artworks back to the church, their historical home. ''We will surely find a state-church consensus,'' he added.
 
Students' Concern Is Jobs
For the moment, however, other things are on people's minds. ''Most of the young people would say, 'What's an old Bible to me?' '' said Elke Neidhardt, a young woman attending a gathering at the pastor's home.
The assistant principal of the high school, Horst Muller, said: ''My students are worried about whether they will graduate into unemployment rather than the guaranteed jobs that used to await them.''
Citing other common worries, Michael Steinmetzer, a reporter on the Quedlinburger Zeitung, a new daily financed by a West German newspaper group, said: ''What will be left of their low pay when high West German social security deductions eat into it? They're unhappy that new regulations will limit the Western food products they hoped to be able to buy.''
Mayor Rohricht said he thought that about one-quarter to one-third of the people had read reports picked up from the American press that artworks dating from the time of the first German kings and emperors had been traced to a vault of the First National Bank of Whitewright, Tex., where the lieutenant's heirs are said to have deposited them.
Local newspapers have said the find may include a richly bound manuscript of the Gospels, the jeweled ivory comb of Henry I, ruler of the Germans from 919 to 936, a precious reliquary and crystal vials. Few people in town know that in the spring a West German foundation paid an art dealer a $3 million ''finder's fee'' for one of the missing Quedlinburg treasures, an illuminated 10th-century manuscript of the Gospels. The manuscript is now in safekeeping just across the border in Wolfenbuttel, West Germany.
 
The Emperors Came Often
Quedlinburg was one of the first capitals of Germany in the days when the capital was wherever the peripatetic kings, later emperors, were in residence. History records at least 67 imperial visits to the town.
Every time a ruler took up residence, he presented a gift to the noblewoman who ruled as abbess over the cloister for aristocrats founded by Henry's widow, Queen Mathilde. Together, these donations make up the bulk of the treasure of the church Mathilde had built on Castle Hill for her convent.
The treasure was on display until 1944, even after Heinrich Himmler, chief of the SS, confiscated the church in 1938 and turned it into a ''Germanic sanctuary,'' in which SS men swore fidelity on a sword that he extended to them. As Allied armies approached late in 1944, the treasure, together with riches from Quedlinburg's many libraries, was crated in 16 cases and stored in a nearby mine shaft. Between the time of the American arrival in April and the crates' delivery to the Town Hall a month later, one case disappeared, said Heinz Muller, father of the assistant high school principal and former director of the town's museums.
When he became the Town Council's cultural director after the Russians occupied Quedlinburg on July 1, 1945, Mr. Muller said, he found all of the precious objects, uncrated, lying about the Town Hall and oversaw their return.
Mr. Muller is one of those who rejoices that some of the missing treasures will be returned from Texas. And Pastor Gosslau and his custodian, Mr. Bley, pray that the artworks will soon come into their care.
Mrs. Wagner, the museum director, said the Gospel recovered by the West German foundation did not belong to the church treasure but to the Library of the Gymnasium, a former church school founded 450 years ago.
But Pastor Gosslau showed a letter from the foundation in which it promised him its eventual return here and included some photographs ''for your anticipatory pleasure.''
Church and town are aware that only in West Germany can the money be found to pay for the return of the artworks should that be necessary. ''It is painful to us that we have to beg to get back what is ours,'' Mr. Bley said.
Pastor Gosslau, who has engaged an American lawyer at the expense of West Germany to recover what may be in Texas, said he was excited and worried about the security problems that publicity was causing for the rich treasure that remains in his church. He wondered why the state would want to contest possession.
''Whoever owns it can never again sleep in peace,'' the pastor said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The cathedral in Quedlinburg, East Germany, background, from which medieval manuscripts and other treasures that came to light recently in Texas were apparently looted by an American officer in 1945. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Gamble Against Keynesian Theory

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
President Bush's new proposal to raise taxes and cut spending is a huge gamble that he can devise a deficit-cutting plan convincing enough to revive the sluggish United States economy.
The Bush thesis seems to be that raising taxes is necessary to shrink the inflationary budget deficit. Once American businesses and consumers see the deficit declining, their economic behavior will change, the theory goes. They'll stop worrying about inflation, lend their money at lower interest rates, and invest enthusiastically in the nation's businesses. 
The problem is that the Bush proposal, by bleeding upward of $50 billion from Federal spending in a single year, flies in the face of a theory developed in the 1920's and 1930's by John Maynard Keynes, the British economist, and practiced by nearly every American Administration since Franklin D. Roosevelt to avoid recessions.
 
'Playing Russian Roulette'
Keynesian theory, still a mainstay among Western economists, holds that lower taxes and more Government spending constitute the best way to make the economy prosper, particularly when consumers are spending less and companies are cutting back on production, as they are today.
The President's proposal to undo Keynesian stimulus is raising cries of alarm. ''It is coming at the wrong time; the President is playing Russian roulette with the American economy,'' said Robert Giordano, co-director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Moreover, though the Reagan Administration criticized Keynesian theory, it nevertheless ended up practicing it. Through much of the 1980's, instead of raising taxes to reduce the budget deficit, Ronald Reagan cut them and put more money in people's pockets. And rather than reduce Federal spending, his Administration made it surge, mostly to rebuild the military.
Now, Mr. Bush is proposing a package of spending cuts and tax revenue increases - mostly through various sales taxes - that would reduce the budget deficit to the $100 billion range or so in 1991. What is more, his proposal comes at a time when many state and local governments are also ignoring Keynesianism, and raising taxes to offset budget deficits that first appeared in 1987.
 
Merits of Bush Plan Noted
Still, the Bush plan does have its merits. One cited by many economists is that if the Government spends less on the military, then the workers and machinery now dedicated to making weapons will be freed for use in civilian production. Spending on things like highways and telecommunications networks creates more jobs and personal wealth than weapons making, economists say.
Secondly, the circumstances are different today than they were in Keynes's day. Keynes assumed that interest rates would not come into play.
''He wrote in the Great Depression, when interest rates were down to zero,'' said Charles L. Schultze, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. ''But now we are living in a world in which real interest rates are very high, and there is plenty of room to bring them down.''
 
Counting on Interest Rates
Clearly, the Bush Administration is counting on lower interest rates to encourage more spending, particularly for housing, as an offset to the President's new strategy. The assumption is that the Federal Reserve Board will use its powers to bring down rates, perhaps even deciding to do so at a policy-setting meeting next Tuesday. Or, rates will come down on their own in response to the Bush plan.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has indicated in public statements that the central bank will wait for the latter to happen, rather than act to bring down rates as a safety precaution for the economy.
Theoretically, rates would come down on their own if Americans became convinced that the Government was no longer bent on spending more money than it collected, thus making prices rise. The new, relaxed attitude about inflation would prompt banks, money lenders and pension fund managers to lend their billions at lower interest rates, since they would no longer have to charge an inflation premium. Consumers would borrow more, particularly to buy homes, and business executives would be quicker to buy machinery and build new factories on credit.
 
Speculation on Bush's Thinking
But that is theory. And given the risk, why is President Bush abandoning his no-new-taxes pledge? Economists can only speculate.
One view is that the Bush proposal to raise tax revenues is mainly part of the negotiating strategy to get Congress to agree to a deficit-cutting package. Another is that Mr. Bush is afraid that the alternative to a tax increase is the large across-the-board cut required by the Gramm-Rudman law, which might be more damaging to the economy than selectively raising taxes.
''The Gramm-Rudman cutbacks would surely trigger a recession,'' said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bank in San Francisco.

HEADLINE: De Klerk, Addressing Blacks, Speaks of a New Constitution

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, June 27

 BODY:
President F. W. de Klerk promised black South Africans today that he is prepared to negotiate a new constitution that would eliminate remaining legal bulwarks of apartheid.
Mr. de Klerk also challenged Nelson Mandela's argument that foreign governments should maintain economic sanctions against South Africa and that the African National Congress must continue its armed struggle in order to end apartheid.
The President made these points in a long interview in English on two television channels of the South African Broadcasting Corporation that cater to black viewers. He gave a similar interview in Afrikaans that appeared later on a channel for white viewers. 
The main distinction between the channels is that black programming is carried largely in African languages like Xhosa or Sotho while programming aimed at whites, which many blacks also watch, is in English or Afrikaans, the Dutch-derived language that the majority of whites speak.
 
De Klerk Talks to Blacks
In making his argument, Mr. de Klerk appeared to be trying to upstage Mr. Mandela at home, wooing the nationalist figure's domestic constituency while he is touring the United States.
When a black interviewer observed that some people described the political changes so far as merely cosmetic, Mr. de Klerk responded that the Government had abolished influx control, under which blacks had to carry passes entitling them to be in areas reserved for whites, and the Separate Amenities Act, which permitted local officials to bar blacks from public facilities.
The influx-control legislation was repealed in 1986 and the Separate Amenities Act, last week.
''I really think there is a wide appreciation, even from people strongly opposed to much of what we say, who recognize that what has already taken place is fundamental,'' Mr. de Klerk said.
The President reminded viewers of his promise last week that when Parliament reconvenes early next year, legislation will be introduced to repeal the Group Areas Act, which segregates neighborhoods by race, and the Land Acts, which reserve most property for whites.
The President also ruled out the African National Congress's call for election of a constitutional assembly to negotiate a new constitution and act as an interim government.
''A constitutional assembly elected before you start with negotiations causes a constitutional vacuum, causes uncertainty and undermines the capability of present government structures to continue with good government while negotiations take place,'' Mr. de Klerk said. He criticized Mr. Mandela's insistence that the African National Congress would maintain the guerrilla struggle in launched in 1961, saying that it posed an obstacle to negotiations on the country's future.
 
Remarks on Sanctions
The President further criticized Mr. Mandela's call for the maintenance of sanctions, which he said was harmful to the country's economy at a time of transition.
''Sanctions is another way of shooting South Africa in the foot - not the Government but South Africa and all its people,'' Mr. de Klerk said, adding:
''We're not doing what we do because of sanctions. We're doing what we do because we believe it is right.''
Mr. de Klerk, asked about the growing militance of the white right wing, replied that violence would not be tolerated from either side.
In his interview broadcast later to an Afrikaner audience, Mr. de Klerk said the African National Congress had ''a dualistic approach about peaceful talks and negotiation.''
''Their preaching of violence is still a stumbling block,'' he said. ''We will not allow the country to fall into anarchy. That is why we are continuing to talk to people who are committed to finding peaceful solutions,'' Mr. de Klerk added, implying that the African National Congress would not be the only black group at the negotiating table.

PUB-DATE: June 28, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 648 words

HEADLINE: The Deficit, Without Pretense

 BODY:
Grudgingly, belatedly and even now minimally, President Bush at last admits the obvious: Tax revenues have to rise. But that declaration, however cramped, is momentous. By disavowing his misguided pledge to block any new taxes, he frees Congressional Democrats and Republicans to get on with serious budget negotiations. Now Congress can tackle three tough questions:
How much should the Federal deficit be cut?
How much of that cut should be done with tax increases? Which taxes should be raised? The stakes are high. The deficit must be cut by a substantial amount and Congress is always in danger of trying to get away with doing too little. But there's another, less familiar peril. It wouldn't take much to throw the stagnant economy into recession. The negotiators' first task is to cut the deficit without cutting bone. 
What's the right amount to cut? Congress must first decide how much to cut the deficit and then amend the Gramm-Rudman budget law accordingly. Unless changed, it would force Congress to whack almost $200 billion off next year's trillion-dollar budget. That would be six times larger than recent budget cuts. Cuts that huge could precipitate a recession and eviscerate every discretionary domestic program, from education grants to the Border Patrol.
Excessive deficits harm the economy by siphoning money away from capital markets. That money would otherwise go to corporate investment in new plant and equipment. Without it, there is no short-run calamity. But over time, an economy that does not invest does not grow.
The remedy is to commit the Government to steady deficit reduction. That requires hard choices - but not risking recession or gutting social programs. Since 1985, Congress has reduced the deficit, measured in relation to the size of the economy, by nearly half. In recent years, that has been achieved with annual cuts of about $30 billion. Cuts of that order would suffice next year as well.
What's the right mix of taxes and cuts? A reasonable rule of thumb would be to achieve at least half of next year's deficit reduction through tax increases. That would mean raising about $15 billion, which would still leave Americans lightly taxed. To raise less in new taxes would mean cutting more in military and domestic spending.
What are the right taxes to cut? Fortunately, raising taxes by $15 billion or so requires nothing draconian. It could be done by imposing a small 5 percent excise tax on energy use. That might amount to a nickel a gallon on gasoline, for instance. Even with the new tax, energy prices here would remain below those of Western Europe. And the tax would help conserve energy and fight pollution.
Congress could raise an additional $10 billion or more from higher ''sin'' taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Like energy taxes, these taxes produce secondary benefits: fewer highway fatalities and lower health costs. To protect poor families, Congress could boost the Earned Income Tax Credit - an income supplement for parents in low-wage jobs -and other targeted subsidies.
Energy and sin taxes alone could solve the new tax problem, without jeopardizing the grand tax reform compromise of 1986. Specifically, Congress is not compelled to grant Mr. Bush's ill-conceived wish to lower the tax on capital gains - which would generate extra revenues next year, but lower them steadily thereafter.
As opinion polls demonstrate, everyone has known, for a long time, that taxes must go up to control the deficit. But no Congressional leader could say so while President Bush remained obstinately unwilling to say so.
Now that he has at least crossed the verbal threshold to sane policy, the Administration and Congress can get to work on a balanced program of tax increases and expenditure cuts. After nearly two years, the central issue of American politics can now be addressed with sense, not pretense.

HEADLINE: Some Donations Cost Charities Too Much

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With apologies to Howard Schneider for not picking up his offered donation (letter, May 30), the sad truth is that it often costs the charity more to collect and transport a donation than the value of that donation. Responsible charities must make difficult economic decisions when deciding whether or not to pick up a donation. It would not be responsible to pay more to collect or transport a gift than the value of the gift. It is indeed unfortunate that the high cost of transportation has put charities in this difficult situation.
At Goodwill Industries, we search for the most efficient way to collect donations so that we can avoid saying no to our donors. We are always happy to accept donations at one of our thrift shops or our collection stations around the city.
Because Goodwill has worked hard to be a good steward of the public's gifts, we were able to serve almost 9,000 people in 1989, which is more than twice the 1988 number. We were able to place more than 1,300 people in competitive employment after they received vocational training and other services.
 
REX L. DAVIDSON
Executive Director, Goodwill
Industries of Greater New York
 Astoria, Queens, June 11, 1990
