HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Revenues, Not Taxes

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker; A.M. Rosenthal is traveling.

 BODY:
If anything can, President Bush's flip-flop on taxes, plus two others on spotted owls and off-shore oil drilling, ought to bring his approval rating down from the unreal 70-plus percent he's been enjoying.
But don't bank on it. That kind of popularity may be based less on issues than on a nice-guy exterior, a folks-next-door syntax and a motherly First Lady with a hometown hairdo.
Still, since Mr. Bush just recently reversed himself on helping the third world protect the ozone layer, for him to take three more about-face steps in a single day suggests that the heat is making him uncomfortable in the kitchen. 
Partially reneging on spotted owls as an endangered species, while limiting the support Republicans have been giving to off-shore oil drilling, pleased neither side of either issue. When at the same time Mr. Bush abandoned his no-new-taxes pledge - the hard core of his 1988 campaign, and of his party's strategy in the Reagan-Bush years - he outraged Republicans running for office in 1990. They think he sabotaged their best issue to avoid a recession when he runs for re-election in 1992.
Democrats, however, should temper their glee. On the tax issue, there may be method in Mr. Bush's alleged surrender.
His list of things that need to be done to fight the deficit included code words for the capital gains tax break he lusts for. The easiest new revenues, however, would be obtained from higher sin taxes and other excises. If that's the final mix, the Democrats will have been conned into a tax benefit for the rich and a regressive tax increase for everybody else.
The hit list also included ''entitlement and mandatory program reform.'' That parses out to some kind of limits on Social Security, retirement, health and other benefits for people who tend to vote Democratic. Is that a good swap in return for new taxes on many of the same people? And to pay down a deficit that does not clearly and immediately threaten them, if at all?
Worse, and even if a new tax burden is spread equitably among rich and poor, Mr. Bush can and probably will campaign for Republican candidates next fall on the premise: ''Don't blame me. The spendthrift Democrats made me do it.''
Worse still, maybe there's more truth than poetry in what some Republicans are counting on, that Mr. Bush only called for ''new tax revenues'' - not for new taxes. That leaves him what supple politicians A. M. Rosenthal is traveling. admire as ''wiggle room'' to back out of the arrangement if the Democrats are insistent on raising taxes he doesn't want to raise - say, on the incomes of the rich. He could, and probably would, then tell the electorate next fall: ''They tried to raise your taxes and I wouldn't stand for it.''
He may even have been right the first time, that new taxes are not needed. There's no automatic link between the deficit and interest rates, despite cries to the contrary. A substantial reduction in the Federal deficit could be damaging to what is at best a tentative economy. And the Gramm-Rudman limit of $64 billion on a 1991 Federal deficit likely to be $160 billion can't be reached without disastrous recessionary effect.
If the deficit is not reduced to that level, however, the foolish Gramm-Rudman law will mandate draconian budget cuts to reach it. The Republicans do not want to make such cuts in military expenditures; the Democrats are anxious to avoid them in non-military programs; and no one wants a recession.
The threat of Gramm-Rudman, therefore, far more than the more touted threat of the deficit itself, is the major reason why negotiators for both parties want deficit reduction -even at the cost of higher taxes, and even though they concede that they'll still have to adjust the Gramm-Rudman limits upward.
Why not repeal a bad law and be done with it, if its supposed disciplinary effect is going to be eased anyway? And does Ronald Reagan's deficit, which has been around for nearly a decade without producing the various catastrophes so often predicted, really demand a tax increase?
A vitally needed public investment (an important form of savings) in education, research, the environment, roads, bridges, housing, renewable energy sources, etc., would serve far better purposes. In addition to meeting real needs, such investment would put thousands of idle Americans to work, including many now headed for the welfare rolls and/or the penitentiary. That in turn would produce the new tax revenues Mr. Bush finally admits are necessary -but without new taxes.

HEADLINE: New Haven's Bond Rating Is Downgraded by Moody's

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, June 27

 BODY:
Citing the rapid weakening of the city's financial position over the last two years, Moody's Investors Service today lowered its rating of New Haven's bonds. 
The action came four months after the other major bond rating service, Standard & Poor's Corporation, downgraded its assessment of New Haven's financial strength.
A lower bond rating means the city must pay higher interest rates on the bonds it sells to investors to finance building and other capital projects.
Moody's said the new administration of Mayor John C. Daniels had moved quickly to address the city's financial problems, but ''the already severe nature of prior financial problems will require extended commitment and demonstrable progress to regain fiscal stability.''

HEADLINE: President Announces Plan For More Latin Debt Relief

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
Under pressure from Latin American countries who fear that Eastern Europe is draining Western aid programs, President Bush today announced an expansion of Washington's debt-relief program for the region and proposed the creation of a free-trade zone for the hemisphere.
Although it was accompanied by the soaring oratory of a major foreign policy initiative, Mr. Bush's plan amounted primarily to an extension of a program initiated by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady in March 1989 to help Latin America reduce the $388 billion in crippling debts it owed to foreign governments and banks.
But international bankers and some other specialists in Latin American debt problems said Mr. Bush was proposing a significant expansion of the existing program. Some suggested that the announcement also had an important political aspect, since it comes at a time of mounting concern in Latin America about Mr. Bush's financial commitment to his own region. 
''I know there is some concern that the revolutionary changes we've witnessed this past year in Eastern Europe will shift our attention away from Latin America,'' Mr. Bush said in a White House speech to Latin American diplomats and Washington-based bankers.
''But I want to assure all of you here today,as I've assured many democratic leaders in Central and South America and the Caribbean and Mexico, the United States will not lose sight of the tremendous challenges and opportunities right here in our own hemisphere.''
Talking to reporters later, Mr. Brady also noted the region's concerns about Eastern Europe and said Mr. Bush's proposals were intended to reward ''a quieter but equally dramatic revolution that has occurred in Latin America and the Caribbean.''
In outlining his program, Mr. Bush said his Administration would negotiate to reduce $7 billion of the $12 billion in loans to Latin American Governments made by the United States Government.
Mr. Bush did not say how much of the $7 billion would be reduced. The existing debt-reduction plan introduced by Mr. Brady, covers only loans from commercial banks.
Mr. Bush also proposed increasing the pool of funds available to help Latin American countries guarantee loan payments to commercial banks in exchange for reduction of their debt. Administration officials said the largest debtor nations could receive as much as $200 million in additional aid from the expanded pool.
 
Free-Trade Agreements
He said his Administration stood ready to negotiate free-trade agreements with individual countries or groups of countries, as a prelude to a trade zone for the hemisphere in the future. And he pledged to help the hemisphere's developing nations win tariff reductions in the United States and around the world on critical exports.
Free-trade zones eliminate all tariffs and other trade barriers, thus reducing the cost of exports.
The President also offered a modest increase of $100 million a year in United States aid to promote financial reforms in Latin America and the Caribbean.
That was the only actual Federal spending included in the program, called ''Enterprise for the Americas.'' The initiative was presented in vague terms that made it difficult to assess its potential impact on trade, industrial development or debt reduction in the hemisphere.
 
New Economic Partnership
The program commits the United States to few immediate actions, and Administration officials acknowledged that the thrust of Mr. Bush's proposals was to provide long-term incentives for growth, not immediate help. In his speech, Mr. Bush said, ''All signs point to the fact that we must shift the focus of our economic interaction toward a new economic partnership, because prosperity in our hemisphere depends on trade, not aid.''
International bankers and some other specialists in Latin American debt welcomed Mr. Bush's initiative, particularly his offer to begin reducing governmental loans to Latin American countries.
Barber Conable, president of the World Bank, said in a written statement, ''By combining proposals for freer trade, debt reduction and increased investment in the region, the impact of each should be multiplied.''
''This is a well-timed and comprehensive speech,'' said M. Peter McPherson, executive vice president in charge of debt restructuring for the Bank of America. He noted that it came at a time when there were increasing demands in Latin America to expand the debt-reduction program initiated by Treasury Secretary Brady.
The new program also comes at a time when the United States has already registered a hesitant response to a Mexican proposal for a free-trade zone made earlier this year. Though Mr. Bush's program could have the effect of swallowing up the Mexican proposal, he and his aides made it clear that the new initiative would take more than a decade to put in place.
Mr. Bush said he would negotiate free-trade agreements with Latin American countries that ''demonstrate a commitment to economic reform, including trade and investment liberalization.'' More immediately, he offered to negotiate ''framework agreements'' for discussing trade issues.
Mr. Bush proposed a new investment loan program in the Inter-American Development Bank, a multinational lending organization much like the World Bank, to help countries privatize government industries.
He also said the United States would give $100 million a year to provide grants to countries undertaking reforms like privatizing industries and removing restrictions on currency and foreign investment. The grants are contingent on matching contributions from Japan and the European Community nations.
To help debt-reduction, Mr. Bush proposed that money from the Inter-American Development Bank be added to the funds used to help Latin American nations restructure their commercial debts by providing guarantees on new loans. This pool currently amounts to about $30 billion from the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and Japan. It was not clear how much would be added.
Mr. Bush also offered to reduce some of the $7 billion in loans given to Latin American nations as part of the Food for Peace and Agency for International Development aid programs. The Treasury Department said this could cut loans more than 50 percent in some cases.
Mr. McPherson said these aspects of the program were the most important. ''The reduction of official debt is a logical complement to the Brady plan reduction of commercial bank debt,'' he said.
He added, ''One of the major burdens in negotiating further Brady agreements is the availability of money from the official sector to put together the packages. The President's suggestion that the Inter-American bank could play an expanded role in providing those resources is a particularly positive one.''

HEADLINE: Indicators Rose 0.8% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
The Government's economic forecasting index climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, continuing its bumpy pattern of recent months and confirming, analysts said, expectations that the economy will eke out gains in coming months and avoid a recession.
The rise in the index of leading economic indicators - which fell in April after rising in March - was about as anticipated. But it was seen as somewhat exaggerating economic strength since the biggest contributor was a jump in the length of the factory workweek. Much of this was thought to reflect a reluctance by Detroit to add new employees as it approaches contract negotiations. 
At the same time, some economists said they were disturbed by a hefty decline in the component that measures the confidence of consumers, who account for some two-thirds of economic activity.
The overall May result, declared David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, ''indicates continued slow growth of the economy,'' which he estimated expanded at an annual rate of a bit less than 2 percent for the quarter that ends on Saturday.
But despite such lackluster growth - and some sectors like housing are contracting - most analysts contend that a general downturn remains unlikely. ''If we were to have a recession, the leading index would be missing it,'' Mr. Berson said.
 
'Subdued' Expansion
The record shows that the index, designed by the Commerce Department to call economic turns six to nine months in advance, sometimes predicts recessions that do not then occur but almost never fails to warn of those that do occur.
According to Joan D. Schneider, an economist for Continental Bank of Chicago, the barometer continues to emit signals consistent with ''subdued'' expansion.
Seven of the 11 components contributed to the May advance, with much of the strength reflecting an apparent bottoming out of the decline in the industrial sector.
In addition to the longer workweek, there was a firming of prices of materials particularly sensitive to the business cycle; an advance in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods; higher stock prices; a decline in initial claims for state unemployment insurance; slower deliveries by vendors and a rise in contracts and orders for plant and equipment.
Three components - besides the consumer expectations survey, which is conducted by the University of Michigan - held the leading index down. These were a lower money supply, a drop in building permits and a decline in unfilled orders at factories.
 
Coincident Indicators
The May increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 146.2, followed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in April -initially reported as a two-tenths decline - and a 1 percent increase for March.
A private forecasting index compiled by Safian Investment Research gained 1.1 percent in May, the New York firm reported. This was the best gain since August but rising components outnumbered falling ones by a margin of only 12 to 11.
The Government's report today also showed that its index of coincident indicators edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month while its index of lagging indicators eased two-tenths of 1 percent. The former is designed to track current economic conditions; the latter's seven components, including consumer prices and the prime rate, are those that tend to lag behind changes in the economy at large.
''The recent declines in consumer expectations and household spending suggest that the broader economy remains weak, despite the slight pickup in industrial production,'' said Robert T. McGee, an economist at Tokai Bank in New York. ''More slow growth is still the best bet for the U.S. economy.''

HEADLINE: An Eager Texas Buyer Of Failed Savings Units

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
As the Government sells off hundreds of failed savings and loan associations, its biggest customer is right here in Texas, where so many of the problems began.
NCNB Texas, the distant outpost of a leading North Carolina banking company, is sweeping through the Texas countryside, buying sick savings units at a healthy clip. NCNB Texas's strategy of picking up valuable deposit franchises and leaving the troubled loans in Government hands has enabled it to become the biggest bank in one of the nation's biggest banking markets.
And, in doing so, the bank has set a formula that is expected to be followed by other banks as they bid on the hundreds of savings units - an estimated 800 in the next four years - that may soon come up for sale. 81 of 110 Sales Go to Banks ''We're interested in building a banking franchise in Texas,'' said Timothy P. Hartman, who became chairman of NCNB Texas when it was created in 1988. ''There's not a banker in America that wouldn't fight tooth and nail for good loans.'' And that is in addition to some $6.9 billion in newly acquired core deposits from failed savings units that have given NCNB Texas a toehold in towns like Cedar Hill and Greenville as well as cities like Houston and San Antonio. 
So far, banks have been the biggest buyers of savings units. Of the 110 sold by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government entity disposing of savings assets, a total of 81 have been acquired by banks - and 18 by NCNB Texas, more than anyone else. The remaining 29 have been bought by other savings institutions.
One by one, these sales are quietly bringing about a shift in financial assets from savings associations to commerical banks. Indeed, these sales are shrinking the industry: for every bank that buys a savings unit, one less savings unit exists. Its deposits and some of its loans become bank property.
''The acquisition process of NCNB and many other banks is a very significant indicator of the future of the thrift industry,'' said Bert Ely, a savings industry consultant. ''From an economic perspective, you no longer need a separate thrift industry, and this eliminates a lot of excess capacity in the deposit-taking business, This is one of the silver linings of the thrift cleanup process.''
 
Savings Group Sees a Problem
But others argue that the sales do not really resolve the savings crisis, since the Government is still left with assets the acquiring banks do not want - generally shaky real estate loans and foreclosed properties. ''Selling deposits is not a major accomplishment,'' said Dennis J. Jacobe, research director at the United States League of Savings Institutions, a trade group. ''The R.T.C. takes back many of the loans, so the problem is basically left with the R.T.C. It's a non-resolution resolution.''
But it is precisely the ability to bid only for the good assets that makes banks active buyers. For many banks, particularly those seeking to expand retail operations, these troubled units have attractive deposit franchises - a core base of customers who are sources of low-cost money that can be lent out at higher rates and who are also potential buyers of high-margin consumer loans.
For that reason, it is not only NCNB Texas, whose Charlotte, N.C.-based parent is the NCNB Corporation, that is bidding. In Texas, both the Banc One Corporation and the Hibernia Corporation have walked away with several savings units that NCNB Texas bid on but lost.
 
Bank Deals in Other States
Outside Texas, interest is equally keen. In Arizona, for instance, the BankAmerica Corporation acquired the insolvent Western Savings and Loan Association, the state's second-largest savings unit, topping a bid by the Security Pacific Corporation. In Minneapolis, the Norwest Corporation recently acquired First Minnesota Savings Bank.
In Pennsylvania, Pittsburgh National Bank, the city's largest bank, merged with the city's largest savings unit, First Federal of Pittsburgh. Near Chicago, Harris Bankcorp and Citicorp have acquired suburban savings institutions while a bidding war is expected to break out over several other suburban institutions coming up for sale.
But NCNB Texas was in the field first. In fact, NCNB Texas itself was created in 1988 from the remnants of Texas's biggest failed banking company, the First Republicbank Corporation. Since then, NCNB Texas has grown into a statewide network of 250 branches, with $33 billion in assets, and is the largest subsidiary of the NCNB Corporation. NCNB, whose initials formerly stood for North Carolina National Bank, has operations concentrated in North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Florida. NCNB Texas is nearly twice the size of its nearest competitors - Texas Commerce Bankshares Inc. and the Banc One Corporation.
 
Risks Go to Government
NCNB Texas's acquisition of First Republicbank assets set it up here almost overnight. NCNB Texas initially paid only $210 million for a 20 percent stake in the failed First Republicbank, with the assurance that the Government would assume the risk for loan losses. That ability to transfer bad loans to the Government has been the underpinning of all deals done since.
''Our initial reaction was to transfer the risk to the Government,'' Mr. Hartman said in his 71st-floor office here. ''Any executive would react the same way. We are committed to raising capital, but not to assuming risk for troubled loans. The quality of loans here is severe enough that transferring risk to banks with fiduciary responsibilty doesn't make sense. And other potential investors are arriving at the same conclusion.''
The initial NCNB Texas deal is also considered one of the sweetest ever struck with regulators. In return for its initial investment, NCNB Texas got all First Republicbank deposits, its choice of loans and some $2.8 billion in tax benefits that will allow it to operate virtually tax free for another three to five years. NCNB invested an additional $1.1 billion in 1989 to buy the remaining 80 percent of First Republicbank from the Government, and ultimately brought its total investment to $1.7 billion.
 
'A Clean Bank With No Risk'
The loans that NCNB did not want were transferred to a special asset bank, which is owned by regulators and managed by NCNB Texas for a fee.
''Basically, NCNB got a clean bank in Texas with no risk,'' said Frank Anderson, an analyst with Stephens Inc., a Little Rock, Ark., broker. ''It's a sweet deal; no doubt, the best ever done with regulators. But you can't discount the fact that NCNB made it work. And that set a new standard on how to buy a bank.''
Mr. Hartman is defensive about charges that NCNB Texas's growth came all too easy. ''In hindsight, the transaction appears to have required little effort, but I can't tell you the effort involved,'' he said of the deal. That effort included streamlining the operations of First Republicbank and picking through the bank's loan portfolio to determine which loans could be sold to other financial intermediaries, restructured or foreclosed, and which NCNB would keep. In the process, NCNB gained the reputation of a tight-fisted lender with initials that stood for ''No Cash for No Body.''
 
Two Elements That Aided Growth
The experience with First Republicbank also left NCNB Texas with two elements that have aided growth here - tax benefits that allow it to bid aggressively for insolvent Texas savings units as well as a sharp understanding of the depth of problems in troubled loan portfolios. The tax benefits give the bank money to bid, and the understanding of the problems has made it reluctant to assume many loans.
For instance, when it acquired the Houston-based University Savings Association last year, NCNB Texas was happy to gain some $3.5 billion in deposits but agreed to buy only about 15 percent of University's $2.5 billion in loans. In general, Mr. Hartman said, NCNB Texas will keep from 5 percent to 15 percent of an acquired savings institution's loan portfolio.
''NCNB Texas is primarily buying deposits and customers and doesn't want to take much of the loan risks,'' said Moshe A. Orenbuch, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Added Richard Stillinger, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc.: ''The thrift acquisitions give them more locations to take advantage of the potential market for consumer lending. The more locations they can build, the greater the opportunities they have.''
 
NCNB's Approach Questioned
Yet, some question NCNB's approach. Paul Horvitz, a finance professor at the University of Houston and a former Federal regulator, is worried that current policy could lead to too much bank concentration. He pointed out that the bailout legislation makes it easy for commercial banks to acquire insolvent savings institutions, but harder for savings units to buy them.
''At some point the R.T.C. ought to be paying attention to market share,'' Professor Horvitz said. ''One advantage Texas had was a relatively unconcentrated banking structure. We can't go back to that. But it would be unfortunate if one or two institutions ended up with predominant market share.''
Gerard L. Smith, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc., questions whether NCNB's desire to be a big player in Texas is wise, the low cost of entry notwithstanding. ''What efficiencies are there to be gained?'' he asked. ''You've got to run two operations, and you've got a massive investment 2,000 miles from headquarters. And where are you? Texas is a tough market where the competition for funds and assets is fierce.''
Mr. Hartman disagrees strongly: ''We think this is the best banking market today. Otherwise, we would not have invested $1.7 billion here.''

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. Expects Profit Drop

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were likely to be lower than last year's, and that the company might have difficulty meeting its own targets for earnings growth this year.
A.T.&T. stock, which is more widely held than that of any other American company, dropped $2.125 a share, to close at $39.125, after trading as low as $37.625. Some 11.5 million shares changed hands in composite New York Stock Exchange trading, nearly six times the volume of the second most-active stock.
The New York-based telecommunications giant said its earnings for the quarter that ends Saturday would be less than the $699 million, or 65 cents a share, it reported in last year's second quarter. 
The announcement yesterday was the first time since A.T.&T. divested itself of its local telephone operations in 1984 that the company had issued a statement about its earnings before the end of a quarter. Morris Tanenbaum, the chief financial officer and a vice chairman of A.T.&T., said the company felt obliged to make an announcement because its own profit forecasts were considerably lower than the estimates of Wall Street analysts.
''We hope we don't have to do this again in the future,'' he said in a telephone interview.
 
Sale of Equipment Lags
A.T.&T. attributed the expected fall in second-quarter earnings to lagging sales of computer and telephone equipment and to the high cost of the company's entry into the credit card market. A sluggish economy and, to a lesser extent, conditions in the telephone equipment market were responsible for weak equipment sales, Mr. Tanenbaum said.
Mr. Tanenbaum said A.T.&T.'s earnings this year should exceed last year's $2.7 billion, which came on sales of $36.1 billion. But problems in this quarter will make it difficult, he said, for A.T.&T. to meet its target this year of 10 to 12 percent annual earnings growth.
''I don't think it's impossible, but it's going to be difficult. I wouldn't want anybody to count on it,'' Mr. Tanenbaum said.
Analysts had expected an increase this quarter greater than the 65 cents a share A.T.&T. earned in the second quarter last year, but they quickly cut their earnings estimates after the announcement. Jack B. Grubman, a telecommunications analyst at Paine Webber, changed his recommendation on the stock from a ''buy'' to a ''hold'' and reduced his second-quarter profits estimate to 58 cents, from 72 cents; he also cut his estimate of 1990 profits to $2.65 a share, from $2.90.
The company's troubles with equipment sales ''were even worse than I thought,'' Mr. Grubman said. A.T.&T.'s credit card introduction may cost as much as $200 million this year, he added, with most of the expense coming in the second quarter.
Equipment sales accounted for two-fifths of A.T.&T.'s $36 billion revenue last year. Demand has been strong for consumer products, which include answering machines and telephone handsets, but has fallen for equipment typically sold to businesses and to local telephone companies, Mr. Tanenbaum said. A.T.&T. sells electronic switchboards and multiple-line telephones to businesses and sells telephone network switching and transmission equipment to telephone companies.
Sales and profits from A.T.&T.'s long-distance services have not suffered in this quarter, said Richard A. Gray, a company spokesman. Prices rose yesterday for the stocks of A.T.&T.'s two biggest long-distance rivals, the MCI Communications Corporation and United Telecommunications, which owns 80 percent of US Sprint.
 
Heavy Competition
Demand has been weak and competition fierce for large, expensive telecommunications equipment, said Richard M. Wolf, a consultant in Ridgewood, N.J. The seven regional Bell operating companies created by the breakup of A.T.&T. in 1984 are cutting back, he said, after bolstering their investment programs during the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, when the economy did not slow as much as most had predicted.
Foreign manufacturers are moving into the American equipment market and putting pressure on profit margins, said Frank J. Governali, a telecommunications analyst at First Boston. ''It's hard to find a shred of positive news in the industry,'' he said.
According to the Gartner Group Inc., a large telecommunications consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn., A.T.&T.'s share of the $27.5 billion telephone equipment industry has been slowly falling, to 40 percent in the first quarter of this year.
Demand for the Universal credit card, which A.T.&T. introduced on March 26, has been twice as strong as expected but has resulted in high processing costs, the company said. A.T.&T. announced last week that customers had opened a million accounts for the card, which serves as both a telephone card and a credit card for general purchases.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Talks Go On

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, June 28

 BODY:
American and Japanese officials entered an unexpected fourth day of negotiations today as they sought ways to remove trade barriers between the two nations.
A United States Government official said the talks resumed after Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu phoned President Bush in an effort to break a deadlock among negotiators on the issue of increasing Japan's public-works spending over the next decade. 
Foreign Ministry officials said they could not confirm press reports that Japanese and American officials had agreed to public-works spending of 430 trillion yen, or about $2.77 trillion at current exchange rates.
The American official declined to say what disputes remained to be settled, although negotiators said a final agreement on the joint report was expected to be reached today.
A spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Ministry said Prime Minister Kaifu was scheduled to hold a press conference later today.
Both sides were under pressure to bring the talks to a close ahead of the two-day economic summit meeting of seven industrialized countries, which begins July 9 in Houston.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Less Euphoria On East Germany

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Christian Picot, the chief of equities trading at Banque Paribas in New York, spent several days last week visiting factories in East Berlin and East Germany, talking to workers and managers. ''You have to be there to see what is going to happen,'' he said. His conclusion: not much for now.
It is just days before the eagerly awaited July 1 economic unification of East and West Germany, the first step to political unification. But Mr. Picot and other analysts have shed the German euphoria that sent the Frankfurt stock market to a record high in March of 1,976.43 on the DAX 30-stock index, up 35 percent since the Berlin Wall began to crumble on Nov. 9. 
The main activity next week is likely to be at the 10,000 or so centers in East Germany for the exchange of the East's marks for the West's.
The spending spree that many economists worried about, with East Germans cleaning out the boutiques and department stores on the Kurfuerstendamm in West Berlin, seems less likely now. East Germans are now expected, Mr. Picot said, to keep their marks as a hedge against the unemployment that seems likely for hundreds of thousands of workers as East Germany switches from a planned to an open economy.
In the stock market, more negative than positive surprises are expected as it becomes clearer that the returns from East Germany - and the rest of Eastern Europe - will take years to materialize. And because stock prices have already risen enough to account for this future gain, the near-term outlook is for volatility rather than a rise.
''When it comes to the reality of this unification, all the hype is unfounded,'' Mr. Picot said. ''For the capital markets nothing will happen.''
Traders in the Frankfurt stock market, however, have not agreed with this view for the last two weeks. The DAX index has risen in eight of the last nine days, bringing it back above the important 1,900 level yesterday, to 1,901.46. This rally came after the market, worried about the cost to West Germany of economic union and the expectation of higher interest rates, fell amost 10 percent from the high reached in March.
But the analysts who see problems in Germany dismiss this rally as a normal rebound from a sharp correction, not the beginning of a new surge.
David C. Roche, the European strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company in London, is now pessimistic about Germany and much of the rest of Europe. Morgan Stanley has already recommended a reduction of investment in West Germany.
One main reason for Mr. Roche's view is that he thinks the Soviet Union and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are in trouble and that the orderly transformation that Mr. Gorbachev began will come to a halt. Such a development would have a depressing effect on many European markets, including West Germany's.
In addition, Mr. Roche said the perceptions of equity strategists are changing. First, like Morgan Stanley, they saw the growth and quick returns from Eastern Europe. Now there is growing acceptance that these returns will be delayed.
And with some bankruptcies of East German and other companies, the perception could change to ''it won't happen at all.'' That is when Mr. Roche plans to buy again.
The market has also lost some of its attraction because of the sharp rise in stock prices, which has meant that stocks have gone from selling at 10 times earnings to 18 times earnings, making them expensive.
The decision to exchange the East German mark one to one for the West's mark has also dampened some enthusiasm. After the wall fell, East Germany was thought to be a new source of inexpensive labor. But with the higher costs set by the one-to-one exchange, this labor may not be so attractive now and companies could return their attention to places like Portugal and Turkey.
''It just put things in a different light,'' said Madhav Dhar, a global strategist in New York for Morgan Stanley.
Volkswagen A.G. is an example of what the East German euphoria has done for some stocks. And it could become an example of what happens when reality sets in.
The recent rally in Frankfurt has sent Volkswagen, which is set to build the East German cars of the future, to its high for the year of 631 marks after it fell sharply in the spring on the expectation of losses in Brazil.
''People are playing Volkswagen again,'' said Stephen Reitman, an automobile analyst for UBS in London. But he said buyers have ''yet to really look at the hard facts, like what is the cost of labor; for returns, we are really talking about the second half of the decade.''
Once this view sinks in, he said, he expects Volkswagen to fall again.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Mostly Higher; Gold Firms in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against most major currencies in quiet trading yesterday as the markets ignored a report that showed the economy may be strengthening, traders said.
Currency traders said that there was little activity in the market, and that the dollar moved in a tight range.
The market had little reaction to the Commerce Department's report that its index of leading indicators, intended to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May. 
News of increasing economic activity normally is good for the dollar, but ''a market that's bearish on the dollar ignores good news,'' said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer for the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York.
 
Bush Sets the Tone
President Bush's statement Tuesday that he may accept a tax increase to reach a budget accord set the tone for the market, Mr. McCarthy said. An accord that cuts the Federal deficit could lead to lower interest rates, which tend to devalue the dollar relative to other currencies.
Against the West German currency yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.6637 marks, from 1.6618 late Tuesday in New York trading.
The dollar also strengthened against the pound in New York, where it traded at $1.7428, cheaper than $1.7430 late Tuesday.
Against the Japanese currency, however, the dollar weakened. In New York, one dollar bought 154.40 yen, down from 154.55 late Tuesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had closed at 154.35 yen, down from 155.23 Tuesday, and in London, the dollar also traded at 154.35.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's late quotes, included: 1.4095 Swiss francs, up from 1.3975; 5.5910 French francs, up from 5.5770; 1,221.50 Italian lire, up from 1,217.50, and 1.1695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1719.
In the precious metals market, gold prices firmed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for June delivery closed at $351.40 an ounce, up $1. Later, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold at $350.10, unchanged, as of 4 P.M.
Gold traded in a narrow range in Europe. Dealers said there was no investor interest and most participants were squaring up their positions for end-of-the-month accounting.
Gold closed in London at $350.05 an ounce, up from $349.50 late Tuesday, and in Zurich at $349.90, down from $350. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $350.55 bid, down from $353.25.
Silver bullion closed in London at $4.84 an ounce, up from $4.79. In New York trading, silver for June delivery closed at $4.794 on the Comex, down from $4.820 Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Military Newspapers Flourish

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
At a time when many newspapers are facing a slump in advertising, Army Times and its sister publications, Navy Times and Air Force Times, are doing well.
Advertisers like the publications, which are owned by The Times Journal Company, a newspaper publisher in Springfield, Va., because they are an easy way to reach an attractive market. The publications issued by the military, like Stars and Stripes and Army magazine, do not accept advertising.
''It's a classic case of niche marketing,'' said Charlie Rutman, a group media director at Backer Spielvogel Bates. ''These newspapers reach young consumers with a high amount of disposable income and who are not as easily reached by other media.'' 
The average household income for military personnel is $47,400, said Nat Kornfeld, the vice president for advertising for Army Times, which will celebrate its 50th anniversary in September. Members of the armed forces have a greater percentage of disposable income than do civilians because much of their living expenses, like food, housing and medical costs, are paid for by the military services.
The weekly newspapers provide a rundown of who is being transferred, who is getting promoted and sometimes even report blunders the military may have made.
''It is the bible of what is happening in the military,'' said Robert Sims, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs who is now a senior vice president at the National Geographic Society. ''The publications give military personnel all the information they need to know about how the armed services affects their lives.''
The close ties that Army Times maintains with the military allows it to report on information important to military personnel several weeks before the armed forces makes the news official, said James Doyle, the editorial director for the Army Times publishing division of the Times Journal Company. ''Because of all of the red tape involved in anything the military does, it uses us as a quick conduit for information,'' he said.
The three publications are the only non-military publications reporting exclusively on the armed forces. Readership has been growing, and now stands at a combined paid circulation of 312,000, although circulation peaked during the Vietnam War years, at 400,000.
Analysts said the publications are particularly attractive to advertisers selling products like automobiles, liquor and insurance, which are popular with the military market.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has been using Army Times for five years to advertise special services like its long-distance calling card for miltary personnel.
''It's ideal for selling products geared to the active-duty military market because its reach is greater and it is more economically efficient than using regular consumer publications,'' said Deanna Kenny, the military market manager for A.T.&T.
Since 1975, the number of advertising pages for the three papers has risen nearly 30 percent, to a total of 6,002 pages last year. In comparison, Business Week, which ranks No.1 in ad pages for consumer publications measured by the Publishers' Information Bureau, had 4,914 ad pages last year.
Advertising revenue has been increasing at an even faster clip: during the same period, revenues more than doubled to $24.4 million in 1989.
Analysts said advertisers were also attracted to Army Times because of its high credibility with readers.
Its tough reporting on the military makes it clear that it is not ''in the pocket of the Pentagon,'' said Mr. Rutman of Backer Spielvogel Bates. ''If readers find a publication credible, then they often find the advertising equally credible. That's important in developing brand loyalty.''
Army Times was the first to report a number of important stories concerning the military. It was the first to report, for example, that the Army had charged an American soldier with the murder of a Panamanian prisoner during the United States invasion of Panama, said Mr. Doyle of Army Times.
Of course, Army Times and the military have had disputes about stories. ''They have asked us not to run stories, but even when the military has threatened to take the papers off the newsstands we haven't bowed to the pressure,'' said Henry Belber, the president of The Times Journal. ''If we didn't fight for our readers rights, we'd lose our legitimacy.''

HEADLINE: Designs for Europe;
Germany in NATO? Not Important

BYLINE: By Ronald Steel; Ronald Steel teaches international relations at the University of Southern California.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
A unified Germany will probably be in NATO -but will the United States? The question may seem odd since the Atlantic alliance is, after all, our property. We created it, pay for most of it, and provide the nuclear umbrella that makes it credible. NATO without the U.S. is like the Holy Roman Empire without the Romans. But that's the point.
That entity - neither holy, nor Roman, nor an empire - thrived long after the Romans pulled up their tents and returned to their seven hills. 
The same could well be true of our 50-year encampment in Western Europe.
We put NATO together to protect our European allies from the Russians, but also for some other reasons: to reassure them that we would keep watch over the Germans, and to prevent Europeans from once again dragging us into a war.
One of the purposes of NATO, in other words, was to keep Europe in its place, where its endemic rivalries would be muted and its ability to harm itself and others limited. We did this not only by paying the bills, but also through an integrated command structure that put the West European armies (except that of obstreperous France) under U.S. command.
This worked fine for more than four decades, as the Europeans recovered from their war and focused their energies on getting rich. They kibbitzed from the sidelines as the U.S. emmeshed itself in two land wars in Asia, and they let Washington and Moscow jockey for influence in the third world and argue about missiles at various talks from which they were excluded.
The trans-Atlantic arrangement started wobbling a few years ago, however, when U.S. taxpayers began wondering why half the Pentagon's budget went for subsidizing the defense of rich Europeans. And now it is seriously unraveling as the Soviet Union day by day transforms itself from a menacing ogre to one of the world's neediest cases.
NATO planners used to lie awake nights fearing the Soviet Union might march west; today their greatest fear is that it may collapse. Even if it doesn't, the revolution in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union has posed an identity crisis for NATO.
The East Europeans want to join it, Mikhail Gorbachev wants it to disappear into an all-European security system stretching, as General de Gaulle used to say, ''from the Atlantic to the Urals.'' The West Europeans want to keep it as an insurance policy, though whether against the Russians or the Germans they coyly refuse to say.
The Germans see no harm in NATO, particularly since they are likely to dominate it anyway. And the Americans persist in the assumption that somehow everything will continue more or less as before.
Here Washington may be in for a surprise. It was because of the cold war and Europe's military dependency that the U.S. has played such a powerful role in Europe. NATO is both the symbol and the instrument of that dependency. In a post-cold-war Europe NATO will be less important to Europeans. For that reason it will also mean less to Americans.
With the threat of Soviet invasion virtually vanished, with U.S. forces eventually cut by two-thirds or more, with economic rather than military power calling the tune, an evolving Europe will be far less responsive to U.S. wishes. Even Europe's reliance on U.S. nuclear protection will loosen. To contain a weakened Russia, the French and British nuclear forces, with a German voice on the board of directors, may be deterrent enough.
The European Community, already a bigger and as rich a market as the U.S., will do its own negotiating with Moscow rather than letting President Bush do the talking. A unified Germany, as the powerhouse of the community and the paymaster for Eastern Europe, will take the lead in forging a post-cold-war European diplomacy, one responsible to European rather than Atlantic concerns.
What place will there be for the U.S. in a Europe whose armed forces it can no longer control, whose economy is bigger than its own and whose citizens no longer feel dependent on an American protector - a Europe that is reaching out to embrace, even swallow, the Soviet Union in its economic net? Clearly something far less important than it has been.
U.S. officials are not only understandably sentimental about NATO, but see it as the best hope for maintaining American influence in Europe. They should use the card for what it's worth, but not exaggerate its importance. NATO will probably endure in some form, though likely with a new name, less centralized control and a wider geographical scope.
An American connection is useful to the Europeans, just in case the Russians, or even the Germans, become difficult again. But it will be a traditional mutual security pact rather than the integrated military alliance - with U.S. command of Europe's armed forces - it has been. A European-Atlantic pact might even extend far to the east and include whatever remains of the Soviet Union once it has gone through its current ethnic convulsions.
Thus, the current argument over whether a unified Germany should be allowed to join NATO is less important than it seems. In or out of NATO, Germany will be the major actor in tomorrow's Europe. The Europe of two superpower blocs will give way to a European entity, perhaps unified, perhaps not, in which Brussels or Berlin will carry more weight than Washington.

HEADLINE: 3 Little Words: How Bush Dropped His Tax Pledge

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
When President Bush announced this week that ''tax revenue increases'' were essential to reduce the budget deficit, White House aides were hoping that the wording was vague enough for them to argue that Mr. Bush had not explicitly abandoned his campaign pledge of ''no new taxes.''
But the Democrats quickly prevailed in the debate over how Mr. Bush's purposely vague reference to taxes should be interpreted. With the White House silent and refusing to elaborate, Republican members of Congress joined Democrats in ending the discussion: with his three words, Mr. Bush had broken the central promise of his 1988 campaign.
A reconstruction based on interviews with Administration officials, lawmakers and Congressional aides, including some who witnessed a two-hour meeting on Tuesday that led to one of the most momentous political decisions of the Bush Presidency, established this as one of several miscalculations by White House officials.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, said the White House had underestimated ''by orders of magnitude'' how dramatic the reaction to Mr. Bush's announcement would be. ''The Democrats,'' he said, ''understood far better than the White House what the symbolic meaning of the word 'tax' is in this town.'' 
Today the President's close aides, closeted in the White House under a code of silence, were increasingly worried by the reaction to the tax statement and were debating how to proceed.
 
A Breakfast Breakthrough
The process by which Mr. Bush made his decision began last week on Capitol Hill, according to Congressional officials and those Bush associates who were willing to ignore the ban on interviews. That ban was being enforced by John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, who was described by one Senator as ''the obstacle'' that had to be overcome in persuading the President to issue the tax statement.
The process culminated in a two-hour breakfast meeting on Tuesday morning at the White House, where House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington was designated by the Democrats to warn Mr. Bush that they would pull out of the budget talks unless the President made some gesture to help them avoid the political blame for any tax increase that might come out of the talks.
Witnesses to the meeting said Mr. Bush listened to an hour of debate before he agreed to draft a statement that might be interpreted by some people as putting him on record as accepting the idea of tax increases to help cut the budget deficit.
Based on a format suggested by Mr. Foley, Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, wrote out a draft statement in his own hand.
Mr. Darman included the phrase ''tax revenue increases'' as one that would give the Democrats the political cover they needed, while still leaving Mr. Bush enough ''wiggle room.'' Officials said the White House hoped to argue that ''new tax revenues'' might come from increased money from existing taxes in a growing economy, rather than from a tax increase.
 
The 'T-word' in Disguise
Discussing how the phrase was chosen, a White House official said, ''The idea was that it had to have the 'T-word' in it, but it also had to be general enough that the actual decision on taxes would be left up to the budget negotiators.''
The Democrats discussed the phrase and decided that its meaning was clear enough for them.
Democrats credited Mr. Foley with making a stern and protracted presentation to the President at the breakfast meeting, a presentation they felt was a key element in swaying Mr. Bush.
As the meeting closed, the two sides agreed that each would hold one news conference. The three-paragraph document was posted in the White House press room and the public relations struggle was on, with the White House losing the semantic argument almost as soon as it began.
Many of those interviewed today said the events that led to Mr. Bush's statement began on June 19 when, as the budget negotiations dragged on, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney presented a new plan for cutting the size of the military.
Democrats had been expecting the cuts to reduce the overall size of the budget substantially. But Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said Mr. Cheney's presentation went ''nowhere.''
Early on June 20, Congress and the White House came up with new forecasts that put the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1991 at $160 billion, requiring $100 billion in cuts to reach the level dictated by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
That afternoon Mr. Darman presented the Administration's proposed budget cuts of $51 billion, most of it from domestic programs. The Democratic response was angry and the Administration began a frantic four days of damage control.
The next morning, Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady met with Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and with Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who is chairman of the Senater Finance Committee, in the first of a series of exploratory meetings.
 
A Pivotal Broker's Role
On Thursday afternoon Mr. Darman and Mr. Brady met again with Senator Bentsen, who played a pivotal broker's role in the discussions. The Senator said he told them ''that the talks were going to come apart, that the Democrats were not going to come up with taxes and that the President had to make a high-profile move.''
At this point the Administration was seeking assurances that if Mr. Bush agreed to do that the Democrats would not reject it, officials said.
After his meeting with the White House officials, Mr. Bentsen met with George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader. Mr. Bentsen told Mr. Mitchell that he thought the Administration would work out a ''good-faith, high-profile move from the President,'' according to a Senate official.
Mr. Brady and Mr. Darman also met on Thursday with two other Democratic Senators, Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the Budget Committee chairman, and Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia, Senator Mitchell's delegate at the budget talks.
Congressional aides and lawmakers said Mr. Darman was told the Democrats could not accept the Administration's new plan as the starting point of negotiations. Still trying to salvage the talks, Mr. Darman proposed what one Senate aide called ''the immaculate conception'' plan, arguing that everyone should keep talking and somehow taxes would spring from the process.
''I sensed after our conversation Thursday afternoon that they seemed to be under substantial stress or pressure,'' Senator Sasser recalled. ''Brady and Darman were leading the charge to try to do something. On the other side I think you've got Sununu, who probably was more concerned about the political side of it.''
The Democrats turned up the pressure a notch. On Friday, after conferring with Mr. Mitchell, Mr. Foley told the White House he was canceling a budget meeting that had been scheduled for Monday, the first such cancellation since the talks began in May.
On Saturday morning, Mr. Bentsen had breakfast with Mr. Brady and left feeling that the deal was all but sealed if the proper language could be worked out, Congressional officials said.
On Monday, the President invited the Congressional leadership to the White House for the Tuesday morning meeting, saying he wanted to break the logjam in the negotiations.
 
'That Sounds All Right'
At 1:30 P.M. on Monday, Mr. Bush met with Republican Congressional leaders - most of whom, with the exception of Mr. Gingrich and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a sponsor of the budget-balancing law, were already urging Mr. Bush to accept a tax increase to bring the deficit under control.
At 7:30 A.M. on Tuesday, Mr. Bush met with the bipartisan delegation in his private residence. One participant said that Mr. Foley raised the subject of a statement by the President on taxes and that after a long discussion on the document's language, Mr. Bush said, ''That sounds all right to me.''
A White House official said today that the statement did not substantially change the President's position on raising taxes. ''We made that decision back when we went into the negotiations and said everything was on the table,'' the official said.
But the White House realized that the new statement went farther than before because it put Mr. Bush on record as saying that he felt a tax increase would be needed, not just that he would discuss the idea.
White House officials calculated that they could keep Mr. Bush out of sight and avoid having him make any comment in person. They also planned to present the statement differently to different audiences: For the Democrats, it was to be a significant, new statement of policy. For Republicans, it would be described as nothing new.
Republican officials met to consider their public relations strategy and decided to paint the President's statement as an act of political courage. They said the eventual budget agreement would contain so many significant measures, like cuts in domestic spending and a reduction in the capital gains tax, that no one would fault Mr. Bush for a tax increase.
At the same time, the White House decided to keep quiet. All interviews were refused. Today, Mr. Darman left this message with his secretary: ''Mr. Darman is not talking to any press right now.''
 
A Public Relations Blunder
That left the Democrats, Republicans outside the leadership circle and the news media doing all the interpretation. As early as Tuesday afternoon, some Bush advisers were concerned that the White House had botched the public relations campaign.
''Don't they think they need to explain it?'' asked one White House adviser. ''They take a piece of paper and tack it up on the press office wall. Bush wants to raise taxes but he doesn't want to have anybody see him visibly move his lips. They want to say, 'See, we put it in writing,' but they don't want to say it.''
Today some White House advisers were worrying that Mr. Bush's response on the tax issue seemed limp. They argued that before he loses his credibility, he should tell the public why he was willing to break his campaign promise. But others said the President should simply wait for the budget negotiations to produce a compromise for which neither side can blame the other.
Still, one aide said the biggest worry in the White House now is how Mr. Bush will address ''the charge that he's a fraud - that there was misrepresentation in what he did.''
The aide added, ''What we need to do is answer that.''

HEADLINE: Senator Urges Military Resources Be Turned to Environmental Battle

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
Calling environmental destruction ''a growing national security threat,'' Senator Sam Nunn, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, today proposed shifting substantial Defense Department and intelligence resources to address ecological problems.
Mr. Nunn, a Georgia Democrat, was joined on the Senate floor by fellow Democrats Al Gore of Tennessee, Tim Wirth of Colorado, Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and Jim Exon of Nebraska, all members of the Armed Services Committee, in calling for the creation of a Strategic Environmental Research Program.
An influential Democratic leader who has played no significant role on environmental issues, Mr. Nunn made it plain that he had two goals: In an age of diminishing tensions with the Soviet Union, he wants to retain the extensive national security research apparatus at the Pentagon, the Energy Department and Central Intelligence Agency, and at the same time turn much of its focus to what he described as a rising security threat posed by degradation of the environment.
The program outlined by Mr. Nunn would enlist the research talent available to the military and intelligence establishment, as well as its computers, planes, ships, satellites and other resources, to address environmental threats. 
Some new Federal spending would be required, including the costs of a proposed new Defense Environmental Research Council. No detailed financial estimates are available, but in general, planners foresee the diverting resources worth billions of dollars.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Nunn acknowledged that one purpose of his proposal was to retain research and technological capacity for the military establishment at a time when military budgets will be shrinking. ''But the major purpose is environmental,'' he said.
In his speech, the Senator said that global environmental problems were worsening and leading to tensions that could pose military problems, especially in the third world.
''The end of the cold war has greatly reduced the risk of superpower confrontation,'' Mr. Nunn said, but he added that pressures on the environment could increase the danger of ethnic or regional conflicts.
 
The Main Problems
Among the problems listed by Mr. Nunn were population pressures on food and water supplies, the depletion of the ozone layer in the atmosphere, large-scale destruction of forests and global warming linked to air pollution.
Many traditional security problems remain, Mr. Nunn said, citing the proliferation of nuclear weapons, chemical weapons and missles in the third world; ''radical Moslem fundamentalism;'' global terrorism, and the drug trade. But he said he now believes ''that there is also a new and different threat to our national security emerging: the destruction of our environment.''
''I believe that America must lead the way in marshaling a global response to the problems of environmental degradation, and the defense establishment should play an important role in this effort,'' Mr. Nunn said.
Like Senator Nunn, who is a leading Congressional expert on military affairs, the top commanders at the Pentagon from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney down have been concerned about how they would keep the military establishment intact in a time of decreasing world tension.
A Defense Department spokesman, Glenn Flood, said of the plan today: ''On the surface it sounds good. We just have to see what the specifics are before we can embrace everything he has proposed.''
 
Unlocking Secret Data
Among other things, Mr. Nunn's plan would open to nonmilitary scientists and researchers some data gathered by the armed services and intelligence agencies that is now kept secret. An example would be the thickness of polar ice as measured by the Navy's nuclear submarines.
Military aircraft, ships, submarines and satellites could collect information on air and water quality and on global climate, Mr. Nunn said. The powerful computers used by the Defense and Energy Departments could be made available to civilian researchers. The two departments could devote research money and equipment now used for military programs to developing energy technology for civilian use, including new nuclear reactor designs, energy storage techniques and superconducting materials.
Senator Nunn suggested that many resources could be used for military and environmental purposes at once. Aircraft and ships on military exercises, for example, could also collect environmental data.
Mr. Nunn also stressed that the technology for cleaning up the environment would become an increasingly important economic factor in world trade. ''I would like to see American technology leading the world,'' he said. Although a growing number of scholars and Government officials have warned that environmental deterioration is a major threat to national security, this would be the first time the threat would be addressed in the nation's strategic planning. Senator Gore, who has long called for a shift in strategic thinking, said in an interview today that the most significant thing about the proposal is ''this philosophic point that the environment is recognized as a national security issue.''
Senator John W. Warner, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said he thought Mr. Nunn's proposal was ''worth serious consideration.''

HEADLINE: U.S. AND JAPAN SET ACCORD TO RECTIFY TRADE IMBALANCES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 28

 BODY:
After a year of wide-ranging critiques of each other's economies, the United States and Japan reached an unusual agreement today intended to trim America's spending excesses and to transform the Japanese economy, making it easier for foreigners to do business here.
The trade pact, if faithfully enforced, would change Japan from a nation that fiercely favors producers into one that encourages shoppers and gives new powers to shareholders.
The agreement, aimed at dealing with the underlying causes of the huge United States trade deficit with Japan, was reached tonight after a four-day marathon session that ultimately required the personal intervention of President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. The two leaders spoke by telephone, with the aid of interpreters, during the late stages of the negotiations, formally known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, American officials said. They did not disclose the content of the discussion. 
 
Earlier Stage in April
The accord followed an interim agreement reached in early April, when the two countries first acknowledged that both economies needed fundamental changes if Japan's trade surplus were to be reduced.
But the interim pact lacked details. The current accord, prepared in time for Mr. Kaifu's trip to the United States next week for the Houston economic meeting and more bilateral talks with President Bush, was hard-fought because it establishes a specific action plan.
Specifically, Japan pledged to increase its public works spending over the next decade by 63 percent, reduce the time it takes to issue patents to 24 months from more than 37, reduce the protection afforded small shops and begin vigorous criminal enforcement against bid-rigging, price-fixing and other anticompetitive actions that have long been tolerated by Japanese authorities. All these measures are intended to make Japan more open to competitive foreign goods. $50 Billion Surplus The unresolved question is how much and how quickly the effort will reduce Japan's $50 billion annual trade surplus with the United States. Congress has made clear that if the effort does not appear to work, pressure for retaliation against Japan - what President Bush and Mr. Kaifu were trying to sidestep - will probably grow. [In Washington, President Bush welcomed the agreement and said it should benefit both nations. But some in Congress were cautious about its enforcement. Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who heads the Senate Finance Committee, said it can be measured only by results.] The Japanese decision to increase public works spending was one of the most politically difficult elements in the agreement. The powerful Finance Ministry resisted the big increase, fearing that more public spending could add to inflation. Japan agreed to increase its public works spending program over the next 10 years to 430 trillion yen, about $2.8 trillion at current exchange rates, as part of a broader push to increase Japan's demand for imported goods. The projected level is 63 percent more than in the preceding decade.
In past negotiations with Japan, American and other foreign representatives have sought access for specific industries, like agricultural products, computer chips or satellites.
But the talks over the past year represent a new approach - an attempt to change some of the fundamental charactistics of the American and Japanese economies that have allowed the trade problems to develop.
At times the talks have ventured into areas so rooted in national culture - like Japanese proposals to limit the number of credit cards American consumers can hold or American proposals to destroy the links that bind families of companies here - that they seemed sure to fail.
In return for Japanese concessions, the United States pledged not only to move toward eliminating the Federal budget deficit, but also to reform antitrust laws to allow companies to enter joint production ventures, and provide more education programs for an American work force.
The Bush Administration also pledged to keep the United States open to direct investment from abroad and to relax somewhat the ban on exports of California heavy crude oil. Japan has argued that if it could buy the crude, much of the trade deficit would disappear.
The American commitments included increased spending for scientific and commericial research . In the 1991 fiscal year, beginning October 1990, the Administration said it would increase Federal spending on civilian research by 12 percent, a 4 percent rise for the military, 22 percent for nonmilitary space research and 14 percent for the National Science Foundation.
 
Much Uncertainty
Because of the unusual nature of the trade agreement, there is considerable uncertainty about how far-reach its impact would be.
''We have never attempted anything like this before,'' said S. Linn Williams, the deputy United States trade representative. ''These are two sovereign countries, big countries, that are discussing issues that until now were considered no one's business but their own.''
Japan's press is doubtful about whether America is taking its own commitments seriously.
The Mainichi Shimbun, one of the country's largest newspapers, this morning seemed to reflect a widely held view that it is so politically unpopular in the United States to curb consumers that the country ''won't give a firm promise on the restraint of its own consumption.'' Such a restraint, the paper said, is ''an impossible thing anyway.''
There are equal reasons to doubt how quickly Japan will change. But one of the odd aspects of the current negotiations is that the American side often found itself cheered on by traditionally passive Japanese consumers, who have begun to question why they pay such high prices and live in such cramped quarters.
For example, the agreement says that Japan will move to eliminate zoning limits and get rid of taxes that encourage land owners to cultivate small farms in the middle of crowded cities, including Tokyo. It also calls for converting unused Government-owned land ''to productive use by the end of fiscal year 1991.''
 
Shareholders' Rights
Japan also agreed to review its commercial code to enhance shareholders' rights and increase public disclosure requirements for corporations. It also agreed to abolish the Government's broad authority to block foreign direct investment in Japan and to relax regulations that require foreign companies to give advance notice of plans to invest in Japan or import technology.
The agreement also commits Japan to a liberalization of a law here that, to the frustration of Japanese and American retail chains, allows small shopkeepers to delay the opening of department stores for more than 10 years. That period will be reduced first to 18 months and then to one year, as part of an effort to open more outlets likely to carry foreign and discount goods.
Japan also committed itself to greatly strengthening its Fair Trade Commission, and allowing the commission for the first time to aid consumers who sue businesses for unfair business practices. ''We want to see the Government take a more active role as a friend of plantiffs,'' Mr. Williams said.
Under the agreement, the Japanese Government will also issue a policy statement soon leading to new measures against ''keiretsu,'' companies that are tightly bound together and often supply each other while sqeezing out opportunities for outsiders. In some cases, companies will be restricted from holding too many of each other's shares, but no timetable was set.
 
Late Sticking Point
In the lastest round of negotiations, one main sticking point was how much Japan was willing to spend on its own public works chiefly houses, airports, ports, parks and sewers.
Though the connection sometimes seems remote, American negotiators have argued that such investments will inevitably close the Japan's current account imbalances. The projects will reduce the gap between Japan's huge domestic savings rate - three times higher than in the United States - and the amount it invests. Moreover, the theory goes, Japanese in bigger houses, driving on wider roads, will become greater consumers, including of foreign goods.
Initially the United States insisted that Japan commit itself to spending a specific percentage of its gross national product on its infrastructure. But that was opposed by the Japanese bureaucracy, which feared it would lose a vital tool in controling the economy. In the end, Mr. Kaifu agreed to spend the $2.8 trillion, and an additional $100 billion through recently privatized companies like Nippon Telegraph and Telephone and Japan Railways, two of the country's largest industrial enterprises.
 
Pact Hailed in U.S.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (Special to The New York Times) - President Bush in a statement called the agreement particularly welcome, adding that it should benefit the economies of both nations. The White House statement said the trade accord was a two-way street, with the United States agreeing in general terms to pursue policies to raise the nation's savings rate and reduce the Federal budget deficit.
In a telephone interview, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mossbacher said that while the Japanese negotiations were not the main reason for Mr. Bush's decision this week to accept new taxes, ''the timing was right.''
American lawmakers welcomed the trade agreement, but stressed that it would require careful monitoring to make sure it is enforced. ''I'm glad to see that the U.S. trade negotiators have reached a final agreement,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, who chairs the Senate Finance Committee. ''However, the worth of that agreement can only be measured by hard trade results. In that sense, the jury is still out.''
John B. Taylor, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, said: ''It is difficult to say when it will have an impact. This is a medium-term strategy we have in mind, but it could have a dramatic effect.''
