HEADLINE: Slow Day at the Spy Shop in Teheran: Is It a Sign?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, June 28

 BODY:
Business was only fair today at the spy shop.
It is usually brisk, the store clerk said. But today few customers had shown up by early afternoon, and they seemed less interested in spies than in religious works.
Although some call it the spy shop, or even the spy boutique, the formal name is the Center for the Publication of the U.S. Espionage Den's Documents. It is a most unusual book store, opened eight months ago at the edge of a walled compound on the well-traveled Ayatollah Taleghani Street. 
The compound is a base for the Revolutionary Guards, enforcers of Iran's Islamic fundamentalism, who also use the main building as a school for their children. Most outsiders probably remember the place better as the former United States Embassy, an early target of the 1979 Islamic revolution and birthplace of America's enduring hostage-taking anguish.
 
Shredded Papers Reassembled
On the store's shelves are collections of secret and confidential documents seized from the embassy and, in some instances, painstakingly pieced together after having been hastily shredded.
Their existence is hardly new, but now bound copies of them are on sale. For $5 - payment is in Iranian rials, but prices are marked in the old espionage den's currency - one can buy any of a dozen volumes called ''U.S. Interventions In Iran.''
There are also tracts on the Zionist conspiracy and South Africa, plus religious books and a few less-than-bloodracing volumes on contract law and Japanese postwar growth. But the name of the snappily tiled shop, nestled below a Revolutionary Guard observation tower, leaves no doubt about its mission to help maintain the anti-American tone that has been basic policy since the Shah's downfall 11 years ago.
The street running by the former embassy compound retains its tension. When two foreign journalists and their Iranian interpreter lingered too long today for the taste of one Revolutionary Guard, he held and questioned them at length before finally letting them move on.
 
Hard-Liner Out of Touch
Judging from available evidence, most of it anecdotal, Iran's fundamentalist and anti-Western hard-liners are out of touch with large numbers of their people, perhaps even a significant majority.
That becomes quickly clear on basic matters like religion, economics and the Government's anti-American stance, which has been softened somewhat in recent days as Iran has accepted United States relief aid after the devastating earthquake last week.
A large sign in the lobby of a major Teheran hotel blares, ''Down With U.S.A.,'' alongside an unsmiling black-ribboned photograph of the country's spiritual leader until his death last year, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
Yet every ordinary Iranian encountered this week told a visiting American, even before he could raise the subject, that they had affection for the United States and longed for improved relations.
 
Business Has Sagged
As for their daily lives, Iranians complain that business has sagged since the 1988 cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war and that many food staples have become too expensive. And from telephone operators to shop owners in the sprawling, vibrant bazaar in central Teheran, they say they are tired of the stringent rules of Islamic fundamentalism that are imposed upon them from on high.
In 1979, merchants in the bazaar provided important support for the Islamic revolution. But now many of them express regret, speaking freely if guaranteed anonymity.
''We thought we would be better off, but we're not,'' an appliance store owner said. ''The Shah took your money, but he gave 25 percent of it back. This regime takes it all.''
''The religion is killing us,'' another shopowner complained. Paradoxically, he makes his living on religion. He sells polyester fabric imported from Japan and South Korea that is used to make chadors, the all-enveloping black cloak that Iranian women wear to meet Islamic dictates of modesty.
 
Dislike for the Chador
It is clear that many women, in Teheran at least, would throw off this garment in a second if they could.
His chador business has not been great in the last few years, the store owner said, so he has begun to sell blankets and throw-rugs to take up the slack.
Covering up remains the rule for all women, foreigners along with Iranians, and if they reject a chador, they must wear equally concealing scarves and long coats. But beneath the layers of clothing, one can spot signs of rebellion and attempts at individual expression.
Some women are clearly testing the limits by wearing striking eye makeup, expensive rings, designer blouses, blue jeans and even, in one instance, mesh stockings that offered more than a suggestion of ankle.
 
Dress Rules Tightened
There are frequent pendulum swings here between hard and soft lines on clothing standards. Toughness won out last month when the authorities tightened the rules to forbid unmarried men and women from walking alone together, and to require that men also cover up more of themselves by wearing long-sleeved shirts.
The new regulations do not seem to be enforced, however. Teheran's streets are filled with men in short sleeves or with their long sleeves rolled up.
It might have taken an earthquake to shake up the rules a bit, some Iranians believe. The Government, they say, has been too distracted by last week's disaster to deal for now with something like a dress code.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Model East German Business Looks to Even Better Days Ahead

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RADEBEUL, East Germany

 BODY:
When the sink-or-swim economic era dawns in East Germany on July 2, Planeta, a manufacturer of printing presses, will be a shoo-in not only to swim, but to leave everyone else in its wake.
With its forward-looking management, its sophisticated products and production techniques, and its large export sales to the West, Planeta is a model for East Germany's 7,000 enterprises, an Olympic swimmer amidst hundreds of slow-moving weaklings. Based in a suburb of Dresden, Planeta is one of the world's top 10 producers of printing presses and is also a leading example of how East German industry is expected, after a shakeout, to grow and become more efficient as a result of economic unification.
Planeta had been part of the giant Polygraph machinery industrial group, which the Government broke up into smaller units in May. Planeta remains state-owned, without clear plans for privatization, although its general manager is interested in attracting some outside investors. 
Peter Kahlert, the general manager, says he is confident that his company will double its sales in just three years as Communist-imposed obstacles to efficiency are swept away. Mr. Kahlert, who has headed Planeta for two years, complains that Communism prevented his 92-year-old company from becoming even more of an East European success story than it already is.
 
Heavy Export to West
Its presses, which cost up to $3 million apiece, are as good as Western-made machines, and it exports half its production to the West. Indeed, the Planeta machines, used to print calendars, magazine covers, detergent boxes and the like, are in demand in the United States and Western Europe.
Another index of Planeta's success is that a dozen Western suitors are eager to sign cooperation agreements with it. And Planeta recently chose a West German company, Konig & Bauer, as a partner over several companies from West Germany, Japan and the United States, including Rockwell Graphics Systems. The West German company will supply Planeta with needed investment funds and technological know-how. Konig and Bauer said it might take an equity interest in Planeta.
Some experts place a value of more than $100 million on Planeta, which Mr. Kahlert said earned about $30 million last year on revenues of $180 million.
''Our product is right, our market is right, and our labor force is good,'' he said.
Though skilled, the Planeta workers lack the Western work ethic, the 50-year-old Mr. Kahlert said. ''There isn't the right approach to work in the whole German Democratic Republic, not just at Planeta,'' he said.
But he expects all that to change come early July, when economic unification of the two Germanys begins. In his view, the advent of capitalism will mean an end to a common feature of central planning: supply snags that closed down Planeta's production line one-and-a-half days a week on average and sapped employee morale. Thanks to more flexible labor rules, he plans to slash bloated costs by laying off 1,000 of Planeta's 5,500 workers.
And he expects Planeta's employees to work harder because they will be paid in West German marks, which can buy whatever the world has to offer.
 
Profit Re-invested in Company
Although 90 percent of its profits went directly to the central Government, $12 million dollars a year was returned to Planeta, a generous sum by East German standards, to buy the latest manufacturing equipment from East or West. This gave Planeta advanced electronics and top-of-the-line machine tools, which were rarities in Eastern Europe.
In a first for an East German enterprise, Planeta acquired an American company in January, buying Royal Zenith, which is based in Long Isaldn and was Planeta's American distributor. Mr. Kahlert said the acquisition would allow Planeta to be more aggressive in North America, and it has already doubled its American order book to $35 million.
Planeta's presses have received favorable reviews in the United States. ''I am several times a millionaire because I got into Planeta presses 15 years ago,'' said John Jarbo, whose Washington, D.C., print-shop owns five of the East German presses. He said they were as good as Western presses, and often lower-priced.
Mr. Kahlert often sounds like a union member when he talks about wages; he is eager to raise them by 25 percent this year. He fears that unless Planeta can keep its profits strong, enabling it to raise wages quickly, many valuable skilled workers will move to higher-paying jobs in West Germany.
He has met repeatedly with his workers to explain that though he would like to raise wages, it would be imprudent to do so now. He says Planeta will first have to improve its productivity.
 
Workers Are Understanding
At a time when workers at many enterprises are clamoring for 70 percent raises to catch up with West German workers, Mr. Kahlert's explanations seem to have won over his workers.
''West German workers needed 40 years to achieve their standard of living,'' said Matthias Reiche, a 30-year-old machine tool operator. ''We can't expect to achieve that standard of living in four months.''
Many of the workers understand Mr. Kahlert's layoff plans. Because of gaps in central planning, Planeta had to establish many operations in house, including construction and laundry, for which Western companies would have found outside suppliers.
Mr. Kahlert said Planeta's work force should be reduced by 18 percent by lopping off these extraneous operations and by laying off hundreds of administrative workers who spend their lives cajoling, yelling, pulling strings and filling out forms in an effort to obtain supplies from central planners.
Planeta's Western partner plans to be tougher than Mr. Kahlert. ''The staff at Planeta will have to be reduced by 25 to 30 percent,'' said Klaus Schmidt, assistant to the president of Konig & Bauer, which is based in Wurzburg.

HEADLINE: Canadian Voices: Crisis Over Quebec Arouses More Chagrin Than Alarm

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, June 28

 BODY:
Anybody watching television here in recent days might have thought Canada was preparing for its own funeral.
There have been scenes of people stomping on Maple Leaf flags in the streets of Montreal, of a doleful Prime Minister Brian Mulroney warning the nation not to delude itself about dangers to the nation's survival and glimpses of him and other politicians agonizing over economic damage to Canada if Quebec secedes.
In the decades that the country has wrestled to keep its English-speaking and French-speaking peoples within the confines of a single state, there has rarely been such gloomy clamor.
But already, calmer voices are suggesting that Canada may find a way to remain one country. 
In interviews with Canadians who write about the country, who manage some of its largest financial institutions and who have designed some of its most celebrated buildings, the mood seemed to be less one of alarm than of chagrin that politicians could have allowed the bonds uniting the country to become so strained. How Is It Perceived in U.S.? Away from the emotional roller-coaster ridden by the politicians, some Canadians expressed bemusement about how their crisis was being perceived in the United States, where Canada has often been seen as a stable and perhaps stolid neighbor.
''People down there think we're nuts,'' said Stephen Lewis, who was Canada's chief delegate to the United Nations until 1988, and who now serves as a special adviser to the United Nations on Africa.
After reading about the collapse of a constitutional agreement that would have given Quebec special status as a ''distinct society,'' Mr. Lewis said, his American friends telephoned to ask what was going on.
 
'Orgy of Self-Immolation'
''It's simply beyond their imagination that a country like Canada, with so much that other countries can envy, could engage in this orgy of self-immolation,'' he said.
The sense that Canada offers too much to its 25.9 million people for them to demolish the country turned up in some surprising places.
In Quebec, where the latest opinion polls have shown close to 60 percent of those surveyed favoring some form of independence, French-language newspapers have been considered stalwarts of the ''nationalist'' cause.
Yet at the largest newspaper in Quebec, La Presse, with more than 220,000 daily circulation, Alain Dubuc, the editorial page editor, said that the anger against English Canada that drove the independence movement a decade ago had given way to a ''pro-Quebec'' feeling. And this feeling, he said, might still be accommodated within Canada.
''Most people in Quebec really don't want to separate,'' he said. ''It would be a heavy, burdensome process.''
The editor, noting that the Premier of British Columbia, William Vander Zalm, had said that he would favor a constitution that declared his timber and fish province on the Pacific coast also to be a ''distinct society,'' suggested that Canada should become a looser confederation.
In it, all provinces, including Quebec, would have broad autonomy while uniting around a common currency, unified armed forces and allegiance to treaties.
''I think our demands could be the basis for a new deal for Canada, which might not only be good for us but for the rest of the country, too,'' Mr. Duboc said.
 
Soul-Searching Deplored
Some of those interviewed felt the country had been through needless soul-searching since two English-speaking provinces killed the constitutional accord with Quebec by withholding consent.
''I think it's not a crisis at all,'' said Richard M. Thomson, chairman of the Toronto Dominion Bank, which has assets of $57 billion.
Mr. Thomson noted that provinces representing more than 90 percent of the English-speaking population outside Quebec had ratified Quebec's desire to protect its identify as home to five million French-speaking people.
''This was a technical failure, not a failure of spirit,'' the executive said.
On Saturday, in a televised lament for the constitutional pact, Prime Minister Mulroney backed away from earlier expressions of foreboding by stressing that Canada was held together by more than ''dry parchment'' - meaning the Constitution.
The interviews turned up a strong echo of this. Several people predicted that Quebec and the rest of the country, whatever the strains of working out new arrangements, would eventually rally around their shared history, economic links and unwillingness to risk being submerged politically by the United States.
''Have you been to Louisiana?'' asked Margaret Atwood, the Toronto writer who has won critical acclaim in the United States, most recently for her novels ''The Handmaid's Tale'' and ''Cat's Eye.''
Ms. Atwood said that visits to a writer friend in Louisiana had shown her how a once-thriving French culture had withered without the protections given to Quebec.
Among the English-speaking Canadians interviewed, a common view was that after living alongside each other for more than 300 years, French and English Canadians know disturbingly little about each other. This must be changed, they agreed, if a lasting political accord is to be reached.
Ms. Atwood suggested that much of the fault lay with Quebec, where, she said, resentments over the British conquest in 1759 seemed to outweigh efforts in recent decades to spread the use of French and to guarantee Quebec a decisive share of power.
''I understand the historical background, the desire to protect an identity but I don't feel I'm stepping on anyone's neck,'' she said.
 
Strong Echoes of View
Among English-speaking Canadians with Quebec roots, this view found strong echoes.
Mordecai Richler, the novelist, spoke of the dissension as ''a childish tribal squabble'' that he said had been touched off by the Quebec Government's imposing French-only laws.
Moshe Safdie, the architect of Canada's new National Art Gallery, assailed the ''hypocrisy'' of blaming English-speaking Canada for a lack of understanding of Quebec while remaining silent about Quebec's treatment of its English-speaking minority.
While Canada would have to make allowance for Quebec's cultural distinctiveness, Mr. Safdie said in a telephone call from London, where he was celebrating his 60th birthday, Quebec would have to reciprocate by accepting that it was bound, like other provinces, to respect the rights of minorities under the country's Bill of Rights, which the province overrode in imposing its French-only laws.
But Mr. Lewis, the former chief delegate to the United Nations, said that if Quebec was to be discouraged from taking its independence, the effort to break down misunderstandings would have to begin among English-speaking Canadians. They have shown, he said, ''a determined imperviousness to what has been going on in Quebec for years.''
Mr. Lewis suggested that this insensitivity was part of a broader pattern.
''We have a quite unwarranted reputation as a generous, sympathetic, tolerant society,'' he said. ''But it's just not the case. Canada is simply not the angelic crucible of tolerance we've always pretended.''

HEADLINE: Mandela Mania: Inner-City Children Find Hero of Their Own

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 28

 BODY:
In a sun-dappled schoolyard here, a dozen children lost themselves in the furious foot-stomping of an African dance. They flailed their arms and twirled and swooned, and chided the few who got out of step because everything had to be perfect.
They were, after all, rehearsing to perform today for Nelson Mandela, the South African anti-apartheid leader, matter-of-factly described by one young dancer, Quirita Quates, as ''just the greatest man in the world.''
In his eight days in this country, Mr. Mandela may have charmed the United Nations and won standing ovations at a joint session of Congress, but perhaps his most captivated audience is the generation of schoolchildren who were not even thought of when he was first jailed more than 27 years ago. 
But when Mr. Mandela arrived at the airport here at 5:45 this afternoon, he was more than three hours behind schedule, so the children were not able to perform for him. Still they waved and cheered as he was officially greeted by Mayor Coleman A. Young, and dignitaries including the president of the United Automobile Workers, Owen Bieber, whose union has given strong support to the anti-apartheid movement.
 
Warm Reception at Ford Plant
Shortly afterward, Mr. Mandela was greeted with a roar by hundreds of U.A.W. Local 600 workers at the Ford River Rouge plant in Dearborn. Ford had pulled its operations out of South Africa as part of an anti-apartheid protest.
Tonight a crowd of 52,000 people waited for more than three hours in Tiger Stadium for a 25-minute speech by Mr. Mandela, who was welcomed by a 2,000-member choir singing, in Zulu, the anthem of the African National Congress.
At almost every stop so far in his eight-city tour, young people have been right beside him, presenting him flowers at the airport, singing African hymns and urban rap songs, cheering and dancing for a man who has caused near-mania among inner-city children hungry for a hero.
''The tension is high,'' Marvis Cofield, who runs a youth center in Detroit, said on the eve of Mr. Mandela's visit here. ''When you're black, how many times do you get to see somebody that looks like you and has gotten the attention of the world?''
A sense of wonder and jubilation has swept through playgrounds and summer school classrooms where, after hearing adults talk of little else in recent days, many children -black and white - are embracing Mr. Mandela as a grandfather they've heard about and are finally getting to see in the flesh.
 
History Comes to Life
''For the last three months, the schools have been full of Mandela, Mandela, Mandela,'' said the Rev. Jim Holley of Little Rock Baptist Church, who is a coordinator of the Detroit visit. ''Now all the books and pictures are coming to life, and he's responding in a storybook way - gentle, kind and cuddly at a time when we need a hero. We need one so bad.''
For a week now children have been making the most of their big chance to see history in progress. At Madison Park High School in Boston, students made posters greeting Mr. Mandela's wife that said, ''We love you Winnie.'' They waited for hours to hear Mr. Mandela's 10-minute speech.
At Boys and Girls High School in New York, students joined Mr. Mandela on stage and accompanied him to City Hall. ''They were not just throwing ticker tape at the parade,'' said Alan Walls, a youth group administrator in Brooklyn. ''They were up on stage with him looking at the crowd from his eyes. Now, anytime they feel they can't do something, they can think of Mandela.''
In Detroit, where city officials are in an unabashed race to raise more money for Mr. Mandela's African National Congress than any other city, children are the cheerleaders.
 
Rally at Tiger Stadium
Five hundred pairs of commemorative Mandela sneakers in the red, black and green of the A.N.C. went faster than prime seats at Tiger Stadium. Competition to go on youth group charters to the stadium's sold-out rally and to the private children's reception for the Mandelas has been so fierce that youth groups have had to hold lotteries and essay contests to decide which children could go.
Last Saturday, several teen-agers stood in the rain for four hours at an intersection near the airport to raise money for Mr. Mandela's cause. They planned to hand-deliver a check to Mr. Mandela for $327 - the amount they raised from curbside donations and a dance they held.
''He's standing up for us,'' said 16-year-old Nezula Sibert, who helped raise the money. ''He was in jail for longer than I have even lived. We wanted to do something to help him out.''
Most children want to do more than that. They want to touch him, play basketball with him, ask him what kind of music he likes and what kind of food he ate while he was in prison. And they are already assessing the possible effects of his visit. ''If he makes life better in South Africa, he makes life better for us,'' said Jason Bradford, an 11-year-old at Mr. Cofield's Youth Center. ''If Africa's strong, it makes us stronger. Pretty soon we'll have a black President.''
For now, people in the remaining cities on his tour are still trying to figure out how best to see Mr. Mandela. Going to see the man has become the hip thing for the grade school set.
''Not that long ago, some of the kids were ashamed of Africa,'' said Hakim Abdal-Khallaq, owner of Nubian Notions in the Roxbury section of Boston. ''Now they want anything African. They want anything with Mandela on it.''
Black leaders are hoping the euphoria lasts after the commemorative Mandela sneakers are scuffed up and outgrown.
''With Mandela here, this is the closest many of these kids will ever get to Africa,'' Mr. Holley said. ''Many of them wear the continent on their neck and can't find it on the map. I'm hoping that after Mandela, these kids will feel that they're not just going to school for themselves, but they're going to school for a nation.''

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Beware The Condor

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
A charge was made in this space a month ago that the Defense Ministry of France was turning a blind eye to the shipment of Sagem inertial missile guidance systems to Iraq.
French officials denied this with the same air of offended innocence displayed 18 months ago by West Germans when The New York Times revealed that German companies built Libyan and Iraqi poison-gas factories. (This week, a German Todeskramer - ''merchant of death'' - was sentenced to five years in jail.) When asked by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee about the report that the French had helped extend the range and improve the accuracy of Iraqi missiles, John Kelly, Assistant Secretary of State, testified, ''the intelligence, as I understand it, doesn't demonstrate that we have evidence that that is true.'' 
If the C.I.A. is unaware of sophisticated guidance systems sold to Iraq, it would be the only major intelligence service in the dark.
However, Secretary Kelly also testified, ''I know of no written or oral communication'' by State Department lawyers to Justice prosecutors about the potential indictment of a high-ranking Iraqi in the investigation into $3 billion in funny funding at the Lavoro bank's Atlanta office.
Because the misleading Kelly assertion could be controverted by further Senate questioning of others, I conclude that State is studiously ignoring data that might compromise Western relations with Iraq.
If French journalists want to emulate their hard-digging German brethren, chercher les dual-use guidance systems: orders that are intended for use in the new Condor II missiles are disguised as inertial guidance for aircraft. As a result, Iraq is getting a ''smart'' new missile system capable of delivering a quarter-ton warhead on a target more than 400 miles from its frontier.
Note that this Condor warhead is not so big: that suggests it is designed to deliver a nuclear bomb rather than poison gas. Saddam Hussein already has Soviet Scud missiles capable of reaching both Teheran and Tel Aviv; he is evidently preparing for a delivery system for a nuclear weapon to be ready by 1995.
Put yourself in the shoes of the only man who has started and won a war that cost a million lives. Last time Saddam began building a nuclear bomb 20 miles southeast of Baghdad, the Israelis took it out in a surgical strike. (That was deplored in 1981 by George Bush, but probably prevented the later incineration of three million residents of Teheran.) Saddam needs an interim threatener to deter any strike at his greater threat to come. That's what his present missiles are for, and explains his vow to ''scorch half of Israel'' with gas if it takes out his nuclear plant again. Last week, curiously, he extended his retaliatory protection to the West African seacoast nation of Mauritania.
If he already has missiles able to reach Israel, why is he spending great sums on sophisticated guidance systems for the longer-range Condor II? Why does he need to extend his missile-testing area to roomy Mauritania?
The answer to both: The capacity to obliterate the U.S. Sixth Fleet and the capitals of Syria and Turkey would satisfy any dictator's power drive. His past record of destruction would make him a superpower: as Saddam coolly told ABC's Diane Sawyer this week, didn't the U.S. drop the bomb on Hiroshima?
In his PR putsch this week, undertaken at the behest of his panicky Jordanian puppet, Saddam told The Wall Street Journal's Karen Elliott House he would accept nuclear weapons as a gift from the U.S. That was his idea of a joke.
The Bush Administration counsels appeasement: although a half-billion dollars in grain credit guarantees has recently been suspended because kickback greed got out of hand, our Export-Import Bank guarantees continue. An Ex-Im release says serenely about Dow Chemical shipments financed by the U.S. taxpayer: ''it was unlikely that they would be used for the production of chemical weapons.''
Unlikely! Tell that to the 5,000 Kurdish dead in Saddam's poison-gas attack on Halabja.
Before the U.S. can protest other countries' aid to Iraq's Condor II, we need to clean up our act. Senator Inouye has a quarantine bill to stop trade, aid and the arms buildup.
The Bush Administration argues that other suppliers will take our place and Senator Dole says this will hurt our farmers, but Senator Nancy Kassebaum makes them all look like moral pygmies: ''It would hurt wheat sales in Kansas, that's true. But sometimes we have to stand up and be counted.''

HEADLINE: Albany Leaders Agree on Hospital Aid Increase

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 28

 BODY:
Legislative leaders agreed tonight on a major revision of the state's system of health-care financing that would bail out distressed hospitals. The pact would also provide substantial incentives for expanding the availability of primary care, although not by as much as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had requested.
The accord between the Assembly and the Senate will pump $420 million into New York's health-care system. The state will provide $52 million through increased Medicaid payments, a move that will set off an automatic increase in contributions from the Federal government, local governments and private insurers, who will pay the rest. Some business leaders fear that health insurance premiums paid by private businesses could jump as much as 20 percent because of the accord. 
The agreement was seen as a major victory for the state's hospitals, which would receive far more than had been recommended by Mr. Cuomo and his Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod. The money will help hospitals cope with a debilitating nursing shortage and crowded emergency rooms and compensate them for rapidly increasing labor costs and the high price of treating patients with AIDS and drug-related conditions. ''It appears that the Legislature has attempted to come to terms with every major problem the hospital system faces,'' said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
 
No Veto Expected
Mr. Cuomo, whose aides were not involved in the hospital reimbursement negotiations, had not signed off on the agreement by late this afternoon. But legislative leaders believe their bill gives the Governor enough of what he wants to forestall a veto.
The risk of a veto was not the only political obstacle facing the legislation today. After a day of bizarre election-year maneuvering, the reimbursement bill remained the political captive of two other pieces of important health-care legislation.
When the discussions on hospital reimbursement concluded tonight, the Democratic negotiators representing the Assembly majority believed they had reached an agreement with their Republican colleagues from the Senate on an innovative, but potentially expensive, plan to provide state-subsidized health insurance for poor children.
Senate officials said today that there was a basic understanding on the framework for such a plan. But they said that they would not pass a children's health insurance plan unless the Assembly and Mr. Cuomo accepted legislation to cap the fees doctors can charge senior citizens.
Senator Michael J. Tully, the chairman of the Health Committee, said the Senate Republicans were very concerned about the potential cost of the children's health insurance plan. But he and other Senate leaders suggested that the bill would be easier to swallow if passed in conjunction with the legislation limiting doctors' fees, which is known as mandatory Medicare assignment.
''They want to hold the kids hostage for the seniors,'' said Eve E. Brooks, executive director of Statewide Youth Advocacy and a leading lobbyist for the children's health insurance package.
The political wrangling over the health bills, all of it conducted behind closed doors with the Legislature seemingly close to adjournment, was largely about how the measures might affect this fall's elections. The Republicans hold a 34-to-26 margin in the 61-member Senate, but the Democrats have threatened a strong campaign to reverse that majority. One seat is vacant.
Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, both Democrats, have made a children's health insurance plan an important part of their legislative agenda for the year. The law would provide free or low-cost insurance for almost half of the 260,000 children in New York State who are currently without medical coverage, a program with great appeal to traditional Democratic constituent groups.
 
New Formula Needed
The Senate Republicans, meanwhile, hope to appeal to the state's influential senior citizens lobby by portraying themselves as the defenders of Medicare benefits.
The Senate's proposal for to limit doctors' fees is actually less generous to senior citizens than one favored by the Assembly. But by insisting that the bill be linked to hospital reimbursement, campaigning Republicans would be able to argue that they forced action on an issue that might otherwise have died this session.
The Legislature has no choice about approving a new hospital reimbursement formula this year. The current three-year formula, which determines the amount hospitals are paid by Medicaid, Blue Cross/Blue Shield and private insurers, expires on Dec. 31.
The state's hospitals have run up operating losses estimated at more than $1 billion in each of the last two years.
The state's budget, which was approved last month, included almost $500 million for a normal inflationary adjustment for hospitals. It also included $13 million to pay for the changes the Legislature would later make in the reimbursement formula.
 
Dividing the Aid
That $13 million covers the state's share of Medicaid payments, the government's health insurance program for the poor, in the last quarter of this fiscal year. Because it also dictates the share of Medicaid payments that must be made by the Federal and local governments, as well as the reimbursements required of private insurers, the state's $13 million, which will grow into $52 million on an annual basis, will bring hospitals an estimated total of $420 million.
Mr. Cuomo and Dr. Axelrod had hoped that the $13 million would be divided by providing approximately $7 million for hospital inpatient services and $6 million for outpatient services. By giving such a large proportion to outpatient services, they reasoned that hospitals would be prodded into opening and expanding family and community clinics, a move that would relieve crowding in emergency rooms.
 
Bonus for Rural Hospitals
The formula announced today, however, would give between $9 million and $10 million to inpatient services and the rest to outpatient programs.
The largest chunk would give hospitals money to increase the salaries and benefits needed to attract registered nurses and other health care professionals. Money also was provided for the acquisition of new medical technology, unexpected capital expenses like asbestos removal and the cost of inpatient admissions from emergency rooms.
Rural hospitals that have difficulty retaining personnel were given a bonus, as were hospitals with high proportions of complicated cases, like AIDS.
Although the money for outpatient services is not as much as Mr. Cuomo wanted, that area did receive a financial boost. Among other measures, the cap on Medicaid payments for visits to outpatient clinics would be raised to $70 from $60 and the maximum payment to hospitals for outpatient services provided in emergency rooms would rise to $97.50 from $90.

HEADLINE: Get Tough With Cuomo Is Bush Advice to Rinfret

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
Pierre A. Rinfret, New York's Republican candidate for Governor, said President Bush told him today to hit Mario M. Cuomo and ''hit him hard'' in this fall's election campaign.
Mr. Rinfret then spent much of his day here hammering away at the Governor for having been ''too chicken'' to serve in the Korean War, when Mr. Cuomo had a student deferment.
But Mr. Rinfret, who saw the President during a brief photo session at the White House with gubernatorial candidates from several states, declined to offer any specifics on the advice Mr. Bush may have given him and said, in any event, that it was not particularly detailed.
''We were like cattle through a chute,'' said the economist, who began his first run for political office after nearly a score of other possible contenders turned down offers from Republican leaders. ''He said, 'Hi ya, Pierre.' I've never met him in my life.'' 
 
Bush Looks 'Much Thinner'
Mr. Rinfret, who said the President looked ''in great shape, much thinner than he does in the pictures,'' continued his free-wheeling style in several other appearances today.
He suggested that officials ''down the line'' from Mr. Cuomo were going to single him out for an audit of his state income taxes but admitted this was only conjecture. When a reporter asked why he was throwing out such a charge without proof, he said, ''Then I'll pull it back. How's that?''
He also said that he would not speculate on whether his candidacy might be damaged by President Bush's concession on the need for more tax revenues, saying that ''nobody knows any details'' about what taxes might be raised.
Republican officials publicly sang Mr. Rinfret's praises and Eddie Mahe, a political consultant who has been hired by the Rinfret campaign, said the candidate would have a lot of appeal because ''the guy's open, he's forthright, he doesn't play games.''
But there were some difficult moments as well. One official at the Republican National Committee silently banged his forehead when Mr. Rinfret said in a television interview that President Lyndon B. Johnson had led the country into the Korean War; actually Harry S. Truman was President when the war began. Mr. Rinfret said that the Republicans had discussed both arranging a Presidential campaign visit this fall and pumping some money into the candidate's treasury, but acknowledged that there had been no firm commitments on either score.
Although Mr. Rinfret is expected to use footage from today's White House visit in his campaign commercials, President Bush is widely seen as having essentially backed away from New York Republicans this year once it became clear that they were encountering difficulty finding both the money and the candidate to defeat Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Rinfret's dig at Mr. Cuomo for not serving in the Korean War came in the context of accusing Mr. Cuomo of also being afraid to engage in a debate. Both candidates have said that they would would be willing to debate, but have set no dates.
''He's too chicken to debate, just as he was too chicken to serve his country,'' said Mr. Rinfret of Mr. Cuomo. ''All I know is that I served my country, my family served, and my brother-in-law is dead. And I think it's a very fair question to say, 'You had a chance to serve your country in the military and you didn't.' ''
Mr. Cuomo's spokesman, Gary G. Fryer, said the Governor did get a student deferment while at St. John's University. But he said to say that Mr. Cuomo got it because of a lack of courage was ''absurd on its face.''
''We had hoped for a positive campaign, and it's sad that Mr. Rinfret isn't interested in that,'' he said.

HEADLINE: 4 Projects Honored For Design

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
The Albert S. Bard Awards, presented since 1963 by the City Club of New York to outstanding works of architecture and urban design in the city, were given yesterday to four New York projects and four New York public officials. The awards to officials, one of whom is former Mayor John V. Lindsay, represent something of a departure for the Bard Awards, which have gone to more than 100 buildings and projects over the last 25 years but have been presented only four times before to individuals.
Two city-owned buildings received top honors: the reconstruction of the Central Park Zoo, designed by Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo & Associates, and the restoration and modernization of Brooklyn Borough Hall, designed by Conklin Rossant Architects. Two privately owned buildings - the St. Thomas Choir School at 202 West 58th Street in Manhattan, designed by Buttrick White & Burtis, and the Columbus Townhouses, a development at 103-113 West 89th Street in Manhattan, by Hoberman & Wasserman Architects - received honorable mention. The awards were presented at a program yesterday evening at the Central Park Zoo. 
Mr. Lindsay is being honored by the City Club for his administration's ''enlightened concern for urban design and planning,'' according to the Bard citation. The City Club committee that conferred the award said, ''His administration was unique in establishing quality of design as an important factor in decision-making.'' Mr. Lindsay oversaw the creation of the Urban Design Group within the City Planning Commission, which has since been disbanded, as well the establishment of community planning boards and numerous innovative programs in zoning.
 
More Recent Officials Honored
The other special awards went to more recent officials: Paul A. Crotty and Abraham Biderman, former commissioners of the Housing and Development Administration under Mayor Edward I. Koch, who are being honored jointly for conceiving and implementing the city's 10-year master plan to rehabilitate 250,000 low- to moderate-income dwelling units, and David Gunn, former president of the New York City Transit Authority, for overseeing the renovation of the subway system.
The decision this year by the Bard Awards jury, which was headed by the architects Lee Harris Pomeroy and John Ellis, to confer its highest awards on two projects built by the city itself is unusual for this awards program. In recent years the Bard Awards, generally considered the most prestigious architectural awards that are given specifically to buildings within New York City, have gone mainly to privately built projects. The awards were actually created to encourage serious architectural quality in civic architecture, and were originally intended to go only to city-owned buildings. But when the first Bard jury in 1963 could not find a single building worthy of honoring, the scope was expanded to include any recently completed work of architecture and urban design within the city.
''This marks a kind of return to the original premise of the Bard Awards, honoring projects in which the city itself is the client and the owner,'' said Peter Samton, president of the City Club. ''By honoring these projects, as well as former Mayor Lindsay and these other public officials, we want to send a message that this is a time for the city to plan, to strengthen what it does in design and planning, and not to be shortsighted and use the budget crunch as an excuse to do less.''
 
Fitting Into the Context
The two city-owned projects that received Bard Awards, as well as the two private projects receiving honorable mention, all represent the current trend toward making architecture that seeks to fit into the existing urban context.
The Brooklyn Borough Hall is literally an old building, of course, completed in 1848, modified continually over the years, and now restored to something approximating its original appearance while getting completely modern mechanical systems.
The Central Park Zoo is new, but was designed by Kevin Roche to fit comfortably into the landscape of Central Park as well as relate to the older architecture of the park. It is fanciful and dignified at the same time, and could not be more right for Central Park; in some ways it is the single most encouraging example of city-sponsored public architecture in the last decade.
The St. Thomas Choir School is among the city's best examples of ''contextual architecture'': it is a building of brick and limestone that manages to fit gracefully into a midtown streetscape while still appearing to be a special and distinct place.
The Columbus Townhouses are less handsomely detailed than the choir school, but speak more of the trials and tribulations of the real world. In this case the architect Joseph Wasserman was his own developer, taking on several adjacent sites in the Upper West Side urban renewal district, and this grouping is unquestionably the best of them.
In addition to Mr. Pomeroy, Mr. Ellis and Mr. Samton, this year's Bard awards jury included Amanda Burden, former vice president of planning and design for Battery Park City; Meyer S. Frucher, executive vice president of the development firm Olympia & York; the planner Raquel Ramati, and the architects David Childs and Rafael Vinoly.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
The Urge to Gamble, and How to Fight It

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Gambling as an addiction, as severe and destructive as an addiction to alcohol or any other drug, is the subject of ''Lucky Number,'' a feisty documentary tomorrow at 8 P.M. on Channel 13. Presented by Maryland Public Television, the hourlong essay was made by the same team that did ''Other Faces of AIDS.'' John Grassie is the producer, Everett Marshburn the executive producer. The host and narrator is Charles Gibson of ABC's ''Good Morning America.'' 
At issue is compulsive gambling. The program estimates that at least 110 million Americans gamble, up to 5 million of them compulsively. In a sense, they represent the purest form of addiction: totally psychological. That's one problem. As one victim observes: ''People don't smell dice on your breath or see card marks on your arm.'' As a result, very few treatment programs are available, and some of the better ones, like the one at the Taylor Manor clinic in Maryland, may not always have their expensive tabs covered by medical insurance.
Another problem is that gambling in America is a very big business, reported to generate $250 billion a year, legally and otherwise. In addition to the casinos, there are state lotteries, parimutuel betting and sports wagers. Some of the more pertinent statistics offered about compulsive gamblers: 65 percent are men; 96 percent started betting before the age of 14. Their personal profiles cut across all social, economic and age groups. One expert, Dr. Robert Custer, says that 20 percent of the compulsive gamblers he now treats started in the financial markets.
For compulsive gamblers, addiction takes over their lives. It may start by ''chasing money,'' trying to win back losses, to clean up and pay off debts. But Dr. Robert E. Hunter, a psychologist at Charter Hospital in Las Vegas, Nev., observes: ''In the end stage of the disease, it has to do with anesthesia. They are blocking feelings, blocking sensation, blocking pain, through their gambling.'' The by now familiar penalties are bankruptcy, destroyed families and even imprisonment. Yet these victims are often encouraged by casinos that go on extending credit, and occasionally even free transportation, far beyond the point of no return.
''Lucky Number'' poses some tough questions for the sponsors of gambling, including the 32 states that run lotteries. ''For legislators,'' Mr. Gibson says, ''approving a lottery is a whole lot easier than asking for new taxes.'' Only Iowa has a provision for putting part of its lottery revenues into a Gamblers Assistance Fund designed to support treatment centers throughout the state.
The casinos continue to devise ways to get more money out of their patrons faster. In Las Vegas, for instance, we see the new rapid-play ''video poker'' machines that are especially appealing to women who, it is theorized, do not like the competitive atmosphere of the gaming tables. Some of the women interviewed admit to spending more than 12 hours a day with the machines. A couple of them talk about pawning their valuables to keep going.
The problem of the compulsive gambler is receiving more attention through organizations like Gamblers Anonymous. The producers of this documentary argue that much more could be done, including programs supported directly by clearly reluctant casino operators. Mr. Gibson concludes, ''Just because the problem isn't completely understood doesn't mean it can be ignored.''
 
Lucky Number
Produced by John Grassie; executive producer, Everett Marshburn; presented by Maryland Public Television; Charles Gibson, narrator. Saturday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13.

HEADLINE: American's Big Plans For New Latin Routes

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
If European and Asian routes are the highways of international aviation, Latin America has long been merely a side street. Until now, Pan American World Airways and Eastern Airlines have been the only major United States carriers to fly these southern routes.
But starting on Sunday, American Airlines will begin flying to Central and South America, using Miami as its gateway, in what will be the largest route expansion for the nation's largest airline. American, which bought the routes to 20 cities in 15 countries from Eastern Airlines for $330 million, is expected to exploit the market better than did its struggling predecessor. American has the feeder traffic, advertising budget and reputation for service that Eastern could only dream of. 
''It's a market that's been allowed to lie fallow,'' said Ed Greenslet, an industry consultant. ''Someone with American's punch and aggressiveness will stimulate the traffic flow and make a profit.''
 
An Increase in Flights
American's arrival in Latin America will not set off fare wars, because ticket prices must be approved by the governments of both countries on a route, and do not vary much between airlines. But American will offer more flights to the region than Eastern did and plans to win customers with high standards of service.
American tried to elbow its way into Latin America in 1982, with little success. A route from Dallas to Rio de Janeiro proved unprofitable and the airline dropped it after nine months.
This time, American has shown it is more serious. For instance, it has been building up its hub in Miami, a city that, with its large Hispanic population and southern location, has become the nation's gateway to Latin America. Even before the new Latin service begins, American has 48 flights a day to and from Miami, compared with only about a dozen a year ago.
Analysts estimated that, at first, the new routes would generate less than 10 percent of the airline's $10 billion in annual revenue. But they expect the routes to be profitble by next year.
American plans to expand its Latin American route system, said Arnold J. Grossman, vice president of international planning. For instance, Eastern flew to Santiago, Chile, three times a week, but American will fly there daily. American plans eventually to offer direct flights to Latin America from its Dallas/Fort Worth hub airport and from New York.
With 200,000 passengers a day, American has more traffic than any other airline to funnel into its Latin American flights. That kind of volume is sure to put pressure on financially feeble Pan Am. Latin routes account for 16 percent of Pan Am's revenue and are important to its survival. Pan Am objected to the route sale to American, arguing that it would be placed at a competitive disadvantage. ''We recognize that American is a more formidable competitor, but we don't think they're invincible,'' said Jeff Kriendler, a Pan Am spokesman.
But American's major competition will most likely come from Varig, the Brazilian airline. With 6.7 million passengers last year, the carrier is by far the largest in the region and has the best reputation for service among the Latin American carriers, industry analysts say. Pan Am carried three million passengers in Latin America, Eastern 1.5 million and Aerolineas Argentinas, the second-largest Latin American carrier, 3.7 million. $106 Million Outlay Set American will spend $106 million to begin the new service, including $42 million in Miami alone. That $106 million includes the training of workers, the purchase of computers and the construction of check-in counters.
Industry analysts estimate that the figure also includes at least $20 million for advertising. Executives at American concede that the airline has to overcome a lack of name recognition overseas.
American is expanding so rapidly that it now has a shortage of airplanes. In fact, the carrier has had to delay the expansion of its European service to divert planes to Latin America. American will use mostly twin-engine planes on the new routes, while Eastern used less fuel-efficient three-engine aircraft.
The route purchase is part of American's plan to become a major international airline; air travel is expected to grow much more rapidly abroad than in this country. Indeed, American has already added dozens of weekly flights to Europe in the last few years and is one of nine carriers competing for Government approval for six more routes to Tokyo, one of the most lucrative destinations.
But air travel to Latin America is expected to grow by only 5 percent annually, about half the rate for the Pacific market. ''There is a lot of room to grow in Latin America, but it will never be anywhere near the size of Europe or the Pacific,'' said Mr. Greenslet, the industry consultant.
Next week, American begins flying from Miami to Argentina, Brazil and Chile. By Aug. 15, it plans to fly to 20 cities in 15 Central and South American countries. The routes that American purchased are mainly along the west coast of South America - to destinations like Santiago, Chile, and Lima, Peru, that are more popular with business travelers than tourists. ''It's a beautiful route structure,'' said Russ Thayer, a vice president at Airline Economics, a consulting firm based in Washington. By contrast, Pan Am flies mainly to the east coast of the continent.
The transfer of the routes from Eastern to American has not been seamless. American contends that Eastern misrepresented the condition of its hangar in New York, and is asking that $7.2 million be set aside in an escrow account to cover cleanup costs.
American's flight attendants' union sued the airline when it tried to hire foreign residents in Latin America. (The union has since settled with the airline, which has agreed to limit the number of foreign flight attendants.) American has also faced red tape, as the change in route ownership is processed in South America. ''The biggest problem has been the regressive bureaucracies, which can't process our paperwork in a reasonable amount of time,'' said one American executive who asked not to be identified. Indeed, American has still not received approval to fly to Ecuador.
Eastern had not made a profit on its Latin routes for years, said Timothy Pettee, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. Last year, the airline lost $169 million on the routes.
Karen Ceremsak, a spokeswoman for Eastern, said that in addition to the financial drain the airline also encountered unusual problems on some of its flights. For instance, there were ''quite a number of drug finds'' on Eastern planes flying from Latin America, and as a result several of the airline's jets were confiscated. Mr. Grossman of American said the carrier would take extra security precautions on its flights to the region but he declined to elaborate.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
How to Read Bush's Lips

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
Did President Bush break his pledge of ''no new taxes,'' or, with his carefully phrased, succinct but ambiguous acknowledgement of the need for ''tax revenue increases,'' did he not?
The whooping and hollering of many Republicans against the President's statement indicates that they think he did break his pledge, which they regard as crucial to the outcome of this year's Congressional and gubernatorial elections. ''The President may well go into a back room somewhere and sign off on this deal,'' said Representative Robert S. Walker, a Pennsylvania Republican, ''but Republicans haven't.''
But some Republicans and ideological opponents of tax increases contend that Mr. Bush has not really changed his position. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, famous as a supply sider, said higher tax revenues can come from many sources, including a growing economy, new Federal fees or taxes on tobacco - or even from lower tax rates. Indeed, President Bush still wants a cut in the capital gains tax, contending that it would spur the economy and raise tax revenues. His statement on the budget deficit and tax revenue increases, issued after his meeting with Congressional leaders, also calls for ''growth incentives,'' presumably including a cut in the capital gains tax. 
Nevertheless, something important has happened; the President's statement on taxes markedly improves prospects of a deal between the White House and Congress to cut the budget deficit. The specifics from Mr. Bush are lacking and need to be worked out in negotiations. Mr. Bush declined to elaborate on his position, telling reporters, ''I'll let the statement speak for itself.''
But in an interview this week, Under Secretary of State Richard T. McCormack, who is serving as the President's ''sherpa'' for next month's economic summit meeting in Houston with the other leaders of the major industrial countries, did discuss Mr. Bush's statement and the reasons he made it now. ''He had this sense,'' Mr. McCormack said, ''that the budget negotiations with Congress were stuck at dead center, and he was determined to move the process off dead center.''
The need to act is urgent, Mr. McCormack added, ''because the budget problem had been made worse by the savings and loan problem; we have had horrible news on the S.&L. problem.''
The President and his advisers clearly do not accept the argument of some economists that the savings and loan bailout need not affect either the budget or the economy, representing a ''wash transaction,'' a transfer of capital from bondholders and taxpayers to depositors.
Even without including the rising costs of the savings bailout in the budget, the Administration has raised its estimate of the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1991 to $159 billion, far above the Gramm-Rudman ceiling of $64 billion.
Slicing the deficit by a mere $30 billion or so, as some have proposed, looks painfully inadequate to stem the buildup of debt. The President has long been deeply troubled by the mounting debt and its long-term effects on the economy and the American people. ''He has a sense of stewardship,'' Mr. McCormack said. ''He doesn't want to pile debt on debt, leaving it for our grandchildren.''
But Mr. Bush wants ''tax revenue increases'' as part of a ''broad package,'' Mr. McCormack added, that would also include ''entitlement and mandatory-program reform,'' cuts in discretionary spending, ''orderly reductions'' in military spending, and ''budget-process reform.'' The President does not want the United States to wind up like Canada after it raised taxes, with ''the same enormous budget deficit, the same percentage of gross national product, but at a higher level.''
Mr. Bush sees long-term benefits for the economy's growth resulting from fiscal measures to cut the budget deficit. ''Reducing the claims on public capital would lower the costs of capital'' and spur investment, Mr. McCormack said.
Another reason the President made his statement now was his concern about the talks with Japan over ''strategic impediments'' to trade. As the United States pressed the Japanese to curb their monopolistic practices and devote more capital to public works at home, Japan urged this country to cut its budget deficit as the basic cause of its trade deficit and growing dependence on foreign capital. The two countries reached a broad agreement on these issues yesterday.
Summing up the President's reasons for opening the door to tax increases, Mr. McCormack ranked the President's ''sense of stewardship'' as No. 1, the danger that the ''budget summit was falling apart'' as No. 2, and the need for a breakthrough in negotiations with Japan on the Strategic Impediments Initiative as No. 3.
But the economic summit meeting also affected the President's decision to move on the vexatious issue of taxes, to show America's will and ability to tackle problems of its own making.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
TREASURY ISSUES CONTINUE TO GAIN

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The credit market rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates dipped in moderately active trading. For the first time this week, dealers said, retail customers were significant buyers of securities.
Traders said that there likely was further room for improvement.
''For now the market is under the trance of a budget accord,'' one Government bond trader said, ''and there is nothing of substance to get in the way of that feeling until we get to the employment numbers a week from Friday.'' 
Most market participants remain skeptical that Congress and the Bush Admnistration will come up with a meaningful package to reduce the Federal budget deficit. Nevertheless, President Bush's statement earlier in the week that tax revenue increases will be needed as part of a comprehensive effort to cut the deficit is still ringing in Wall Street's ears.
 
Afraid Not to Believe
''Whether traders believe what Mr. Bush said or not is not the issue,'' said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
''At this juncture, they are afraid not to believe it. There is a clear nervousness about selling securities right now, especially when they are holding meetings in Washington to look for ways to cut the deficit.''
Yesterday's price rise began in London, where traders said a Japanese account bought large amounts of securities.
That purchase, plus a successful auction of new one-year Treasury notes in the early afternoon, bolstered prices further.
''The market is firm and the tone is positive,'' another trader said. ''Despite the auctions this week, it doesn't seem like the Street has many securities on its books.''
At yesterday's auction, the new one-year bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.52 percent, down from the average rate of 7.65 percent on the one-year bills auctioned on May 31.
 
Savings Bailout Bonds
In addition to the successful bill auction, traders were also heartened by the Resolution Funding Corporation's announcement yesterday that early next month it will sell an unspecified amount of 30-year bonds.
Earlier this year, Resolution Funding, the entity established to finance the bailout of troubled savings and loan associations, made two offerings of 40-year bonds that were poorly received. But traders said issues with maturities of 30 years are far easier to sell.
The size of the new bond offering will be announced next week.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered in late trading at a price of 103 13/32, up 15/32, to yield 8.43 percent, compared with a yield of 8.47 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 102 27/ 32 late yesterday, up 3/8 of a point, to yield 8.44 percent.
Prices of the two note issues auctioned earlier in the week also improved.
By late in the day, the 8 1/2 percent four-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.38 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes sold on Tuesday were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.27 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.73 percent, down 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.61 percent.
 
Corporate Issues
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the American General Finance Corporation offered $150 million worth of four-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The 9 1/4 percent notes, which mature on July 1, 1994, were priced at $99.55 to yield 9.387, 97 basis points more than the prevailing when-issued yield on the 8 1/2 percent four-year Treasury notes auctioned on Wednesday.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Also in the corporate market, Texaco Capital Inc., a financing subsidiary of Texaco Inc., offered $150 million worth of debentures.
The 8 5/8 percent debentures have a final maturity of June 30, 2010, but holders may redeem the securities in three years by exercising a put option at 100. The debentures were priced at $99.85 to yield 8.682, 30 basis points more than the prevailing yield on the 8 5/8 percent three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is also rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was slow, dealers said. Prices of most actively quoted issues were unchanged to up 1/8 of a point.
The tone was somewhat firmer in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds.
According to municipal bond traders, prices of most issues improved by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended June 18. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading Is Focused on Yen; Dollar Ends Mostly Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher yesterday in relatively quiet trading on world currency markets.
Traders said much of the day's activity centered on the Japanese yen, which was helped early in Asian trading by expectations of another increase in Japanese interest rates.
When activity shifted to the West, traders sold the West German mark and the Swiss franc to buy yen, and the dollar retreated to the sidelines. It fell more than a yen against the Japanese currency. 
 
Marginal Interest in Dollar
''It looked as if the yen sort of caught on,'' said Curtis Perkins, a trader with the Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. He said there was only marginal interest in the dollar.
Volume was relatively light in United States markets, said Ian Spence, chief dealer at Manufacturers Hanover Trust. Trading was also subdued in Europe, where dealers awaited Sunday's economic and monetary union of East and West Germany.
In New York trading, the dollar settled at 153.15 yen, down from 154.40 on Wednesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had gained against the yen, closing at 154.42 yen, up from 154.35 yen. Later in London, it slipped to close at 153.20 yen.
In London, one British pound cost $1.7400 late Thursday, compared with $1.7445 late Wednesday. In New York, one pound cost $1.7384, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7428.
Against the West German currency, the dollar rose to 1.6730 marks, from 1.6637.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.4200 Swiss francs, up from 1.4095; 5.6155 French francs, up from 5.5915; 1,228.00 Italian lire, up from 1,221.50, and 1.1699 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1695.
 
Gold, Silver Gain
In the precious metals market, gold prices firmed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for June delivery closed at $352.10 an ounce, up 70 cents. Later, Republic National Bank in New York quoted an ounce of gold at $351.10, up $1 an ounce.
The late price of gold in London was a bid of $352.25, up from $350.05. In Zurich, the late bid was $352.60, up from $349.90. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $350.55, unchanged.
Silver prices also rose. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery settled at $4.813 an ounce, up from $4.794 on Wednesday. In London the metal traded at a bid of $4.85 an ounce, up $4.84.

HEADLINE: Bush Defends Reversal on Taxes, Citing Nation's Economic Needs

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
Coming very close to admitting that he had abandoned a campaign promise, President Bush defended his reversal on taxes today by painting a bleak economic picture and saying he trusted Americans to understand why he was prepared to accept higher taxes in the 1991 fiscal year.
In an adroit display of verbal gymnastics at a 35-minute news conference that offered unusual insight into the thoughts of a usually reticent man, Mr. Bush never denied that taxes were going to go up or that he had reversed the 1988 ''read my lips'' pledge that helped bring him into the White House. He simply avoided making either point himself.
But several times he all but acknowledged that taxes would be increased to reduce a swelling Federal deficit. He also made clear that he expected to make a speech in a matter of months to defend a budget that does just that. 
Mr. Bush acknowledged the ''arrows'' that had been shot at him this week, but he said with resignation, ''That's what I get paid for.'' [Transcript, page 8.] Reaching for ways to protect himself against a backlash from voters and conservative Republicans, Mr. Bush invoked two party icons: Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. He also cited a need for ''responsible government,'' appealed for bipartisan support and said his announcement on Tuesday that ''tax revenue increases'' were needed to reduce the budget deficit was an act of political leadership.
The deficit-reduction negotiations now under way between the White House and Congress ''are a make-or-break effort at responsible government,'' Mr. Bush said. ''The Congressional budgeting process must succeed, and the negotiators are facing tough questions about where to make cuts and where to raise revenues, and these are not decisions that anyone relishes. They are decisions that Democrats and Republicans alike have got to face with candor and courage.''
 
A Turbulent Week
With the news conference, which capped one of the most turbulent weeks of his Presidency, Mr. Bush emerged from three days of silence on the tax issue. In that time his top aides had struggled to stanch protests from the Republican right and fought a losing battle with the Democrats over interpretation of his tax announcement Tuesday.
Mr. Bush did not demur when several reporters referred to his ''reversal'' on the tax issue, and he said he could understand those who accused him of breaking his 1988 campaign pledge of ''no new taxes.''
''I think it's wrong,'' he said of that interpretation, ''but I can understand it.''
At least eight times during the news conference, Mr. Bush used language that forecast a tax increase of some kind. ''People know we are going to have to take action,'' he said in one instance. In another, he said, ''The negotiators are free to discuss a wide array of options, including tax increases.''
Mr. Bush explained his shift by offering a grim picture of the economy: ''We now estimate a deficit of over $150 billion in fiscal 1991, not counting the costs of the savings and loan cleanup.''
He went on with a grim picture of budget cuts that would be automatically made if the deficit was not brought down enough: ''Unless Congress acts, there will be a cutoff in October of nearly $100 billion in Government services under the sequester provisions of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. The potential results are Draconian cuts in defense, student grants and a wide array of other domestic services. And to avoid this, tough decisions must be made.''
Mr. Bush said he was sincere in 1988 when he pledged not to raise taxes. ''I go back to the experiences of previous people that have been in this office who say one thing in a campaign, come in and keep that pledge, if you're talking about taxes, for quite a while and then see there's an enormous problem facing the nation that requires a bipartisan answer.''
Mr. Bush insisted that the economic situation had changed significantly since his campaign. That assertion was in keeping with an economic picture that includes interest rates that have been higher and corporate profits that have been lower than were projected by the Administration when it submitted its 1991 budget proposal to Congress in January. On the other hand, Congressional Democrats have declared all along that the White House budget assumptions were far too optimistic.
''I thought I could do a better job on getting spending down,'' Mr. Bush said today, ''and perhaps getting the reforms of the budget process that I also talked about.''
Asked whether he thought his shift on taxes would damage his credibility, Mr. Bush said, ''No, not in the long run.''
He said that if a bipartisan budget agreement is struck, ''I can go to the Amercan people and say, 'Look we've all had to give or take a little on this, but this agreement is going to be good for future generations, it's going to be good for the economy, it's going to be good for jobs.' Then people will say, 'Look, we support the President.' ''
Mr. Bush said the reaction to his announcement on Tuesday had been ''intense.'' At one point, he said, he met with Republican Congressional candidates and found the atmosphere charged with unspoken concern that he had stripped them of the party's most potent campaign weapon: a no-tax policy.
''I could totally sympathize, empathize, with what they were going through,'' said Mr. Bush.
He continued: ''We didn't have time, because it was about a 45-second handshake, but if we had, I'd have said: 'Now, look, you've got to look at the big picture here. Stay with your position. Advocate what you believe and tell your constituents what you'll try to do, and then just stay a bit open-minded so when we get an agreement - and I hope we will - that is good for the country, that you can say, Well, we can accept this.' ''
 
Reaching for Lincoln
Over and over, Mr. Bush reached for the legacy of Lincoln, who in 1862 spoke of the need to leave old dogmas behind in troubled times. The reference was not to taxes, of course, but to how he should deal with Southern secession.
''Like Abraham Lincoln said, 'I'll think anew,' '' Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Bush, who is usually stung by comparisons between himself and Mr. Reagan, especially on issues that test political conservatism, also said he had comforted himself this week by remembering that in 1982 his predecessor, having run on a no-tax platform in 1980, weathered a similar storm after proposing a budget that raised taxes.
''That caused a furor like we're hearing now,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And the President, in my view, did what was right, and so I think that we're on the right track.''
After Mr. Bush's news conference, negotiators in the deficit-reduction talks resumed their discussions, focusing on proposals for deeper cuts in military spending than those proposed by the President in the budget he submitted in January.
Republicans are talking about shaving $9 billion from the current level of Pentagon outlays, while Democrats have suggested a cut of nearly twice that size.
The negotiations will resume July 10, when Congress returns from a weeklong recess for the 4th of July holiday.

Gephardt before deficit-reduction negotiations with Administration officials yesterday. The meeting was delayed by the President's news conference on taxes. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg9)
