HEADLINE: Pulling the Plug in a Savings Failure

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS

 BODY:
After a century in business, Otero Savings closed its doors for good last month, another casualty in the collapse of the nation's savings industry.
The story of Otero's last days, when Federal regulators shut down the failed Colorado savings and loan, selling its assets and paying off depositors quickly to prevent a panic, is one that is being repeated across the country as the Government strives to resolve the industry's crisis.
In most cases, the Government has been able to sell failed institutions to banks or other savings and loans, which typically acquire the depositors' accounts. But when bidders cannot be found, the institution is liquidated and depositors, whose individual accounts are federally insured up to $100,000, are reimbursed with Government checks.
The Government has sold or liquidated more than 200 failed savings and loans, and scores more are expected to be disposed of by the end of the year. 
Otero, one of the largest savings institutions in Colorado, was liquidated. Its closing became more dramatic than the regulators had hoped after word of the imminent closing was leaked to a local radio station, causing alarm among depositors.
At 11 A.M. on Friday, May 25, Jeanne F. McBride, an official with the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency responsible for the savings industry bailout, called together a team of auditors and lawyers in a Denver conference room. In the calmest voice she could manage, Ms. McBride announced that Otero, which was insolvent and had been under Government control for more than a year, would have to be closed hours ahead of schedule.
''We're going to call all the branch managers, we're going to call security, and we're going to tell them to close those doors at 2 P.M. today,'' Ms. McBride said at the time. ''We'll need to hurry.''
Rumors about Otero's fate were spreading quickly that morning in Colorado Springs, where the savings institution was based. Jittery customers had lined up at tellers' windows to empty their accounts.
The concern throughout the liquidation of Otero and other savings and loan associations is not only for the customers, but for the banking system as a whole.
In Otero's case, if the Government had been unable to reassure Otero customers that their money was safe and that they would be repaid quickly, regulators say, a run on deposits could have developed at other troubled savings associations in the area, and even at commercial banks. A Year of U.S. Control The Government actually took control of Otero in March 1989, when it became clear that its managers could not save the savings and loan. For more than a year, regulators tried to find a buyer for Otero. When none emerged, they shut it down.
When it closed, the assets on Otero's books were valued at $484 million. Yet much of the assets consisted of real estate loans on residential and commercial developments, often based on the assumption that property values would continue to rise. But with the downturn in the Colorado economy, the market value of the property fell sharply.
Accordingly, the Government estimates that it will have a shortfall of $196 million after all depositors have been paid and all of Otero's assets have been sold off. The $196 million is the projected cost to American taxpayers of Otero's failure. Investigators are also studying whether fraud may have contributed to Otero's demise. No charges have been filed.
 
Friday Closings Are Typical
Typically, a team of Government auditors and lawyers takes over an insolvent savings association when it closes on a Friday afternoon. They work through the weekend, sometimes around the clock, to review the books and insure that depositors with federally insured accounts can get their money the next week.
Otero's closing should have been routine as well. The Government had originally planned to shut it down at 5 P.M. on Friday, May 25, after customers had conducted their business for the week.
But after the local radio station learned of the Government's plan to liquidate Otero, the regulators' timetable was accelerated. News of the savings institution's demise was spreading quickly in Colorado Springs, 65 miles south of Denver.
Even though their accounts were fully insured by the Federal Government, Otero depositors were lining up at branch offices and demanding their money.
One Otero branch was left with less than $50,000 in cash, meaning that tellers would have to turn away customers if only a few more large accounts were closed. A Colorado Springs supermarket posted a notice announcing that it would refuse checks from Otero.
 
Doors Shut and Locked
Ms. McBride and the rest of the team in Denver rushed to their cars and drove to Colorado Springs.
At each of the 11 offices, they taped up notices announcing that Otero was closed. The automated teller system was shut down. Branch managers were told to close their teller windows and organize Otero's ledgers as if they were about to undergo a year-end audit. At exactly 2 P.M., the doors were shut and locked.
An investigator for the Resolution Trust Corporation, William Cobelli, began to gather documents that might shed light on whether fraud had contributed to Otero's failure. ''We want to be certain that we haven't missed anything,'' he said.
The first customer to learn of the shutdown was Darrin Zappa, an unemployed 22-year-old who had stopped by to withdraw $10 from his account to help him get through the long Memorial Day weekend.
He reacted more with sadness than anger to the news that he would have to wait until the next week for his money. There was, after all, only $71 in his account. ''Everybody here was real nice,'' he said.
 
A Rush to Prepare Checks
At Otero's nine branches, plans were readied to reimburse more than 20,000 depositors with Government checks. The checks would have to be ready by Tuesday morning, when Resolution Trust planned to reopen Otero temporarily after the long holiday weekend.
''Come hell or high water, we will get those doors open on Tuesday and we'll have those checks ready,'' said Michael Esch, one of the Resolution Trust supervisors assigned to the liquidation.
The job of reviewing the accounts and preparing thousands of checks was left to a team of agency employees led by Peter Sullivan. Like many of his colleagues, Mr. Sullivan is young, only 27. The hours required of regulators involved in the Government bailout are often grueling.
''In the past two months, I have spent one weekend at home in Denver,'' said Mr. Sullivan, who looked weary from so many nights on the road.
 
Armed Guards at the Ready
Resolution Trust employees were stationed outside Otero to act as ''public confidence'' agents - to answer questions from depositors who had just heard about the liquidation.
An armed guard stood nearby to deal with any emergency - a necessity, the R.T.C. has found. In mid-May, at the closing of a savings and loan in San Bernandino, Calif., a frantic depositor drew a knife on an agency employee, Mary Shattles, who talked to the man and calmed him down. ''They wanted me to prosecute, but I just couldn't,'' Ms. Shattles recalled. ''All that man wanted was his money.''
Although virutally all of Otero's scores of employees lost their jobs, most volunteered to pitch in over the weekend to help the regulators.
''We've been prepared for the fact that this could happen,'' said Karen Vasil, who was in charge of the safe-deposit-box department at Otero's main branch in Colorado Springs.
By late June, more than 90 percent of Otero's depositors had been paid. Resolution Trust was still trying to contact the remaining depositors by mail, urging them to claim their money, said Kevin Shields, an agency spokesman in Denver.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kevin Shields, back to camera, a spokesman for the Resolution Trust Corporation, answered depositors' questions outside a Colorado Springs branch of Otero Savings in May after regulators closed the institution. (Bruce McAllister for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ARCO to Pay $800 Million In Tax Case

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEV, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 29

 BODY:
ARCO said today that it had settled a long-standing dispute with the Internal Revenue Service by paying $800 million in back taxes and interest owed on Alaskan oil production.
The dispute centered on the value assigned by the company to the crude oil it pumped from wells on the Alaskan North Slope. The I.R.S. contended that ARCO, also known as the Atlantic Richfield Company, had assigned the oil a value lower than it should have at that point and thereby underpaid on taxes.
ARCO said its payment, made today after two years of negotiations, is for less than half the total amount billed by the I.R.S. In July 1988, the company received a bill for $1.3 billion from the I.R.S. covering the years 1980 to 1983. Earlier this year, the company received a bill for an additional $500 million, including tax and interest, covering production from the years 1984 and 1985. 
In the early 1980's, when the value of oil rose above a certain base rate, oil companies were required to pay a ''windfall profits'' tax. If a company assigned oil a lower value at the well, it reduced the windfall-profits tax it had to pay.
A spokesman for ARCO, Albert Greenstein, said the company used one method for calculating the value of oil at the well. ''The I.R.S. had another,'' he continued, ''and we reached a settlement we consider fair.''
ARCO, the nation's eighth-largest oil company, said it had previously set aside an unspecified amount to cover the payment.
''The company is adequately reserved, and so this settlement payment we made today will have no impact on earnings,'' Mr. Greenstein said.
 
'It Might Be a Blip'
Analysts agreed. Thomas R. Samuelson, an analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago, said he anticipated little effect on earnings. ''It might be a blip,'' he said. ''In the oil industry, there are a lot of unusual items.''
Mr. Samuelson noted that in a settlement a few days ago, ARCO said it will collect $300 million in damages from the Southern Natural Gas Company stemming from an accident on an ARCO drilling platform in the Gulf of Mexico in which seven workers were killed.
Analysts have said the I.R.S. began investigating ARCO in the mid-1980's after receiving complaints from other oil companies. During much of the 1980-83 period, analysts said, ARCO was often underpricing rivals by a cent or two a gallon at the pump. One reason for the company's advantage was that it was paying a lower windfall-profits tax than its competitors, analysts said.
 
ARCO's Previous Contention
At the time it received the original I.R.S. bill, ARCO contended that its crude-oil pricing policies conformed to ''widely held'' economic theories about pricing Alaskan crude oil.
The windfall-profits tax was enacted in 1980 at a time of rapidly rising oil prices. It was intended to insure that the Government's share of revenue would increase along with the industry's by imposing an additional tax on oil producers when crude prices surpassed a certain level. The tax was in effect from 1980 to 1985 but was made obsolete when prices dropped in 1986. It was repealed in 1988.
Other oil companies, including Standard Oil (Indiana), have settled similar windfall-profits tax disputes with the I.R.S.
 
ACQUISITION CHALLENGED
 WASHINGTON, June 29 (Special to The New York Times) - The Federal Trade Commission, in an unusual action, moved today to rescind the already-paid-for acquisition by the Arco Chemical Company of $220 million of properties belonging to the Union Carbide Corporation's Chemicals and Plastics Group.
The commission said it authorized its staff to seek a court order to unwind the transaction on both substantive antitrust grounds and because the companies failed, it contended, to follow Government pre-merger notification procedures.
The companies announced the deal, involving Carbide's worldwide urethane polyols and propylene glycols businesses, last September. They said Arco Chemical, which is 83 percent owned by ARCO, would pay the $220 million before the closing of the transaction, which was subject only to Government review, with Arco Chemical assuming all regulatory risk from possible challenge.
The Federal Trade Commission said today that it ''has reason to believe that the acquisition could substantially reduce competition'' in the production and sale of the two products, as well as potential competition in propylene oxide, a feedstock for them. Moreover, it complained that there were indications the companies had violated their agreement not to consummate the transaction without giving the commission 10 days' prior notice.
In a statement, Arco Chemical said it has been ''actively negotiating'' with the commission staff and ''will continue to deal with the commission in a good-faith effort to resolve the issues between us.'' The company said that the staff had presented the case to the commissioners a month ago and that their vote announced today was ''intended only to authorize litigation'' if the issue could not otherwise be resolved.
Commission lawyers declined to say what led the commission to contend that beneficial ownership of the chemical assets had passed to Arco Chemical.
Union Carbide officials could not be reached directly for comment, but they were reported to have predicted the deal would stand. Carbide was also said to be asserting that it made all notifications under the Hart-Scott-Rodino legislation in a timely way and that there is no precedent under these circumstances for rescinding the agreement.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
In the Long Run Stocks Are Better

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
''It is heartbreaking to sit down with people 63 to 65 years old and to have to tell them: You can't afford to maintain your life style now; how are you going to retire with a 40 to 50 percent cut?'' Joel S. Isaacson said at a meeting of the Greater New York Chapter of the International Society for Retirement Planning earlier this month.
''Start retirement planning at age 35 to 40; let time work for you,'' said Mr. Isaacson, a partner with Weber, Lipshie & Company, certified public accountants in New York, and director of personal financial planning for the firm.
That advice, of course, means making choices about personal finances and maintaining discipline in spending and saving, so that money can be put aside regularly to provide income in the retirement years. And it means deciding where to put that money so it will grow. 
''Time is the thing that really reduces your risk - time to ride out volatility,'' Mr. Isaacson said. He showed charts of market performances demonstrating that each $1 invested in 1926 in common stocks, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500- stock index, had grown to $535 by 1989; in intermediate-term Treasury bonds to $22 and in Treasury bills to $10. These numbers are before inflation and taxes.
The chart lines for bills and bonds are relatively smooth. For stocks the chart line is jagged, showing volatility, but over time, equities provide by far the greatest return, in part because of reinvested dividends and in part because of capital appreciation. Mr. Isaacson noted that the growth in dividends had outpaced inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index. Corporate earnings and dividend growth fed the equity profits.
The growth of $1 from 1980 through 1989 was as follows: stocks, $5.04; intermediate-term bonds, $3.08, and Treasury bills, $2.34. Because of inflation in that decade, it would have taken $1.65 in 1989 to buy as much as $1 in 1980. When only one-year periods are studied, stocks chalked up gains in 45 years and losses in 19 years; bonds were in plus territory in 58 years and negative in 6, and Treasury bills showed a positive return all 64 years. For the rolling 10-year periods covering that span stocks made gains 53 times against only two losses, while intermediate-term Treasuries showed positive returns in all 55 periods.
Because of these records of return and volatility, financial-planning experts say portfolios should include equities to get growth in long-term holdings but they see credit-market instruments as more appropriate for short-term needs.
Tim Kochis, who is in charge of executive financial consulting for Deloitte & Touche, addressed this point last week at a seminar for the firm's new partners in New York.
Because as partners they are going from salaried positions to sharing in the firm's profits and because many are in areas like auditing and consulting, rather than personal finance, they are treated to executive financial counseling sessions similar to those held for corporate clients' executives. When investing for 10 to 15 years or longer, Mr. Kochis said, equities can bring high returns. For the short term, however, he recommended ''maturity matching,'' that is buying a bond, note, bill or certificate of deposit that will mature when the funds are needed for a particular purpose, like a tax or tuition payment.
''Zero-coupon bonds are the classic maturity-matched instrument,'' he said, ''but I wouldn't buy a 20-year zero.''
For the equity portion of a portfolio, for retirement savings for those who start at age 35 to 40, for example, Mr. Kochis said, ''I believe very strongly that the index approach is the way to go.''
''In the long term, luck will balance out, and you're not going to consistently outwit the competition,'' he added, so it makes sense to keep transaction and portfolio management costs down by simply buying into a mutual fund like the Vanguard Index Trust that mirrors the S.&P. 500.
 
Winning Funds
 Past is not necessarily prologue in investing. Nevertheless, it is interesting to note that some mutual funds have beaten the market consistently.
The Mutual Fund News Service, edited by Reg Green, reports that five funds have beaten both the Dow Jones industrial average and the S.&P. 500 in every 10-year period in the past 30 years. There were 21 such periods beginning in the 1960-69 decade and ending in the 1980-89 decade.
The funds and their average annual rates of return for the 10 years ended March 31, 1990, after all expenses including the maximum sales charge for each, were: the American Mutual Fund, 17.9 percent; the Investment Company of America, 17.9 percent; the Washington Mutual Investors Fund, 19.3 percent; the Windsor Fund, 20.7 percent, and Investors Research, 17.1 percent.
The first three are members of the Los Angeles-based American Funds Group. Its distinguishing characteristics are that each fund is run by three or four managers, not just one, and that it has an intensive global research program.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Drop 1.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
Prices farmers get for raw products declined 1.3 percent in June, but were still about 2.7 percent above a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.
Lower prices for oranges, wheat, hay and soybeans were mostly responsible for the overall drop in the commodity price index from May, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report.
Higher prices were reported for tomatoes, corn, eggs and grapefruit, partly offsetting the declines for the other commodities. Most prices are mid-June averages which will be revised next month to reflect June as a whole. 
Department economists say farm income may rise to record levels this year, depending on 1990 production and market demands. Recent forecasts show 1990 net cash income of farmers in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion, compared with about $54 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988.
Net cash income is the money farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year.
Another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be $47 billion to $51 billion, compared with $49 billion last year.
Consumer food prices are forecast by department economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981.
Based on the preliminary figures, the June price index for livestock and poultry dropped six-tenths of a percent from May but still averaged 9.6 percent more than a year earlier.
Milk prices rose 10 cents in June, to an average of $13.60 a l00 pounds. That was up $1.20 from June 1989. The farm price of milk rose to a record $16 a hundredweight in December before easing down.
Crop prices over all dropped 3 percent from May and averaged 5.8 percent below the year-earlier level. Fruit prices declined 4.9 percent from May, led by a drop in the price of oranges. The fruit index was down 4 percent from a year earlier.
Wheat prices, under pressure from the new harvest, dropped 25 cents during the month, to $3.15 a bushel in June.

HEADLINE: Home Sales Rose 0.4% During May

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 29

 BODY:
Sales of new single-family homes rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May, for the first gain in six months, the Commerce Department said today, but high interest rates and buyer wariness continued to plague the housing industry.
''Housing's performance is well below normal,'' said Robert Villanueva, director of forecasting for the National Association of Home Builders.
That softness continues to drag down the overall economy, which is growing at a sluggish 1 1/2 percent to 2 percent annual rate after inflation, other analysts said. 
Home sales last month rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 532,000 units, after a 5.2 percent decline in April, to a rate of 530,000 units. The May rise was the first increase since November, when sales were 687,000 units, the department said.
The rate of sales in both May and April was the lowest since 521,000 units were sold in December 1982, when the nation was emerging from its last recession.
 
Industry Below Peak Level
 While sales improved from April, the industry remained far below its peak level. The May sales total was 18.3 percent lower than a year earlier, when sales were running at an annual rate of 651,000.
In May, the actual sales total before seasonal adjustment fell to 50,000 units, from 52,000 in April.
Behind the gain in May was a 7.9 percent rise in the Midwest. Sales in the West were also stronger, rising 4.8 percent.
But other regions remained weak, with sales dropping 10.6 percent in the Northeast and 1 percent in the South.
Helping improve demand was a drop in new-home prices, with the average falling to $150,400, from $154,200 in April. The median price decreased to $128,500, from $133,400.
Mr. Villanueva said it was encouraging that sales had stabilized but said it would take a significant drop in interest rates for housing to recover. Fixed-rate mortgages currently average 10 percent, the same as a year ago.
David Wyss, chief financial economist for the forecasting firm Data Resources Inc., said that in addition to high rates, housing remains soft because consumers are wary about making major purchases.
''They see the newspaper headlines that property prices are not going up, and they ask themselves, 'Is this such a good investment?' '' he said.
The outlook is for rates to show little change until early next year, when they could edge higher because of a pickup in the economy, Mr. Wyss said.
Reports of tighter credit, with lenders in certain areas of the country said to be exercising more caution about making loans for construction and land acquisition, also is a negative factor for housing, Mr. Wyss said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Anticipation Of Lower U.S. Interest Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday in quiet trading on world currency markets.
Traders said the dollar lost ground amid anticipation of lower United States interest rates.
''The dollar is once again in a vulnerable position vis-a-vis the European countries, which have a demand for capital,'' said Ron Holzer, chief dealer at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. 
Because the demand for capital is high overseas, European interest rates have been edging up and, in turn, attracting investors to European securities.
 
Effect of Bush Tax Plan
President Bush's announcement that taxes must be raised to help offset the nation's budget deficit also served to push the dollar lower. To many traders, new taxes and a reduced budget deficit enhance the notion that interest rates will head lower, because reduced Federal borrowing needs would curtail demand for credit.
Traders are bracing themselves for next week, which they expect to be laden with market-moving news. The German monetary union is scheduled to take effect Sunday, and the Labor Department is to release the June unemployment report next Friday.
''Most of the market was happy to make a small profit at the end of the week,'' said Linda McLaughlin, a trader at the Chemical New York Capital Markets Group.
Dealers said the dollar's biggest decline Friday came against the Japanese yen, which has been rising because of firmer Japanese money market rates.
 
Fall Against the Yen
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 152.85 Japanese yen, from 154.42 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 152.30 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 152.10 yen, down from 153.15 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7450, from $1.7400 late Thursday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.7490, from $1.7384.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6607 West German marks, down from 1.6730; 1.4150 Swiss francs, down from 1.4200; 5.5795 French francs, down from 5.6155; 1,219.75 Italian lire, down from 1,228.00, and 1.1634 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1699.
